dnuorgkcaB noitargetnI lanoigeR rof krowemarF ehT :)PECR( pihsrentraP cimonocE evisneherpmoC lanoigeR dna aisA tsaE fo msimanyD :kooB AIRE fo gnihcnuaL dna PECR fo yenruoJ eht gnicsinimeR :yrasrevinnA raeY-01 PECR noitargetnI lanoigeR rof krowemarF ehT :)PECR( pihsrentraP cimonocE evisneherpmoC lanoigeR dna aisA tsaE fo msimanyD :kooB AIRE fo gnihcnuaL dna PECR fo yenruoJ eht gnicsinimeR :yrasrevinnA raeY-01 PECR";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-10-26 16:00:56";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-11-01 16:30:36";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:22:"ulfa.rizkiana@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:32;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7165";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:115:"comprehensive-asia-development-plan-30-symposium-towards-an-integrated-innovative-inclusive-and-sustainable-economy";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:120:"Comprehensive Asia Development Plan 3.0 Symposium: Towards an Integrated, Innovative, Inclusive, and Sustainable Economy";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-11-09";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"11";s:7:"content";s:5993:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_Nov_CADP.jpg" alt="" width="775" height="436" /></p><p>The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has caused trade disruptions; a drop in foreign direct investment; and scarring effects on poverty, education, and women in many nations. However, it has also had beneficial features. Factory Asia has continued to produce and export during the pandemic, in contrast with North America and Europe. COVID-19 has boosted digitalisation, notably in information and communication technology (ICT). The adoption of ICT has boosted economic growth. Maintaining the competitiveness of international production networks and utilising digitalisation are essential to the region&rsquo;s future post-COVID-19.</p><p>Based on this understanding, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) has developed the <em>Comprehensive Asia Development Plan 3.0</em> (CADP 3.0). Since the previous version (CADP 2.0) in 2015, nearly 7 years have passed. CADP 3.0 addresses the above-mentioned urgent concerns and discusses economic growth and social problem-solving in the region from the viewpoints of (i) integration, (ii) innovation, (iii) inclusiveness, and (iv) sustainability. CADP 3.0 comprises 18 original chapters on the four viewpoints and digitalisation.</p><p>First, CADP 3.0 claims that integration is at the core of development strategies. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and developing East Asia could use three forms of the international division of labour (the first to the third unbundlings) simultaneously. To stimulate economic growth, the region should adhere to globalisation. Second, CADP 3.0 asserts that digital technology has transformed the nature of innovation. ASEAN and East Asia must move from intensive research and development (R&amp;D) to technology deployment. Combining incremental and disruptive innovation could revive creative manufacturing. Third, CADP 3.0 declares that inclusiveness in its three dimensions &ndash; geographical, industrial, and social &ndash; is a core value for ASEAN and East Asia. Before resorting to income/welfare redistribution, the region should employ economic forces to achieve inclusiveness wherever practicable. Last, CADP 3.0 affirms that sustainability must be realised through economic expansion and improved well-being. Decarbonisation, resource management, and disaster management are not just long-term objectives but also present challenges. The use of new technology will facilitate international cooperation in establishing a circular economy.</p><p>This symposium will share an understanding of CADP 3.0 as a framework for future development with government officials, the private sector and academics.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Wednesday, 9 November &nbsp;2022</li><li>Time: 9 AM - 2 PM (Cambodia Time, UTC+7)</li><li>Venue: Hyatt Regency Hotel Phnom Penh</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>9:00AM - 9:05AM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Playing of the National Anthem</strong></p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>9:05AM - 9:25AM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Welcome Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>H.E. PAN Sorasak, Minister, Ministry of Commerce, Kingdom of Cambodia</li><li>Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>9:25AM - 9:30AM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Photo</strong></p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>9:30AM - 9:50AM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Key Note Address</strong></p><p>CADP 3.0: Concept and what it will bring to the region</p><p>Prof Fukunari Kimura, Chief Economist, ERIA</p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>9:50AM - 10AM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p><strong>Coffee Break</strong></p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>10AM - 11AM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p><strong>Session 1: Integrative and Innovative Asia </strong></p><p><strong>Moderator: </strong>Dr&nbsp;Keita Oikawa, Economist, ERIA</p><p><strong>Panellists: </strong></p><ul><li>Dr Lurong Chen (Digital Connectivity)</li><li>Mr Ikumo Isono (Geographical Simulation Analysis)</li><li>Dr Rashesh Shrestha (Skill Development System)</li><li>Mr Fusanori Iwasaki (Automotive Sector)</li></ul></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>11AM - 12PM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p><strong>Session 2: Inclusive and Sustainable Asia</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator: </strong>Dr&nbsp;Masahito Ambashi, Associate Professor, Kyoto University</p><p><strong>Panellists: </strong></p><ul><li>Dr Fauziah Zen (Inclusive Growth)</li><li>Mr Masanori Kozono (Agriculture)</li><li>Dr Han Phoumin (Energy Infrastructure Development)</li><li>Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi (Environment and Sustainability)</li></ul></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>12PM - 12:10PM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Koji Hachiyama, COO, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia</li></ul></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>12:10PM - 2PM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p><strong>Lunch</strong></p></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/comprehensive-asian-development-plan-30-cadp-30-symposium-online-tickets-445114949797" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ONLINE REGISTRATION</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/comprehensive-asian-development-plan-30-cadp-30-symposium-offline-tickets-445112392147" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IN-PERSON REGISTRATION</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:20:"Phnom Penh, Cambodia";s:5:"major";s:13:"Ms Denise Ann";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:4:"ERIA";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-11-09";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:9095:"Comprehensive Asia Development Plan 3.0 Symposium: Towards an Integrated, Innovative, Inclusive, and Sustainable Economy Comprehensive Asia Development Plan 3.0 Symposium: Towards an Integrated, Innovative, Inclusive, and Sustainable Economy The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has caused trade disruptions; a drop in foreign direct investment; and scarring effects on poverty, education, and women in many nations. However, it has also had beneficial features. Factory Asia has continued to produce and export during the pandemic, in contrast with North America and Europe. COVID-19 has boosted digitalisation, notably in information and communication technology (ICT). The adoption of ICT has boosted economic growth. Maintaining the competitiveness of international production networks and utilising digitalisation are essential to the region&rsquo;s future post-COVID-19.
Based on this understanding, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) has developed the Comprehensive Asia Development Plan 3.0 (CADP 3.0). Since the previous version (CADP 2.0) in 2015, nearly 7 years have passed. CADP 3.0 addresses the above-mentioned urgent concerns and discusses economic growth and social problem-solving in the region from the viewpoints of (i) integration, (ii) innovation, (iii) inclusiveness, and (iv) sustainability. CADP 3.0 comprises 18 original chapters on the four viewpoints and digitalisation.
First, CADP 3.0 claims that integration is at the core of development strategies. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and developing East Asia could use three forms of the international division of labour (the first to the third unbundlings) simultaneously. To stimulate economic growth, the region should adhere to globalisation. Second, CADP 3.0 asserts that digital technology has transformed the nature of innovation. ASEAN and East Asia must move from intensive research and development (R&amp;D) to technology deployment. Combining incremental and disruptive innovation could revive creative manufacturing. Third, CADP 3.0 declares that inclusiveness in its three dimensions &ndash; geographical, industrial, and social &ndash; is a core value for ASEAN and East Asia. Before resorting to income/welfare redistribution, the region should employ economic forces to achieve inclusiveness wherever practicable. Last, CADP 3.0 affirms that sustainability must be realised through economic expansion and improved well-being. Decarbonisation, resource management, and disaster management are not just long-term objectives but also present challenges. The use of new technology will facilitate international cooperation in establishing a circular economy.
This symposium will share an understanding of CADP 3.0 as a framework for future development with government officials, the private sector and academics.
Event Details

Date: Wednesday, 9 November &nbsp;2022
Time: 9 AM - 2 PM (Cambodia Time, UTC+7)
Venue: Hyatt Regency Hotel Phnom Penh

Agenda




9:00AM - 9:05AM


Playing of the National Anthem

evisneherpmoC";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-10-25 17:21:34";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-11-03 12:04:30";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:19:"denise.ann@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:33;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7136";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:81:"asean-economic-outlook-building-strategies-for-resilient-and-sustainable-recovery";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:82:"ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-10-26";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:5100:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Event%20banner_ASEAN%20Econ%20Outlook_Oct2022.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p>The ASEAN region is mending strongly with growth expected to reach an average of 5% in the next two years. The growth recovery is predicated on widespread vaccination efforts, easing mobility restrictions, and opening of borders to tourism. Despite this sanguine outlook, the performance in the region also varies with bigger and resource-rich economies growing faster than smaller economies or those dependent on oil and food imports. Sectoral growth is also quite uneven with the nascent recovery in transport, accommodation, and tourism occurring in a protracted manner. This K-shape recovery puts at risk inclusive growth in the region. Global risks have also increased and could weaken the growth outlook through trade and supply chain disruptions, high-commodity prices, and rising financial stress. Last but not least: economic scarring could also slow productivity growth through destruction of human capital, rising trade costs and impediment, and higher interest costs which discourages innovation. The unprecedented scale and impact of COVID-19 pandemic has also put hard-won development progress at risk. For example, poverty estimates show that the number of people in extreme poverty in Southeast Asia has increased by an average of over 5 million in 2020 and 2021, compared to a no-COVID scenario. More so, with limited fiscal space and rising debt, delivering the SDGs and staying on a net-zero path becomes even more difficult.</p><p>The Asian Development Bank (ADB), in partnership with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP) will hold a webinar on <strong><em>ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery. </em></strong>The aim of the webinar is to provide the venue to discuss the implications of competing short-term, medium-term, and long-term challenges on the region&rsquo;s prospect for building a resilient and sustainable recovery.</p><p>Some of the questions that will be discussed are:</p><ol><li>There are many economic and social challenges confronting policymakers in Southeast Asia, namely: the K-shape recovery, numerous risks from global headwinds, potential economic scarring in the medium-term, long-term development impact of COVID-19, and the goal of delivering SDGs and net zero. Which among these challenges are the most important? And which among them should be prioritized by policymakers. And why? Are they related in some ways?</li><li>What are the policy instruments that can be used to address the: a) macroeconomic issues and challenges pose by global headwinds, K-shape recovery, and economic scarring; and b) social and development issues related to poverty and inequality, and accelerating SDG progress and achieving a net zero society?</li></ol><h2>Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Wednesday, 26 October 2022</li><li>Time: 10:00 AM &ndash; 11:30 AM (Manila/UTC+8)</li><li>Venue:&nbsp;Virtual Room</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table><tr><td width="161"><p>10:00 - 10:05</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Start of the Webinar</strong></p><p>Moderator:</p><ul><li><strong>Anna Fink</strong>, Country Economist, Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>10:05 - 10:15</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Ramesh Subramaniam</strong>, Director General, Southeast Asia Department, ADB<strong><br /></strong></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>10:15 &ndash; 10:20</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Video of Southeast Asia&rsquo;s Economic Performance plays</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>10:20 -10:30</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Keynote Presentation </strong></p><ul><li><strong>Shuvojit Banerjee</strong>, Officer-in-charge, Macroeconomic Policy and Analysis Section, UNESCAP - presents the findings and key messages of their report on Economic and Social Survey of Asia and the Pacific 2022: Economic Policies for an Inclusive Recovery and Development</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>10:30 - 11:15</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Panel Discussion </strong></p><ul><li><strong>TBD</strong>, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, Philippines</li><li><strong>Datuk Dr. Suhana Binti MD. Saleh</strong>, Director, Economic Planning Unit, Malaysia</li><li><strong>Aladdin D. Rillo, </strong>Senior Economic Advisor, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li><li><strong>James P. Villafuerte</strong>, Principal Economist, ADB</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>11:15 - 11:30</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Moderated Q&amp;A</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>11:30</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Closing</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Aladdin D Rillo</strong>, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://adb-org.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_bwKq-JfDS1-OZenImBUL9w">REGISTER HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:22:"ASEAN,economic outlook";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-10-26";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-10-26";s:8:"keywords";s:8693:"ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery The ASEAN region is mending strongly with growth expected to reach an average of 5% in the next two years. The growth recovery is predicated on widespread vaccination efforts, easing mobility restrictions, and opening of borders to tourism. Despite this sanguine outlook, the performance in the region also varies with bigger and resource-rich economies growing faster than smaller economies or those dependent on oil and food imports. Sectoral growth is also quite uneven with the nascent recovery in transport, accommodation, and tourism occurring in a protracted manner. This K-shape recovery puts at risk inclusive growth in the region. Global risks have also increased and could weaken the growth outlook through trade and supply chain disruptions, high-commodity prices, and rising financial stress. Last but not least: economic scarring could also slow productivity growth through destruction of human capital, rising trade costs and impediment, and higher interest costs which discourages innovation. The unprecedented scale and impact of COVID-19 pandemic has also put hard-won development progress at risk. For example, poverty estimates show that the number of people in extreme poverty in Southeast Asia has increased by an average of over 5 million in 2020 and 2021, compared to a no-COVID scenario. More so, with limited fiscal space and rising debt, delivering the SDGs and staying on a net-zero path becomes even more difficult.
The Asian Development Bank (ADB), in partnership with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP) will hold a webinar on ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery. The aim of the webinar is to provide the venue to discuss the implications of competing short-term, medium-term, and long-term challenges on the region&rsquo;s prospect for building a resilient and sustainable recovery.
Some of the questions that will be discussed are:

There are many economic and social challenges confronting policymakers in Southeast Asia, namely: the K-shape recovery, numerous risks from global headwinds, potential economic scarring in the medium-term, long-term development impact of COVID-19, and the goal of delivering SDGs and net zero. Which among these challenges are the most important? And which among them should be prioritized by policymakers. And why? Are they related in some ways?
What are the policy instruments that can be used to address the: a) macroeconomic issues and challenges pose by global headwinds, K-shape recovery, and economic scarring; and b) social and development issues related to poverty and inequality, and accelerating SDG progress and achieving a net zero society?

Schedule

Date: Wednesday, 26 October 2022
Time: 10:00 AM &ndash; 11:30 AM (Manila/UTC+8)
Venue:&nbsp;Virtual Room

10:30 - 11:15

James P. Villafuerte, Principal Economist, ADB

Aladdin D Rillo, ERIA

Regulatory Practice: Why It Matters to ASEAN?";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-10-17";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:3506:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_Oct_Good-Regulatory-Practice-Why-It-Matters-to-ASEAN.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p>The ASEAN Secretariat, in partnership with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), is pleased to invite you to the Regional Socialisation Seminar on Good Regulatory Practice (GRP) in ASEAN.</p><p>The Seminar, which will also be used to officially launch &lsquo;ASEAN Handbook on Good Regulatory Practice&rsquo; is part of the ongoing work that ASEAN pursues to implement its Work Plan on Good Regulatory Practice 2016-2025, which includes awareness raising and capacity building to promote ASEAN&rsquo;s GRP Core Principles across institutions, sectors, and ASEAN Member States (AMS).</p><p>The Seminar will be held virtually via Zoom and registration is required. The Zoom details will be provided after your registration.</p><h2>Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date :&nbsp; Monday, 17 October 2022</li><li>Time :&nbsp; 9 AM to Noon (UTC+7)</li><li>Venue: Virtual Room (link will be sent with confirmation of RSVP)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 678px;"><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p>8:45 AM &ndash; 9:00 AM</p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>Registration</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p>9:00 AM &ndash; 9:15 AM</p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Alexander Chandra</strong>, Assistant Director, Analysis Monitoring Trade Industry and Emerging Issues Division, ASEAN Secretariat</li></ul><p><strong>Photo session</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p>9:15 AM &ndash; 9:35 AM</p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>First Session:&nbsp;</strong></p><p><strong>Launching of the Handbook on Good Regulatory Practice</strong></p><p><strong>Overview of the Handbook</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Intan Murnira Ramli</strong>, Policy Fellow, ERIA<br />Questions &amp; Answers</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p>9:35 AM &ndash; 9:45 AM</p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><strong>Short Break</strong></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p>9:45 AM &ndash; 11.30 AM</p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>Second Session:</strong></p><p><strong>Exchange of Experiences, Perspective, and Best Practices</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Rashesh Shrestha</strong>, Research Fellow, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Ms Eunice Huang</strong>, Google</li><li><strong>Dr Gilberto M. Good Regulatory Practice: Why It Matters to ASEAN? The ASEAN Secretariat, in partnership with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), is pleased to invite you to the Regional Socialisation Seminar on Good Regulatory Practice (GRP) in ASEAN.
The Seminar, which will also be used to officially launch &lsquo;ASEAN Handbook on Good Regulatory Practice&rsquo; is part of the ongoing work that ASEAN pursues to implement its Work Plan on Good Regulatory Practice 2016-2025, which includes awareness raising and capacity building to promote ASEAN&rsquo;s GRP Core Principles across institutions, sectors, and ASEAN Member States (AMS).
The Seminar will be held virtually via Zoom and registration is required. The Zoom details will be provided after your registration.
Schedule

Date :&nbsp; Monday, 17 October 2022
Time :&nbsp; 9 AM to Noon (UTC+7)
Venue: Virtual Room (link will be sent with confirmation of RSVP)

Agenda




8:45 AM &ndash; 9:00 AM


Registration




9:00 AM &ndash; 9:15 AM


Opening Remarks

Dr Alexander Chandra, Assistant Director, Analysis Monitoring Trade Industry and Emerging Issues Division, ASEAN Secretariat

Photo session




9:15 AM &ndash; 9:35 AM


First Session:&nbsp;
Launching of the Handbook on Good Regulatory Practice
Overview of the Handbook

Dr Intan Murnira Ramli, Policy Fellow, ERIAQuestions &amp; Answers





9:35 AM &ndash; 9:45 AM

Short Break



9:45 AM &ndash; 11.30 AM


Second Session:
Exchange of Experiences, Perspective, and Best Practices
Moderator:

Dr Rashesh Shrestha, Research Fellow, ERIA

Speakers:

Ms Eunice Huang, Google
Dr Gilberto M. Llanto, Philippine Institute for Development Studies (PIDS)
Ms Shahriza Bahari, Malaysia Productivity Corporation (MPC)

Questions &amp; Answers



&nbsp;11:30 AM - 11:50 AM

Recommendations / Way forward

Dr Intan Murnira Ramli, Policy Fellow, ERIA




&nbsp;11:50 AM - 12:00 PM

Closing Remarks

Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building, ERIA

forum | Harnessing the Power of Technology for Healthy Aging in Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-11-08";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"11";s:7:"content";s:4113:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2180216_6246275_6333d3ae05b59.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>The 2022 AHWIN Forum will focus on regional efforts to translate data and innovations into better policies, products, and programs for healthy aging and care for older persons, and will examine best practices in designing age-friendly cities that enable people to stay active and connected and foster solidarity among the generations.<br /> <br /> The AHWIN Forum is a joint initiative of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the Japan Center for International Exchange (JCIE) to encourage and inform effective aging-related policies throughout the world and to foster regional cooperation in promoting healthy and active aging among older persons in Asia. It is convened under the auspices of the Government of Japan&rsquo;s <a href="https://jcie.us19.list-manage.com/track/click?u=79dc5920fbd3249d82c1afcfa&amp;id=91add4b8c8&amp;e=1df25664a2"><strong>Asia Health and Wellbeing Initiative (AHWIN)</strong></a> to bring together policymakers, researchers, private sector enterprises, and practical program implementers across the region for a dialogue on the future direction of global and regional collaboration to harness the benefits of data, technology, and innovation for the promotion of healthy aging in Asia and throughout the world.<br /> <br /> The event will also include a special award ceremony and reception to honor the winners of the 2022 <a href="https://jcie.us19.list-manage.com/track/click?u=79dc5920fbd3249d82c1afcfa&amp;id=79efce4ddc&amp;e=1df25664a2"><strong>Healthy Aging Prize for Asian Innovation</strong></a>.</p><h2>Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Tuesday, November 8th&nbsp;</li><li>Time<strong>: </strong>13:30&ndash;18:00 JST (GMT+9)</li><li>Venue: Tokyo Prince Hotel / Online</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 569.5px; height: 860px;"><tr><td style="width: 526.5px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Akio Okawara</strong>, <em>President and CEO, JCIE</em></li></ul><p><strong>Special remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Keizo Takemi</strong>, <em>Member, House of Councillors, Senior Fellow, JCIE</em></li><li><strong>Alana HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:17:"ageing,healthcare";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Tokyo, Japan";s:5:"major";s:14:"Ms Nanda Putri";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-11-08";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6235:"AHWIN forum | Harnessing the Power of Technology for Healthy Aging in Asia AHWIN forum | Harnessing the Power of Technology for Healthy Aging in Asia The 2022 AHWIN Forum will focus on regional efforts to translate data and innovations into better policies, products, and programs for healthy aging and care for older persons, and will examine best practices in designing age-friendly cities that enable people to stay active and connected and foster solidarity among the generations.  The AHWIN Forum is a joint initiative of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the Japan Center for International Exchange (JCIE) to encourage and inform effective aging-related policies throughout the world and to foster regional cooperation in promoting healthy and active aging among older persons in Asia. It is convened under the auspices of the Government of Japan&rsquo;s Asia Health and Wellbeing Initiative (AHWIN) to bring together policymakers, researchers, private sector enterprises, and practical program implementers across the region for a dialogue on the future direction of global and regional collaboration to harness the benefits of data, technology, and innovation for the promotion of healthy aging in Asia and throughout the world.  The event will also include a special award ceremony and reception to honor the winners of the 2022 Healthy Aging Prize for Asian Innovation.
Schedule

Date: Tuesday, November 8th&nbsp;
Time: 13:30&ndash;18:00 JST (GMT+9)
Venue: Tokyo Prince Hotel / Online

Agenda




Opening Remarks

Akio Okawara, President and CEO, JCIE

Special remarks

Keizo Takemi, Member, House of Councillors, Senior Fellow, JCIE
Alana Officer, Unit Head, Demographic Change and Healthy Ageing, WHO&nbsp;

Keynote speaker

John Eu-Li Wong, Isabel Chan Professor in Medical Sciences, Senior Vice President, Health Innovation and Translation, The National University of Singapore





Panel 1: Translating data and innovation to policy and practice

Tengku Aizan Hamid,&nbsp;Professor in Gerontology and Social Policy, Universiti Putra Malaysia, Research Fellow, Malaysian Research Institute on Ageing (MyAgeing)&nbsp;(Moderator)
Hiro Fujita,&nbsp;Founder and CEO, Quality Electrodynamics; Chief Technology Officer, CT-MR Division, Canon Medical Systems Corporation; OIST Foundation Health Innovation Ambassador
Atsuko Okuda,&nbsp;Regional Director, ITU Regional Office for Asia and the Pacific
Prasert Assantachai,&nbsp;Deputy Dean, Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital, Mahidol University, Thailand





Panel 2: Designing age-friendly cities facilitating mobility and social inclusion

Momoko Abe,&nbsp;Program Officer, JCIE&nbsp;(Moderator)
Chong Keng Hua,&nbsp;Associate Professor, Singapore University of Technology and Design
Katsunori Kondo,&nbsp;Professor of Social Epidemiology and Health Policy, Center for Preventive Medical Sciences, Graduate School of Medicine at Chiba University

11:39:22";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:20:"nanda.putri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:36;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7128";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:82:"female-entrepreneurs-in-the-asean-region-innovation-to-tackle-marine-plastic-waste";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"3";s:5:"title";s:83:"Female Entrepreneurs in the ASEAN Region: Innovation to Tackle Marine Plastic Waste";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-12-12";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"11";s:7:"content";s:3957:"<p></p><p><strong>Special Webinar,&nbsp;A collaboration between the E-S-I Knowledge Lab and the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris</strong></p><p>As a result of rapid economic growth coupled with the lack of solid waste management infrastructure, ASEAN region is regarded today as one of the biggest contributors to marine plastic pollution. Along with policymakers, researchers and consumers, the private sector is recognized as a key stakeholder to address this issue. In an attempt to change the linear way we have been managing plastic across its lifecycle and nudge it toward a more circular production and consumption, the private sector has a greater role to play with its economic and innovative power and its capacity to induce behavior change among the consumers.</p><p>The objective of the webinar is fivefold:</p><ol><li>&nbsp;Raise awareness on the current alarming situation surrounding marine plastics and highlight the efforts undertaken by the private sector to tackle this issue from both production and consumption (so-called “upstream”) level to recycling and waste management (so-called 'downstream') level.</li><li>&nbsp;Introduce innovative private sector efforts led by young female entrepreneurs from the ASEAN region in the hope to encourage the young generation, and inspire particularly young girls, and woman to consider entrepreneurship in the environmental field as a viable career option.</li><li>&nbsp;Share innovative good practices from Japan such as (a) research study on industry and consumer behaviour change, and (b) consumer-industry-public sectors dialogue on plastics consumption.</li><li>&nbsp;Highlight the Private Sector Platform launched by the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris of ERIA and invite private companies operating in the ASEAN+3 region to join the platform.</li><li>&nbsp;Introduce the E-S-I Knowledge Lab as the knowledge hub for the Entrepreneurship, Startup and Innovation community.</li></ol><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 3&nbsp;November &nbsp;2022</li><li>Time: 2 PM - 3:30 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 616px;"><tbody><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>2:00PM - 2:03PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Start of Webinar:&nbsp;</strong></p><p>Moderator:&nbsp;Tiat Jin (TJ) Ooi,&nbsp;Principal Consultant, Curated Connectors,&nbsp;Lead Consultant, ERIA E-S-I Knowledge Lab</p></td></tr></tbody></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tbody><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>2:03PM - 2:10PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Michikazu Kojima, Senior Advisor on Environmental Issues, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>2:10PM - 3:00PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Panel Discussion</strong></p><p>Speakers:</p><ul><li>Ms Ovy Sabrina, Co-founder/COO, Rebricks (Indonesia)</li><li>Ms Supatchaya Techachoochert, Co-founder, Refill Station (Thailand)</li><li>Ms Juliana Adam, CEO, Biji-biji Initiative (Malaysia)</li><li>Dr Misuzu Asari, Associate Professor, Kyoto University (Japan)</li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tbody><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>3:00PM - 3:25PM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p><strong>Q&amp;A</strong></p><p>Moderator: Tiat Jin (TJ) Ooi,&nbsp;Principal Consultant, Curated Connectors,&nbsp;Lead Consultant, ERIA E-S-I Knowledge Lab</p></td></tr></tbody></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tbody><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>3:25PM - 3:30PM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Dr Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director, Strategy &amp; Partnership, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/female-entrepreneurs-in-the-asean-region-tickets-440140571297" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:37:"/uploads/events/logo6396ae740222e.jpg";s:9:"video_url";s:28:"https://youtu.be/TpweUy52w8c";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:0:"";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-11-03";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-11-03";s:8:"keywords";s:6499:"Female Entrepreneurs in the ASEAN Region: Innovation to Tackle Marine Plastic Waste Female Entrepreneurs in the ASEAN Region: Innovation to Tackle Marine Plastic Waste Special Webinar,&nbsp;A collaboration between the E-S-I Knowledge Lab and the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris
As a result of rapid economic growth coupled with the lack of solid waste management infrastructure, ASEAN region is regarded today as one of the biggest contributors to marine plastic pollution. Along with policymakers, researchers and consumers, the private sector is recognized as a key stakeholder to address this issue. In an attempt to change the linear way we have been managing plastic across its lifecycle and nudge it toward a more circular production and consumption, the private sector has a greater role to play with its economic and innovative power and its capacity to induce behavior change among the consumers.
The objective of the webinar is fivefold:

&nbsp;Raise awareness on the current alarming situation surrounding marine plastics and highlight the efforts undertaken by the private sector to tackle this issue from both production and consumption (so-called &ldquo;upstream&rdquo;) level to recycling and waste management (so-called 'downstream') level.
&nbsp;Introduce innovative private sector efforts led by young female entrepreneurs from the ASEAN region in the hope to encourage the young generation, and inspire particularly young girls, and woman to consider entrepreneurship in the environmental field as a viable career option.
&nbsp;Share innovative good practices from Japan such as (a) research study on industry and consumer behaviour change, and (b) consumer-industry-public sectors dialogue on plastics consumption.
&nbsp;Highlight the Private Sector Platform launched by the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris of ERIA and invite private companies operating in the ASEAN+3 region to join the platform.
&nbsp;Introduce the E-S-I Knowledge Lab as the knowledge hub for the Entrepreneurship, Startup and Innovation community.

Event Details

Date: Thursday, 3&nbsp;November &nbsp;2022
Time: 2 PM - 3:30 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)

Agenda




2:00PM - 2:03PM


Start of Webinar:&nbsp;
Moderator:&nbsp;Tiat Jin (TJ) Ooi,&nbsp;Principal Consultant, Curated Connectors,&nbsp;Lead Consultant, ERIA E-S-I Knowledge Lab








2:03PM - 2:10PM


Opening Remarks

Mr Michikazu Kojima, Senior Advisor on Environmental Issues, ERIA





2:10PM - 3:00PM


Panel Discussion
Speakers:

Ms Ovy Sabrina, Co-founder/COO, Rebricks (Indonesia)
Ms Supatchaya Techachoochert, Co-founder, Refill Station (Thailand)
Ms Juliana Adam, CEO, Biji-biji Initiative (Malaysia)
Dr Misuzu Asari, Associate Professor, Kyoto University (Japan)









3:00PM - 3:25PM


Q&amp;A
Moderator: Tiat Jin (TJ) Ooi,&nbsp;Principal Consultant, Curated Connectors,&nbsp;Lead Consultant, ERIA E-S-I Knowledge Lab








3:25PM - 3:30PM


Closing Remarks

Dr Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director, Strategy &amp; Partnership, ERIA

By bringing together government leaders, investors, and industry players from across Indonesia and around the world, we will converge and share insights on how to promote key areas of growth, and facilitate investment in Indonesia.</p><p class="fs-5">We invite you to take part and join the thought leaders, movers and shakers, and decision-makers of Indonesia&rsquo;s economy.</p><h2 class="fs-5">Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Tues-Wed, 11-12 October 2022</li><li>Time: 9:00 AM &ndash; 6:00 PM (Jakarta/GMT+7)</li><li>Venue: Assembly Hall, Jakarta Convention Center</li></ul><p>Please confirm your attendance through&nbsp;&nbsp;<a class="bluebtn" href="https://wa.link/rgp9zl">HERE</a>&nbsp; or through WhatsApp at +6281218009765.&nbsp;</p><p>Once your registration is confirmed, your ID can be taken up on Monday, 10 October 2022 between 12-8pm at JCC Lower Lobby or on today of the Summit.&nbsp;</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:10:"Investment";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:18:"Jakarta, Indonesia";s:5:"major";s:15:"Ms Ivana Markus";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-10-11";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-10-12";s:8:"keywords";s:2053:"Investor Daily Summit 2022 Investor Daily Summit 2022 The Investor Daily Summit will host Indonesia&rsquo;s seminal investment forum. By bringing together government leaders, investors, and industry players from across Indonesia and around the world, we will converge and share insights on how to promote key areas of growth, and facilitate investment in Indonesia.
We invite you to take part and join the thought leaders, movers and shakers, and decision-makers of Indonesia&rsquo;s economy.

.ymonoce s;ouqsr&aisenodnI fo srekam-noisiced dna ,srekahs dna srevom ,sredael thguoht eht nioj dna trap ekat ot uoy etivni eW
.aisenodnI ni tnemtsevni etatilicaf dna ,htworg fo saera yek etomorp ot woh no sthgisni erahs dna egrevnoc lliw ew ,dlrow eht dnuora dna aisenodnI ssorca morf sreyalp yrtsudni dna ,srotsevni ,sredael tnemnrevog rehtegot gnignirb yB .murof tnemtsevni lanimes s;ouqsr&aisenodnI tsoh lliw timmuS yliaD rotsevnI ehT 2202 timmuS yliaD rotsevnI 2202 timmuS yliaD rotsevnI";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-10-06 14:07:11";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-10-11 17:43:19";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:21:"ivana.markus@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:38;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7125";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:38:"east-asia-summit-eas-hydrogen-workshop";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:40:"East Asia Summit (EAS) Hydrogen Workshop";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-10-18";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:6506:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/EASHW-10.10.2022.png" alt="" width="800" /><img src="/uploads/media/EASHW-10.10.2022_1.png" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Carbon neutrality has become a globally relevant issue since COP 26 and hydrogen is highlighted as one an important zero emission technology in the East Asia Summit (EAS) region. Hydrogen is a very versatile fuel which can be used for power generation, vehicles, heating, and space missions, and can therefore replace fossil fuels, coal, oil, and gas. &nbsp;</p><p>The &lsquo;ERIA East Asia Summit (EAS) Hydrogen Workshop&rsquo; will focus on hydrogen demand and production potential in the EAS region in comparison to the global situation and outlook of hydrogen.</p><p>Production potential in the EAS region should include the use of unused energy including hydropower sources in isolated areas, gas flaring at oil and gas production sites, and low-ranked coal. While considering issues and challenges surrounding hydrogen technology development, hydrogen policies of EAS countries, especially those of the hydrogen technology frontrunners such as Japan, play a crucial role in achieving a carbon-neutral society by 2050 by pioneering the creation of optimal hydrogen supply networks in the EAS region and setting up a conducive environment for hydrogen business. &nbsp;</p><p>This workshop will be opened with remarks from the Director of Advanced Energy Systems and Structure Division, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI) Japan, followed by keynote speeches from ERIA, the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), and METI Japan. After that, the Working Group that consists of selected EAS countries&rsquo; representatives will discuss how to promote hydrogen energy in the region in terms of policy, technology, and finance.</p><p>The workshop is hosted by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) Supported by Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan.</p><h2>Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Tuesday, 18 October 2022</li><li>Time: 1:00 PM &ndash; 4:00 PM (Japan/JST)</li><li>Venue: Oriental Hotel Kobe, Japan | Hybrid Forum</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 678px;"><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p><strong>1:00 PM &ndash; 1:10 PM</strong></p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>Opening Address</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Ms Hino Yukari</strong>, Director, Advanced Energy Systems and Structure Division, Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Department, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI)<strong>&nbsp;(TBC)</strong></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p><strong>1:10 PM &ndash; 1:30 PM</strong></p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>Keynote Speech 1:&nbsp;</strong>Hydrogen Outlook of ASEAN Region</p><ul><li><strong>Mr Shigeru Kimura</strong>, Special Advisor on Energy Affairs, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p><strong>1:30 PM &ndash; 1:50 PM</strong></p><p><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>Keynote Speech 2:</strong>&nbsp;Global Hydrogen Perspective</p><ul><li><strong>Mr Emanuele Bianco</strong>, International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p><strong>1:50 PM &ndash; 2:10 PM</strong></p><p><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>Keynote Speech 3:</strong>&nbsp;Japan Hydrogen Policy</p><ul><li><strong>Mr Yoshida Hiroki</strong>, Deputy Director, Advanced Energy Systems and Structure Division, Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Department, ANRE, METI</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p><strong>2.10 PM &ndash; 3.50 PM</strong></p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>Panel Discussion on &ldquo;Issues and Challenges towards Hydrogen Utilization&rdquo;</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:</strong></p><p><strong>Dr Alloysius Joko Purwanto</strong>, Energy Economist, ERIA</p><p><strong>Panellists:</strong></p><ul><li>Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water (DCCEEW), Australia&nbsp;<strong>(TBC)</strong></li><li><strong>Mr Shaikh Mohamad Faiz bin Shaikh Hj Fadilah</strong>, Special Duties Officer II, Renewable Energy Unit, Sustainable Energy Division, Department of Energy, Prime Minister&rsquo;s Office (PMO), Brunei Darussalam</li><li><strong>Dr Zheng Lyu,&nbsp;</strong>Deputy Director, Carbon Data and Carbon Assessment Research Center, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences</li><li><strong>Dr Natarajan Rajalakshmi,&nbsp;</strong>Former Team Leader and Senior Scientist, Centre for Fuelcell Technology (CFCT), International Advanced Research Centre for Powder Metallurgy and New Materials (ARCI)</li><li><strong>Ms Andriah Feby Misna</strong>, Director, Directorate of Various New and Renewable Energy, Directorate General of New Renewable Energy and Energy Conservation, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR), Indonesia</li><li><strong>Mr OHIRA Eiji</strong>, Director General, Fuel Cell &amp; Hydrogen Office, Advanced Battery and Hydrogen Technology Department, The New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization (NEDO), Japan</li><li><strong>Mr Khairul Anuar Mukhtar</strong>,&nbsp;Senior Assistant Secretary, Electricity Supply Policy and Planning, Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources (KeTSA), Malaysia&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Mr Mark Pickup</strong>, Principal Policy Advisor, Energy Markets Policy, Energy &amp; Resource Markets Branch, Ministry of Business Innovation and Employment (MBIE), New Zealand</li></ul><p><strong>Presentation</strong>&nbsp;(40 min)</p><p><strong>Panel discussion</strong>&nbsp;(25 min)</p><p><strong>Q &amp; A</strong>&nbsp;(15 min)</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 169.167px;"><p><strong>3:50 PM &ndash; 4:00 PM</strong></p></td><td style="width: 490.833px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Prof Jun Arima</strong>, Senior Policy Fellow for Energy and Environment, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Group Photo</strong></p></td></tr></table><p>&nbsp;</p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://bit.ly/ERIA-EAS-Hydrogen-Workshop" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ONLINE REGISTRATION</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/east-asia-summit-eas-hydrogen-workshop-offline-tickets-432326027787" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IN-PERSON REGISTRATION</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:15:"Energy,Workshop";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:11:"Kobe, Japan";s:5:"major";s:28:"Ms Citra Endah Nur Setyawati";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-10-18";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-10-18";s:8:"keywords";s:9895:"East Asia Summit (EAS) Hydrogen Workshop East Asia Summit (EAS) Hydrogen Workshop Carbon neutrality has become a globally relevant issue since COP 26 and hydrogen is highlighted as one an important zero emission technology in the East Asia Summit (EAS) region. Hydrogen is a very versatile fuel which can be used for power generation, vehicles, heating, and space missions, and can therefore replace fossil fuels, coal, oil, and gas. &nbsp;
The &lsquo;ERIA East Asia Summit (EAS) Hydrogen Workshop&rsquo; will focus on hydrogen demand and production potential in the EAS region in comparison to the global situation and outlook of hydrogen.
Production potential in the EAS region should include the use of unused energy including hydropower sources in isolated areas, gas flaring at oil and gas production sites, and low-ranked coal. While considering issues and challenges surrounding hydrogen technology development, hydrogen policies of EAS countries, especially those of the hydrogen technology frontrunners such as Japan, play a crucial role in achieving a carbon-neutral society by 2050 by pioneering the creation of optimal hydrogen supply networks in the EAS region and setting up a conducive environment for hydrogen business. &nbsp;
This workshop will be opened with remarks from the Director of Advanced Energy Systems and Structure Division, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI) Japan, followed by keynote speeches from ERIA, the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), and METI Japan. After that, the Working Group that consists of selected EAS countries&rsquo; representatives will discuss how to promote hydrogen energy in the region in terms of policy, technology, and finance.
The workshop is hosted by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) Supported by Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan.
Schedule

Date: Tuesday, 18 October 2022
Time: 1:00 PM &ndash; 4:00 PM (Japan/JST)
Venue: Oriental Hotel Kobe, Japan | Hybrid Forum

Agenda




1:00 PM &ndash; 1:10 PM


Opening Address

Ms Hino Yukari, Director, Advanced Energy Systems and Structure Division, Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Department, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI)&nbsp;(TBC)





1:10 PM &ndash; 1:30 PM


Keynote Speech 1:&nbsp;Hydrogen Outlook of ASEAN Region

Mr Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor on Energy Affairs, ERIA





1:30 PM &ndash; 1:50 PM
&nbsp;


Keynote Speech 2:&nbsp;Global Hydrogen Perspective

Mr Emanuele Bianco, International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA)





1:50 PM &ndash; 2:10 PM
&nbsp;


Keynote Speech 3:&nbsp;Japan Hydrogen Policy

Mr Yoshida Hiroki, Deputy Director, Advanced Energy Systems and Structure Division, Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Department, ANRE, METI





2.10 PM &ndash; 3.50 PM


Panel Discussion on &ldquo;Issues and Challenges towards Hydrogen Utilization&rdquo;
Moderator:
Dr Alloysius Joko Purwanto, Energy Economist, ERIA
Panellists:

Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water (DCCEEW), Australia&nbsp;(TBC)
Mr Shaikh Mohamad Faiz bin Shaikh Hj Fadilah, Special Duties Officer II, Renewable Energy Unit, Sustainable Energy Division, Department of Energy, Prime Minister&rsquo;s Office (PMO), Brunei Darussalam
Dr Zheng Lyu,&nbsp;Deputy Director, Carbon Data and Carbon Assessment Research Center, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Dr Natarajan Rajalakshmi,&nbsp;Former Team Leader and Senior Scientist, Centre for Fuelcell Technology (CFCT), International Advanced Research Centre for Powder Metallurgy and New Materials (ARCI)
Ms Andriah Feby Misna, Director, Directorate of Various New and Renewable Energy, Directorate General of New Renewable Energy and Energy Conservation, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR), Indonesia
Mr OHIRA Eiji, Director General, Fuel Cell &amp; Hydrogen Office, Advanced Battery and Hydrogen Technology Department, The New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization (NEDO), Japan
Mr Khairul Anuar Mukhtar,&nbsp;Senior Assistant Secretary, Electricity Supply Policy and Planning, Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources (KeTSA), Malaysia&nbsp;
Mr Mark Pickup, Principal Policy Advisor, Energy Markets Policy, Energy &amp; Resource Markets Branch, Ministry of Business Innovation and Employment (MBIE), New Zealand

Presentation&nbsp;(40 min)

3:50 PM &ndash; 4:00 PM


Closing Remarks

Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow for Energy and Environment, ERIA

Best Policy Strategies Part II: Balancing Health and Economy";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-10-13";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:3950:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_Oct_Pandemic-Best-Policy-Strategies_800x450.jpg" alt="" width="678" height="339" /></p><p>Although many pandemic experts predicted the COVID-19 pandemic to follow the path of other pandemics in history and drizzle away after two years, the Omicron variants have pushed the timeline to now approach three. Inevitably, Governments across the globe have been hard-pressed to work alone within their borders as well as together across borders while striving to balance health and economy. Within the diverse community of ERIA Member States alone, a variety of measures have been tackled to survive through attempts to balance each nation&rsquo;s health and economy.</p><p>This webinar series offers the opportunity to share knowledge and experience from each ERIA Member State (EMS) about what they have learned to be most effective, in order to more smoothly exit this pandemic and if necessary, how to live with its endemicity as well as to better prepare for upcoming ones.</p><p>In the first part of this series, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, India, Japan, and a senior economist from ERIA shared their notable policy experiences. Due to popular demand, this part two will invite six speakers from other EMSs (candidates are Cambodia, Malaysia, Myanmar, Singapore, Viet Nam, Australia, and China). The webinar will be conducted in English.</p><h2>Objectives</h2><ol><li>Enhance public awareness of pandemic best policy strategies that have been implemented and observed to balance health and economy successfully within the region.</li><li>Share actual innovative pandemic best practices from both developing and developed economies within the region.</li><li>Document pandemic best practices that can be referred to in preparation for and during upcoming pandemics and related health emergencies.</li><li>Build and strengthen collaborations by better understanding the situations of neighbors.</li><li>Explore the needs of collaborations in research and development within the region.</li></ol><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 13 October 2022</li><li>Time: 2:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Jakarta/UTC+7)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table><tr><td width="118"><p>14:00-14:05</p></td><td width="486"><p><strong>Welcome Remarks:&nbsp;</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Takuma Kato, Antonio Villanueva</strong>, Senior Advisor on Healthcare Policy, ERIA</li></ul><p><em>Experts:</em></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Sovann Ly</strong>, Advisor to Ministry of Health as Secretary of State, Phnom Penh, Cambodia</li><li><strong>Prof Kun Tang</strong>,&nbsp;Vanke School of Public Health, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China</li><li><strong>Dr Lili Yan Ing</strong>, Lead Advisor for Southeast Asia, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="118"><p>14:50-14:55</p></td><td width="486"><p><strong>Break</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="118"><p>14:55-15:25</p></td><td Now!</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:19:"healthcare,pandemic";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:14:"Ms Nanda Putri";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-10-13";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-10-13";s:8:"keywords";s:6333:"Pandemic Best Policy Strategies Part II: Balancing Health and Economy Pandemic Best Policy Strategies Part II: Balancing Health and Economy Although many pandemic experts predicted the COVID-19 pandemic to follow the path of other pandemics in history and drizzle away after two years, the Omicron variants have pushed the timeline to now approach three. Inevitably, Governments across the globe have been hard-pressed to work alone within their borders as well as together across borders while striving to balance health and economy. Within the diverse community of ERIA Member States alone, a variety of measures have been tackled to survive through attempts to balance each nation&rsquo;s health and economy.
This webinar series offers the opportunity to share knowledge and experience from each ERIA Member State (EMS) about what they have learned to be most effective, in order to more smoothly exit this pandemic and if necessary, how to live with its endemicity as well as to better prepare for upcoming ones.
In the first part of this series, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, India, Japan, and a senior economist from ERIA shared their notable policy experiences. Due to popular demand, this part two will invite six speakers from other EMSs (candidates are Cambodia, Malaysia, Myanmar, Singapore, Viet Nam, Australia, and China). The webinar will be conducted in English.
Objectives

Enhance public awareness of pandemic best policy strategies that have been implemented and observed to balance health and economy successfully within the region.
Share actual innovative pandemic best practices from both developing and developed economies within the region.
Document pandemic best practices that can be referred to in preparation for and during upcoming pandemics and related health emergencies.
Build and strengthen collaborations by better understanding the situations of neighbors.
Explore the needs of collaborations in research and development within the region.

Event Details

Date: Thursday, 13 October 2022
Time: 2:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Jakarta/UTC+7)

Agenda




14:00-14:05


Welcome Remarks:&nbsp;

Dr Takuma Kato, Director of Healthcare Unit, ERIA





14:05-14:50


Part 1
Moderator:

Dr Antonio Villanueva, Senior Advisor on Healthcare Policy, ERIA

Experts:

Dr Sovann Ly, Advisor to Ministry of Health as Secretary of State, Phnom Penh, Cambodia

With networks across government, business and beyond, UAC provides a platform for conversations on priority issues and a launching pad for social impact in the Indo-Pacific.</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Under the 2022 theme of &ldquo;Development and Diversity&rdquo;, UAC2022 will explore how we can promote inclusive growth within the region whilst preserving important traditions and culture. You will hear from world-class speakers, future leaders and yourself engage in conversations, networking, workshops, panels, and expos to develop the skills and expertise needed to become the change you wish to see in the world.</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Plus, you&#039;ll wrap up the day with their mini Southeast Asian night markets!</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Register for the conference to gain meaningful new connections and take a step towards social impact.</span></p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Saturday, 24 September 2022</li><li>Time: 10AM -&nbsp;9PM (GMT+10)</li><li>Venue: <span style="font-weight: 400;">John Niland Scientia Building, Kensington NSW 2033, Australia</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">More information about the conference can be found on the <a href="https://www.unswaseanconference.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">UAC website</a>.</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;"><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://events.humanitix.com/unsw-asean-conference-2022" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IN-PERSON REGISTRATION</a></strong></span></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:17:"Sydney, Australia";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Abigail Balthazar";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-24";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:2739:"The UNSW ASEAN Conference The UNSW ASEAN Conference The UNSW ASEAN Conference brings together hundreds of students and working professionals annually to spark conversations around emerging issues in the ASEAN region. With networks across government, business and beyond, UAC provides a platform for conversations on priority issues and a launching pad for social impact in the Indo-Pacific.
Under the 2022 theme of &ldquo;Development and Diversity&rdquo;, UAC2022 will explore how we can promote inclusive growth within the region whilst preserving important traditions and culture. You will hear from world-class speakers, future leaders and yourself engage in conversations, networking, workshops, panels, and expos to develop the skills and expertise needed to become the change you wish to see in the world.
Plus, you'll wrap up the day with their mini Southeast Asian night markets!
Register for the conference to gain meaningful new connections and take a step towards social impact.
Event Details

Date: Saturday, 24 September 2022
Time: 10AM -&nbsp;9PM (GMT+10)
Venue: John Niland Scientia Building, Kensington NSW 2033, Australia

More information about the conference can be found on the UAC website.

ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-09-19 15:50:46";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-19 15:54:54";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:26:"abigail.balthazar@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:52;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7019";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:65:"digital-transformation-with-the-cloud-eria-aws-adb-webinar-series";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:66:"Digital Transformation with the Cloud: ERIA-AWS-ADB Webinar Series";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-10-06";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:3869:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/FN-Digital%20Transformation%20with%20the%20Cloud%20Webinar%20Poster%20%20(Instagram%20Post%20(Square)).pdf" alt="" /><img src="/uploads/media/FN-Digital%20Transformation%20with%20the%20Cloud%20Webinar%20Poster%20%20(Instagram%20Post%20(Square)).png" alt="" width="601" height="601" /><img src="/uploads/media/FN-Digital%20Transformation%20with%20the%20Cloud%20Webinar%20Poster%20%20(Instagram%20Post%20(Square)).pdf" alt="" /><img src="/uploads/media/FN-Digital%20Transformation%20with%20the%20Cloud%20Webinar%20Poster%20%20(Instagram%20Post%20(Square)).pdf" alt="" /></p><p>Over the past decade, cloud computing has revolutionized how people and organizations work around the world by democratizing access to technology, affording organizations of all sizes with access to a plethora of digital tools, as well as the security and sustainability benefits of the cloud. Cloud computing is the foundational enabler of the digital transformation of governments, businesses and organizations of all sizes; the default pathway for innovation. Today, governments, public sector organizations, not-for-profits, universities, small and medium enterprises, and enterprises of all sizes across Asia innovate better, faster, and more cost-efficiently through the cloud. Yet, many organizations, both in the public and private sector, have a rudimentary understanding of the cloud and the policies that can enable cloud adoption across different sectors.</p><p>&nbsp;<strong>Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and Amazon Web Services (AWS) are hosting a series of Policy Webinars centered around the theme of &ldquo;Digital Transformation with the Cloud&rdquo;. </strong>This Policy Webinar series is a multi-stakeholder dialogue that will bring together policymakers, regulators, think tanks, academia, industry, and other key stakeholders to explore how the cloud and forward-thinking, pro-innovation digital policies can accelerate the digital transformation journey of nations. It will focus on enhancing our collective understanding about the cloud, its benefits, and the policy best practices for digital transformation through the cloud. The Launch Webinar will be held on <strong>6 Oct 2022</strong> and will focus on the theme of digital inclusion in the Cloud with the theme<em> &ldquo;</em><strong>Building Blocks for a Cloud First Environment</strong>&rdquo;. The panel discussion will cover topics that lay the foundation for creating a Cloud First environment and the way forward for building a Cloud First mindset in the Asia-Pacific and beyond.</p><h2>Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 6 October 2022</li><li>Time: 2:00 PM - 3:30 PM (Singapore Time/GMT+8)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><p>Opening remarks:</p><ul><li>Alfredo Perdiguero, Director of the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination, Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank</li></ul><p>Keynote speech:</p><ul><li>Agne Makauskaite, Head of Public Policy for Regulated Industries, Asia Pacific and Japan, AWS&nbsp;</li></ul><p>Panel discussion speakers:</p><ul><li>Thomas Abell, Advisor, Digital Technology for Development, ADB</li><li>Semuel A. Pangerapan, Director General of Application Informatics, Ministry of ICT, Indonesia</li><li>Mary Joy Abueg, President of the National ICT Confederation of the Philippines</li><li>Tahir Hashmi, SVP of Engineering atTokopedia and CTO at Dekara</li></ul><p>Moderator:</p><ul><li>Moderator: May-Ann Lim, Director, Fair Tech Institute &amp; Emeritus Director, Asia Cloud Computing Association</li></ul><p>Closing remarks:</p><ul><li>Lili Yan Ing,&nbsp;Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia Region, ERIA</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://adb-org.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_VHvNCE80SB-plaGTZFsk0g" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:29:"digital transformation,Policy";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-10-06";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-10-06";s:8:"keywords";s:6377:"Digital Transformation with the Cloud: ERIA-AWS-ADB Webinar Series Digital Transformation with the Cloud: ERIA-AWS-ADB Webinar Series Over the past decade, cloud computing has revolutionized how people and organizations work around the world by democratizing access to technology, affording organizations of all sizes with access to a plethora of digital tools, as well as the security and sustainability benefits of the cloud. Cloud computing is the foundational enabler of the digital transformation of governments, businesses and organizations of all sizes; the default pathway for innovation. Today, governments, public sector organizations, not-for-profits, universities, small and medium enterprises, and enterprises of all sizes across Asia innovate better, faster, and more cost-efficiently through the cloud. Yet, many organizations, both in the public and private sector, have a rudimentary understanding of the cloud and the policies that can enable cloud adoption across different sectors.
&nbsp;Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and Amazon Web Services (AWS) are hosting a series of Policy Webinars centered around the theme of &ldquo;Digital Transformation with the Cloud&rdquo;. This Policy Webinar series is a multi-stakeholder dialogue that will bring together policymakers, regulators, think tanks, academia, industry, and other key stakeholders to explore how the cloud and forward-thinking, pro-innovation digital policies can accelerate the digital transformation journey of nations. It will focus on enhancing our collective understanding about the cloud, its benefits, and the policy best practices for digital transformation through the cloud. The Launch Webinar will be held on 6 Oct 2022 and will focus on the theme of digital inclusion in the Cloud with the theme &ldquo;Building Blocks for a Cloud First Environment&rdquo;. The panel discussion will cover topics that lay the foundation for creating a Cloud First environment and the way forward for building a Cloud First mindset in the Asia-Pacific and beyond.
Schedule

Date: Thursday, 6 October 2022
Time: 2:00 PM - 3:30 PM (Singapore Time/GMT+8)

Agenda
Opening remarks:

Alfredo Perdiguero, Director of the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination, Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank

Keynote speech:

Agne Makauskaite, Head of Public Policy for Regulated Industries, Asia Pacific and Japan, AWS&nbsp;

Panel discussion speakers:

Thomas Abell, Advisor, Digital Technology for Development, ADB
Semuel A. Pangerapan, Director General of Application Informatics, Ministry of ICT, Indonesia
Mary Joy Abueg, President of the National ICT Confederation of the Philippines
Tahir Hashmi, SVP of Engineering atTokopedia and CTO at Dekara

Moderator:

Moderator: May-Ann Lim, Director, Fair Tech Institute &amp; Emeritus Director, Asia Cloud Computing Association

Closing remarks:

Lili Yan Ing,&nbsp;Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia Region, ERIA

32-90-2202  32-90-2202   gro.aire@ayihtaf.aliehs ayihtaF aliehS sM aisyalaM ,rupmuL alauK        aisyalaM ni hcnuaL baL egdelwonK I-S-E aisyalaM ni hcnuaL baL egdelwonK I-S-E";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-09-08 09:39:00";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-08 09:39:00";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"sheila.fathiya@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:56;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7012";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:73:"the-eus-carbon-border-adjustment-mechanism-implication-for-southeast-asia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:75:"The EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism: Implication for Southeast Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-09";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:1819:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Webinar%20%20CBAM%20Poster.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="1132" /></p><p>As a region which trades heavily with the European Union, the bloc&rsquo;s planned Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) is likely to have deep and meaningful effects on ASEAN economies. Beyond this, and as carbon pricing instruments proliferate, an increasing number of countries are likely to follow the EU&rsquo;s lead in implementing carbon border taxes in order to protect the competitiveness of local industries against competitors whose products originate from jurisdictions without domestic carbon pricing legislation, and to prevent carbon leakage. Border adjustment taxes can also spur countries towards enacting their own domestic carbon pricing instruments and in doing so, can be a tool towards the export of climate ambition. Serious consideration must be placed on how ASEAN economies respond to this changing climate policy landscape.</p><p>This discussion aims to unpack the EU&rsquo;s proposed CBAM; consider the role of carbon border taxes in international climate policy responses; and overviews the economic and strategic implications of these instruments on Southeast Asian economies and the EU-ASEAN relationship.</p><p>&nbsp;This discussion will feature commentaries from Dr Michael R. DiGregorio and Mr Darshan Joshi of The Asia Foundation; Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA); and Ms Melinda Martinus of the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies&ndash;Yusof Ishak Institute (ISEAS).</p><ul><li>Date: Friday, 9 September 2022</li><li>Time: 3:00 PM - 5:00 PM (Singapore/GMT+8)</li><li>Venue: Webinar (Zoom)</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_dCctEqBbQb22tSBshQlTTw">Register Here</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:39:"Energy,Carbon Neutrality,Climate Change";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Abigail Balthazar";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-09";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-09";s:8:"keywords";s:3771:"The EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism: Implication for Southeast Asia The EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism: Implication for Southeast Asia As a region which trades heavily with the European Union, the bloc&rsquo;s planned Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) is likely to have deep and meaningful effects on ASEAN economies. Beyond this, and as carbon pricing instruments proliferate, an increasing number of countries are likely to follow the EU&rsquo;s lead in implementing carbon border taxes in order to protect the competitiveness of local industries against competitors whose products originate from jurisdictions without domestic carbon pricing legislation, and to prevent carbon leakage. Border adjustment taxes can also spur countries towards enacting their own domestic carbon pricing instruments and in doing so, can be a tool towards the export of climate ambition. Serious consideration must be placed on how ASEAN economies respond to this changing climate policy landscape.
This discussion aims to unpack the EU&rsquo;s proposed CBAM; consider the role of carbon border taxes in international climate policy responses; and overviews the economic and strategic implications of these instruments on Southeast Asian economies and the EU-ASEAN relationship.
&nbsp;This discussion will feature commentaries from Dr Michael R. DiGregorio and Mr Darshan Joshi of The Asia Foundation; Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA); and Ms Melinda Martinus of the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies&ndash;Yusof Ishak Institute (ISEAS).

Date: Friday, 9 September 2022
Time: 3:00 PM - 5:00 PM (Singapore/GMT+8)
Venue: Webinar (Zoom)
