tnemtsujdA redroB nobraC s'UE ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-09-07 17:10:37";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-08 12:07:06";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:26:"abigail.balthazar@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:57;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6995";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:85:"climate-change-vulnerabilities-social-impacts-and-education-for-autonomous-adaptation";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:87:"Climate Change Vulnerabilities, Social Impacts, and Education for Autonomous Adaptation";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-12";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:13640:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Copy%20of%20Copy%20of%20Event%20Flyer%20Template%20(2).png" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Southeast Asia is one of the world&rsquo;s most vulnerable regions to climate change, due to its long coastlines, high concentration of population and economic activity in coastal areas, and heavy reliance on agriculture, fisheries, forestry, and other natural resources. Climate hazards such as temperature increase, erratic rainfall patterns, and extreme climatic events (such as strong typhoons and severe droughts) cause adverse effects and impacts on ecosystems&rsquo; livelihoods and on many other aspects of human societies. In particular, climate change threatens agricultural production and indirectly food security, ecological stability, and sustainable development.</p><p>Climate variability and change present many risks to the well-being of the populations of the Association of Southeast Asia Nations (ASEAN). The vulnerability, capacity, and adaptation assessments conducted at provincial to national scales are designed to provide information to decision-and policymakers on the risks of climate variability, and on the options for managing those risks.</p><p>Conducting an integrated assessment is an essential input in developing national adaptation plans. Additionally, ensuring that climate change scenarios are integrated into national policies and programs will prepare stakeholders for and manage the risks of climate variability and climate change.</p><h3>Objectives:</h3><p>The main objective of the event is to strengthen the capacity of officials from ASEAN member states on climate change vulnerability assessment and the implementation of successful autonomous and planned adaptation measures.</p><h3>Expected Outputs:</h3><p>Expected outputs from the three-day event are:</p><ul><li>The participants from ASEAN member states acquire knowledge on vulnerability assessment and adaptation at national and local scales;</li><li>The participants discussed and shared lessons learned and experiences on vulnerability assessment and autonomous adaptation; and</li><li>Practical learning and knowledge acquisition through field visits in vulnerable areas in Cambodia, where successful local adaptation measures are</li></ul><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: 12 - 14 September 2022</li><li>Venue: Siem Reap, Cambodia | Hybrid Workshop</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 702px;"><tr style="height: 22px;"><td style="width: 686px; Dr. Vann Monyneath,&nbsp;</strong>Director General of Policy &amp; Strategy</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://us06web.zoom.us/j/88059969897?pwd=eVhsV3FwSVBZby9SNVhZK3c3Sk1QUT09" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ATTEND VIA ZOOM HERE</a></p><p>Passcode: 136096</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:19:"Siam Reap, Cambodia";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Abigail Balthazar";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-12";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-14";s:8:"keywords";s:14931:"Climate Change Vulnerabilities, Social Impacts, and Education for Autonomous Adaptation Climate Change Vulnerabilities, Social Impacts, and Education for Autonomous Adaptation Southeast Asia is one of the world&rsquo;s most vulnerable regions to climate change, due to its long coastlines, high concentration of population and economic activity in coastal areas, and heavy reliance on agriculture, fisheries, forestry, and other natural resources. Climate hazards such as temperature increase, erratic rainfall patterns, and extreme climatic events (such as strong typhoons and severe droughts) cause adverse effects and impacts on ecosystems&rsquo; livelihoods and on many other aspects of human societies. In particular, climate change threatens agricultural production and indirectly food security, ecological stability, and sustainable development.
Climate variability and change present many risks to the well-being of the populations of the Association of Southeast Asia Nations (ASEAN). The vulnerability, capacity, and adaptation assessments conducted at provincial to national scales are designed to provide information to decision-and policymakers on the risks of climate variability, and on the options for managing those risks.
Conducting an integrated assessment is an essential input in developing national adaptation plans. Additionally, ensuring that climate change scenarios are integrated into national policies and programs will prepare stakeholders for and manage the risks of climate variability and climate change.
Objectives:
The main objective of the event is to strengthen the capacity of officials from ASEAN member states on climate change vulnerability assessment and the implementation of successful autonomous and planned adaptation measures.
Expected Outputs:
Expected outputs from the three-day event are:

The participants from ASEAN member states acquire knowledge on vulnerability assessment and adaptation at national and local scales;
The participants discussed and shared lessons learned and experiences on vulnerability assessment and autonomous adaptation; and
Practical learning and knowledge acquisition through field visits in vulnerable areas in Cambodia, where successful local adaptation measures are

Event Details

Date: 12 - 14 September 2022
Venue: Siem Reap, Cambodia | Hybrid Workshop

2022 2202 rebmetpeS 62 62-90-2202 03-90-2202 62-90-2202   gro.aire@itnayamrad.ait itnayamraD aiT sM senippilihP ,alinaM        secivreS rof eettimmoC gnitanidrooC NAESA dn201 secivreS rof eettimmoC gnitanidrooC NAESA dn201";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-09-01 07:00:02";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-01 07:00:02";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"tia.darmayanti@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:59;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6992";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:73:"asean-on-point-public-forum-ensuring-food-security-in-post-pandemic-asean";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:74:"ASEAN On Point Public Forum: Ensuring Food Security in Post-Pandemic ASEAN";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-26";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:3464:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_Sept_Asean-on-Point_800x450.jpg" alt="" width="770" height="385" /></p><p>Food security has become a critical issue facing policymakers around the world.&nbsp; With rising inflation, supply chain disruptions, climate change, and conflicts, the cost of basic foods has skyrocketed as much as 50% since the beginning of 2021. As families are struggling to rebuild after the pandemic, financial means are limited, and the poorest people are hit the hardest.&nbsp; The added expense will push some people into poverty &ndash; an estimated 118 million people have become chronically hungry since the beginning of the pandemic according to the UN.</p><p>The agriculture and food sector is one of the most vulnerable sectors affected by the pandemic as it is heavily linked with key economic factors such as global agricultural commodities trade in the region (trade and regional integration), and more importantly, food supply and food security (trade and sustainable development).&nbsp; For the first event of the 2022 ASEAN on Point Public Forum Series, the ASEAN Secretariat, in collaboration with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia, is hosting a panel discussion to investigate the issue of food security in ASEAN. This event builds on the findings on the first ASEAN on Point forum on sustainable food and agriculture which focused on agricultural productivity and sustainability (see report <a href="/publications/asean-on-point-public-forum-ensuring-the-resilience-and-sustainability-of-the-agriculture-and-food-sector-in-asean-in-the-context-of-covid-19/">here</a>). This session will focus on trade, logistics, infrastructure, and the threat of food nationalism.</p><p>Hosted by ERIA and ASEC, the online Webinar will last 1 hour via Zoom platform with a period of moderated discussion at the end.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Monday, 26 September 2022</li><li>Time: 9:30 AM - 10:30 AM (Jakarta/GMT+7)</li><li>Venue: Zoom Webinar</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 641px;"><tr><td style="width: 158.674px;"><p>9:30 AM &ndash; 9:35 AM</p></td><td style="width: 467.326px;"><p><strong>ASEC Opening Remarks:&nbsp;</strong><strong>Mr Ahmad Zafarullah</strong>, Director of ASEAN Integration Monitoring Directorate</p><p><strong>ERIA Welcome Remarks&nbsp;&nbsp; </strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 158.674px;"><p>9:35 AM &ndash; 10:15 AM</p></td><td style="width: 467.326px;"><p><strong>Moderated Panel Discussion</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Ramon Clarete</strong>, Professor, University of the Philippines of Economics</li><li><strong>Dr Risti Permani</strong>, Senior Lecturer in Agribusiness, University of Queensland</li></ul><p>Moderator:</p><ul><li><strong>Professor Paul P.S. Teng, Ph.D., Hon.D.Sc.,FAAET</strong>, Managing Director &amp; &nbsp;&nbsp;Dean, NIE International Pte Ltd | National Institute of Education</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 158.674px;"><p>10:15 AM &ndash; 10:25 AM</p></td><td style="width: 467.326px;"><p><strong>Q &amp; A </strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 158.674px;"><p>10:25 AM &ndash; 10:30 AM</p></td><td style="width: 467.326px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks </strong></p></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/asean-on-point-public-forum-ensuring-food-security-in-post-pandemic-asean-tickets-415126593817" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:18:"Ms Debora Tambunan";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-26";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:5299:"ASEAN On Point Public Forum: Ensuring Food Security in Post-Pandemic ASEAN ASEAN On Point Public Forum: Ensuring Food Security in Post-Pandemic ASEAN Food security has become a critical issue facing policymakers around the world.&nbsp; With rising inflation, supply chain disruptions, climate change, and conflicts, the cost of basic foods has skyrocketed as much as 50% since the beginning of 2021. As families are struggling to rebuild after the pandemic, financial means are limited, and the poorest people are hit the hardest.&nbsp; The added expense will push some people into poverty &ndash; an estimated 118 million people have become chronically hungry since the beginning of the pandemic according to the UN.
The agriculture and food sector is one of the most vulnerable sectors affected by the pandemic as it is heavily linked with key economic factors such as global agricultural commodities trade in the region (trade and regional integration), and more importantly, food supply and food security (trade and sustainable development).&nbsp; For the first event of the 2022 ASEAN on Point Public Forum Series, the ASEAN Secretariat, in collaboration with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia, is hosting a panel discussion to investigate the issue of food security in ASEAN. This event builds on the findings on the first ASEAN on Point forum on sustainable food and agriculture which focused on agricultural productivity and sustainability (see report here). This session will focus on trade, logistics, infrastructure, and the threat of food nationalism.
Hosted by ERIA and ASEC, the online Webinar will last 1 hour via Zoom platform with a period of moderated discussion at the end.
Event Details

Date: Monday, 26 September 2022
Time: 9:30 AM - 10:30 AM (Jakarta/GMT+7)
Venue: Zoom Webinar

Agenda




9:30 AM &ndash; 9:35 AM


ASEC Opening Remarks:&nbsp;Mr Ahmad Zafarullah, Director of ASEAN Integration Monitoring Directorate
ERIA Welcome Remarks&nbsp;&nbsp; 




9:35 AM &ndash; 10:15 AM


Moderated Panel Discussion

Dr Ramon Clarete, Professor, University of the Philippines of Economics
Dr Risti Permani, Senior Lecturer in Agribusiness, University of Queensland

Moderator:

Professor Paul P.S. Teng, Ph.D., Hon.D.Sc.,FAAET, Managing Director &amp; &nbsp;&nbsp;Dean, NIE International Pte Ltd | National Institute of Education





10:15 AM &ndash; 10:25 AM


Q &amp; A 




10:25 AM &ndash; 10:30 AM


Closing Remarks

Session: Launch of â€˜G20 Research Forumâ€™: Towards Multi-Dimensional Perspectives on G20 Development Agenda";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-05";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:4443:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_September_G20-Research-Forum.png" alt="" width="800" height="1000" />Over the years, G20 along with its various organs like Working Groups, Engagement Groups, etc has emerged as an important platform for exchange of ideas, policy debate and consensus building among governments of the member countries and diverse stakeholders including from non-G20 countries. Although Engagement Groups like Think 20 (T20) has grown as an organised process over time there is still not much space within the existing formats of deliberations; hence constraining articulation of diverse perspectives on various development issues relevant to G20 and the global economy. In particular, G20 development agenda has undergone tremendous diversification in recent years with the inclusion of SDGs, climate change, quality infrastructure, gender, social inclusion, etc which require pooling specialised knowledge and expertise from academics, policymakers and practitioners.</p><p>In order to provide well-researched inputs to the G20 process through T20, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), Jakarta; Research and Information System for Developing Countries (RIS), New Delhi; and LPEM, University of Indonesia have set up the G20 Research Forum (GRF) with open membership for others. GRF aims to undertake studies, organise brainstorming sessions, collaborate with governments and chairs of G20; and establish linkages with multilateral organisations such as WTO, World Bank, ILO, EIB, etc.</p><p>For wider dissemination of this proposed forum, ERIA, RIS and LPEM in collaboration with T20 Indonesia are organising a Special Session in the T20 Summit to launch the G20 Research Forum with a Panel Discussion on the need for multi-dimensional perspectives on G20 Development agenda on 5 September 2022.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><p>Date: Monday, 5 September 2022<br />Time: 1:30 PM to 3 PM (Bali time, UTC+8)<br />RSVP for online attendance: <a title="Click here to register" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/t20-indonesia-summit-online-tickets-399876500377" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://www.eventbrite.com/e/t20-indonesia-summit-online-tickets-399876500377<br /></a><strong>The Special Session is part of the Day 1 Bundle - Parallel Session 1 All Sessions</strong></p><h2>Agenda</h2><p><em>Welcome Remarks</em>: <strong>Dr Priyadarshi Dash</strong>, Associate Professor, RIS,&nbsp;New Delhi, India (<strong><em>5 min</em></strong>)<br /><em>About G20 Research Forum</em>: <strong>Anita Prakash</strong>, Senior Policy Advisor&nbsp;(IEC), Office of President, ERIA, Jakarta, Indonesia (<strong><em>5 min</em></strong>)</p><p><em>Chair</em><strong>:</strong> &nbsp;<strong>Professor Sachin Chaturvedi</strong>, Director General, RIS, New Delhi,&nbsp;India (<em>5</em><em> min</em>)</p><ul><li><em>Special Remarks</em>: Professor Hidetoshi Nishimura, President, ERIA, Jakarta, Indonesia (<em>10 min</em>)</li><li><em>Special Remarks</em>: Professor Bambang P.S. Brodjonegoro, Lead Co-Chair, T20 Indonesia (<em>10 min</em>)</li></ul><p><strong><em><u>Panellists</u></em></strong></p><ul><li><strong>Elizabeth Sidiropoulos, </strong>Chief Executive, South African Institute of International Affairs (SAIIA), Johannesburg, South Africa (<strong><em>8 min</em></strong>)</li><li><strong>Professor Dennis J. Snower</strong>, President, Global Solutions Initiative, Bonn, Germany (<strong><em>8 min</em></strong>)</li><li><strong>Professor Anna-Katharina Hornidge</strong>, Director, German Institute of Development and Sustainability (IDOS), Bonn, Germany (<strong><em>8 min</em></strong>)</li><li><strong> Fahad Alturki</strong>, Vice President (Knowledge &amp; Analysis), King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center (KAPSARC), Riyadh, Saudi Arabia (<strong><em>8 min</em></strong>)</li><li><strong> Nicolas Buchoud</strong>, President, Grand Alliance, Paris, France (<strong><em>8 min</em></strong>)</li></ul><p><strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Q &amp; A </strong>(<strong><em>15 min</em></strong>)</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/t20-indonesia-summit-online-tickets-399876500377" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></p><h2>YouTube Livestream</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/uu3MyZsq8mE" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:22:"G20,G20 Research Forum";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:15:"Bali, Indonesia";s:5:"major";s:15:"Ms Kemala Putri";s:16:"article_keywords";s:23:"G20, G20 Research Forum";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-05";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:7225:"Special Session: Launch of â€˜G20 Research Forumâ€™: Towards Multi-Dimensional Perspectives on G20 Development Agenda Special Session: Launch of â€˜G20 Research Forumâ€™: Towards Multi-Dimensional Perspectives on G20 Development Agenda Over the years, G20 along with its various organs like Working Groups, Engagement Groups, etc has emerged as an important platform for exchange of ideas, policy debate and consensus building among governments of the member countries and diverse stakeholders including from non-G20 countries. Although Engagement Groups like Think 20 (T20) has grown as an organised process over time there is still not much space within the existing formats of deliberations; hence constraining articulation of diverse perspectives on various development issues relevant to G20 and the global economy. In particular, G20 development agenda has undergone tremendous diversification in recent years with the inclusion of SDGs, climate change, quality infrastructure, gender, social inclusion, etc which require pooling specialised knowledge and expertise from academics, policymakers and practitioners.
In order to provide well-researched inputs to the G20 process through T20, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), Jakarta; Research and Information System for Developing Countries (RIS), New Delhi; and LPEM, University of Indonesia have set up the G20 Research Forum (GRF) with open membership for others. GRF aims to undertake studies, organise brainstorming sessions, collaborate with governments and chairs of G20; and establish linkages with multilateral organisations such as WTO, World Bank, ILO, EIB, etc.
For wider dissemination of this proposed forum, ERIA, RIS and LPEM in collaboration with T20 Indonesia are organising a Special Session in the T20 Summit to launch the G20 Research Forum with a Panel Discussion on the need for multi-dimensional perspectives on G20 Development agenda on 5 September 2022.
Event Details
Date: Monday, 5 September 2022Time: 1:30 PM to 3 PM (Bali time, UTC+8)RSVP for online attendance: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/t20-indonesia-summit-online-tickets-399876500377The Special Session is part of the Day 1 Bundle - Parallel Session 1 All Sessions

laicepS";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-09-01 06:55:19";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-05 06:17:38";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:21:"kemala.putri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:65;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6986";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:47:"the-second-asia-ccus-network-forum-hybrid-forum";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:49:"The Second Asia CCUS Network Forum | Hybrid Forum";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-30";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:7747:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/The%20Second%20Asia%20CCUS%20Network%20Forum-new(2).png" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>After the COP26 held in Glasgow, United Kingdom, last autumn 2021, many Asian countries echoed western countries regarding the need to find pathways to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 and beyond with international assistance. In trying to find such pathways, attention will need to be paid to the accessibility, availability, and affordability of energy supply to achieve reasonable economic growth continuously up until 2050. Therefore, in the energy transition period towards carbon neutrality beyond 2050, a gradual shift from coal to gas in power generation will be an important policy to reduce emissions. Co-firing of hydrogen and ammonia with gas and coal power plants is another important policy to move towards carbon neutrality together with maximising the share of variable renewable energy and minimising the share of electric storage. Besides, switching to cleaner fuels such as gas, ammonia, and hydrogen, and to clean technologies, an application of CCUS will be the most appropriate clean energy technologies for the Asian region to achieve net zero emissions. Current challenge to apply CCUS technology is due to geopolitical factors that affect international fossil fuel market. The significant increase of fossil fuels&rsquo; price will lead to an additional investment on fossil fuel that means its consumption and CO2 emissions will also increase.</p><p>Looking at the Asian region, Indonesia prepared a draft CCS/CCUS regulation, which is currently awaiting approval by the president. Moreover, PETRONAS is ready to start CCS projects with a Japanese company. Various activities have been organised by the Asia CCUS Network over the past year &ndash; knowledge sharing, research studies, and capacity building trainings.</p><p>The aim of the Second Asia CCUS Network Forum is to report the ACN&rsquo;s activities in 2021&ndash;2202 and the workplan of ACN&rsquo;s activities/milestones for 2022&ndash;2023, after the ministerial remarks, and the Second Forum will hold panel discussions to review the current CCUS situation and policies in the East Asia Summit (EAS) region concerning issues and challenges of CCUS deployment in the region. The Second Forum invites the CCS+ Initiative to introduce its activities regarding the calculation of carbon credit for CCS businesses</p><p>The Asia CCUS Network Forum is co-hosted by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) as Secretariat of Asia CCUS Network (ACN) and Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Friday, 30 September 2022</li><li>Time: 09:00 AM - 12:00 PM (Japan/JST)</li><li>Venue: Tokyo, Japan | Hybrid Forum</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 640.549px;"><tr style="height: 43px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 43px;"><p>08:30 AM &ndash; 09:00 AM&nbsp;&nbsp;</p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 43px;"><p><strong>Registration </strong></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 129px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 129px;"><p>09:00 AM &ndash; 09:10 AM</p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 129px;"><p><strong>Welcoming and Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Minister of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan</li><li><strong>Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura</strong>, President of ERIA&nbsp;</li></ul><p><em>Followed by <strong>Group Photo</strong></em></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 132px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 132px;"><p>09:10 AM &ndash; 10:10 AM</p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 132px;"><p><strong>Ministerial remarks</strong></p><p>Congratulatory remarks by several EAS Energy Ministers</p><p>Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, India, Singapore, Thailand, Viet Nam, Australia, and the United States (TBC)</p><ul><li><strong>H.E. Arifin Tasrif</strong>, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resource, Indonesia</li><li><strong>H.E. Raphael Perpetuo Mercado Lotilla, </strong>Secretary of&nbsp; &nbsp;Department of Energy, Philippines</li><li><strong>Mr Kulit Sombatsiri</strong>, Permanent Secretary of Energy of Thailand</li><li><strong>H.E. Brad Crabtree</strong>, Assistant Secretary for Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, Department of Energy, United States</li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 178px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 178px;"><p>10:10 AM &ndash; Gas Upstream Unit,&nbsp;Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation (JOGMEC)&nbsp;</li><li><p><strong>Mr Patrick BÅ±rgi</strong>, Director Innovation, South Pole, and Co-Founder of the CCS+ Initiative&nbsp;</p></li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 109px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 109px;"><p>10:50 AM &ndash; 11:00 AM</p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 109px;"><p><strong>ACN Annual Report 2021&ndash;2022</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Han Phoumin</strong>, Senior Energy Economist, Energy Unit, ERIA and Senior Officer of ACN Secretariat&nbsp;</li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 626px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 626px;"><p>11:00 AM &ndash; 11:55 AM</p><p><em>&nbsp;</em></p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 626px;"><p><strong>Panel Session: &lsquo;</strong><strong>CCS Policies in EAS Countries&rsquo; &ndash; Issues and Challenges on CO2 Deployment and CO2 Value Chain</strong></p><p><em>Moderator:</em></p><ul><li><strong>Mr Shigeru Kimura</strong>, Special Advisor on Energy Affairs, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Panellists:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Ms Ayaka Jones</strong>, International Technical Advisor, Strategic Engagement, Office of Clean Coal and Carbon Manage, Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, Department of Energy (DOE), United States</li><li><strong>Mr Norihiro Saeki</strong>, Director of CCUS Policy, Agency of Natural Resources and Energy, METI, Japan</li><li><em>&nbsp;</em><strong>Ms Jocelyn Taylor</strong>, Manager, International CCUS Policy, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources (DISER), Australia</li><li><strong>Dr. Ir. Muhammad Wafid A.N, M.Sc.</strong>, Senior Advisor for Environment and Spatial Planning, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Indonesia</li><li><strong>Mr Zaharin Zulkifli, Deputy Director</strong>, Energy Data and Research Unit, Strategic Planning and Communication Department, Energy Commission of Malaysia</li><li><strong>Mr Jesus Tamang, </strong>Director, Energy Policy and Planning Bureau, Department of Energy, Philippines</li></ul><p><em>Followed by <strong>Questions and Answers</strong> </em></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 93.3999px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 93.3999px;"><p>11:55 AM &ndash; 12:00 PM</p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 93.3999px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Mr Yuki Sadamitsu</strong>, Director General, Natural Resources and Fuel Department, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE), Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), Japan</li></ul><ul><li><strong>Mr Koji Hachiyama</strong>, Chief Operating Officer, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/411110782417" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ONLINE REGISTRATION</a></strong></p><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-second-asia-ccus-network-forum-in-person-tickets-411834256347" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IN-PERSON REGISTRATION (limited seats)</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:35:"CCUS,forum,hybrid,hybrid event,METI";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Tokyo, Japan";s:5:"major";s:16:"Ms Dian Lutfiana";s:16:"article_keywords";s:4:"CCUS";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-30";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-30";s:8:"keywords";s:11617:"The Second Asia CCUS Network Forum | Hybrid Forum The Second Asia CCUS Network Forum | Hybrid Forum After the COP26 held in Glasgow, United Kingdom, last autumn 2021, many Asian countries echoed western countries regarding the need to find pathways to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 and beyond with international assistance. In trying to find such pathways, attention will need to be paid to the accessibility, availability, and affordability of energy supply to achieve reasonable economic growth continuously up until 2050. Therefore, in the energy transition period towards carbon neutrality beyond 2050, a gradual shift from coal to gas in power generation will be an important policy to reduce emissions. Co-firing of hydrogen and ammonia with gas and coal power plants is another important policy to move towards carbon neutrality together with maximising the share of variable renewable energy and minimising the share of electric storage. Besides, switching to cleaner fuels such as gas, ammonia, and hydrogen, and to clean technologies, an application of CCUS will be the most appropriate clean energy technologies for the Asian region to achieve net zero emissions. Current challenge to apply CCUS technology is due to geopolitical factors that affect international fossil fuel market. The significant increase of fossil fuels&rsquo; price will lead to an additional investment on fossil fuel that means its consumption and CO2 emissions will also increase.
Looking at the Asian region, Indonesia prepared a draft CCS/CCUS regulation, which is currently awaiting approval by the president. Moreover, PETRONAS is ready to start CCS projects with a Japanese company. Various activities have been organised by the Asia CCUS Network over the past year &ndash; knowledge sharing, research studies, and capacity building trainings.
The aim of the Second Asia CCUS Network Forum is to report the ACN&rsquo;s activities in 2021&ndash;2202 and the workplan of ACN&rsquo;s activities/milestones for 2022&ndash;2023, after the ministerial remarks, and the Second Forum will hold panel discussions to review the current CCUS situation and policies in the East Asia Summit (EAS) region concerning issues and challenges of CCUS deployment in the region. The Second Forum invites the CCS+ Initiative to introduce its activities regarding the calculation of carbon credit for CCS businesses
The Asia CCUS Network Forum is co-hosted by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) as Secretariat of Asia CCUS Network (ACN) and Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan.
Event Details

Time: 09:00 AM - 12:00 PM (Japan/JST)
Venue: Tokyo, Japan | Hybrid Forum

Panel Session: &lsquo;CCS Policies in EAS Countries&rsquo; &ndash; Issues and Challenges on CO2 Deployment and CO2 Value Chain
Moderator:

Mr Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor on Energy Affairs, ERIA

Panellists:

Ms Ayaka Jones, International Technical Advisor, Strategic Engagement, Office of Clean Coal and Carbon Manage, Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, Department of Energy (DOE), United States
Mr Norihiro Saeki, Director of CCUS Policy, Agency of Natural Resources and Energy, METI, Japan
&nbsp;Ms Jocelyn Taylor, Manager, International CCUS Policy, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources (DISER), Australia
Dr. Ir. Muhammad Wafid A.N, M.Sc., Senior Advisor for Environment and Spatial Planning, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Indonesia
Mr Zaharin Zulkifli, Deputy Director, Energy Data and Research Unit, Strategic Planning and Communication Department, Energy Commission of Malaysia
Mr Jesus Tamang, Director, Energy Policy and Planning Bureau, Department of Energy, Philippines

Followed by Questions and Answers 




11:55 AM &ndash; 12:00 PM


Closing Remarks

Mr Yuki Sadamitsu, Director General, Natural Resources and Fuel Department, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE), Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), Japan


Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, ERIA

sliateD tnevE ymonocE nobraC ralucriC labolG eht gnicnavdA 02T ymonocE nobraC ralucriC labolG eht gnicnavdA 02T";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-29 14:59:53";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-29 14:59:53";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:26:"abigail.balthazar@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:67;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6980";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:70:"g20-and-ai-connecting-the-dotted-lines-between-technology-and-humanity";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:71:"G20 and AI: Connecting the dotted lines between technology and humanity";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-04";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:13590:"<p>The digital society must be built on trust among all stakeholders including governments, civil society, international organizations, academics and businesses through sharing common values and principles including equality, justice, transparency and accountability taking into account the global economy and interoperability. G20 encompasses world&rsquo;s most powerful political and economic powers and an ideal platform to deliberate, discuss, and debate key issues of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the newly emerging technologies. Clearer and transparent concepts on AI systems would form the foundation for its development and implementation by addressing some of the growing concerns related to its safety and security as well as governance and ethics. The proposed international conference on &ldquo;G20 and AI: Connecting the dotted lines between technology and humanity&rdquo;, to be held on side lines of meeting of the G20 digital ministers from September 1-2, 2022 in Bali, Indonesia would be an excellent opportunity to support policies and initiatives undertaken by the G20 leadership under the Indonesian Presidency under Track 1.5 and Track 2.0 diplomacy.</p><h4>Session I: G20 and AI - Exploring a new horizon of opportunities and possibilities</h4><p>To build a better future, the G20 needs to raise the level of ambition and digital co-operation. This is particularly important for new technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI), quantum computing, blockchain, Internet of Things, among others. The responsible development and use of AI can be a driving force to help advance SDGs and to realize a sustainable and inclusive society while mitigating risks to wider societal values of equity, access, and fairness. Benefits brought by responsible use of AI can improve the work environment and quality of life, creating potential for realizing a human-centred future society with opportunities for everyone. The session will focus on adopting a multi-stakeholder approach towards AI adoption by supporting standards that help transition to an increasingly digital society. The successful incorporation of AI requires public administrations to redefine strategies based on emerging technologies and to develop a functional governance structure. It will exchange views on how G20 can help achieve an inclusive, sustainable, and innovative society through digitalization. The importance of international cooperation for harnessing full potential of emerging technologies like AI will also be discussed which includes enhanced research and development as well as policy formulation for the global citizenry.</p><h4>Session II: AI and digital ecosystem - A transformative experience in the making</h4><p>Digitalization is expected to continue creating benefits for economies and societies as a whole. The benefits brought by increased productivity through the use of emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), fifth-generation mobile telecommunication technologies (5G), the Internet of Things (IoT), Distributed Ledger Technologies (e.g. block chain) will empower the G20 nations by creating new opportunities and generating new services and employment, all of which can lead to greater well-being and further inclusiveness for both society and individuals. G20 is committed to promoting policies to share benefits from digitalization of economies and societies. This session would facilitate discussion on how the G20 can design and implement policies to maximize benefits and minimize risks from development of the digital ecosystem and how to overcome the resulting challenges. The key focus would be how to support development of a digital ecosystem that supports transition to novel way of thinking and working unleashed by AI. As human civilization leaps into a new frontier of technology enabled lifestyle and living, the challenge is to make the transformative experience rewarding and accessible to all.</p><h4>Session III: AI governance and ethics - The role of the G20 community</h4><p>Issues related to privacy and security in the digital economy are central concerns to the domain of public policy as citizens embrace introduction of big data collection related to artificial intelligence (AI). Citizens seek assurance that AI and automation will be introduced in a manner that respects human integrity and functions within a framework of accountability. While delivering productivity, key issues like safety and privacy need to be adequately addressed. The G20 is committed to promoting a free, open and secure internet that encourages the digital industry to work with stakeholders in fighting misuse of the internet and social media and also safeguarding against violent extremism and addressing content that incites terrorist acts. Against this background, this session would emphasize on recommendations and principles that G20 leaders could formulate in developing an accountability framework. The session would facilitate discussion on exploring potentials of digitalization and addressing concerns that it brings along, including adoption of international standardization on AI led by the G20.</p><h4>Session IV: AI and humans - Maximizing benefits and minimizing risks</h4><p>For G20, AI acts as a governable and interoperable technology that aims to eradicate or minimize inequalities. Like other emerging technologies, AI presents societal challenges, including transitions in the labour market and addressing issues related to privacy, security, ethics, and digital divides. In pursuing human-centred AI, G20 recognizes the importance of promoting protection of privacy and personal data. It also recognizes the need to promote AI capacity building and skills development. This session will explore how some of the international bodies that could serve as focal points to ensure a common framework to regulate the digital environment. As the human-machine interface enters a new phase, this session will look into how to navigate the delicate balance where human ingenuity is complemented and not upstaged by the machine driven efficiency</p><h2>Event Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Sunday, 4 September 2022</li><li>Time: 9:00 AM - 05:05 PM (Bali Time/GMT+8)</li><li>Venue:&nbsp;Hilton Hotel, Nusa Dua, Bali</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="height: 296px; G20 encompasses world&rsquo;s most powerful political and economic powers and an ideal platform to deliberate, discuss, and debate key issues of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the newly emerging technologies. Clearer and transparent concepts on AI systems would form the foundation for its development and implementation by addressing some of the growing concerns related to its safety and security as well as governance and ethics. The proposed international conference on &ldquo;G20 and AI: Connecting the dotted lines between technology and humanity&rdquo;, to be held on side lines of meeting of the G20 digital ministers from September 1-2, 2022 in Bali, Indonesia would be an excellent opportunity to support policies and initiatives undertaken by the G20 leadership under the Indonesian Presidency under Track 1.5 and Track 2.0 diplomacy.
Session I: G20 and AI - Exploring a new horizon of opportunities and possibilities
To build a better future, the G20 needs to raise the level of ambition and digital co-operation. This is particularly important for new technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI), quantum computing, blockchain, Internet of Things, among others. The responsible development and use of AI can be a driving force to help advance SDGs and to realize a sustainable and inclusive society while mitigating risks to wider societal values of equity, access, and fairness. Benefits brought by responsible use of AI can improve the work environment and quality of life, creating potential for realizing a human-centred future society with opportunities for everyone. The session will focus on adopting a multi-stakeholder approach towards AI adoption by supporting standards that help transition to an increasingly digital society. The successful incorporation of AI requires public administrations to redefine strategies based on emerging technologies and to develop a functional governance structure. It will exchange views on how G20 can help achieve an inclusive, sustainable, and innovative society through digitalization. The importance of international cooperation for harnessing full potential of emerging technologies like AI will also be discussed which includes enhanced research and development as well as policy formulation for the global citizenry.
Session II: AI and digital ecosystem - A transformative experience in the making
Digitalization is expected to continue creating benefits for economies and societies as a whole. The benefits brought by increased productivity through the use of emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), fifth-generation mobile telecommunication technologies (5G), the Internet of Things (IoT), Distributed Ledger Technologies (e.g. block chain) will empower the G20 nations by creating new opportunities and generating new services and employment, all of which can lead to greater well-being and further inclusiveness for both society and individuals. G20 is committed to promoting policies to share benefits from digitalization of economies and societies. This session would facilitate discussion on how the G20 can design and implement policies to maximize benefits and minimize risks from development of the digital ecosystem and how to overcome the resulting challenges. The key focus would be how to support development of a digital ecosystem that supports transition to novel way of thinking and working unleashed by AI. As human civilization leaps into a new frontier of technology enabled lifestyle and living, the challenge is to make the transformative experience rewarding and accessible to all.
Session III: AI governance and ethics - The role of the G20 community
Issues related to privacy and security in the digital economy are central concerns to the domain of public policy as citizens embrace introduction of big data collection related to artificial intelligence (AI). Citizens seek assurance that AI and automation will be introduced in a manner that respects human integrity and functions within a framework of accountability. While delivering productivity, key issues like safety and privacy need to be adequately addressed. The G20 is committed to promoting a free, open and secure internet that encourages the digital industry to work with stakeholders in fighting misuse of the internet and social media and also safeguarding against violent extremism and addressing content that incites terrorist acts. Against this background, this session would emphasize on recommendations and principles that G20 leaders could formulate in developing an accountability framework. The session would facilitate discussion on exploring potentials of digitalization and addressing concerns that it brings along, including adoption of international standardization on AI led by the G20.
Session IV: AI and humans - Maximizing benefits and minimizing risks
For G20, AI acts as a governable and interoperable technology that aims to eradicate or minimize inequalities. Like other emerging technologies, AI presents societal challenges, including transitions in the labour market and addressing issues related to privacy, security, ethics, and digital divides. In pursuing human-centred AI, G20 recognizes the importance of promoting protection of privacy and personal data. It also recognizes the need to promote AI capacity building and skills development. This session will explore how some of the international bodies that could serve as focal points to ensure a common framework to regulate the digital environment. As the human-machine interface enters a new phase, this session will look into how to navigate the delicate balance where human ingenuity is complemented and not upstaged by the machine driven efficiency

ycneiciffe nevird enihcam eht yb degatspu ton dna detnemelpmoc si ytiunegni namuh erehw ecnalab etaciled eht etagivan ot woh otni kool lliw noisses siht ,esahp wen a sretne ecafretni enihcam-namuh eht sA .tnemnorivne latigid eht etaluger ot krowemarf nommoc a erusne ot stniop lacof sa evres dluoc taht seidob lanoitanretni eht fo emos woh erolpxe lliw noisses sihT .tnempoleved slliks dna gnidliub yticapac IA etomorp ot deen eht sezingocer osla tI .atad lanosrep dna ycavirp fo noitcetorp gnitomorp fo ecnatropmi eht sezingocer 02G ,IA dertnec-namuh gniusrup nI .sedivid latigid dna ,scihte ,ytiruces ,ycavirp ot detaler seussi gnisserdda dna tekram ruobal eht ni snoitisnart gnidulcni ,segnellahc lateicos stneserp IA ,seigolonhcet gnigreme rehto ekiL .seitilauqeni eziminim ro etacidare ot smia taht ygolonhcet elbareporetni dna elbanrevog a sa stca IA ,02G roF
sksir gniziminim dna stifeneb gnizimixaM - snamuh dna IA :VI noisseS
.02G eht yb del IA no noitazidradnats lanoitanretni fo noitpoda gnidulcni ,gnola sgnirb ti taht snrecnoc gnisserdda dna noitazilatigid fo slaitnetop gnirolpxe no noissucsid etatilicaf dluow noisses ehT .krowemarf ytilibatnuocca na gnipoleved ni etalumrof dluoc sredael 02G taht selpicnirp dna snoitadnemmocer no ezisahpme dluow noisses siht ,dnuorgkcab siht tsniagA .stca tsirorret seticni taht tnetnoc gnisserdda dna msimertxe tneloiv tsniaga gnidraugefas osla dna aidem laicos dna tenretni eht fo esusim gnithgif ni sredlohekats htiw krow ot yrtsudni latigid eht segaruocne taht tenretni eruces dna nepo ,eerf a gnitomorp ot dettimmoc si 02G ehT .desserdda yletauqeda eb ot deen ycavirp dna ytefas ekil seussi yek ,ytivitcudorp gnireviled elihW .ytilibatnuocca fo krowemarf a nihtiw snoitcnuf dna ytirgetni namuh stcepser taht rennam a ni decudortni eb lliw noitamotua dna IA taht ecnarussa kees snezitiC .)IA( ecnegilletni laicifitra ot detaler noitcelloc atad gib fo noitcudortni ecarbme snezitic sa ycilop cilbup fo niamod eht ot snrecnoc lartnec era ymonoce latigid eht ni ytiruces dna ycavirp ot detaler seussI
ytinummoc 02G eht fo elor ehT - scihte dna ecnanrevog IA :III noisseS

02G";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-29 12:41:20";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-29 14:46:00";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:26:"abigail.balthazar@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:68;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6972";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:51:"u20---g20-urban-infrastructure-for-circular-economy";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:51:"U20 / G20 Urban Infrastructure for Circular Economy";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-08-30";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:6818:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/V3%20poster%20session%20U20%2030%2008-1.png" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p>Under the chairmanship of Jakarta in the Urban 20, cities have called upon the G20 Leaders to respond to the issues of economic and social recovery for all, ensuring that post-pandemic global recovery is inclusive and equitable, while supporting decent livelihoods for all. In that perspective, the provision of quality and sustainable infrastructure is key to prepare for future shocks, while addressing pressing environment and energy transition needs. Cities are facing many priorities, form the provision of affordable housing to fostering an equal access to sustainable mobility and the promotion of urban regeneration. A new approach of urban metabolism is another immediate priority to address a systemic overflow of waste impacting all ecosystems and livelihoods and ensure the provision of water and energy to all while contributing to curb down C02 emissions. The delivery of sustainable urbanization is therefore both a local and a global issue that require a new approach of multilevel governance. Echoing the main pillars of the G20 presidency of Indonesia that are 1) Global health architecture, 2) Digital transformation, and 3) Sustainable energy transition, the infrastructure taskforce of the group of think-tanks of the G20 has proposed to establish a global investment platform for sustainable urban development projects.<a href="#_ftn1" name="_ftnref1">[1]</a> The Urban 20 summit session <em>Urban Infrastructure for Circular Economy and a Just Transition</em> will explore in particular the challenges and opportunities linked with urban infrastructure, especially related to waste, water and energy.</p><p>The Urban 20 Summit session <em>Urban Infrastructure for Circular Economy and a Just Transition</em> is organized jointly with the Think-tank 20 Indonesia (T20), the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the Global Solutions Initiative (GSI).</p><h2>Objectives</h2><p>The interactive and hybrid Urban 20 session <em>Urban Infrastructure for Circular Economy and a Just Transition</em> will feature world-class experts and practitioners from public and private spheres, government, investment, research and industry. It is a dialogue between experts and utilities, crossing the lines between local and global issues, project investment and policy and regulatory issues.</p><p>The session aims at building and sharing recommendations at U20 level and to highlight new directions to overcome the systemic finance gaps for sustainable infrastructure, ahead of the COP27 summit of sustainable urban development ministers and of the assessment of the SDG11 in 2023.</p><p>The session follows the joint Statement of the T20/B20/D20 LTIC on sustainable and quality infrastructure issued at the G20 Finance Ministers&rsquo; meeting Investors Dialogue in Bali in July 2022. It also echoes the T7 proposal of a G20/G7 infrastructure club and pact on sustainable urbanization, alongside the creation of the Urban 7 Alliance.<a href="#_ftn1" name="_ftnref1">[1]</a></p><p>In the round of G20 presidencies of Indonesia, India, Brazil, and to be followed by South Africa, the conclusions of the session will contribute to nurture a joint approach by the U20 and T20 to support the establishment of a global investment platform for sustainable urban development projects and policies, to be developed jointly by voluntary engagement groups, and G20 ministerial working groups.</p><h2>Event Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Tuesday, 30 August 2022</li><li>Time: 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM (WIB/GMT+7)</li><li>Venue: Fairmont Hotel, Jakarta</li><li>Hybrid&nbsp;Session, link to connect online TBA</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="height: 255px; width: 637.448px;"><tr><td style="width: 152px;">9:00 AM - 9:05 AM</td><td style="width: 469.448px;"><p><strong>Opening Session</strong></p><p>Session MC</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 152px;">9:05 AM - 9:15 AM</td><td style="width: 469.448px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Danang PARIKESIT</strong>,&nbsp;Head, Indonesia tollroad regulatory agency (BPJT) and lead co-chair, T20 Infrastructure investment and financing taskforce and lead co-chair T20 TF8 infrastructure investment and financing</li><li><strong>Benni AGUSCANDRA</strong>,&nbsp;Head of department of investment, Jakarta Capital City Government</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 152px;">9:15 AM - 9:45 AM</td><td style="width: 469.448px;"><p><strong>Keynote</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Caroline CHAL</strong>,&nbsp;Director, Institutional and external relations, Syctom (the greater Paris metropolitan waste management)</li><li><strong>Anbumozhi VENKATACHALAM</strong>,&nbsp;Director of Research Strategy and Innovations at ERIA: Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 152px;">9:45 AM - 11:15 AM</td><td style="width: 469.448px;"><p><strong>Panel Discussion</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Kuki SOEJACHMOEN</strong>,&nbsp;Co-Founder &amp; Executive Director, Indonesia Research Institute for Decarbonization (IRID), and lead co-chair, T20 TF3 Governing Climate Target, Energy Transition and Environmental Protection</li><li><strong>Joakim GIACOMONI</strong>,&nbsp;Member of the board, Siaap (the greater Paris metropolitan waste water public company), Paris, France</li><li><strong>Hitesh VAIDYA</strong>,&nbsp;Director, National Institute for urban Affairs (NIUA), New Dehli, India</li><li><strong>Asep KUSWANTO</strong>,&nbsp;Head of Environment Agency, Jakarta Capital City Government&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Widi AMANASTO</strong>,&nbsp;CEO, PT Jakarta Propertindo (Perseroda)&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Caroline CHAL</strong>,&nbsp;Director, Institutional and external relations, Syctom (the greater Paris metropolitan waste management)</li><li><strong>Yamunna RAO</strong>,&nbsp;Program coordinator, Circular Economy Solutions Dialogues, Global Solutions Initiative (GSI)&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Asri INDIYANI</strong>,&nbsp;Director Of Technical Operations, Perumda PAL Jaya (waste water)&nbsp;</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 152px;">11:15 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td style="width: 469.448px;"><p><strong>Q&amp;A Session</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 152px;">11:30 AM - 11:45 AM</td><td style="width: 469.448px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Peter KURZ </strong>(TBC),<strong>&nbsp;</strong>President, Global Parliament of Mayors and Mayor of Mannheim, co-founder of the Urban 7 Alliance</li></ul><p>Moderator:</p><ul><li><strong>Nicolas J.A. Buchoud</strong>,&nbsp;Fellow, Global Solutions Initiative and president, Grand Paris Alliance for Metropolitan Development</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1"></a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:47:"G20,Urban 20,Urban Development,circular economy";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:31:"Fairmont Jakarta | Hybrid Event";s:5:"major";s:27:"Ms Abigail Gracia Balthazar";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-08-30";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:11605:"U20 / G20 Urban Infrastructure for Circular Economy U20 / G20 Urban Infrastructure for Circular Economy Under the chairmanship of Jakarta in the Urban 20, cities have called upon the G20 Leaders to respond to the issues of economic and social recovery for all, ensuring that post-pandemic global recovery is inclusive and equitable, while supporting decent livelihoods for all. In that perspective, the provision of quality and sustainable infrastructure is key to prepare for future shocks, while addressing pressing environment and energy transition needs. Cities are facing many priorities, form the provision of affordable housing to fostering an equal access to sustainable mobility and the promotion of urban regeneration. A new approach of urban metabolism is another immediate priority to address a systemic overflow of waste impacting all ecosystems and livelihoods and ensure the provision of water and energy to all while contributing to curb down C02 emissions. The delivery of sustainable urbanization is therefore both a local and a global issue that require a new approach of multilevel governance. Echoing the main pillars of the G20 presidency of Indonesia that are 1) Global health architecture, 2) Digital transformation, and 3) Sustainable energy transition, the infrastructure taskforce of the group of think-tanks of the G20 has proposed to establish a global investment platform for sustainable urban development projects.[1] The Urban 20 summit session Urban Infrastructure for Circular Economy and a Just Transition will explore in particular the challenges and opportunities linked with urban infrastructure, especially related to waste, water and energy.
The Urban 20 Summit session Urban Infrastructure for Circular Economy and a Just Transition is organized jointly with the Think-tank 20 Indonesia (T20), the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the Global Solutions Initiative (GSI).
Objectives
The interactive and hybrid Urban 20 session Urban Infrastructure for Circular Economy and a Just Transition will feature world-class experts and practitioners from public and private spheres, government, investment, research and industry. It is a dialogue between experts and utilities, crossing the lines between local and global issues, project investment and policy and regulatory issues.
The session aims at building and sharing recommendations at U20 level and to highlight new directions to overcome the systemic finance gaps for sustainable infrastructure, ahead of the COP27 summit of sustainable urban development ministers and of the assessment of the SDG11 in 2023.
The session follows the joint Statement of the T20/B20/D20 LTIC on sustainable and quality infrastructure issued at the G20 Finance Ministers&rsquo; meeting Investors Dialogue in Bali in July 2022. It also echoes the T7 proposal of a G20/G7 infrastructure club and pact on sustainable urbanization, alongside the creation of the Urban 7 Alliance.[1]
In the round of G20 presidencies of Indonesia, India, Brazil, and to be followed by South Africa, the conclusions of the session will contribute to nurture a joint approach by the U20 and T20 to support the establishment of a global investment platform for sustainable urban development projects and policies, to be developed jointly by voluntary engagement groups, and G20 ministerial working groups.
Event Schedule

Date: Tuesday, 30 August 2022
Time: 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM (WIB/GMT+7)
Venue: Fairmont Hotel, Jakarta
Hybrid&nbsp;Session, link to connect online TBA

9:15 AM - 9:45 AM

Keynote

Caroline CHAL,&nbsp;Director, Institutional and external relations, Syctom (the greater Paris metropolitan waste management)

9:45 AM - 11:15 AM

Panel Discussion

Joakim GIACOMONI,&nbsp;Member of the board, Siaap (the greater Paris metropolitan waste water public company), Paris, France
Hitesh VAIDYA,&nbsp;Director, National Institute for urban Affairs (NIUA), New Dehli, India

02U";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-26 09:44:15";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-26 13:56:11";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:26:"abigail.balthazar@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:69;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6971";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:73:"circular-economy-for-a-stronger-recovery-a-just-transition-agenda-for-g20";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:75:"Circular Economy for a Stronger Recovery:  A Just Transition Agenda for G20";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-03";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:6500:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_September_Circular-Economy-for-a-Stronger-Recovery_Photo-Flyer_1.jpg" alt="" width="812" height="406" /></p><p>Economic disruptions during the pandemic have brought to light the urgency of the transition to more sustainable consumption and production. The circular economy comes from the idea that resources, when adequately treated and regenerated, can become a source of sustainable economic growth, aided by eco-innovations while preserving the natural capital. Compared to a linear economy, a circular economy encourages greater collaboration between economic actors and can become a powerful force for climate change mitigation, biodiversity conservation, and reducing local pollution impacts. This is critical to identify opportunities to shift swiftly toward a more just, equal, and circular society, instead of going back to linear, wasteful, and inherently fragile supply chains.</p><p>Innovative and context-sensitive technology, the transfer, uptake, and scaling of the use of technology together with adequate public financial mechanisms and mobilizing private capital are fundamental to ensuring a transformative, inclusive, and sustainable recovery that unleashes the transition to circular economies. The technological solutions for and reorienting financial institutions to embed circularity can change the way we produce, consume, and address the issues ranging from carbon emissions, resource scarcity, and the use of hazardous chemicals and fossil fuels, while increasing resilience. Also, international cooperation can facilitate the successful transfer and implementation of established technology keeping materials in the loop.</p><p>This high-level event brings together emerging ideas, practices, and policy pathways to accelerate the shift away from a take-make-waste model of resource use and pollution to a circular green recovery, and the practical steps G20 economies could consider embedding circularity into their economies. The insights from the keynotes and panel discussion can guide policymakers to address the opportunities and barriers, providing recommendations for a common framework to accelerate just transition, with examples of measures that have proven effective around the world.</p><p>Organized by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and in cooperation with Deutsche Gesellschaft f&uuml;r Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ)</p><h2><span style="font-size: 17px;">Event Details</span></h2><ul><li>Date: Saturday, 3 September 2022</li><li>Time: 3:00PM - 6:00PM (Bali Time/GMT+8)</li><li>Venue: Hilton Hotel Bali, in Graha Paruman 4 5 room meeting</li></ul><h2><span style="font-size: 17px;">Agenda</span></h2><table style="height: 291px; width: 605.706px;"><tr><td style="width: 138px;">2:30 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Registration</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">3:00 PM - 3:05 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Welcoming Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><span style="font-size: 14px;"><strong>Koji Hachiyama</strong>,&nbsp;Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</span></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">3:05 PM - 3:45 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Key Note Speeches</strong></p><p>Green and Circular Ideas for a Stronger Economic Recovery</p><ul><li><strong>Izabella Teixeira</strong>, Co-Chair International Resource Panel, Former Minister of Environment, Brazil)</li></ul><p>Bending the Supply Chains towards Net Zero Targets</p><ul><li><strong>Venkatachalam Anbumozhi</strong>, Director of Research Strategy and Innovation, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">3:45 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Panel Session:</strong> Innovative Technologies and Financial Innovations or a Circular Low-Carbon Economy: Opportunities for G20</p><p>Moderator:</p><p><strong>Nicholas Buchoud</strong>, Fellow, Global Solutions Initiative, Berlin, Germany</p><p>Panelists:</p><ul><li><strong>Konstantinos Karampourniotis</strong>, Circular Economy Solutions Advocate, European Union</li><li><strong>Noura Monsurri</strong>, Senior Fellow, King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center</li><li><strong>Anouj Mehta</strong>, Director &nbsp;Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank</li><li><strong>Caroline Chal</strong>, Director of institutional relations, Syctom, Paris, France&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Tadahiro KANEKO</strong>,&nbsp; Head of Sustainability, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation</li><li><strong>Kari Herlevi</strong>, Project Director, Circular Economy, Finnish Innovation Fund, Sitra.</li></ul><p><em>Followed by&nbsp;<strong>Q &amp; A session</strong></em></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">5:30 PM - 5:50 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Tripartite G20 Insights:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Sigit Relianto</strong>, Co-Chair of Environmental Deputies Meeting G20 Indonesia</li><li><strong>Antonio Villafranca</strong>, Director of Research, Italian Institute for International Political Studies (ISPI)</li><li><strong>Sachin Chaturvedi</strong>, Director General, Research and Information System for Developing Countries (RIS)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">&nbsp;5:50 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks:</strong></p><p><strong>Khule Holger</strong>, Advisor. Strategic Knowledge Partnerships, GIZ</p></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://bit.ly/CESR-G20" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ONLINE REGISTRATION</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://bit.ly/CESR-G20-IP" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IN-PERSON REGISTRATION (limited seats)</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:15:"Bali, Indonesia";s:5:"major";s:16:"Ms Dian Lutfiana";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-03";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-03";s:8:"keywords";s:10035:"Circular Economy for a Stronger Recovery:  A Just Transition Agenda for G20 Circular Economy for a Stronger Recovery:  A Just Transition Agenda for G20 Economic disruptions during the pandemic have brought to light the urgency of the transition to more sustainable consumption and production. The circular economy comes from the idea that resources, when adequately treated and regenerated, can become a source of sustainable economic growth, aided by eco-innovations while preserving the natural capital. Compared to a linear economy, a circular economy encourages greater collaboration between economic actors and can become a powerful force for climate change mitigation, biodiversity conservation, and reducing local pollution impacts. This is critical to identify opportunities to shift swiftly toward a more just, equal, and circular society, instead of going back to linear, wasteful, and inherently fragile supply chains.
Innovative and context-sensitive technology, the transfer, uptake, and scaling of the use of technology together with adequate public financial mechanisms and mobilizing private capital are fundamental to ensuring a transformative, inclusive, and sustainable recovery that unleashes the transition to circular economies. The technological solutions for and reorienting financial institutions to embed circularity can change the way we produce, consume, and address the issues ranging from carbon emissions, resource scarcity, and the use of hazardous chemicals and fossil fuels, while increasing resilience. Also, international cooperation can facilitate the successful transfer and implementation of established technology keeping materials in the loop.
This high-level event brings together emerging ideas, practices, and policy pathways to accelerate the shift away from a take-make-waste model of resource use and pollution to a circular green recovery, and the practical steps G20 economies could consider embedding circularity into their economies. The insights from the keynotes and panel discussion can guide policymakers to address the opportunities and barriers, providing recommendations for a common framework to accelerate just transition, with examples of measures that have proven effective around the world.
Organized by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and in cooperation with Deutsche Gesellschaft f&uuml;r Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ)
Event Details

Date: Saturday, 3 September 2022
Time: 3:00PM - 6:00PM (Bali Time/GMT+8)
Venue: Hilton Hotel Bali, in Graha Paruman 4 5 room meeting

Agenda



2:30 PM - 3:00 PM

Registration



3:00 PM - 3:05 PM

Welcoming Remarks

Koji Hachiyama,&nbsp;Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)




3:05 PM - 3:10 PM

Opening Remarks

Moekti Handajani Soejachmoen, Lead Co-Chair of the T20-Task Force 3: Governing Climate Target, Energy Transition and environmental Protection




3:10 PM - 3:15 PM

Special Address

Anies Baswedan, Governor of Jakarta (TBC)




3:15 PM - 3:45 PM

Key Note Speeches
Green and Circular Ideas for a Stronger Economic Recovery

Izabella Teixeira, Co-Chair International Resource Panel, Former Minister of Environment, Brazil)

Bending the Supply Chains towards Net Zero Targets

Venkatachalam Anbumozhi, Director of Research Strategy and Innovation, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)




3:45 PM - 5:30 PM

Panel Session: Innovative Technologies and Financial Innovations or a Circular Low-Carbon Economy: Opportunities for G20
Moderator:
Nicholas Buchoud, Fellow, Global Solutions Initiative, Berlin, Germany
Panelists:

Konstantinos Karampourniotis, Circular Economy Solutions Advocate, European Union
Noura Monsurri, Senior Fellow, King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center
Anouj Mehta, Director &nbsp;Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank
Caroline Chal, Director of institutional relations, Syctom, Paris, France&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Tadahiro KANEKO,&nbsp; Head of Sustainability, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation
Kari Herlevi, Project Director, Circular Economy, Finnish Innovation Fund, Sitra.

Followed by&nbsp;Q &amp; A session



5:30 PM - 5:50 PM

Tripartite G20 Insights:

Sigit Relianto, Co-Chair of Environmental Deputies Meeting G20 Indonesia
Antonio Villafranca, Director of Research, Italian Institute for International Political Studies (ISPI)
Sachin Chaturvedi, Director General, Research and Information System for Developing Countries (RIS)




&nbsp;5:50 PM - 6:00 PM

Closing Remarks:
Khule Holger, Advisor. Strategic Knowledge Partnerships, GIZ

.pool eht ni slairetam gnipeek ygolonhcet dehsilbatse fo noitatnemelpmi dna refsnart lufsseccus eht etatilicaf nac noitarepooc lanoitanretni ,oslA .ecneiliser gnisaercni elihw ,sleuf lissof dna slacimehc suodrazah fo esu eht dna ,yticracs ecruoser ,snoissime nobrac morf gnignar seussi eht sserdda dna ,emusnoc ,ecudorp ew yaw eht egnahc nac ytiralucric debme ot snoitutitsni laicnanif gnitneiroer dna rof snoitulos lacigolonhcet ehT .seimonoce ralucric ot noitisnart eht sehsaelnu taht yrevocer elbaniatsus dna ,evisulcni ,evitamrofsnart a gnirusne ot latnemadnuf era latipac etavirp gnizilibom dna smsinahcem laicnanif cilbup etauqeda htiw rehtegot ygolonhcet fo esu eht fo gnilacs dna ,ekatpu ,refsnart eht ,ygolonhcet evitisnes-txetnoc dna evitavonnI

adnegA noitisnarT tsuJ A  :yrevoceR regnortS a rof ymonocE ralucriC 02G rof adnegA noitisnarT tsuJ A  :yrevoceR regnortS a rof ymonocE ralucriC";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-25 11:49:25";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-02 12:38:25";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:22:"dian.lutfiana@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:70;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6970";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:91:"the-fifth-east-asia-energy-forum-aseans-challenges-on-carbon-neutrality-and-energy-security";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:114:"The Fifth East Asia Energy Forum â€˜ASEANâ€™s Challenges on Carbon-Neutrality and Energy Securityâ€™";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-12";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:10696:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_September_5th_East-Asia-Energy-Forum.png" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Necessity of carbon neutrality was highlighted at COP26, and many developing countries announced their carbon neutral targets by 2050 with international supports, making carbon neutrality is the priority actions. The urgency of carbon neutral-pathways is key priority for both developed and developing countries. The COP 26 called for deep decarbonization before the turn of 21<sup>st</sup> century, limiting the global temperature rise to well below 2-degree Celsius, and preferably to 1.5 degree Celsius compared to pre-industrial level. Any delayed action could risk triggering impacts of climate change and so catastrophic our world will become unrecognizable. In this regard, the race to carbon neutrality will require climate ambitious actions including the introduction of suite of policy changes and the need to examining all the possibility of low carbon emissions technologies and the renewables. The COP26 has brought approaches of using multiple pathways to carbon-neutrality that could help countries with large dependency on fossil fuels to make a more meaning full of, &ldquo;just energy transition,&rdquo; to protect social well-beings through energy affordability and security, while at the same time, protecting the global warming simultaneously.</p><p>The Russia-Ukraine war has brought an imbalance of demand-supply of fossil fuel in the world. The immediate reduction of oil supply due to the collective efforts of Western-led sanctions on Russian, have made oil market becomes vulnerable; thus, it put pressure on global fossil fuel supply security, as fossil fuels will be needed at least for next decade. The oil market&rsquo;s response to the shock, is the increase of overall energy cost around the world as oil is a global commodity and traded globally. &nbsp;The implication of the supply shortage has a deep effect on energy security for countries around the world. These high energy costs could distract each country&rsquo;s efforts towards long-term decarbonization, with the short-term agenda dominated by domestic energy security in which they are largely dependent on fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and gas.</p><p>The world faces univalent challenges: Carbon neutral and supply security of fossil fuels. &nbsp;This means that human will need to reverse the course of our fossil fuel dependency in which we have rely on these fuels to modernize the human wellbeing and economic growth. This reliance and overuse of the fossil fuels have reached a critical limit where the continuous burning of fossil fuels have caused climate change and any delayed action could risk the future climate stability and so catastrophic our world.</p><p>Thus, the 5th&nbsp;East Asia Energy Forum gathers many big-minded people including key energy policymakers, public and private entities, financial institutions and research institutes working in the frontier of carbon-neutral pathways to share their thoughts, policy developments, and innovative technologies: renewables, suite of low carbon technologies.</p><p>This hybrid workshop is organised by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), Energy Research Institute Network (ERIN), and Ministry of Mines and Energy (MME) Cambodia collaboration with ASEAN Energy Business Forum (AEBF)</p><h2><span style="font-size: 17px;">Event Details</span></h2><ul><li>Date:&nbsp;Monday, 12 September 2022</li><li>Time:&nbsp;9:00AM - 4:00PM (UTC/GMT+7)</li></ul><h2><span style="font-size: 17px;">Agenda</span></h2><table style="width: 661.969px;"><tr><td style="width: 157px;"><p>8:30 AM &ndash; 9:00 AM</p></td><td style="width: 486.969px;"><p><strong>Registration </strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 157px;"><p>9:00 AM &ndash; 9:20 AM</p></td><td style="width: 486.969px;"><p><strong>Welcoming and Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>H.E.
