4:00 PM</p></td><td style="width: 486.969px;"><p><strong>Wrap-up and Closing Remark</strong></p><p><strong>Prof </strong><strong>Hidetoshi Nishimura</strong>, President of ERIA</p></td></tr></table><p>&nbsp;</p><h2>Relive the&nbsp;Event</h2><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to watch the sessions on YouTube" href="https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWClhwI4oDPaB-EzyNevBSlcEpL58kKH1" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Video Playlist on YouTube</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:20:"Phnom Penh, Cambodia";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-12";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-12";s:8:"keywords";s:16929:"The Fifth East Asia Energy Forum â€˜ASEANâ€™s Challenges on Carbon-Neutrality and Energy Securityâ€™ The Fifth East Asia Energy Forum â€˜ASEANâ€™s Challenges on Carbon-Neutrality and Energy Securityâ€™ Necessity of carbon neutrality was highlighted at COP26, and many developing countries announced their carbon neutral targets by 2050 with international supports, making carbon neutrality is the priority actions. The urgency of carbon neutral-pathways is key priority for both developed and developing countries. The COP 26 called for deep decarbonization before the turn of 21st century, limiting the global temperature rise to well below 2-degree Celsius, and preferably to 1.5 degree Celsius compared to pre-industrial level. Any delayed action could risk triggering impacts of climate change and so catastrophic our world will become unrecognizable. In this regard, the race to carbon neutrality will require climate ambitious actions including the introduction of suite of policy changes and the need to examining all the possibility of low carbon emissions technologies and the renewables. The COP26 has brought approaches of using multiple pathways to carbon-neutrality that could help countries with large dependency on fossil fuels to make a more meaning full of, &ldquo;just energy transition,&rdquo; to protect social well-beings through energy affordability and security, while at the same time, protecting the global warming simultaneously.
The Russia-Ukraine war has brought an imbalance of demand-supply of fossil fuel in the world. The immediate reduction of oil supply due to the collective efforts of Western-led sanctions on Russian, have made oil market becomes vulnerable; thus, it put pressure on global fossil fuel supply security, as fossil fuels will be needed at least for next decade. The oil market&rsquo;s response to the shock, is the increase of overall energy cost around the world as oil is a global commodity and traded globally. &nbsp;The implication of the supply shortage has a deep effect on energy security for countries around the world. These high energy costs could distract each country&rsquo;s efforts towards long-term decarbonization, with the short-term agenda dominated by domestic energy security in which they are largely dependent on fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and gas.
The world faces univalent challenges: Carbon neutral and supply security of fossil fuels. &nbsp;This means that human will need to reverse the course of our fossil fuel dependency in which we have rely on these fuels to modernize the human wellbeing and economic growth. This reliance and overuse of the fossil fuels have reached a critical limit where the continuous burning of fossil fuels have caused climate change and any delayed action could risk the future climate stability and so catastrophic our world.
Thus, the 5th&nbsp;East Asia Energy Forum gathers many big-minded people including key energy policymakers, public and private entities, financial institutions and research institutes working in the frontier of carbon-neutral pathways to share their thoughts, policy developments, and innovative technologies: renewables, suite of low carbon technologies.
This hybrid workshop is organised by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), Energy Research Institute Network (ERIN), and Ministry of Mines and Energy (MME) Cambodia collaboration with ASEAN Energy Business Forum (AEBF)
Event Details

Date:&nbsp;Monday, 12 September 2022
Time:&nbsp;9:00AM - 4:00PM (UTC/GMT+7)

Agenda




8:30 AM &ndash; 9:00 AM


Registration 




9:00 AM &ndash; 9:20 AM


Welcoming and Opening Remarks

H.E. Suy Sem, Minister of Mines and Energy, Cambodia (Live broadcast)
H.E. Dato Lim Jock Hoi, Secretary General of ASEAN (Live broadcast or pre-recorded video) (TBC)

MC:&nbsp;Ms&nbsp;Isabella Italia Gentajaya, ERIA




9:20 AM &ndash; 10:05 AM


Keynote Speeches (Pre-recorded videos) &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 

Honourable Pehin Datu Lailaraja Major General (Retired) Dato Paduka Seri Haji Awang Halbi bin Haji Mohd Yussof, Minister at the Prime Minister&rsquo;s Office, Brunei Darussalam&nbsp;(TBC)
H.E. Arifin Tasrif, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resource, Indonesia (live via zoom)
H.E. Nakatani Shinichi, State Minister of Economy, Trade, and Industry, Japan
H.E. Daovong Phonekeo, Minister of Ministry of Energy and Mines, Lao PDR (TBC)
E U Myo Myint Oo, Union Minister, Ministry of Energy, Myanmar
H.E. Raphael Perpetuo Mercado Lotilla, Secretary of Department of Energy, Philippines&nbsp;
H.E. Gan Kim Yong, Minister of Trade &amp; Industry, Singapore&nbsp;(TBC)
H.E. Supattanapong Punmeechaow, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Energy, The Kingdom of Thailand
H.E. Tráº§n Tuáº¥n Anh, Minister of Industry and Trade, Vietnam&nbsp;(TBC)
H.E. Brad Crabtree, Assistant Secretary for Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, Department of Energy, United States





10:05 AM &ndash; 10:20 AM


Scene-Setting Presentation: &ldquo;Opportunities and Challenges for Carbon-neural Pathways&rdquo;

Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)





10:20 AM &ndash; 10:30 AM


Coffee break&nbsp; 




10:30 AM &ndash; 11:30 AM
&nbsp;


Panel Session 1: Implication of Ukraine War to Regional Energy Situation
Moderator:
Mr Shigeru Kimura, Special Adviser to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA
Panelists:

Dr Nuki Agya Utama, Executive Director of ASEAN Centre for Energy (ACE)
Ms Toril Bosoni, Head of Oil Industry and Market Division, IEA: to share us mid. and long-term global oil market
Mr Hiroshi Hashimoto, Head of Gas Group, Institute of Energy Economics, Japan
Mr Yuichiro Torikata, Senior Energy Analytic Product Specialist, KPLER
Mr Matthew Boyle, Lead Analyst of Thermal Fuels, KPLER





11:30 AM &ndash; 12:30 PM


Panel Session 2: How to Secure Affordable Energy Transition Pathways?
Moderator:
Dr Yanfei Li, Research Fellow, ERIA
Panelists:

Dr Poonpat Leesombatpiboon, Executive Director of International Affairs Division, Ministry of Energy, Thailand
Dr Saleh Abdurrahman, Member of Committee for Downstream Oil and Gas Regulatory Body &ndash; Former Senior Advisor for Environment and Spatial Planning, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR), Indonesia
H.E. Victor Jona, Under Secretary of State, Ministry of Mines and Energy (MME), Cambodia





12:30 PM &ndash; 1:30 PM


Lunch break &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 




1:30 PM &ndash; 2:40 PM


Panel Session 3: Accelerating Energy Transitions: Electric Vehicles &amp; Battery Storage
Moderator:
Dr Alloysius Joko Purwanto, Energy Economist, ERIA
Panelists:

Mr Indra Chandra Setiawan, S.T., M.T, Project Deputy General Manager Toyota Daihatsu Engineering &amp; Manufacturing
Ms Minta Poowatanavong, Engineer, Professional Level, Division of Energy Efficiency Promotion, Department of Alternative Energy Development and Efficiency (DEDE), Ministry of Energy, Thailand
Mr Shiv Aggarwal, Sales &amp; BD Leader APAC - GE Renewable Energy





2:40 PM &ndash; 3:50 PM


Panel Session 4: How to Secure Investment for Carbon-Neutrality and Energy Security?
Moderator:&nbsp;
Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA
Panellists:

Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)
Ms Cecilia Tam, Team Leader, Clean Energy Finance and Investment Mobilisation, OECD
Mr Masayuki Fujiki, Managing Director, Head of Structured Finance, Solution Products Division, MUFG Bank, Ltd.
MrTakeshi Soda, Director for Petroleum and Natural Gas Division, Natural Resources and Fuel Department, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE) / Director for International Carbon Neutral Policy Office, Minister&rsquo;s Secretariat, Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan





3:50 PM &ndash; 4:00 PM


Wrap-up and Closing Remark
Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of ERIA

ytilartueN-nobraC no segnellahC s™€âNAESA˜€â muroF ygrenE aisA tsaE htfiF ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-25 10:53:48";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-11-11 15:26:24";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:18:"tri.manik@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:71;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6968";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:30:"g20-digital-innovation-network";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:30:"G20 Digital Innovation Network";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-02";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:2492:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/2022_September_Digital-Innovation-Network_800x450.jpg" alt="" width="678" height="531" /></p><p>G20 Digital Innovation Network (DIN) is a premier forum to share knowledge, encourage discussion and build partnerships among global innovation players. As the world faces global crises like pandemic, endemic, climate change and war conflict, collaboration and cooperation among countries and international ecosystem become imperative. It is crucial to foster the spirit of global collaboration, considering that securing future global economic growth and prosperities are in the G20 countries&rsquo; strategic role. Since G20 members represent more than 80% of the world&rsquo;s GDP, 75% of international trade, and 60% of the world&rsquo;s population, the local strength of the collaboration of these countries is indeed globally impactful.</p><p>Nowadays, seven out of the ten biggest companies in the world come from the technology sector. These startups bring technological innovations and tangible impact on the world economy and encourage collaboration between stakeholders and policies to make these solutions more accessible and scalable.</p><p>The G20 DIN was initiated by Italy in 2021 under the name G20 Digital Innovation League by selecting the ten best startups: ACT Blade, Biomicrogels Group, Dott, Ntechlab, Nalagenetics, Poka, Ruangguru, Sansure, Virtuo, and Zerynth. Since then, the name has changed to G20 Digital Innovation Network with this year&rsquo;s aim to find the 100 most promising startups in 5 priority sectors: Healthcare, Renewable Energy, Smart Society, Financial Inclusivity, and Supply Chain.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date:&nbsp;Friday, 2&nbsp;September - Sunday, 4 September&nbsp;2022 (Hybrid Event)</li></ul><p>This forum will offer a variety of event sessions, including&nbsp;startup pitches, keynote speeches, panel discussions, cultural events, 1-on-1 business meetings, and world-class networking sessions.</p><p>The essence of this forum is to build a network between the public and private sectors and creates a digital platform to ease the introduction, communication, and collaboration between startups, venture capitalists, corporations, and policymakers.</p><p>It is about time you get immersed into the global startup ecosystem network.</p><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://g20innovationnetwork.org/register/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:15:"Bali, Indonesia";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-02";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-04";s:8:"keywords";s:4685:"G20 Digital Innovation Network G20 Digital Innovation Network G20 Digital Innovation Network (DIN) is a premier forum to share knowledge, encourage discussion and build partnerships among global innovation players. As the world faces global crises like pandemic, endemic, climate change and war conflict, collaboration and cooperation among countries and international ecosystem become imperative. It is crucial to foster the spirit of global collaboration, considering that securing future global economic growth and prosperities are in the G20 countries&rsquo; strategic role. Since G20 members represent more than 80% of the world&rsquo;s GDP, 75% of international trade, and 60% of the world&rsquo;s population, the local strength of the collaboration of these countries is indeed globally impactful.
Nowadays, seven out of the ten biggest companies in the world come from the technology sector. These startups bring technological innovations and tangible impact on the world economy and encourage collaboration between stakeholders and policies to make these solutions more accessible and scalable.
The G20 DIN was initiated by Italy in 2021 under the name G20 Digital Innovation League by selecting the ten best startups: ACT Blade, Biomicrogels Group, Dott, Ntechlab, Nalagenetics, Poka, Ruangguru, Sansure, Virtuo, and Zerynth. Since then, the name has changed to G20 Digital Innovation Network with this year&rsquo;s aim to find the 100 most promising startups in 5 priority sectors: Healthcare, Renewable Energy, Smart Society, Financial Inclusivity, and Supply Chain.
Event Details

Date:&nbsp;Friday, 2&nbsp;September - Sunday, 4 September&nbsp;2022 (Hybrid Event)

This forum will offer a variety of event sessions, including&nbsp;startup pitches, keynote speeches, panel discussions, cultural events, 1-on-1 business meetings, and world-class networking sessions.
The essence of this forum is to build a network between the public and private sectors and creates a digital platform to ease the introduction, communication, and collaboration between startups, venture capitalists, corporations, and policymakers.
It is about time you get immersed into the global startup ecosystem network.

After working with more than 600 authors on policy briefs around three key themes this year aimed at delivering policy options that can be adopted by the G20 leaders on: global health architecture, digital transformation, and energy transition. The Summit will also serve as an interactive platform for peers to advance and share ideas on building a more prosperous, sustainable, and inclusive world.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date &amp; Time: Sunday, 5 September 2022&nbsp; - Tuesday, 6 September 2022&nbsp;</li><li>Hybrid event</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register for online participation" href="https://summit.t20indonesia.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Agenda&nbsp;</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register for online participation" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/t20-indonesia-summit-online-tickets-399876500377" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:15:"Bali, Indonesia";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Wuri Wulandari";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-05";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-06";s:8:"keywords";s:1873:"T20 Indonesia Summit 2022 T20 Indonesia Summit 2022 Held as the capstone event for T20 Indonesia, the T20 Summit 2022 will gather world-leading thinkers, policy makers, and experts to discuss the latest research-based policy recommendations and matters of global importance. After working with more than 600 authors on policy briefs around three key themes this year aimed at delivering policy options that can be adopted by the G20 leaders on: global health architecture, digital transformation, and energy transition. The Summit will also serve as an interactive platform for peers to advance and share ideas on building a more prosperous, sustainable, and inclusive world.
Event Details

Date &amp; Time: Sunday, 5 September 2022&nbsp; - Tuesday, 6 September 2022&nbsp;

.dlrow evisulcni dna ,elbaniatsus ,suorepsorp erom a gnidliub no saedi erahs dna ecnavda ot sreep rof mroftalp evitcaretni na sa evres osla lliw timmuS ehT .noitisnart ygrene dna ,noitamrofsnart latigid ,erutcetihcra htlaeh labolg :no sredael 02G eht yb detpoda eb nac taht snoitpo ycilop gnireviled ta demia raey siht semeht yek eerht dnuora sfeirb ycilop no srohtua 006 naht erom htiw gnikrow retfA .ecnatropmi labolg fo srettam dna snoitadnemmocer ycilop desab-hcraeser tsetal eht ssucsid ot strepxe dna ,srekam ycilop ,srekniht gnidael-dlrow rehtag lliw 2202 timmuS 02T eht ,aisenodnI 02T rof tneve enotspac eht sa dleH 2202 timmuS aisenodnI 02T 2202 timmuS aisenodnI 02T";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-19 10:26:08";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-05 06:54:58";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"wuri.wulandari@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:73;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6966";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:62:"regional-roundtable-cross-border-data-flows-in-south-east-asia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:63:"Regional Roundtable: Cross-border Data Flows in South-East Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-08-23";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:2865:"<p><span style="font-weight: 400;"><img src="/uploads/media/2022_Aug_Cross-border-Data-Flows_800x450.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Digitalization is now a key to enable economic growth amidst COVID-19. Cross-border data flows (CBDF) become more vital to support the growth of digital transformation across all sectors. In the region, mechanisms for encouraging cross-border data flows to stimulate innovation and economic growth still need to be promoted at the national and regional level. The commitment of the ASEAN countries towards a regional integration could be leveraged towards that purpose.&nbsp;</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">What efforts are being made on the national and regional level to drive cross-border data flow in the SEA region? What are the challenges and opportunities in the region in enabling cross-border data flow to drive a more integrated digital economy?&nbsp;Join us online to address these questions.&nbsp;</span></p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Tuesday, 23 August&nbsp; 2022</li><li>Time: 10.30 AM - 11:45 AM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 618px;"><tr><td style="width: 156.3px;"><p><strong>TIME (UTC+7)</strong></p></td><td style="width: 446.7px;"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 153.887px;"><p>10:30AM - 10:35AM</p></td><td style="width: 441.113px;"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Opening</span></p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 152.887px;"><p>10:35AM - 11:15AM</p></td><td style="width: 442.113px;"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Panel Discussion</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Panelists:</span></p><ul><li><strong>Chheang Vannarith</strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">, &nbsp;President of Asian Vision Institute, Cambodia</span></li><li><span style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>Imelda Tiongson</strong>, Trustee and Teaching Fellow of Institute of Corporate Directors, Philippines </span></li></ul><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Moderator:<strong>&nbsp;</strong>Pingkan Audrine, Researcher at the Center for Indonesian Policy Studies</span></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 152.887px;"><p>11:15AM - 11:40AM</p></td><td style="width: 442.113px;"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Q&amp;A Session with the audience</span></p><p>Moderator:&nbsp;Pingkan Audrine, Researcher at the Center for Indonesian Policy Studies</p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 152.575px;"><p>11:40AM - 11:45AM</p></td><td style="width: 443.425px;"><p>Closing</p></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZYqf-qoqDstHtYDwI0OyqqdqeGK_Y0F9Bf3" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:18:"Ms Debora Tambunan";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-08-23";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3543:"Regional Roundtable: Cross-border Data Flows in South-East Asia Regional Roundtable: Cross-border Data Flows in South-East Asia Digitalization is now a key to enable economic growth amidst COVID-19. Cross-border data flows (CBDF) become more vital to support the growth of digital transformation across all sectors. In the region, mechanisms for encouraging cross-border data flows to stimulate innovation and economic growth still need to be promoted at the national and regional level. The commitment of the ASEAN countries towards a regional integration could be leveraged towards that purpose.&nbsp;
What efforts are being made on the national and regional level to drive cross-border data flow in the SEA region? What are the challenges and opportunities in the region in enabling cross-border data flow to drive a more integrated digital economy?&nbsp;Join us online to address these questions.&nbsp;
Event Details

Date: Tuesday, 23 August&nbsp; 2022
Time: 10.30 AM - 11:45 AM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)

Job creation was already high on the global agenda before the advent of COVID-19 and resulting economic devastation, as was policy-making that can ideally help both workers and their employers.</p><p>The pace of technology adoption is expected to remain unabated and may accelerate in some areas. Skills gaps continue to be high as in demand skills across jobs change in the next five years. The number of jobs destroyed will be surpassed by the number of &lsquo;jobs of tomorrow&rsquo; created, Those are key findings from the report Future of Jobs from WEF in 2020.</p><p>This virtual conference will gather 15 Leaders from Asia and Europe (Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong-Kong, Singapore, Vietnam, Thailand, Pakistan, France, UK and Germany) sharing their expertise in the Future of Work, Entrepreneurship and Technology for Social Good.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 29 September&nbsp; 2022</li><li>Time: 2 PM - 6 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7) / 9 AM - 1 PM&nbsp; (CET Time)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 618px;"><tr><td style="width: 126.2px;"><p><strong>TIME (UTC+7)</strong></p></td><td style="width: 477.8px;"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>2:00PM - 2:45PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Session I : Enhancing Innovation in Rural Areas</strong></p><p>Opening&nbsp;Remarks:&nbsp;Anne Lochoff, Board member - Findexable Fintech Diversity Advisory Board (TBC)</p><p>Key Points:</p><ul><li>Innovation &amp; Entrepreneurship</strong></p><p>Opening Remarks: Fiorina Mugione, Regional Director at GDSI</p><p>Key Points:&nbsp;</p><ul><li>Economies become increasingly automated and machine driven</li><li>Impact of Covid-19</li><li>More flexible work opportunities</li></ul><p>Speakers:</p><ul><li>James Sancto, Co-Founder &amp; CEO at We Make Change (UK)</li><li>Mallory Loone, Founder Work Inspires (Malaysia)</li><li>Madhavi Shankar, Co-Founder &amp; CEO Space Basics (India)&nbsp;</li></ul><p>Moderator: Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Strategy and Partnership Director at Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>5:55PM - 6:00PM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p>Closing Remarks</p></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.runtheworld.today/app/c/thefutureofwork2022" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-29";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:8499:"ERIA-The Asian Network: The Future of Work in Asia ERIA-The Asian Network: The Future of Work in Asia The world of work is changing fast - and mapping out healthy new work models is necessary to channel that change into the creation of stronger labor markets and sufficient safeguards. Job creation was already high on the global agenda before the advent of COVID-19 and resulting economic devastation, as was policy-making that can ideally help both workers and their employers.
The pace of technology adoption is expected to remain unabated and may accelerate in some areas. Skills gaps continue to be high as in demand skills across jobs change in the next five years. The number of jobs destroyed will be surpassed by the number of &lsquo;jobs of tomorrow&rsquo; created, Those are key findings from the report Future of Jobs from WEF in 2020.
This virtual conference will gather 15 Leaders from Asia and Europe (Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong-Kong, Singapore, Vietnam, Thailand, Pakistan, France, UK and Germany) sharing their expertise in the Future of Work, Entrepreneurship and Technology for Social Good.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 29 September&nbsp; 2022
Time: 2 PM - 6 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7) / 9 AM - 1 PM&nbsp; (CET Time)

Agenda




TIME (UTC+7)


AGENDA








2:00PM - 2:45PM


Session I : Enhancing Innovation in Rural Areas
Opening&nbsp;Remarks:&nbsp;Anne Lochoff, Board member - Findexable Fintech Diversity Advisory Board (TBC)
Key Points:

Innovation &amp; Technology
What drives innovators and early innovation adopters in a rural context
Global mega-trends such as demographic, technological and environmental change, and crises such as the recent COVID-19

Speakers:


Diane le Goff, Global Leader Youth &amp; Education CSR Programs Schneider Electric (Vietnam)


Chimka Munkhbayar, Co-Founder and COO at Agrolly Farmers' App International (Mongolia)


Saran Song, CEO and Founder Amru Rice (Cambodia)


Q&amp;A
Moderator: Ravindra Ngo, Founder &amp; CEO the Asian Network








3:00PM - 3:45PM


Session 2: Technology Disruption and the Future of Jobs
Opening&nbsp;Remarks: Dr Bob Aubrey, Founder and Chair of the Advisory Board - ASEAN Human Development Organization&nbsp;
Key Points:

Legal process and ethics
The influence of new digital technologies
Challenges &amp; opportunities&nbsp;

Speakers:


Susanne Bieller, General Secretary International Federation of Robotics (Germany)


Pei Chin, Digital Government Lead at Tony Blair Institute (Singapore)


Saowaruj Rattanakhamfu, Research Director Innovation Policy for Sustainable Development (Thailand)


Q&amp;A
Moderator:&nbsp;Amelia Litania, Program Officer at Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)




4:00PM - 4:45PM


Session 3: Managing Disability in the Workplace
Opening&nbsp;Remarks: TBC
Key Points:

Disability inclusion at work
How to set up an inclusive workplace values all employees for their strengths
Social skills, hyperactivity &amp; confidence

Speakers:


Nunu Supaanong, Secretary General ASEAN Autism Self-Advocacy Network (Thailand)&nbsp;


Made Wikandana, Disability Inclusion Officer Disability Inclusion Officer UNICEF (Indonesia)


Tanzila Khan, Founder Girl things (Pakistan)&nbsp;


Q&amp;A
Moderator:&nbsp;Lina Maulidina, Senior Program Officer at Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)








5:00PM - 5:45PM


Session 4: New Work Models &amp; Entrepreneurship
Opening Remarks: Fiorina Mugione, Regional Director at GDSI
Key Points:&nbsp;

Economies become increasingly automated and machine driven
Impact of Covid-19
More flexible work opportunities

Speakers:

James Sancto, Co-Founder &amp; CEO at We Make Change (UK)
Mallory Loone, Founder Work Inspires (Malaysia)
Madhavi Shankar, Co-Founder &amp; CEO Space Basics (India)&nbsp;

Moderator: Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Strategy and Partnership Director at Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)








5:55PM - 6:00PM


Closing Remarks

.sreyolpme rieht dna srekrow htob pleh yllaedi nac taht gnikam-ycilop saw sa ,noitatsaved cimonoce gnitluser dna 91-DIVOC fo tnevda eht erofeb adnega labolg eht no hgih ydaerla saw noitaerc boJ .sdraugefas tneiciffus dna stekram robal regnorts fo noitaerc eht otni egnahc taht lennahc ot yrassecen si sledom krow wen yhtlaeh tuo gnippam dna - tsaf gnignahc si krow fo dlrow ehT aisA ni kroW fo erutuF ehT :krowteN naisA ehT-AIRE aisA ni kroW fo erutuF ehT :krowteN naisA ehT-AIRE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-16 20:39:58";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-24 09:53:00";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:75;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6963";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:64:"mapping-the-innovation-driven-entrepreneurial-ecosystem-in-asean";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:64:"Mapping the Innovation-Driven Entrepreneurial Ecosystem in ASEAN";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-22";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:3667:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_September_Mapping-the-Innovation-Driven-Entrepreneurial-Ecosystem-in-ASEAN_800x450.jpg" alt="" width="900" height="450" /></p><p>Innovation-driven entrepreneurship enables people and companies to pursue global opportunities based on innovative processes, products, or services. Studies show that innovation-driven entrepreneurial high-growth firms represent a small fraction (&lt;10%) of all start-ups but create more than 50% of jobs and are more resilient during crises, including the recent coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.</p><p>However, their growth depends on an entrepreneurial ecosystem surrounding them, including access to key markets, finance, networks, and human resources, especially new knowledge and education. To ensure the development of innovation-driven entrepreneurial activities, their geographical and sectoral distribution needs to be mapped, but indicators are lacking, especially for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). New sources of data, including social media, offer a new way to expand these indicators, and we propose a new methodology to identify emerging places of innovation-driven entrepreneurship (E-PIE).</p><p>So what are the key messages of innovation-driven entrepreneurial ecosystems and why is it important for ASEAN? Join our line of speakers to discuss more on the topic in an afternoon of conversations.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 22 September&nbsp; 2022</li><li>Time: 3 PM - 4:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7) / 09:00 - 10:15 AM (BST)&nbsp;</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>3:00PM - 3:05PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Welcome Remarks:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Giulia Ajmone Marsan</strong>, Strategy and Partnership Director, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>3:05PM - 3:20PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Presentation</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Alessandro Rosiello</strong>,&nbsp;Senior Lecturer, Business School Entrepreneurship and Innovation, Innogen Institute, University of Edinburgh</li><li><strong>Matjaz Vidmar</strong>,&nbsp;Lecturer in Engineering Management, School of Engineering, University of Edinburgh</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>3:20PM - 3:50PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p><strong>Panel Discussion</strong></p><p>Speakers:</p><ul><li><strong>Emmanuel A. San Andres</strong>,&nbsp;Senior Analyst, Policy Support Unit, APEC</li><li><strong>Alessandro Rosiello</strong>,&nbsp;Senior Lecturer, Business School Entrepreneurship and Innovation, Innogen Institute, University of Edinburgh</li><li><strong>Matjaz Vidmar</strong>,&nbsp;Lecturer in Engineering Management, School of Engineering, University of Edinburgh</li></ul><p>Moderator:</p><ul><li><strong>Giulia Ajmone Marsan</strong>, Strategy and Partnership Director, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>3:50PM - 4:05PM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p><strong>Q&amp;A</strong></p><p>Moderator:</p><ul><li><strong>Tiat Jin Ooi</strong>, Lead Consultant, E-S-I Knowledge Lab, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>4:05PM - 4:15PM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/mapping-the-innovation-driven-entrepreneurial-ecosystem-in-asean-tickets-411025156307" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-22";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:5359:"Mapping the Innovation-Driven Entrepreneurial Ecosystem in ASEAN Mapping the Innovation-Driven Entrepreneurial Ecosystem in ASEAN Innovation-driven entrepreneurship enables people and companies to pursue global opportunities based on innovative processes, products, or services. Studies show that innovation-driven entrepreneurial high-growth firms represent a small fraction (&lt;10%) of all start-ups but create more than 50% of jobs and are more resilient during crises, including the recent coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.
However, their growth depends on an entrepreneurial ecosystem surrounding them, including access to key markets, finance, networks, and human resources, especially new knowledge and education. To ensure the development of innovation-driven entrepreneurial activities, their geographical and sectoral distribution needs to be mapped, but indicators are lacking, especially for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). New sources of data, including social media, offer a new way to expand these indicators, and we propose a new methodology to identify emerging places of innovation-driven entrepreneurship (E-PIE).
So what are the key messages of innovation-driven entrepreneurial ecosystems and why is it important for ASEAN? Join our line of speakers to discuss more on the topic in an afternoon of conversations.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 22 September&nbsp; 2022
Time: 3 PM - 4:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7) / 09:00 - 10:15 AM (BST)&nbsp;

Agenda

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Strategy and Partnership Director, ERIA

Matjaz Vidmar,&nbsp;Lecturer in Engineering Management, School of Engineering, University of Edinburgh





3:20PM - 3:50PM


Panel Discussion

Emmanuel A. San Andres,&nbsp;Senior Analyst, Policy Support Unit, APEC
Alessandro Rosiello,&nbsp;Senior Lecturer, Business School Entrepreneurship and Innovation, Innogen Institute, University of Edinburgh
Matjaz Vidmar,&nbsp;Lecturer in Engineering Management, School of Engineering, University of Edinburgh

Moderator:

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Strategy and Partnership Director, ERIA









3:50PM - 4:05PM


Q&amp;A
Moderator:

Tiat Jin Ooi, Lead Consultant, E-S-I Knowledge Lab, ERIA









4:05PM - 4:15PM


Closing Remarks

gnippaM";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-16 14:41:32";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-12 15:18:23";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:76;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6955";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:141:"expert-panel-dialogue-on-urban-infrastructure-agenda-in-g20-the-need-to-establish-a-global-investment-platform-for-urban-development-projects";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:143:"Expert Panel Dialogue on Urban Infrastructure Agenda in G20:  The Need to Establish a Global Investment Platform for Urban Development Projects";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-08-11";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:5981:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_August_Expert-Panel-Dialogue-on-Urban-Infrastructure-Agenda-in-G20_800x450.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="490" /></p><p>Under the chairmanship of Jakarta in the U20, G20 leaders are expected to respond to the issues of economic and social recovery for all, to ensure that post-pandemic global recovery is inclusive and equitable, anchored on the creation of middle class jobs that support decent livelihoods for all; productive and affordable housing, as a means to enhance inclusivity, economic productivity, and environmental sustainability of the city; renewable energy transition, to create transformational opportunities that address both climate-related and economic challenges, i.e. to provide more affordable electricity, create new job opportunities, and address long-standing social disparities in urban society; equal access to sustainable mobility, to promote connectivity, active mobility and opportunities in urban informal settlements, peri-urban &amp; rural&nbsp; locations while moving&nbsp;towards a more sustainable mode of mobility that integrates public transportation networks and transforms car-oriented mobility to non-motorized mobility; mental health and pandemic resilience, to ensure that cities are both better prepared to deal with the threat of the next pandemic, including by promoting equity in vaccine technology and production capacity, while protecting the mental health of its citizens in the endemic phase; and the future of work, to grant that government policy contributes to developing digitization and automation processes that are labor friendly and contribute to protecting workers in developing and developed countries, notably informal workers, short term contract workers as well as workers in the giga economy.</p><p>TF8 of the T20 is currently preparing a proposal to G20 members in establishing a global investment platform to provide a more holistic approach to urban development than a sectorial or project-by-project strategy. The global investment platform is expected to assist integrated urban planning, provide public access to trustworthy and accurate location-based information, improve municipal budgets and city creditworthiness, and identify urban investment priorities. Thus, Task Force 8 intends to hold the seminar with the theme &#039;Urban Infrastructure Agenda in G20 and The Need to Establish a Global Investment Platform for Urban Development Projects&#039;.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Objectives</strong></p><p>The objectives of this event are:</p><ul><li>To discuss challenges and strategies in financing urban infrastructure development, as well as the need for a global investment platform, particularly in the context of the urban regeneration, city rejuvenation and the establishment of a new city.</li><li>To gather inputs and policy recommendations for urban infrastructure development finance and a global investment platform for inclusion in TF8 Notes.</li></ul><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 11 August 2022</li><li>Time:&nbsp;13:00 PM -&nbsp; 16:15 PM (Jakarta Time, GMT+7)&nbsp;</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 617px;"><tr><td style="width: 156.3px;"><p>13:00 PM - 13:05 AM</p></td><td style="width: 445.9px;"><p><strong>Opening</strong></p><p>Welcome and introduction to the session&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.3px;"><p>13:05 PM &ndash; 13:15 AM</p></td><td style="width: 445.9px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><p><strong>Prof Danang Parikesit</strong>, Lead Co-Chair of Task Force 8 T20, Head of Indonesia Toll Road Authority, Professor Universitas Gadjah Mada</p></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.3px;"><p>13:10 PM &ndash; 13:40 AM</p></td><td style="width: 445.9px;"><p><strong>Keynote Speeches:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Ir Bambang Susantono, MCP, MSCE, PhD</strong>, Head of the Indonesia New Capital City of Nusantara Authority, Adviser T20</li><li><strong>H Anies Rasyid Baswedan, SE, MPP, PhD</strong>, Governor of Jakarta and the Co-Chair of Urban20 (U20), Sherpa G20 Indonesia</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.3px;"><p>13:40 PM &ndash; 14:46 PM</p></td><td style="width: 445.9px;"><p><strong>Panel Discussion</strong></p><p>Moderated by:</p><ul><li><p><strong>Dr Fauziah Zen</strong>, Senior Economist, ERIA</p></li></ul><p>Panelists:&nbsp;</p><ul><li><strong>Mr Nicolas Buchoud</strong>, President of Cercle Grand Paris de I&rsquo;Investissement Durable, Co-Chair TF8, T20</li><li><strong>Prof John Andrew Black,&nbsp;PhD</strong>, Emeritus Professor of Transport Engineering, School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of New South Wales, Co-Chair TF8, T20</li><li><strong>Mr Wang Wei</strong>, Director of Master Planning and Urbanism, Ramboll Singapore</li><li><strong>Mr Raj Kannan</strong>, Executive Director Deloitte Consulting Indonesia, Thematic Coordinator TF8, T20</li><li><strong>Mr Edwin Syahruzad</strong>, Chief Executive Officer PT. Sarana Multi Infrastruktur (Persero)</li><li>Speaker from PT Nusantara Infrastructure</li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 617px;"><tr><td style="width: 156.3px;"><p>14:46 PM - 16:00 PM</p></td><td style="width: 445.9px;"><p><strong>Q&amp;A</strong></p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 617px;"><tr><td style="width: 156.3px;"><p>16:00 PM - 16:10 PM</p></td><td style="width: 445.9px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><p><strong>Prof Danang Parikesit</strong>, Lead Co-Chair of Task Force 8 T20, Head of Indonesia Toll Road Authority, Professor Universitas Gadjah Mada</p></li></ul></td></tr></table><table style="width: 617px;"><tr><td style="width: 156.3px;"><p>16:10 PM - 16:15 PM</p></td><td style="width: 445.9px;"><p><strong>Closing</strong></p></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://ugm-id.zoom.us/j/95320531419?pwd=Ymh4YzFQa0JIK296WmEwSlBHOCtwdz09#success" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Wuri Wulandari";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-08-11";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:9811:"Expert Panel Dialogue on Urban Infrastructure Agenda in G20:  The Need to Establish a Global Investment Platform for Urban Development Projects Expert Panel Dialogue on Urban Infrastructure Agenda in G20:  The Need to Establish a Global Investment Platform for Urban Development Projects Under the chairmanship of Jakarta in the U20, G20 leaders are expected to respond to the issues of economic and social recovery for all, to ensure that post-pandemic global recovery is inclusive and equitable, anchored on the creation of middle class jobs that support decent livelihoods for all; productive and affordable housing, as a means to enhance inclusivity, economic productivity, and environmental sustainability of the city; renewable energy transition, to create transformational opportunities that address both climate-related and economic challenges, i.e. to provide more affordable electricity, create new job opportunities, and address long-standing social disparities in urban society; equal access to sustainable mobility, to promote connectivity, active mobility and opportunities in urban informal settlements, peri-urban &amp; rural&nbsp; locations while moving&nbsp;towards a more sustainable mode of mobility that integrates public transportation networks and transforms car-oriented mobility to non-motorized mobility; mental health and pandemic resilience, to ensure that cities are both better prepared to deal with the threat of the next pandemic, including by promoting equity in vaccine technology and production capacity, while protecting the mental health of its citizens in the endemic phase; and the future of work, to grant that government policy contributes to developing digitization and automation processes that are labor friendly and contribute to protecting workers in developing and developed countries, notably informal workers, short term contract workers as well as workers in the giga economy.
TF8 of the T20 is currently preparing a proposal to G20 members in establishing a global investment platform to provide a more holistic approach to urban development than a sectorial or project-by-project strategy. The global investment platform is expected to assist integrated urban planning, provide public access to trustworthy and accurate location-based information, improve municipal budgets and city creditworthiness, and identify urban investment priorities. Thus, Task Force 8 intends to hold the seminar with the theme 'Urban Infrastructure Agenda in G20 and The Need to Establish a Global Investment Platform for Urban Development Projects'.&nbsp;
Objectives
The objectives of this event are:

To discuss challenges and strategies in financing urban infrastructure development, as well as the need for a global investment platform, particularly in the context of the urban regeneration, city rejuvenation and the establishment of a new city.
To gather inputs and policy recommendations for urban infrastructure development finance and a global investment platform for inclusion in TF8 Notes.

Event Details

Date: Thursday, 11 August 2022
Time:&nbsp;13:00 PM -&nbsp; 16:15 PM (Jakarta Time, GMT+7)&nbsp;

Agenda




13:00 PM - 13:05 AM


Opening
Welcome and introduction to the session&nbsp;




13:05 PM &ndash; 13:15 AM

Prof Danang Parikesit, Lead Co-Chair of Task Force 8 T20, Head of Indonesia Toll Road Authority, Professor Universitas Gadjah Mada

Dr Ir Bambang Susantono, MCP, MSCE, PhD, Head of the Indonesia New Capital City of Nusantara Authority, Adviser T20
H Anies Rasyid Baswedan, SE, MPP, PhD, Governor of Jakarta and the Co-Chair of Urban20 (U20), Sherpa G20 Indonesia





13:40 PM &ndash; 14:46 PM


Panel Discussion
Moderated by:


Dr Fauziah Zen, Senior Economist, ERIA


Panelists:&nbsp;

Prof John Andrew Black,&nbsp;PhD, Emeritus Professor of Transport Engineering, School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of New South Wales, Co-Chair TF8, T20
Mr Wang Wei, Director of Master Planning and Urbanism, Ramboll Singapore
Mr Raj Kannan, Executive Director Deloitte Consulting Indonesia, Thematic Coordinator TF8, T20
Mr Edwin Syahruzad, Chief Executive Officer PT. Sarana Multi Infrastruktur (Persero)
Speaker from PT Nusantara Infrastructure

&nbsp;

16:10 PM - 16:15 PM

trepxE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-09 09:54:45";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-09 10:18:20";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"wuri.wulandari@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:77;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6940";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:111:"exploring-short-term-solutions-to-the-global-gas-crisis-g20-energy-transition-working-group-etwg-parallel-event";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:124:"'Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis' â€“ G20 Energy Transition Working Group (ETWG) parallel event";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-08-29";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:4549:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_Aug_Exploring-Short-Term-Solutions-to-the-Global-Gas-Crisis_2.jpg" alt="" width="847" height="476" /></p><p>The world is going through a complex energy crisis, and natural gas is just a single dimension. Energy trade is now on a global level and is more interrelated and intertwined than ever before. Therefore, the consequences of the energy crisis are being felt across countries and industries in more acute ways.</p><p>First, natural gas markets were already tight before the outbreak of the Russian&ndash;Ukrainian conflict on 24 February 2022 due to underinvestment since 2015, the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in 2020, the rapid albeit uneven post-COVID-19 recovery, and disrupted supply chains, primarily commodity supply chains. As a result, the supply of energy could not catch up with robust resilient demand recovery. There is an ongoing mismatch of supply and continuous, more responsive, and elastic energy demand.</p><p>Second, the situation was exacerbated afterwards by further elevated energy price levels and volatility.</p><p>The current gas crisis could seriously affect not only the world energy security but also the world energy transition progress.</p><p>A workshop is held with the aim of finding short-term solutions to stabilise the global gas market, so that the world can continue to recover together and strongly, amidst the geopolitical crisis.</p><p>On behalf of the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources of the Republic of Indonesia, as the host of the G20 Presidency, ERIA is pleased to invite you to participate virtually in the upcoming Hybrid Workshop as a G20 ETWG III Parallel Event entitled &#039;Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis&#039; to be organised back-to-back to the 3rd Energy Transition Working Group Meeting and the G20 Energy Transition Ministerial Meeting.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><p>Date: Monday, 29 August 2022 Time: 9 AM &ndash; 12.30 PM (Bali Time; UTC+8)</p><h2>Agenda*</h2><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Yudo Dwinanda Priaadi, Chair of the Energy Transition Working Group G20 ETWG</li></ul><p><strong>Keynote Speeches</strong></p><ul><li>Prof Tutuka Ariadji, Director General of Oil and Gas, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Republic of Indonesia</li><li>HE Eng. Mohamed Hamel, Secretary General of the Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)</li><li>Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li></ul><p><strong>Main presentation: Proposed Short-term Solutions for the Current Gas Crisis</strong></p><p>Main speaker:</p><ul><li>Mr Hiroshi Hashimoto, Senior Analyst, Head of Gas Group, Fossil Energies &amp; International Cooperation Unit, The Institute of Energy Economics Japan</li></ul><p><strong>Panel Discussion I: Importing and Exporting Countries&rsquo; Perspectives and Reactions on the Proposed Solutions</strong></p><p>Moderator: Mr Nanang Untung, Expert Staff for Minister of Energy &amp; Mineral Resources of the Republic of Indonesia</p><p>Panellists:</p><ul><li>Mr Jonathan Goh, Director of External Relations, Energy Market Authority, Singapore</li><li><span lang="nl-BE">Mr Takahiro Hirai,&nbsp;</span><span lang="en-GB">Deputy Director Oil and Gas Division, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, Japan</span></li><li>Ms <span lang="en-GB">Lamiaa Abo Shahba PhD,&nbsp;General Manager of Gas Market Activities, Operations and Networks, Egyptian Natural Gas Holding Company &ndash; EGAS</span></li><li>Mr Martin Squire, Head of International Energy Area, Ministry of Energy, Australia</li><li>Dr Philip Mshelbila, Managing Director, Nigeria LNG Ltd. (NLNG)</li></ul><p><strong>Panel Discussion II: Market Effects of Possible Short-term Solutions</strong></p><p>Moderator: Prof. Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow for Energy and Environment, ERIA</p><p>Panellists:</p><ul><li>Mr Christof van Agt, Director, Energy Dialogue, International Energy Forum (IEF)</li><li>Dr Aydar Shakirov, Head of the Gas Market Analysis Department, Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)</li><li>Mr Edito Barcelona, Senior Research Fellow, Asia Pacific Energy Research Centre (APERC)</li><li>Mr Chong Zhi Xin, Director, South and Southeast Asia Gas, S&amp;P Global</li></ul><p><strong>Conclusions and the Way Forward</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Koji Hachiyama, COO of ERIA</li></ul><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://bit.ly/ESSGGCSeminar" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:15:"Bali, Indonesia";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-08-29";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:8439:"'Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis' â€“ G20 Energy Transition Working Group (ETWG) parallel event 'Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis' â€“ G20 Energy Transition Working Group (ETWG) parallel event The world is going through a complex energy crisis, and natural gas is just a single dimension. Energy trade is now on a global level and is more interrelated and intertwined than ever before. Therefore, the consequences of the energy crisis are being felt across countries and industries in more acute ways.
First, natural gas markets were already tight before the outbreak of the Russian&ndash;Ukrainian conflict on 24 February 2022 due to underinvestment since 2015, the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in 2020, the rapid albeit uneven post-COVID-19 recovery, and disrupted supply chains, primarily commodity supply chains. As a result, the supply of energy could not catch up with robust resilient demand recovery. There is an ongoing mismatch of supply and continuous, more responsive, and elastic energy demand.
Second, the situation was exacerbated afterwards by further elevated energy price levels and volatility.
The current gas crisis could seriously affect not only the world energy security but also the world energy transition progress.
A workshop is held with the aim of finding short-term solutions to stabilise the global gas market, so that the world can continue to recover together and strongly, amidst the geopolitical crisis.
On behalf of the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources of the Republic of Indonesia, as the host of the G20 Presidency, ERIA is pleased to invite you to participate virtually in the upcoming Hybrid Workshop as a G20 ETWG III Parallel Event entitled 'Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis' to be organised back-to-back to the 3rd Energy Transition Working Group Meeting and the G20 Energy Transition Ministerial Meeting.
Event Details
Date: Monday, 29 August 2022 Time: 9 AM &ndash; 12.30 PM (Bali Time; UTC+8)
Agenda*
Opening Remarks

Mr Yudo Dwinanda Priaadi, Chair of the Energy Transition Working Group G20 ETWG

Keynote Speeches

Prof Tutuka Ariadji, Director General of Oil and Gas, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Republic of Indonesia
HE Eng. Mohamed Hamel, Secretary General of the Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)
Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)

Main presentation: Proposed Short-term Solutions for the Current Gas Crisis
Main speaker:

Mr Hiroshi Hashimoto, Senior Analyst, Head of Gas Group, Fossil Energies &amp; International Cooperation Unit, The Institute of Energy Economics Japan

Panel Discussion I: Importing and Exporting Countries&rsquo; Perspectives and Reactions on the Proposed Solutions
Moderator: Mr Nanang Untung, Expert Staff for Minister of Energy &amp; Mineral Resources of the Republic of Indonesia
Panellists:

Mr Jonathan Goh, Director of External Relations, Energy Market Authority, Singapore
Mr Takahiro Hirai,&nbsp;Deputy Director Oil and Gas Division, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, Japan
Ms Lamiaa Abo Shahba PhD,&nbsp;General Manager of Gas Market Activities, Operations and Networks, Egyptian Natural Gas Holding Company &ndash; EGAS
Mr Martin Squire, Head of International Energy Area, Ministry of Energy, Australia
Dr Philip Mshelbila, Managing Director, Nigeria LNG Ltd. (NLNG)

Panel Discussion II: Market Effects of Possible Short-term Solutions
Moderator: Prof. Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow for Energy and Environment, ERIA
Panellists:

Mr Christof van Agt, Director, Energy Dialogue, International Energy Forum (IEF)
Dr Aydar Shakirov, Head of the Gas Market Analysis Department, Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)
Mr Edito Barcelona, Senior Research Fellow, Asia Pacific Energy Research Centre (APERC)
Mr Chong Zhi Xin, Director, South and Southeast Asia Gas, S&amp;P Global

Conclusions and the Way Forward

Mr Koji Hachiyama, COO of ERIA

Actions based on Asia-Japan Investing for the Future Initiative";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-08-09";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:3339:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022-08-09-AJIF-webinar-flyer.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Japanese METI Minister Hagiuda launched the Asia Japan Investing for the Future Initiative (AJIF) this January to improve the region&#039;s attractiveness as a hub of global supply chains and create innovation to enhance sustainability and solve social challenges through collaborations between private and public sectors of both Japan and ASEAN. There are already successful examples of these collaborations.</p><p>In this webinar, we will highlight these success models and best practices in key industrial sectors and discuss how we can jointly expand and deepen our cooperation among industry representatives, government officials, and academia. The result of the webinar will be reported to the upcoming AEM-METI Meeting in September to discuss further actions among the Ministers.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Tuesday, 9 August 2022</li><li>Time:&nbsp;10:00&nbsp;AM -&nbsp; 12:00 PM (Jakarta/Phnom Penh time, GMT+7)&nbsp;</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table><tr><td width="104"><p>10:00 &ndash; 10:05</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Opening Speech</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Hidetoshi Nishimura</strong>, President, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>10:05 - 10:25</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Keynote Speech</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Tetsuya Watanabe,&nbsp;</strong>Special Advisor to the Minister, METI / Vice President, RIETI / Visiting Professor, Graduate School of Public Policy, The University of Tokyo</li><li><strong>Rath Saravuth</strong>, Director-General,&nbsp;General Directorate of International Trade, MOC</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>10:25 &ndash; 11:10</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Presentation from Japanese Private Companies</strong></p><ul><li><p><strong>Jun Arii,&nbsp;</strong>President, DMG MORI Thailand &amp; Mekong Sub Region</p></li><li><p><strong>Yasuhiro Emi</strong>,&nbsp;Director / Vice President of Administrative &amp; Corporate Division, DENSO (CAMBODIA) CO., LTD</p></li><li><p><strong>Masaharu Morita</strong>, Global Head for New business, Medical System DIV, Fujifilm Corporation (Japan)</p></li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>11:10 - 11:25</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Expectation to Japanese Investment from ASEAN Side</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Eko S. A. Cahyanto</strong>, Director General of Resilience, Representatives and Access of International Industry, Ministry of Industry</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>11:25 &ndash; 11:30</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Koji Hachiyama,</strong> Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register for online participation" href="https://www.meti.go.jp/press/2021/01/20220110001/20220110001-2.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">AJIF</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register for online participation" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/concrete-actions-based-on-asia-japan-investing-for-the-future-initiative-tickets-395713950077" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Hybrid Event";s:5:"major";s:21:"Ms Nadira Priastianda";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-08-09";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4825:"Concrete Actions based on Asia-Japan Investing for the Future Initiative Concrete Actions based on Asia-Japan Investing for the Future Initiative Japanese METI Minister Hagiuda launched the Asia Japan Investing for the Future Initiative (AJIF) this January to improve the region's attractiveness as a hub of global supply chains and create innovation to enhance sustainability and solve social challenges through collaborations between private and public sectors of both Japan and ASEAN. There are already successful examples of these collaborations.
In this webinar, we will highlight these success models and best practices in key industrial sectors and discuss how we can jointly expand and deepen our cooperation among industry representatives, government officials, and academia. The result of the webinar will be reported to the upcoming AEM-METI Meeting in September to discuss further actions among the Ministers.
Event Details

Date: Tuesday, 9 August 2022
Time:&nbsp;10:00&nbsp;AM -&nbsp; 12:00 PM (Jakarta/Phnom Penh time, GMT+7)&nbsp;

Agenda




10:00 &ndash; 10:05


Opening Speech

Hidetoshi Nishimura, President, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)





10:05 - 10:25


Keynote Speech

Tetsuya Watanabe,&nbsp;Special Advisor to the Minister, METI / Vice President, RIETI / Visiting Professor, Graduate School of Public Policy, The University of Tokyo
Rath Saravuth, Director-General,&nbsp;General Directorate of International Trade, MOC





10:25 &ndash; 11:10


Presentation from Japanese Private Companies


Jun Arii,&nbsp;President, DMG MORI Thailand &amp; Mekong Sub Region


Yasuhiro Emi,&nbsp;Director / Vice President of Administrative &amp; Corporate Division, DENSO (CAMBODIA) CO., LTD


Masaharu Morita, Global Head for New business, Medical System DIV, Fujifilm Corporation (Japan)










11:10 - 11:25


Expectation to Japanese Investment from ASEAN Side

Eko S. A. Cahyanto, Director General of Resilience, Representatives and Access of International Industry, Ministry of Industry









11:25 &ndash; 11:30


Closing Remarks

Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)

.sretsiniM eht gnoma snoitca rehtruf ssucsid ot rebmetpeS ni gniteeM ITEM-MEA gnimocpu eht ot detroper eb lliw ranibew eht fo tluser ehT .aimedaca dna ,slaiciffo tnemnrevog ,sevitatneserper yrtsudni gnoma noitarepooc ruo nepeed dna dnapxe yltnioj nac ew woh ssucsid dna srotces lairtsudni yek ni secitcarp tseb dna sledom sseccus eseht thgilhgih lliw ew ,ranibew siht nI
.snoitaroballoc eseht fo selpmaxe lufsseccus ydaerla era erehT .NAESA dna napaJ htob fo srotces cilbup dna etavirp neewteb snoitaroballoc hguorht segnellahc laicos evlos dna ytilibaniatsus ecnahne ot noitavonni etaerc dna sniahc ylppus labolg fo buh a sa ssenevitcartta s'noiger eht evorpmi ot yraunaJ siht )FIJA( evitaitinI erutuF eht rof gnitsevnI napaJ aisA eht dehcnual aduigaH retsiniM ITEM esenapaJ evitaitinI erutuF eht rof gnitsevnI napaJ-aisA no desab snoitcA etercnoC evitaitinI erutuF eht rof gnitsevnI napaJ-aisA no desab snoitcA etercnoC";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-07-29 11:49:02";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-09 08:02:42";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:27:"nadira.priastianda@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:86;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6924";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:78:"unpacking-the-rcep-agreement-for-lao-businesses-public-private-dialogue-series";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:80:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement for Lao Businesses : Public Private Dialogue Series";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-08-10";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:2897:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_August_Unpacking-RCEP-Agreement-for-LAO-PDR-Business_800x450.jpg" alt="" width="792" height="396" /></p><p>The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) - the world&rsquo;s largest trade deal - came into effect in early 2022. Its 15 member countries account for 30 percent of the world&rsquo;s population, 29 per cent of global GDP, 27 percent of global trade and 29 percent of global foreign direct investment.&nbsp;RCEP is predicted to have a trade impact of nearly US$42 billion and transform the region into the centre of global trade. The existing trade interdependency between RCEP countries will also promote the development of more complex regional value chains in &lsquo;Factory Asia&rsquo;. Although RCEP aims to consolidate existing ASEAN+1 FTAs, it has added complexity to the region&rsquo;s existing overlapping bilateral and regional FTAs, while providing less aggressive tariff cuts than other modern trade agreements. RCEP&rsquo;s &lsquo;ASEAN Way&rsquo; is defined by gradual commitments which take into account countries&rsquo; various levels of development. Instead of a single tariff commitment, each member will establish specific duty reduction commitments in relation to other exporting member states with a 20-year implementation timeframe.</p><p>The RCEP agreement has great importance for business in Laos, as it will create favorable conditions for more trade, foreign investment and tourism in Laos<strong>. </strong>ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme will held a Public-Private Dialogue Series, &#039;Unpacking the RCEP Agreement for Lao Businesses&#039;, On 10-11 August 2022 (live streaming from Crowne Plaza, Vientiane) focusing on five chapters from the RCEP agreement to discuss opportunities/ benefits / challenges of RCEP along with panel of experts, private sectors and government officials.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Wednesday, 10 August 2022 - Thursday, 11&nbsp;August 2022</li><li>Time: 08.30 AM &ndash; 5 PM (Jakarta/Vientiane Time, GMT+7)</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/uploads/media/Events/RCEP-PPD-Series-Vientiane-agenda.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Agenda (English Version)&nbsp;</a></p><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/RCEP%20PPD%20Series%20-%20Vientiane%20agenda_Lao%20version.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Agenda (Lao Version)</a>&nbsp;</strong></p><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="/database-and-programmes/unpacking-the-rcep-agreement-public-private-dialogue-series/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Capacity Building Program</a></strong></p><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register via Eventbrite" href="https://us06web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_Wh3JhwO3Q6uz_rXhu06CVw" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p><p><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:18:"Vientiane, Lao PDR";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-08-10";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-08-11";s:8:"keywords";s:4477:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement for Lao Businesses : Public Private Dialogue Series Unpacking the RCEP Agreement for Lao Businesses : Public Private Dialogue Series The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) - the world&rsquo;s largest trade deal - came into effect in early 2022. Its 15 member countries account for 30 percent of the world&rsquo;s population, 29 per cent of global GDP, 27 percent of global trade and 29 percent of global foreign direct investment.&nbsp;RCEP is predicted to have a trade impact of nearly US$42 billion and transform the region into the centre of global trade. The existing trade interdependency between RCEP countries will also promote the development of more complex regional value chains in &lsquo;Factory Asia&rsquo;. Although RCEP aims to consolidate existing ASEAN+1 FTAs, it has added complexity to the region&rsquo;s existing overlapping bilateral and regional FTAs, while providing less aggressive tariff cuts than other modern trade agreements. RCEP&rsquo;s &lsquo;ASEAN Way&rsquo; is defined by gradual commitments which take into account countries&rsquo; various levels of development. Instead of a single tariff commitment, each member will establish specific duty reduction commitments in relation to other exporting member states with a 20-year implementation timeframe.
The RCEP agreement has great importance for business in Laos, as it will create favorable conditions for more trade, foreign investment and tourism in Laos. ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme will held a Public-Private Dialogue Series, 'Unpacking the RCEP Agreement for Lao Businesses', On 10-11 August 2022 (live streaming from Crowne Plaza, Vientiane) focusing on five chapters from the RCEP agreement to discuss opportunities/ benefits / challenges of RCEP along with panel of experts, private sectors and government officials.
Event Details

Date: Wednesday, 10 August 2022 - Thursday, 11&nbsp;August 2022
Time: 08.30 AM &ndash; 5 PM (Jakarta/Vientiane Time, GMT+7)

Agenda (English Version)&nbsp;
Agenda (Lao Version)&nbsp;
