laed edart tsegral s;ouqsr&dlrow eht - )PECR( pihsrentraP cimonocE evisneherpmoC lanoigeR ehT seireS eugolaiD etavirP cilbuP : sessenisuB oaL rof tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU seireS eugolaiD etavirP cilbuP : sessenisuB oaL rof tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-07-29 09:43:09";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-09 09:29:38";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:87;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6915";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:103:"2022-energy-security-program-agenda-critical-minerals-global-supply-chains-and-indo-pacific-geopolitics";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:107:"2022 Energy Security Program Agenda 'Critical Minerals:  Global Supply Chains and Indo-Pacific Geopolitics'";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-28";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:3692:"<p>Now in its eighteenth year, NBR&rsquo;s Energy Security Program convenes senior policy and industry leaders and energy specialists to engage in high-level discussion of and research on Asia&rsquo;s energy policies and the geopolitical impact. Today&rsquo;s program will focus on several pressing issues, including the securitization of supply chains, the geopolitics of critical minerals, and the United States&rsquo; role in maintaining critical supply chains in Asia.</p><p>As countries across the Indo-Pacific set increasingly ambitious targets to electrify their energy systems and achieve net-zero emissions in their energy, power, and transportation sectors, demand will sharply rise for critical minerals and rare earth elements essential for this transformation. The IEA estimates that global demand will quadruple by 2040, leading some experts to suggest that the clean energy transition will make critical minerals the &#039;new oil.&#039; Increasing demand for these minerals and metals-including copper, nickel, cobalt, lithium, aluminum, graphite, and rare earth minerals like neodymium-presents numerous obstacles for the clean energy industry and policymakers seeking to expand electrification, renewable energy supplies, and new battery technologies, among other products.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 28 July&nbsp; 2022</li><li>Time: 8:30AM - 1:00 PM EDT</li></ul><table><tr><td width="104"><p>08:30 &ndash; 08:35</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Welcome and Introduction</strong></p><ul><li>Ashley Johnson,&nbsp;The National Bureau of Asian Research</li><li>Michael Kugelman,&nbsp;Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>08:35 - 09:05</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Setting the Stage: The New Geopolitics of Energy</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Mikkal Herberg,&nbsp;The National Bureau of Asian Research, University of California San Diego</p><p><strong>Authors:&nbsp;</strong></p><ul><li>Phung Quoc Huy,&nbsp;Asia Pacific Energy Research Centre</li><li>Wu Yu-Hsuan,&nbsp;Asia Pacific Energy Research Centre</li></ul><p><strong>Discussants:</strong></p><ul><li>Jason Bordoff (Invited), Columbia Climate School</li><li>Meghan O&rsquo;Sullivan (Invited), Harvard Kennedy School</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>09:15 &ndash; 10:30</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Engaging Exporters: Possibilities for Expanding Regional Capacity </strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Ashley Johnson,&nbsp;The National Bureau of Asian Research</p><p><strong>Authors:&nbsp;</strong>Llewelyn Hughes, Australian National University</p><p><strong>Discussants:</strong></p><ul><li>Han Phoumin, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia</li><li>Prashanth Parameswaran,&nbsp;Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars</li><li>Brian Yates, Stantec</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>10:40&nbsp;&ndash; 12:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Reversing Inaction: Secure Supply Chains for Critical Mineral Importers</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Jim Slutz, National Petroleum Council</p><p><strong>Authors:&nbsp;</strong></p><ul><li>Sharon Burke, Ecospherics</li><li>Kristin Vekasi, University of Maine</li></ul><p><strong>Discussants:</strong></p><ul><li>Hisashi Inoue, Japan Bank for International Cooperation</li><li>Abigail Wulf, Securing America&rsquo;s Future Energy</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>12:00 &ndash; 1:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Working Lunch Keynote</strong></p><p><strong>Speaker:&nbsp;</strong>Douglas HOLLETT (Invited), U.S. Department of Energy</p></td></tr></table>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-28";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6537:"2022 Energy Security Program Agenda 'Critical Minerals:  Global Supply Chains and Indo-Pacific Geopolitics' 2022 Energy Security Program Agenda 'Critical Minerals:  Global Supply Chains and Indo-Pacific Geopolitics' Now in its eighteenth year, NBR&rsquo;s Energy Security Program convenes senior policy and industry leaders and energy specialists to engage in high-level discussion of and research on Asia&rsquo;s energy policies and the geopolitical impact. Today&rsquo;s program will focus on several pressing issues, including the securitization of supply chains, the geopolitics of critical minerals, and the United States&rsquo; role in maintaining critical supply chains in Asia.
As countries across the Indo-Pacific set increasingly ambitious targets to electrify their energy systems and achieve net-zero emissions in their energy, power, and transportation sectors, demand will sharply rise for critical minerals and rare earth elements essential for this transformation. The IEA estimates that global demand will quadruple by 2040, leading some experts to suggest that the clean energy transition will make critical minerals the 'new oil.' Increasing demand for these minerals and metals-including copper, nickel, cobalt, lithium, aluminum, graphite, and rare earth minerals like neodymium-presents numerous obstacles for the clean energy industry and policymakers seeking to expand electrification, renewable energy supplies, and new battery technologies, among other products.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 28 July&nbsp; 2022
Time: 8:30AM - 1:00 PM EDT





08:30 &ndash; 08:35


Welcome and Introduction

Ashley Johnson,&nbsp;The National Bureau of Asian Research
Michael Kugelman,&nbsp;Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars





08:35 - 09:05


Setting the Stage: The New Geopolitics of Energy
Moderator:&nbsp;Mikkal Herberg,&nbsp;The National Bureau of Asian Research, University of California San Diego
Authors:&nbsp;

Phung Quoc Huy,&nbsp;Asia Pacific Energy Research Centre
Wu Yu-Hsuan,&nbsp;Asia Pacific Energy Research Centre

Discussants:

Jason Bordoff (Invited), Columbia Climate School
Meghan O&rsquo;Sullivan (Invited), Harvard Kennedy School





09:15 &ndash; 10:30


Engaging Exporters: Possibilities for Expanding Regional Capacity 
Moderator:&nbsp;Ashley Johnson,&nbsp;The National Bureau of Asian Research
Authors:&nbsp;Llewelyn Hughes, Australian National University
Discussants:

Han Phoumin, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia
Prashanth Parameswaran,&nbsp;Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars
Brian Yates, Stantec









10:40&nbsp;&ndash; 12:00


Reversing Inaction: Secure Supply Chains for Critical Mineral Importers
Moderator:&nbsp;Jim Slutz, National Petroleum Council
Authors:&nbsp;

Sharon Burke, Ecospherics
Kristin Vekasi, University of Maine

Discussants:

Hisashi Inoue, Japan Bank for International Cooperation
Abigail Wulf, Securing America&rsquo;s Future Energy

Future Opportunities and Private Sectorâ€™s Good Practices in Cambodia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-08-05";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:5106:"<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Hybrid Conference&nbsp;hosted by The Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) of ERIA and the Ministry of Environment of Cambodia</strong></span></h2><h2><img src="/uploads/media/2022_July_Marine-Plastic-Debris_Banner_800x450.jpg" alt="" width="850" height="425" /></h2><p>ERIA&rsquo;s RKC-MPD in collaboration with the Ministry of Environment of Cambodia will shed light on the current plastic waste management challenges in Cambodia, highlight the important role played by the private sectors, and share lessons learned from international and regional experience.</p><p>One of the important missions of RKC-MPD is to promote private companies whose business activities help combat (marine) plastic waste, in the hope to promote this positive shift. RKC-MPD has established an online platform titled &lsquo;Private sector initiatives to reduce plastic waste and marine plastic debris&rsquo; (https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story). This online interface called the Private Sector Platform (PSP) in short, hosts information submitted by private companies operating in all ASEAN+3 countries to showcase their products, services, or technologies contributing to the reduction of plastic waste and marine plastic debris. The platform collects and disseminates private companies&rsquo; business activities that are conducive to marine plastics mitigation. It also aims to encourage Business-to-Business, Business-to-Government and/or Business-to-Consumer opportunities in the ASEAN+3 region.</p><p>The forum will be an occasion for the Ministry of Environment of Cambodia, Cambodian business alliances, and Cambodian private companies to stocktake the progress made, and discuss the many ways private companies can contribute in combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris. RKC-MPD will reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP) to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness of the platform and attract a larger number of private companies to join the fight against marine plastics.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Friday, 5 August 2022</li><li>Time: 8:30 AM -&nbsp; 12:00 PM (Jakarta/Phnom Penh time, GMT+7)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table><tr><td width="104"><p>08:30 &ndash; 08:50</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Dr Aladdin D. Rillo<strong>,&nbsp;</strong>Senior Economic Advisor, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li></ul><p><strong>Opening Remark:</strong></p><ul><li><p>H.E. Ngin Lina, Deputy Director General, General Directorate of Policy and Strategy, Ministry of Environment Cambodia</p></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>08:50 - 09:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Group Photo and Coffee Break</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>09:00 &ndash; 09:50</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Public Sector Intervention</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator: </strong>Mr Taing Meng Eang, Director of Department of Green Economy, Ministry of Environment Cambodia</p><p><strong>Panellists:</strong></p><ul><li>Dr Keo Vanthoueun, Representative of the Ministry of Environment of Cambodia on Forthcoming Circular Economy Action Plan&nbsp;</li><li>Dr Mongtoeun Yim, Deputy Head of the Environmental Science Department, Royal University of Phnom Penh (on Plastic Waste Management Challenges in Cambodia)</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>09:50 &ndash; 11:40</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Private Sector Intervention</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator: </strong>Ms Ellen Putri Edita, Research Associate, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</p><p><strong>Panellists:</strong></p><ul><li>Ms Hak Chansy, Administration and Education General Manager, AEON Cambodia on Efforts to Reduce Plastics&nbsp;</li><li>Ms Saruom Ran, Business Service Manager, GAEA Waste Management, Plastic Waste Situation and Recycling in Cambodia&nbsp;</li><li>Mr Chris Parker, Director of Plastic Program, ClimeCo, on Plastic Credit Program in Cambodia</li><li>Mr Jef Moons,&nbsp;CEO of Knai Bang Chatt Resort</li><li>Mr Michikazu Kojima, ERIA (on effective policy implementation in the ASEAN region to reduce plastic waste)</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p><p><strong>Introduction of the Private Sector Platform (PSP) of ERIA</strong></p><ul><li>Projection of 2 min. video</li><li>Ms Ellen Putri Edita (ERIA) will invite participants to join the PSP</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>11:40 &ndash; 12:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Closing&nbsp;Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Michikazu Kojima, Senior Advisor to the President on Environmental Issues of ERIA</li><li>H.E. Ngin Lina, Deputy Director General, General Directorate of Policy and Strategy, Ministry of Environment Cambodia</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register via Eventbrite" href="https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_0LL4_5llSKO-bcGSVwhGOA" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Hybrid Event";s:5:"major";s:13:"Ms Hera Diani";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-08-05";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:8689:"Plastic Waste Management - Future Opportunities and Private Sectorâ€™s Good Practices in Cambodia Plastic Waste Management - Future Opportunities and Private Sectorâ€™s Good Practices in Cambodia Hybrid Conference&nbsp;hosted by The Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) of ERIA and the Ministry of Environment of Cambodia

ERIA&rsquo;s RKC-MPD in collaboration with the Ministry of Environment of Cambodia will shed light on the current plastic waste management challenges in Cambodia, highlight the important role played by the private sectors, and share lessons learned from international and regional experience.
One of the important missions of RKC-MPD is to promote private companies whose business activities help combat (marine) plastic waste, in the hope to promote this positive shift. RKC-MPD has established an online platform titled &lsquo;Private sector initiatives to reduce plastic waste and marine plastic debris&rsquo; (https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story). This online interface called the Private Sector Platform (PSP) in short, hosts information submitted by private companies operating in all ASEAN+3 countries to showcase their products, services, or technologies contributing to the reduction of plastic waste and marine plastic debris. The platform collects and disseminates private companies&rsquo; business activities that are conducive to marine plastics mitigation. It also aims to encourage Business-to-Business, Business-to-Government and/or Business-to-Consumer opportunities in the ASEAN+3 region.
The forum will be an occasion for the Ministry of Environment of Cambodia, Cambodian business alliances, and Cambodian private companies to stocktake the progress made, and discuss the many ways private companies can contribute in combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris. RKC-MPD will reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP) to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness of the platform and attract a larger number of private companies to join the fight against marine plastics.
Event Details

Date: Friday, 5 August 2022
Time: 8:30 AM -&nbsp; 12:00 PM (Jakarta/Phnom Penh time, GMT+7)

Agenda

Indonesian Regional Science Association (IRSA) International Conference The 17th Indonesian Regional Science Association (IRSA) International Conference        Lombok, Indonesia Ms Wuri Wulandari wuri.wulandari@eria.org   2022-07-18 2022-07-19 2022-07-18 18 July 2022 2202 yluJ 81 81-70-2202 91-70-2202 81-70-2202   gro.aire@iradnaluw.iruw iradnaluW iruW sM aisenodnI ,kobmoL        ecnerefnoC lanoitanretnI )ASRI( noitaicossA ecneicS lanoigeR naisenodnI ht71 ehT ecnerefnoC lanoitanretnI )ASRI( noitaicossA ecneicS lanoigeR naisenodnI ht71 ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-07-13 11:10:03";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-07-13 11:10:21";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"wuri.wulandari@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:90;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6888";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:110:"the-7th-energy-research-institute-network-erin-workshop-energy-security-and-climate-action-in-east-asia-region";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:113:"The 7th Energy Research Institute Network (ERIN) Workshop: Energy Security and Climate Action in East Asia Region";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-08-16";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:8834:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_August_ERIN.png" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Energy landscape has significantly changed since the conflict between Russia and Ukraine. Prior to the conflict, climate action was at the center of energy debate in which discussions centered on how to increase renewable energy and, conversely, reduce the use of fossil fuels. However, with energy prices further escalating due to the conflict and growing concerns about crude oil and natural gas supply shortages, interest in energy security has rapidly increased. Investments in fossil fuels are essential to resolving the ongoing energy security crisis, and it is obviously contradicted with long-term climate action. Thus, the world faces the difficult challenge of how to deal with strengthening fossil-based energy security while at the same time taking step to combat climate change. Addressing this issue is essential for the economic growth of Asian countries. In this workshop, we will invite experts from Asia and other regions to discuss this issue from multiple perspectives.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Tuesday, 16 August 2022</li><li>Time: 10 AM - 4 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li><li>Hybrid event, open for online and in-person participation</li><li>Offline seats are very limited, register soon to secure your seat&nbsp;</li><li>Venue: Sasono Mulyo 3 Ballroom, Le M&eacute;ridien&nbsp;Jakarta</li><li>This event is free of charge</li></ul><h2>RSVP</h2><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register for online participation" href="https://bit.ly/7thERINws" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Online Participation</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register for offline participation" href="https://bit.ly/7thERINwsLM" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">In-Person Participation&nbsp;</a></p><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 617px;"><tr><td style="width: 156px;"><p>10:00 AM - 10:30 AM</p></td><td style="width: 445px;"><p>Registration</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156px;"><p>10:30 AM &ndash; 10:45 AM</p></td><td style="width: 445px;"><p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Opening Session</strong></span></p><p><strong>Opening Remark </strong></p><ul><li><strong>Prof Tutuka Ariadji</strong>, Director General, Directorate General of Oil and Gas, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR), IndonesiA</li><li><strong>Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura</strong>, President of ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Welcome Remark </strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Siti Indati binti Mustapa</strong>, Director of Institute of Energy Policy and Research, Universiti Tenaga Nasional (UNITEN), Malaysia [Co-Chairperson of ERIN]</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156px;"><p>10:45 AM &ndash; Prior to the conflict, climate action was at the center of energy debate in which discussions centered on how to increase renewable energy and, conversely, reduce the use of fossil fuels. However, with energy prices further escalating due to the conflict and growing concerns about crude oil and natural gas supply shortages, interest in energy security has rapidly increased. Investments in fossil fuels are essential to resolving the ongoing energy security crisis, and it is obviously contradicted with long-term climate action. Thus, the world faces the difficult challenge of how to deal with strengthening fossil-based energy security while at the same time taking step to combat climate change. Addressing this issue is essential for the economic growth of Asian countries. In this workshop, we will invite experts from Asia and other regions to discuss this issue from multiple perspectives.
Event Details

Date: Tuesday, 16 August 2022
Time: 10 AM - 4 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)
Hybrid event, open for online and in-person participation
Offline seats are very limited, register soon to secure your seat&nbsp;
Venue: Sasono Mulyo 3 Ballroom, Le M&eacute;ridien&nbsp;Jakarta
This event is free of charge

RSVP
Online Participation
In-Person Participation&nbsp;
Agenda




10:00 AM - 10:30 AM


Registration




10:30 AM &ndash; 10:45 AM


Opening Session
Opening Remark 

Prof Tutuka Ariadji, Director General, Directorate General of Oil and Gas, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR), IndonesiA
Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of ERIA

Welcome Remark 

Dr Siti Indati binti Mustapa, Director of Institute of Energy Policy and Research, Universiti Tenaga Nasional (UNITEN), Malaysia [Co-Chairperson of ERIN]





10:45 AM &ndash; 11:15 AM


Special Keynote Speeches: 

Ukraine Crisis and Indispensable Cooperation in Asia 

Prof Masakazu Toyoda, Senior Advisor (Former Chairman and CEO), The Institute of Energy Economics, Japan (IEEJ), Japan

Report of G20 Indonesian Presidency on Energy Transition Working Group&nbsp;

Mr Prahoro Yulianto Nurtjahyo, Co-chair of the G20 Energy Transition Working Group, MEMR, Indonesia
PHOTO SESSION




11:15 AM &ndash; 12:15 PM


Session 1: Implication of Russia-Ukraine Conflict on Short- to Mid-Term Energy Security 
Moderated by:

Prof Basil M. H. Sharp, Professor, Chair in Energy Economics, Department of Economics, Faculty of Business and Economics, The University of Auckland (UoA)

Panelists:&nbsp;

Present Situation of Impact and Trends in Policies&nbsp;

Mr Keisuke Sadamori, Director, Energy Markets and Security, International Energy Agency (IEA)

Uneasiness of Importing Countries, Pursuing for Low Prices, and LNG Import has challenged

Mr Michael O. Sinocruz, OIC-Director, Energy Policy and Planning Bureau, Department of Energy (DOE), Philippines

Exploring Alternatives to Russian Crude Oil and LNG 

Dr Woongtae Chung, Director of International Cooperation Research Center, Korea Energy Economics Institute (KEEI), Republic of Korea (TBC)

Potential for Increasing Export of LNG and Crude Oil 

Mr Lucian Pugliaresi, President, Energy Policy Research Foundation (EPRINC), United States
Key questions

Impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflicts on the current and projected energy situation.
How will the Russia-Ukraine conflict influence energy security concerns in the EAS region? Are there any changes in energy strategies responding to the conflict? What are the pragmatic short- to mid-term strategies for EAS countries?





12:15 PM &ndash; 1:15 PM


Lunch Break




1:15 PM &ndash; 2:00 PM


Session 2: Aligning Climate Action with Energy Security in EAS Region 
Moderated by:

Dr Asclepias Rachmi Soerjono Indriyanto, Chairperson of Executive Board, Indonesian Institute for Energy Economics (IIEE), Indonesia [ERIN Member]

Panelists:

Glasglow Climate Fact and Its Implication to ASEAN

Prof Jun Arima,&nbsp;Senior Policy Fellow for Energy and Environment, ERIA

Low Carbonization of Coal-fired Power Plants, and Need for Low-cost Gas 

Mr A. K. Saxena, Senior Fellow and Senior Director of Electricity and Fuels Division, The Energy and Resources Institute (TERI), India (Alternate ERIN Member)

Decarbonization Path based on Actual Situation of ASEAN Countries, and Results of AETI 

Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, Energy Unit, Research Department, ERIA
Key questions

Integrated strategies for energy security and climate protection.
What are the accessible and affordable options for EAS countries both in terms of energy security and GHG mitigation? What kind of investment will be required along the time horizon?





2:15 PM &ndash; 2:45 PM


Break




2:45 PM &ndash; 3:45 PM


Session 3: Necessary Policies and Initiatives for Energy Security and Climate Action in EAS Region 
Moderated by:

Dr&nbsp;Siti Indati binti Mustapa, Director of Institute of Energy Policy and Research, Universiti Tenaga Nasional (UNITEN), Malaysia [Co-Chairperson of ERIN]

Scene Setting Presentation of Session 3Overview of this year's G7 Agreement and Its Implications for Asia

Mr Tatsuya Terazawa, Chairman and CEO, The Institute of Energy Economics, Japan (IEEJ), Japan [ERIN Member]

Panelists:

Needs of Asian Developing Countries, and Necessity of Investment to Fossil Energy 

Dr Djoko Siswanto, Secretary General, National Energy Council (NEC), Indonesia

Needs of Asian Developing Countries, and Necessity of Investment to Fossil Energy 

H.E. Mr Victor Jona, Under Secretary of State, Ministry of Mines and Energy (MME), Cambodia [ERIN Member]

Role of Financial Institution 

Mr Florian Kitt, Senior Energy Specialist, Southeast Asia Department, Asia Development Bank (ADB)
Key questions

Gap between the demand for hasty decarbonization and the reality in Asia. What gaps exist? Is investment in fossil energy unnecessary? What policies or initiatives are needed for Asia to address both energy security and GHG mitigation, including in investment and financing?





3:45 PM- 4:00 PM


Closing Remarks 

Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, Director General of Administration, Personnel, &amp; Outreach Departments, ERIA       Hybrid Event Ms Dewi Anggraini dewi.anggraini@eria.org   2022-08-16 0000-00-00 2022-08-16 16 August 2022 2202 tsuguA 61 61-80-2202 00-00-0000 61-80-2202   gro.aire@iniarggna.iwed iniarggnA iweD sM tnevE dirbyH       AIRE ,stnemtrapeD hcaertuO ;pma& ,lennosreP ,noitartsinimdA fo lareneG rotceriD ,reciffO gnitarepO feihC ,amayihcaH ijoK rM

Investment, and Industry G20 WG Trade, Investment, and Industry        Hybrid Event Ms Catherin Nur Safitri catherin.safitri@eria.org   2022-07-06 2022-07-07 2022-07-06 6 July 2022 2202 yluJ 6 60-70-2202 70-70-2202 60-70-2202   gro.aire@irtifas.nirehtac irtifaS ruN nirehtaC sM tnevE dirbyH        yrtsudnI dna ,tnemtsevnI ,edarT GW 02G yrtsudnI dna ,tnemtsevnI ,edarT GW 02G";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-30 11:17:10";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-06-30 11:17:10";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:25:"catherin.safitri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:94;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6862";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:118:"the-high-level-forum-on-trade-investment-and-industry-hlf-on-tii-g20-trade-investment-and-industry-working-group-tiiwg";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:127:"The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (HLF on TII): G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG)";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-26";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:7782:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_July_G20-High-Level_800x450_2.jpg" alt="" width="480" height="679" /></p><p>The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (The HLF on TII) is a side event that will support the discussion on the priority issues of the G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG) Indonesia. Under the G20 Indonesia Presidency, the G20 Members hold the privilege to shape global trade policies for sustainable and inclusive recovery and growth, representing interests within and beyond its member countries. As reflected in Indonesia presidency theme of &#039;Recover Together, Recover Stronger&#039;, we must ensure that the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is the forefront agenda for G20 members.</p><p>In the two years after the pandemic, the global economy has continued to recover, but many factors are impacting the pace of the recovery. This includes the rising food and energy prices, the spread of COVID-19 variants, supply chain disruptions, and growing geopolitical tensions. Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic has wiped-out years of progress in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). While global recovery continues, it remains uneven and insufficient to reverse the economic and social consequences of the pandemic, especially for people living in vulnerable situations.</p><p>As the foundation of collective economic recovery, this event will take the opportunity to cooperate and discuss in a fruitful way with all G20 Members to align the Trade, Investment, and Industry agenda with the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).</p><p>The event will gather prominent people from the government and business sector including leading international organizations that will promote constructive discussion on better strategies to promote economic recovery by aligning trade, investment, and industry policies. The outcome of the discussion will strengthen the achievement of G20 TIIWG Indonesia deliverables this year.</p><p>Aside from discussing future economic challenges, the HLF on TII will also discuss enhancing the role of the WTO and Multilateral Trading System (MTS) in achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Additionally, it will discuss on how sustainable investment supports the resilience of the global economic recovery as well as how Industry 4.0 can lead to more inclusive and sustainable industrialization. The forum will also highlight the importance of digital transformation and sustainable development.&nbsp;</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date &amp; Time : Tuesday, 26 July&nbsp; 2022, 19:00 - 20:50 PM and Wednesday, 27 July 2022, 9:00 AM - 13:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li></ul><h2>YouTube Livestream</h2><p><strong>Day 1</strong></p><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/7GP_ySMoBoY" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><p><strong>Day 2</strong></p><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/7xYAQQ3ITaQ" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><h2>Agenda</h2><p><strong>DAY 1 : Tuesday, 26 July&nbsp; 2022</strong></p><table><tr><td width="104"><p>19:00 &ndash; 19:10</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Keynote Speeches</strong></p><ul><li>Airlangga Hartarto, Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs of the Republic of Indonesia</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>19:10 - 19:20</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>19:20 &ndash; 10:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session I</strong></p><p>Subtheme: Economic Recovery: New Normal</p><p><strong>Chair:</strong>&nbsp;M. Chatib Basri, Minister of Finance of Indonesia (2013-2014)</p><p><strong>Panelist:</strong></p><ul><li>Vera Songwe, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA)</li><li>Maurice Obstfeld, Professor of Economics, University of California, Berkeley</li><li>Jayati Ghosh, Professor, University of Massachusetts Amherst, USA</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A session</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>10:00 - 11:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session II</strong></p><p>Subtheme: Digital Transformation: New Technologies</p><p><strong>Chair:</strong>&nbsp;Dani Rodrik, Professor of International Political Economy at Harvard University, and President of the International Economic Association (IEA)</p><p><strong>Panelist:</strong></p><ul><li>Lili Yan Ing, Lead Advisor (Southeast Asia Region), ERIA</li><li>Zia Qureshi, Senior Fellow in the Global Economy and Development Program, Brookings Institute</li><li>Albert Park, Chief Economist, Asian Development Bank (ADB)</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A session</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>11:00 &ndash; 12:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Lunch Break</strong></p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>12:00 &ndash; 13:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session III</strong></p><p>Subtheme: Energy Transition: New Financing</p><p><strong>Chair:</strong>&nbsp;Fauziah Zen, Senior Economist, ERIA</p><p><strong>Panelist:</strong></p><ul><li>Justin Yifu Lin, Professor of Economics, Peking University</li><li>Ishac Diwan, Professor of Economics, Paris School of Economic</li><li>Robert Seung, Chairman of Korindo Group</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A session</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>13:00 &ndash; 13:15</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Djatmiko Bris Witjaksono, Chair of G20 TIIWG Indonesia and Director General of International Trade Negotiation, Ministry of Trade of the Republic of Indonesia</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register via Eventbrite" href="https://g20sideevents.id/register" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:23:"Ms Catherin Nur Safitri";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-26";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-07-27";s:8:"keywords";s:12629:"The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (HLF on TII): G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG) The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (HLF on TII): G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG) The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (The HLF on TII) is a side event that will support the discussion on the priority issues of the G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG) Indonesia. Under the G20 Indonesia Presidency, the G20 Members hold the privilege to shape global trade policies for sustainable and inclusive recovery and growth, representing interests within and beyond its member countries. As reflected in Indonesia presidency theme of 'Recover Together, Recover Stronger', we must ensure that the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is the forefront agenda for G20 members.
In the two years after the pandemic, the global economy has continued to recover, but many factors are impacting the pace of the recovery. This includes the rising food and energy prices, the spread of COVID-19 variants, supply chain disruptions, and growing geopolitical tensions. Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic has wiped-out years of progress in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). While global recovery continues, it remains uneven and insufficient to reverse the economic and social consequences of the pandemic, especially for people living in vulnerable situations.
As the foundation of collective economic recovery, this event will take the opportunity to cooperate and discuss in a fruitful way with all G20 Members to align the Trade, Investment, and Industry agenda with the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
The event will gather prominent people from the government and business sector including leading international organizations that will promote constructive discussion on better strategies to promote economic recovery by aligning trade, investment, and industry policies. The outcome of the discussion will strengthen the achievement of G20 TIIWG Indonesia deliverables this year.
Aside from discussing future economic challenges, the HLF on TII will also discuss enhancing the role of the WTO and Multilateral Trading System (MTS) in achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Additionally, it will discuss on how sustainable investment supports the resilience of the global economic recovery as well as how Industry 4.0 can lead to more inclusive and sustainable industrialization. The forum will also highlight the importance of digital transformation and sustainable development.&nbsp;
Event Details

Date &amp; Time : Tuesday, 26 July&nbsp; 2022, 19:00 - 20:50 PM and Wednesday, 27 July 2022, 9:00 AM - 13:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)

YouTube Livestream
Day 1

Day 2

Agenda
DAY 1 : Tuesday, 26 July&nbsp; 2022




19:00 &ndash; 19:10


Keynote Speeches

Airlangga Hartarto, Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs of the Republic of Indonesia





19:10 - 19:20


Opening Remarks

Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)









19:20 &ndash; 19:35


Remarks

Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, Director General of WTO: 'The outcome of WTO&rsquo;s 12th Ministerial Conference' (TBC)









19:35 &ndash; 19:50


Ministers Speeches by G20 TII Ministerial Meeting (TIIMM) Co-Chairs

Zulkifli Hasan, Minister of Trade of Republic of Indonesia
Bahlil Lahadalia, Minister of Investment of Republic of Indonesia
Agus Gumiwang Kartasasmita, Minister of Industry of Republic of Indonesia









19:50 &ndash; 20:50


Panel Discussion
Moderator:&nbsp;Rahma Alia, News Anchor

Achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) via Stronger, Inclusive and Transparent WTO and Multilateral Trading System (MTS)
The Role of Sustainable and Innovative Investment on Addressing Global Economic and Environment Challenges
Ensuring Sustainable and Resilient Industry through Industry 4.0 to Support Economic Recovery

Panelist:

Jerry Sambuaga, Vice Minister of Trade of Republic of Indonesia
Piyush Goyal, Minister of Commerce and Industry of India (TBC)
Mary Ng, Minister of Small Business, Export Promotion, and International Trade of Canada&nbsp;
Ebrahim Patel, Minister of Trade, Industry and Competition of Republic of South Africa
James Zhan, Director of Division on Investment and Enterprise of UNCTAD
Jaime Moll de Alba, Director of the Department of Programme and Partnership Coordination of UNIDO





DAY 2 : Wednesday, 27 July 2022




09:00 &ndash; 10:00


Session I
Subtheme: Economic Recovery: New Normal
Chair:&nbsp;M. Chatib Basri, Minister of Finance of Indonesia (2013-2014)
Panelist:

Vera Songwe, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA)
Maurice Obstfeld, Professor of Economics, University of California, Berkeley
Jayati Ghosh, Professor, University of Massachusetts Amherst, USA

Q&amp;A session




10:00 - 11:00


Session II
Subtheme: Digital Transformation: New Technologies
Chair:&nbsp;Dani Rodrik, Professor of International Political Economy at Harvard University, and President of the International Economic Association (IEA)
Panelist:

Lili Yan Ing, Lead Advisor (Southeast Asia Region), ERIA
Zia Qureshi, Senior Fellow in the Global Economy and Development Program, Brookings Institute
Albert Park, Chief Economist, Asian Development Bank (ADB)

Q&amp;A session








11:00 &ndash; 12:00


Lunch Break








12:00 &ndash; 13:00


Session III
Subtheme: Energy Transition: New Financing
Chair:&nbsp;Fauziah Zen, Senior Economist, ERIA
Panelist:

Justin Yifu Lin, Professor of Economics, Peking University
Ishac Diwan, Professor of Economics, Paris School of Economic
Robert Seung, Chairman of Korindo Group

Q&amp;A session








13:00 &ndash; 13:15


Closing Remarks

Djatmiko Bris Witjaksono, Chair of G20 TIIWG Indonesia and Director General of International Trade Negotiation, Ministry of Trade of the Republic of Indonesia

Aulia Agustine cindy.augustine@eria.org   2022-07-08 2022-07-08 2022-07-08 8 July 2022 2202 yluJ 8 80-70-2202 80-70-2202 80-70-2202   gro.aire@enitsugua.ydnic enitsugA ailuA ydniC sM aisenodnI ,atrakaygoY        'noitacollA ksiR elbatiuqE' )RII( elbatdnuoR erutcurtsarfnI aisenodnI no tneve edis 02T 'noitacollA ksiR elbatiuqE' )RII( elbatdnuoR erutcurtsarfnI aisenodnI no tneve edis 02T";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-30 10:44:27";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-06-30 10:46:43";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:24:"cindy.augustine@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:96;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6859";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:81:"unpacking-the-rcep-agreement-dialogue-5-customs-procedures-and-trade-facilitation";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:84:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Dialogue #5: Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-14";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:4165:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Event-Reports/2022-07-15-Unpacking-the-RCEP-Agreement-PPD-5-Photo-Flyer-FinalRev.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement among the 15 member states. The RCEP Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation Provisions aims to foster and to ensure predictability, consistency, and transparency in the application of customs laws and regulations. The participating members is also envisaged to provide trade facilitation measures related to import to import, export, or transit formalities and procedures in order to strengthen environment for global and regional supply chains. The ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme with the General Department of Customs and Excise (GDCE) will co-host a &lsquo;Public-Private Dialogues: Unpacking the RCEP Agreement#5- Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation&#039; on 14 July. This session will enable different business interests to assess their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP chapter on customs procedures and trade facilitation could be a game changer in the services industry. Join us to glean insights from the line-up of government officials and private sectors.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 14 July 2022</li><li>Time: 9 AM -&nbsp; 11:30 AM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;</li></ul><table><tr><td width="104"><p>9:00 &ndash; 9:15</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Opening Remarks:</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building, ERIA</li><li>PHA Eng Veng, Deputy Director-General, General Department of Customs and Excise (GDCE)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>9:15 - 10:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation Provision</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA</p><p><strong>Presenters:</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Robin Flint, First Secretary, Australian Embassy Phnom Penh</li><li>Mrs OUK Chansopheap, Chief of Free Trade Office, Department of International Customs Cooperation, GDCE</li><li>Mr Noy Sophannareth, Deputy Chief of Office, IT Department, Department of International Customs Cooperation, GDCE</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>10:00 &ndash; 11:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 2: Private Sector Perspectives on Opportunities for Improving Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation in Cambodia through RCEP Provision</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA</p><p><strong>Panelist:</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Sebastian Cortes Sanchez, Deputy Director, Asian Trade Centre</li><li>Mr Kouch Pheng, Executive Director, Triumph Link Logistics, Co-Chair of Customs-Private Partnership Mechanism Technical Working Group 3</li><li>Mr Prayag Chitrakar, Country Manager, DHL Express Cambodia</li><li>Regional expert</li><li>PHA Eng Veng, Deputy Director General, General Department of Customs and Excise (GDCE)</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p><p>This session will enable different business interests to assess their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP chapter on customs procedures and trade facilitation could be a game changer in the services industry.</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>11:00 -11:15</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation</strong></p><ul><li>HE Sok Siphana, Senior Adviser to the Royal Government of Cambodia</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.<strong>&nbsp;</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>11:15 &ndash; 11:30</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Closing remarks by&nbsp;GDCE and ERIA</strong></p></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register via Eventbrite" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/customs-procedures-and-trade-facilitation-tickets-380152585617" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-14";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6923:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Dialogue #5: Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Dialogue #5: Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement among the 15 member states. The RCEP Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation Provisions aims to foster and to ensure predictability, consistency, and transparency in the application of customs laws and regulations. The participating members is also envisaged to provide trade facilitation measures related to import to import, export, or transit formalities and procedures in order to strengthen environment for global and regional supply chains. The ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme with the General Department of Customs and Excise (GDCE) will co-host a &lsquo;Public-Private Dialogues: Unpacking the RCEP Agreement#5- Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation' on 14 July. This session will enable different business interests to assess their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP chapter on customs procedures and trade facilitation could be a game changer in the services industry. Join us to glean insights from the line-up of government officials and private sectors.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 14 July 2022
Time: 9 AM -&nbsp; 11:30 AM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;





9:00 &ndash; 9:15


Opening Remarks:

Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building, ERIA
PHA Eng Veng, Deputy Director-General, General Department of Customs and Excise (GDCE)





9:15 - 10:00


Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation Provision
Moderator:&nbsp;Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA
Presenters:

Mr Robin Flint, First Secretary, Australian Embassy Phnom Penh
Mrs OUK Chansopheap, Chief of Free Trade Office, Department of International Customs Cooperation, GDCE
Mr Noy Sophannareth, Deputy Chief of Office, IT Department, Department of International Customs Cooperation, GDCE

Q&amp;A with the audience.




10:00 &ndash; 11:00


Session 2: Private Sector Perspectives on Opportunities for Improving Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation in Cambodia through RCEP Provision
Moderator:&nbsp;Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA
Panelist:

Mr Sebastian Cortes Sanchez, Deputy Director, Asian Trade Centre
Mr Kouch Pheng, Executive Director, Triumph Link Logistics, Co-Chair of Customs-Private Partnership Mechanism Technical Working Group 3
Mr Prayag Chitrakar, Country Manager, DHL Express Cambodia
Regional expert
PHA Eng Veng, Deputy Director General, General Department of Customs and Excise (GDCE)

Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will enable different business interests to assess their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP chapter on customs procedures and trade facilitation could be a game changer in the services industry.




11:00 -11:15


Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on Customs Procedures and Trade Facilitation

HE Sok Siphana, Senior Adviser to the Royal Government of Cambodia

Q&amp;A with the audience.&nbsp;




11:15 &ndash; 11:30


Closing remarks by&nbsp;GDCE and ERIA

Financing'";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-20";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:9048:"<p data-key="92"><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/2022-07-20-TF3-workshop-flyer-800x450.jpg" alt="" width="850" height="425" /></p><p data-key="92"><span data-key="93">The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency&rsquo;s Energy Transition pillar of &lsquo;Global cleaner energy systems and just transitions&rsquo; aims at achieving a global deal to accelerate the energy transition. G20 Indonesia Presidency has opted, therefore, for its pathway to achieve the carbon neutrality target by accelerating the just process of reducing energy-related greenhouse gas emissions through various forms of decarbonisation. Such decarbonisation means an additional investment is necessary. Nevertheless, the question remains: how to finance the energy transition, especially in the context of reaching carbon neutrality pledges that vary across G20 countries?</span></p><p data-key="94"><span data-key="95">Apart from traditional financial and policy instruments, countries need also to fully employ new and innovative schemes to support clean energy financing and markets. This virtual workshop aims to explore workable financing mechanisms in each technology cluster (including renewable energy resources and their carriers, CCS/CCUS, and Direct Air Capture technologies) that play important roles in the energy transition with an emphasis on the ASEAN countries.</span></p><p data-key="99" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="100">This Virtual Workshop is jointly organised by the Institute of Economic and Social Research Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Indonesia (LPEM-FEB UI) and Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA). </span></p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Wednesday, 20 July 2022</li><li>Time: 2 PM -&nbsp; 4:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><p><strong>Opening Remarks:</strong> Ms Moekti Handajani Soejachmoen (Kuki), Lead Co-Chair of the T20-Task Force 3: Governing Climate Target, Energy Transition, and environmental Protection</p><p>Keynote speech 1: Carbon Neutral Pathway of Indonesia</p><p>Keynote Speech 2: Global Low Carbon Energy Transition by Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow of ERIA and Co-Chair of TF3</p><p><strong>Presentations and Panel Discussion</strong></p><p>Moderator: Dr. Alin Halimatussadiah, LPEM FEB University of Indonesia</p><p><strong>Presentation 1: Energy Technology Perspective (Battery electric storage, Hydrogen/ Ammonia, CCS/CCUS, and Direct Air Capture)</strong></p><ul><li>Battery electric storage: Akira Yasugi, P.E. Engineering manager, I&amp;C and Electrical Engineering Team, Power Plant engineering Group, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd</li><li>Hydrogen/Ammonia: Jitendra Roychoudhury, King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center (KAPSARC), Riyadh, Saudi Arabia</li><li>CCS (Capture)</li><li>CCS (Storage): Dr. Ziqiu Xue, Research Institute for Innovative Technologies for the Earth (RITE)</li><li>Direct Air Capture: Ryohei Numaguchi, Ph.D., Researcher, Energy System Research Department, Corporate Technology Division, Kawasaki Heavy Industry, Ltd.</li></ul><p><strong>Presentation 2: Energy Financing (Public, Private and Climate Finance Mechanisms)</strong></p><ul><li>Public Finance : Darshak Mehta, Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)</li><li>Private Finance: Yukimi Shimura, Director, Sustainable Business Origination team, Sustainable Business Office, Solution Products Division, MUFJ Bank, Ltd.</li><li>Climate Financing: Room";s:5:"major";s:16:"Ms Dian Lutfiana";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-20";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:7905:"T20 side event webinar on 'Emerging Economies towards Net Zero Emission: Challenges and Opportunities on Technology Innovation and Financing' T20 side event webinar on 'Emerging Economies towards Net Zero Emission: Challenges and Opportunities on Technology Innovation and Financing' The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency&rsquo;s Energy Transition pillar of &lsquo;Global cleaner energy systems and just transitions&rsquo; aims at achieving a global deal to accelerate the energy transition. G20 Indonesia Presidency has opted, therefore, for its pathway to achieve the carbon neutrality target by accelerating the just process of reducing energy-related greenhouse gas emissions through various forms of decarbonisation. Such decarbonisation means an additional investment is necessary. Nevertheless, the question remains: how to finance the energy transition, especially in the context of reaching carbon neutrality pledges that vary across G20 countries?
Apart from traditional financial and policy instruments, countries need also to fully employ new and innovative schemes to support clean energy financing and markets. This virtual workshop aims to explore workable financing mechanisms in each technology cluster (including renewable energy resources and their carriers, CCS/CCUS, and Direct Air Capture technologies) that play important roles in the energy transition with an emphasis on the ASEAN countries.
This Virtual Workshop is jointly organised by the Institute of Economic and Social Research Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Indonesia (LPEM-FEB UI) and Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA). 
Event Details

Date: Wednesday, 20 July 2022
Time: 2 PM -&nbsp; 4:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;

Agenda
Opening Remarks: Ms Moekti Handajani Soejachmoen (Kuki), Lead Co-Chair of the T20-Task Force 3: Governing Climate Target, Energy Transition, and environmental Protection
Keynote speech 1: Carbon Neutral Pathway of Indonesia
Keynote Speech 2: Global Low Carbon Energy Transition by Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow of ERIA and Co-Chair of TF3
Presentations and Panel Discussion
Moderator: Dr. Alin Halimatussadiah, LPEM FEB University of Indonesia
Presentation 1: Energy Technology Perspective (Battery electric storage, Hydrogen/ Ammonia, CCS/CCUS, and Direct Air Capture)

Battery electric storage: Akira Yasugi, P.E. Engineering manager, I&amp;C and Electrical Engineering Team, Power Plant engineering Group, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd
Hydrogen/Ammonia: Jitendra Roychoudhury, King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center (KAPSARC), Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
CCS (Capture)
CCS (Storage): Dr. Ziqiu Xue, Research Institute for Innovative Technologies for the Earth (RITE)
Direct Air Capture: Ryohei Numaguchi, Ph.D., Researcher, Energy System Research Department, Corporate Technology Division, Kawasaki Heavy Industry, Ltd.

Presentation 2: Energy Financing (Public, Private and Climate Finance Mechanisms)

Public Finance : Darshak Mehta, Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)
Private Finance: Yukimi Shimura, Director, Sustainable Business Origination team, Sustainable Business Office, Solution Products Division, MUFJ Bank, Ltd.
Climate Financing: Frank Jotzo (Australian National University)
Carbon Credit: Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher, Climate Change Solution Group, Sustainability Division, Mitsubishi Research Institute, Inc.

Panel Discussion: Dialogue between Energy Technology and Financing Group, with topics:

Role of financing for supporting energy technology development and deployment
Expectations to Governments
Comments from the energy technology group
Comments from the financing group

Closing Remarks: Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, ERIA

ffo-kciK";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-29 10:51:45";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-06-29 10:52:59";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:20:"ulfah.aulia@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:104;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6850";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:79:"inclusive-education-in-asean-fostering-belonging-for-students-with-disabilities";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:80:"Inclusive Education in ASEAN: Fostering Belonging for Students with Disabilities";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-21";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:3719:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Event-Reports/2022_July_Flyer_Inclusive_Education_800x450_1.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p>Education systems provide students, who are diverse learners and come from various economic backgrounds, with the unique opportunity to learn skills for the future. It also provides an environment for students to come together and learn from each other. Creating inclusive education systems and environments should be a key focus of education policies, where opportunities abound for all students, including those with different physical and intellectual abilities to have the necessary tools to flourish.</p><p>The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia, ERIA, partnered with Rubeena Singh and conducted a study on inclusive education practices in primary and secondary schools in the ASEAN region and select countries in East Asia. This dissemination event shared will share the key findings from the recently published ERIA&rsquo;s research project report. Join us for this special session where we will share more about the report and where we engage our panel of enlightening speakers in an afternoon of conversations.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 21 July&nbsp; 2022</li><li>Time: 3 PM - 4:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 618px;"><tr><td style="width: 126.2px;"><p><strong>TIME (UTC+7)</strong></p></td><td style="width: 477.8px;"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>3.00PM &ndash; 3:02PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p>Start of Webinar</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>3:02PM - 3:06PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p>Opening Remarks:&nbsp;Antonella Noya, Head of Social Economy and Innovation OECD</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>3:06PM &ndash; 3:10PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p>Opening Remarks: Adrian Gilbert, First Secretary, Australian Mission to ASEAN</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 129.538px;"><p>3:10PM - 3:30PM</p></td><td style="width: 466.462px;"><p>Presentation on Report - Fostering Inclusion in ASEAN: Rubeena Singh, Manager (Research and Knowledge), Kite Insights, Author, ERIA Report on Inclusive Education</p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 129.45px;"><p>3:30PM - 4:00PM</p></td><td style="width: 467.55px;"><p>Panel Discussion</p><p>Speakers:&nbsp;</p><ul><li>Rubeena Singh, Manager (Research and Knowledge),&nbsp;Kite Insights,&nbsp;Author, ERIA Report on Inclusive Education</li><li>Dr Darren Chua, Inspirational Speaker and Empowerment Coach, Mindset Transformation Clinic</li><li>Dr Tze Peng Wong, Associate Professor, University of Nottingham Malaysia</li><li>Dr Roger Chao, Jr., Assistant Director and Head Education, Youth and Sports Division, Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Secretariat, Indonesia</li></ul><p>Moderator: TJ Ooi, Lead Consultant, E-S-I Knowledge Lab</p></td></tr></table><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 128.562px;"><p>4:00PM - 4:15PM</p></td><td style="width: 468.55px;"><p>Closing Remarks:&nbsp;E-S-I Knowledge Lab</p></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register via Eventbrite" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/inclusive-education-in-asean-fostering-belonging-for-students-with-disabil-tickets-380190137937" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-21";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:5429:"Inclusive Education in ASEAN: Fostering Belonging for Students with Disabilities Inclusive Education in ASEAN: Fostering Belonging for Students with Disabilities Education systems provide students, who are diverse learners and come from various economic backgrounds, with the unique opportunity to learn skills for the future. It also provides an environment for students to come together and learn from each other. Creating inclusive education systems and environments should be a key focus of education policies, where opportunities abound for all students, including those with different physical and intellectual abilities to have the necessary tools to flourish.
The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia, ERIA, partnered with Rubeena Singh and conducted a study on inclusive education practices in primary and secondary schools in the ASEAN region and select countries in East Asia. This dissemination event shared will share the key findings from the recently published ERIA&rsquo;s research project report. Join us for this special session where we will share more about the report and where we engage our panel of enlightening speakers in an afternoon of conversations.

Level Dialogue on ASEAN Italy Economic Relations";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-05";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:0:"";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:22:"Kuala ASEAN Italy Economic Relations High Level Dialogue on ASEAN Italy Economic Relations        Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia Ms Denise Ann denise.ann@eria.org   2022-07-05 0000-00-00 2022-07-05 5 July 2022 2202 yluJ 5 50-70-2202 00-00-0000 50-70-2202   gro.aire@nna.esined nnA esineD sM aisyalaM ,rupmuL alauK        snoitaleR cimonocE ylatI NAESA no eugolaiD leveL hgiH snoitaleR cimonocE ylatI NAESA no eugolaiD leveL hgiH";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-29 10:46:20";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-06-30 10:46:22";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:19:"denise.ann@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:107;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6843";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:64:"dare-to-start-addressing-gender-gaps-in-entrepreneurship-in-asia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:65:"Dare to Start: Addressing Gender Gaps in Entrepreneurship in Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-05";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:12150:"<p data-key="193"><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/2022_July_Dare%20to%20Start-%20Addressing%20Gender%20Gaps%20in%20Entrepreneurship%20in%20Asia_flyer_rev2.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p data-key="193">Entrepreneurs are an engine of economic growth (ERIA 2022). Addressing gaps between men and women entrepreneurs can increase innovation, create jobs, improve productivity, boost competitiveness, and grow wealth. In emerging Asia, recent rapid economic growth has led to remarkably improved socio-economic conditions, with expanded and enhanced employment opportunities, improved educational attainment, gradually rising wages and better living standards. Nevertheless, gender gap persists in many areas including entrepreneurship according to metrics such as self-employment rates and business creation rates. There are also gender differences, on average, in the nature of self-employment and entrepreneurship activities (ERIA 2021). This includes sector of operation, likelihood of creating additional jobs and more. Due consideration should be paid in terms of gender gaps in motivations or different barriers they face. Following the launch of ERIA&rsquo;s Entrepreneurship, Start-ups, and Innovation (E-S-I) Knowledge Lab as part of its ongoing efforts to engage the growing community of innovators, aspiring entrepreneurs, and start-uppers in the region, this seminar aims to convene a blend of expertise and knowledge regarding the region, data, policy, education and gender issues, to identify ways to address potential structural and emerging challenges that are hampering women&rsquo;s entrepreneurship. This will also set the path for the future work of E-S-I Knowledge Lab on women entrepreneurship.</p><p data-key="193"><span data-key="194"><strong data-slate-leaf="true">Agenda</strong></span></p><p data-key="195"><span data-key="196">Moderator: Jui Chakravorty, Special Projects Editor, Nikkei Asia</span></p><p data-key="197"><span data-key="198">Opening Remarks: Toru Furuichi, Director General for Research and Policy Design Administration, ERIA</span></p><p data-key="199"><span data-key="200">Moderated Panel Discussion </span></p><ul data-key="201"><li data-key="202"><span data-key="203">Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director, Strategy and Partnership, ERIA </span></li><li data-key="204"><span data-key="205">Naoko Kawaguchi, Acting Head of the Tokyo Centre, OECD </span></li><li data-key="206"><span data-key="207">Natalie Au, Senior Associate, Gender Platform, Asian Ventre Philanthropy Network (AVPN) </span></li><li data-key="208"><span data-key="209">Kanyasorn Tansubhapol, Assistant to the President for Special Affairs, Chulalongkorn University</span></li></ul><p data-key="210" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="211">Wrap up: Jui Chakravorty, Special Projects Editor, Nikkei Asia</span></p><p data-key="210" data-slate-fragment=""><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register via Eventbrite" href="https://bit.ly/3QUh1um" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:19:"Mr Fusanori Iwasaki";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:26:"ERIA and OECD Tokyo Centre";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-05";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4757:"Dare to Start: Addressing Gender Gaps in Entrepreneurship in Asia Dare to Start: Addressing Gender Gaps in Entrepreneurship in Asia Entrepreneurs are an engine of economic growth (ERIA 2022). Addressing gaps between men and women entrepreneurs can increase innovation, create jobs, improve productivity, boost competitiveness, and grow wealth. In emerging Asia, recent rapid economic growth has led to remarkably improved socio-economic conditions, with expanded and enhanced employment opportunities, improved educational attainment, gradually rising wages and better living standards. Nevertheless, gender gap persists in many areas including entrepreneurship according to metrics such as self-employment rates and business creation rates. There are also gender differences, on average, in the nature of self-employment and entrepreneurship activities (ERIA 2021). This includes sector of operation, likelihood of creating additional jobs and more. Due consideration should be paid in terms of gender gaps in motivations or different barriers they face. Following the launch of ERIA&rsquo;s Entrepreneurship, Start-ups, and Innovation (E-S-I) Knowledge Lab as part of its ongoing efforts to engage the growing community of innovators, aspiring entrepreneurs, and start-uppers in the region, this seminar aims to convene a blend of expertise and knowledge regarding the region, data, policy, education and gender issues, to identify ways to address potential structural and emerging challenges that are hampering women&rsquo;s entrepreneurship. This will also set the path for the future work of E-S-I Knowledge Lab on women entrepreneurship.
Agenda
Moderator: Jui Chakravorty, Special Projects Editor, Nikkei Asia

:tratS ot eraD aisA ni pihsruenerpertnE ni spaG redneG gnisserddA :tratS ot eraD";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-27 12:47:29";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-07-05 12:11:53";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:25:"fusanori.iwasaki@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:108;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6840";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:83:"data-release-of-the-2018-longitudinal-study-of-ageing-and-health-in-the-philippines";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:83:"Data release of the 2018 Longitudinal Study of Ageing and Health in the Philippines";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-07";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:4069:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/2022-07-07-Data-release-flyer-rev.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p><span style="font-size: 16px;"><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/longitudinal-study-of-ageing-and-health-in-the-philippines-data-release-tickets-373063913207" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></span></p><p>The Longitudinal Study of Ageing and Health in the Philippines (LSAHP) in 2018 is the first multi-actor longitudinal study on ageing in the Philippines with information coming from older Filipinos, their caregivers, and adult children. It was conducted by ERIA and the Demographic Research and Development Foundation, Inc. (DRDF).</p><p>The 2018 baseline data provides comprehensive information on the health, economic status, and overall well-being of a nationally representative sample of elderly Filipinos aged 60 and above. These data have been a valuable resource for the crafting of evidence-based policies and programmes for this sector of the population.</p><p>Now, ERIA and DRDF are releasing the data of the baseline survey with researchers and policymakers in order to further develop this data to achieve a better society. This webinar is being held to explain the details of the survey and data, with an introduction on how to use it. Some examples of policy-related research will be shared, encouraging participants to utilise the data for impactful achievements. The data is expected to be released soon after the event, to those who the organiser approves after submitting a proposal and signed data usage agreement. The data request form will be activated as soon as this seminar has ended.</p><h2>Date and Time</h2><p>7 July 2022 / 2 PM to 3 PM&nbsp;(GMT+7)</p><h2>Co-host</h2><p>Demographic Research and Development Foundation, Inc. (DRDF)</p><h2>&nbsp;Agenda</h2><p>Hosted by the Healthcare Unit and Communications Department of ERIA and DRDF, the virtual conference will last 1 hour via Zoom platform with a 10-minute introduction and short Q&amp;A at the end.</p><p>During the presentations, the audience may post questions through Q&amp;A. (Chat will be locked.)</p><p>Moderator: Dr Joy Cruz, PhDcip</p><table style="width: 612px;"><tr style="height: 43px;"><td style="height: 43px; width: 158.248px;"><p><strong>TIME </strong>(WIB)</p></td><td style="height: 43px; width: 439.752px;"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 41px;"><td style="height: 41px; width: 158.248px;"><p>2&nbsp;PM to 2:10 PM</p></td><td style="height: 41px; width: 439.752px;"><p>Opening remarks:</p><ul><li>Dr Takuma Kato, Director of Healthcare Unit, ERIA</li><li>Dr&nbsp;Yasuhiko Saito, Senior Advisor on Population Ageing, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 210px;"><td style="height: 210px; width: 158.248px;"><p>2:10 PM to 2:35 PM</p></td><td style="height: 210px; width: 439.752px;"><p>Seminar Part 1: Dr. Grace T. The Longitudinal Study of Ageing and Health in the Philippines (LSAHP) in 2018 is the first multi-actor longitudinal study on ageing in the Philippines with information coming from older Filipinos, their caregivers, and adult children. It was conducted by ERIA and the Demographic Research and Development Foundation, Inc. (DRDF).
The 2018 baseline data provides comprehensive information on the health, economic status, and overall well-being of a nationally representative sample of elderly Filipinos aged 60 and above. These data have been a valuable resource for the crafting of evidence-based policies and programmes for this sector of the population.
Now, ERIA and DRDF are releasing the data of the baseline survey with researchers and policymakers in order to further develop this data to achieve a better society. This webinar is being held to explain the details of the survey and data, with an introduction on how to use it. Some examples of policy-related research will be shared, encouraging participants to utilise the data for impactful achievements. The data is expected to be released soon after the event, to those who the organiser approves after submitting a proposal and signed data usage agreement. The data request form will be activated as soon as this seminar has ended.
Date and Time
7 July 2022 / 2 PM to 3 PM&nbsp;(GMT+7)
Co-host
Demographic Research and Development Foundation, Inc. (DRDF)
&nbsp;Agenda
Hosted by the Healthcare Unit and Communications Department of ERIA and DRDF, the virtual conference will last 1 hour via Zoom platform with a 10-minute introduction and short Q&amp;A at the end.
During the presentations, the audience may post questions through Q&amp;A. (Chat will be locked.)
Moderator: Dr Joy Cruz, PhDcip

LSAHP Findings as Policy and Program Inputs

Data User Agreement and Research Proposal
LSAHP Sampling Weights
