.)FDRD( .cnI ,noitadnuoF tnempoleveD dna hcraeseR cihpargomeD eht dna AIRE yb detcudnoc saw tI .nerdlihc tluda dna ,srevigerac rieht ,sonipiliF redlo morf gnimoc noitamrofni htiw senippilihP eht ni gniega no yduts lanidutignol rotca-itlum tsrif eht si 8102 ni )PHASL( senippilihP eht ni htlaeH dna gniegA fo ydutS lanidutignoL ehT
!woN retsigeR senippilihP eht ni htlaeH dna gniegA fo ydutS lanidutignoL 8102 eht fo esaeler ataD senippilihP eht ni htlaeH dna gniegA fo ydutS lanidutignoL 8102 eht fo esaeler ataD";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-24 07:53:01";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-07-05 15:45:50";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:20:"nanda.putri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:109;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6824";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:73:"unpacking-the-rcep-agreement-public-private-dialogue-series-4--investment";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:75:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series #4- Investment";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-06-29";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"6";s:7:"content";s:3892:"<p><strong>Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series - Dialogue #4</strong></p><p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/2022_June_Unpacking-RCEP-Agreement-Public-Private-Dialogue-4_1.jpg" alt="" width="850" height="425" /></p><p>The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement among the 15 member states. The RCEP Investment Provisions aims to foster the investment ecosystem across ASEAN and relevant RCEP participating countries. Investment has become a significant driver of economic growth over the years, especially when most RCEP countries face economic fallout due to COVID-19. Thus, facilitating a conducive investment ecosystem for all stakeholders is crucial to fostering the region&rsquo;s more attractive and viable market. The ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme with the Secretary-General of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC) will co-host a &lsquo;Public-Private Dialogues: Unpacking the RCEP Agreement#4- Investment&#039; on 29 June. This dialogue will discuss the RCEP Investment Provision in order to unpack different business interests in assessing their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP chapter on investment could be a game-changer in the services industry. Join us to glean insights from the line-up of government officials and private sectors.</p><table><tr><td width="104"><p>09:00 &ndash; 09:25</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Opening Remarks:</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li><li><p>H.E. Sok Chenda Sophea, Minister attached to the Prime Minister, Secretary-General of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC)</p></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>09:25 - 10:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Investment Provisions </strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA</p><p><strong>Presenters:</strong></p><ul><li>Ms Deborah ELMS, Founder and CEO, Asian Trade Centre</li><li>Dr. SAR Senera, Director, Department of Legal Affairs and Investment Law, Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC)</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p><p>This session will provide a precise description of what the RCEP provisions on investment are, how they apply to future investors in Cambodia and how Cambodia&rsquo;s legal and regulatory environment for FDI is fit-for-purpose.</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>10:00 &ndash; 11:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 2: Private sector perspectives on opportunities for Investing in Cambodia through RCEP provisions</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA</p><p><strong>Panellists:</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Paul Clements, Executive Chairperson, IBC</li><li>Mr Soreasmey Ke Bin, CEO Confluences and Chairman CCIFC</li><li>Mr Kenneth Tang, CEO Dynamic Group and Chairman, Auscham Cambodia</li><li>Mr Harrison White, CEO, Cambodia Investment Review</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p><p>This session will explore how the RCEP chapter on investment could be a game changer for Cambodia to attract FDI in priority sectors from RCEP members.</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>11:05 -11:15</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on Investment in Cambodia</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Clint O&rsquo;Connell, DFDL.</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.<strong>&nbsp;</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="104">&nbsp;</td><td width="497">&nbsp;</td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/unpacking-the-rcep-agreement-4-investment-tickets-367339019897" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-06-29";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-06-29";s:8:"keywords";s:6539:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series #4- Investment Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series #4- Investment Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series - Dialogue #4

The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement among the 15 member states. The RCEP Investment Provisions aims to foster the investment ecosystem across ASEAN and relevant RCEP participating countries. Investment has become a significant driver of economic growth over the years, especially when most RCEP countries face economic fallout due to COVID-19. Thus, facilitating a conducive investment ecosystem for all stakeholders is crucial to fostering the region&rsquo;s more attractive and viable market. The ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme with the Secretary-General of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC) will co-host a &lsquo;Public-Private Dialogues: Unpacking the RCEP Agreement#4- Investment' on 29 June. This dialogue will discuss the RCEP Investment Provision in order to unpack different business interests in assessing their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP chapter on investment could be a game-changer in the services industry. Join us to glean insights from the line-up of government officials and private sectors.




09:00 &ndash; 09:25


Opening Remarks:

Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)

H.E. Sok Chenda Sophea, Minister attached to the Prime Minister, Secretary-General of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC)






09:25 - 10:00


Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Investment Provisions 
Moderator:&nbsp;Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA
Presenters:

Ms Deborah ELMS, Founder and CEO, Asian Trade Centre
Dr. SAR Senera, Director, Department of Legal Affairs and Investment Law, Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC)

Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will provide a precise description of what the RCEP provisions on investment are, how they apply to future investors in Cambodia and how Cambodia&rsquo;s legal and regulatory environment for FDI is fit-for-purpose.




10:00 &ndash; 11:00


Session 2: Private sector perspectives on opportunities for Investing in Cambodia through RCEP provisions
Moderator:&nbsp;Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA
Panellists:

Mr Paul Clements, Executive Chairperson, IBC
Mr Soreasmey Ke Bin, CEO Confluences and Chairman CCIFC
Mr Kenneth Tang, CEO Dynamic Group and Chairman, Auscham Cambodia
Mr Harrison White, CEO, Cambodia Investment Review

Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will explore how the RCEP chapter on investment could be a game changer for Cambodia to attract FDI in priority sectors from RCEP members.




11:05 -11:15


Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on Investment in Cambodia

Mr Clint O&rsquo;Connell, DFDL.

Q&amp;A with the audience.&nbsp;

The COVID-19 pandemic has posed severe impacts, exposed the lacking in the current food system, and provide opportunities to take actions beyond business as usual. In 2021, the G20 put forward Matera Declaration on Food Security, Nutrition and Food System which strengthens the G20 commitment in contributing to SDG 2 (End Hunger) target through multi-sector advancement actions and policies. Among many, we underscore the importance of accelerating digital transformation and increasing catalytic investment, especially the rural financing, for the agriculture which are some of the main challenges and to-be-seen as opportunities faced by farmers in the developing countries.</p><p>Digital agriculture/farming enables the increasing the efficiency of agriculture production and permits to increase market opportunities. This approach will transform farming through better prediction, more precise management, and improve value chains. Broadening opportunities stimulate 5 increasing participation of more actors to the agriculture supply chain, including women and youth in rural areas.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Tuesday, 28 June&nbsp; 2022 - Wednesday, 29 June 2022&nbsp;</li><li>Time: 3.30 PM -&nbsp; 6:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://linktr.ee/awg_dwg_webinar" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:27:"Ms Abigail Gracia Balthazar";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-06-28";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-06-29";s:8:"keywords";s:3471:"Enhancing Digital Agriculture and Rural Finance for  Food Security Enhancing Digital Agriculture and Rural Finance for  Food Security Joint Webinar between Agriculture Working Group (AWG) and Development Working Group (DWG) on G-20 Agenda

To end hunger and achieve food security, especially amid the time of crises, it requires a cross-sectoral and holistic approach. The COVID-19 pandemic has posed severe impacts, exposed the lacking in the current food system, and provide opportunities to take actions beyond business as usual. In 2021, the G20 put forward Matera Declaration on Food Security, Nutrition and Food System which strengthens the G20 commitment in contributing to SDG 2 (End Hunger) target through multi-sector advancement actions and policies. Among many, we underscore the importance of accelerating digital transformation and increasing catalytic investment, especially the rural financing, for the agriculture which are some of the main challenges and to-be-seen as opportunities faced by farmers in the developing countries.
Digital agriculture/farming enables the increasing the efficiency of agriculture production and permits to increase market opportunities. This approach will transform farming through better prediction, more precise management, and improve value chains. Broadening opportunities stimulate 5 increasing participation of more actors to the agriculture supply chain, including women and youth in rural areas.
Event Details

Date: Tuesday, 28 June&nbsp; 2022 - Wednesday, 29 June 2022&nbsp;
Time: 3.30 PM -&nbsp; 6:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;

How can the G20 facilitate inclusive digital transformation in the agricultural sector, especially for developing countries and small-scale farmers?The Center for Transdisciplinary and Sustainability Sciences, University of IPB (CTSS IPB) together with the Smart City &amp; Community Innovation Center of the Bandung Institute of Technology (SCCIC ITB) and supported by the Global Solutions Initiative (GSI) and the Center for Indonesian Policy Studies (CIPS) invite you to this multi-stakeholder forum to discuss digital transformation strategies in the agricultural sector.&nbsp;

Future of Health Innovation in Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-06-16";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"6";s:7:"content";s:1634:"<p><strong>Virtual Conference The Asian Network in Partnership with ERIA</strong></p><p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/The-Future-of-Health-Innovation-in-Asia-_2022_Flyer-2.%5B1%5D.png" alt="" width="465" height="580" /></p><p>Global demographic shifts, environmental degradation and climate change, escalating humanitarian emergencies, technology innovation, and a growing global commitment to a universal right to healthcare are all driving change in different ways.</p><p>The cost of mental health conditions (and related consequences) is projected to rise to $6 trillion globally by 2030, from $2.5 trillion in 2010, according to a study published by the World Economic Forum and the Harvard School of Public Health.</p><p>COVID-19 has magnified gender-based inequalities in health and healthcare, and created a more urgent need to understand the forces undermining women&rsquo;s well-being and resilience.</p><p>This virtual conference will gather 17 Leaders from Asia (India, Indonesia, China, Singapore, Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand and Hong Kong) sharing their expertise in Health &amp; Healthcare, Entrepreneurship, and Technology for Social Good.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 16 June&nbsp; 2022</li><li>Time: 2 PM- 6 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li></ul><p>For further information, please visit: <a href="https://www.runtheworld.today/app/c/thefutureofhealthinAsia">Run The World Events</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="The Future of Health Innovation in Asia" href="https://www.runtheworld.today/app/get-started?from=invitation" target="_blank" rel="noopener NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Health Innovation in Asia The Future of Health Innovation in Asia Virtual Conference The Asian Network in Partnership with ERIA

Global demographic shifts, environmental degradation and climate change, escalating humanitarian emergencies, technology innovation, and a growing global commitment to a universal right to healthcare are all driving change in different ways.
The cost of mental health conditions (and related consequences) is projected to rise to $6 trillion globally by 2030, from $2.5 trillion in 2010, according to a study published by the World Economic Forum and the Harvard School of Public Health.
COVID-19 has magnified gender-based inequalities in health and healthcare, and created a more urgent need to understand the forces undermining women&rsquo;s well-being and resilience.
This virtual conference will gather 17 Leaders from Asia (India, Indonesia, China, Singapore, Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand and Hong Kong) sharing their expertise in Health &amp; Healthcare, Entrepreneurship, and Technology for Social Good.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 16 June&nbsp; 2022
Time: 2 PM- 6 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)

For further information, please visit: Run The World Events

Debris";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-06-23";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"6";s:7:"content";s:1523:"<p><strong>Online Forum hosted by the Mission of the Republic of Korea to ASEAN</strong></p><p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/2022_June_Marine-Plastic-Debris_5.jpg" alt="" width="650" height="919" /></p><p style="margin: 0cm;">Given the growing international and regional concerns on marine plastics, the Mission of the Republic of Korea to ASEAN is hosting an online Forum on marine plastic debris issues in the ASEAN region to suggest the way forward for the international legally binding agreement, in collaboration with the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) of Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) as the organizer of the forum.</p><p style="margin: 0cm;">The event will raise awareness on the current alarming situation surrounding marine plastics and the urgent needs to address this issue internationally; stocktake the prevention and mitigation efforts undertaken by different stakeholders and receive recommendations from them; and formulate policy recommendations to advance the UNEA 5.2 resolution for a legally binding international treaty.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 23 June 2022</li><li>Time: 9 AM -&nbsp; 11:30 AM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZclc-ytrjkpGdXefHHkIy9qBBQ5G96ZPMGQ?_x_zm_rtaid=LqK_U5IWQqKS8UmLq9En3w.1655276078460.b1c190b10cc6b0f15b8e76fccf850b54&amp;_x_zm_rhtaid=320" a Stronger Regional and International Cooperation on Marine Plastic Debris The Way Forward for a Stronger Regional and International Cooperation on Marine Plastic Debris Online Forum hosted by the Mission of the Republic of Korea to ASEAN

Given the growing international and regional concerns on marine plastics, the Mission of the Republic of Korea to ASEAN is hosting an online Forum on marine plastic debris issues in the ASEAN region to suggest the way forward for the international legally binding agreement, in collaboration with the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) of Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) as the organizer of the forum.
The event will raise awareness on the current alarming situation surrounding marine plastics and the urgent needs to address this issue internationally; stocktake the prevention and mitigation efforts undertaken by different stakeholders and receive recommendations from them; and formulate policy recommendations to advance the UNEA 5.2 resolution for a legally binding international treaty.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 23 June 2022
Time: 9 AM -&nbsp; 11:30 AM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;

on Economic Security and ASEAN";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-05-25";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"5";s:7:"content";s:0:"";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:18:"Jakarta, Economic Security and ASEAN Roundtable on Economic Security and ASEAN        Jakarta, Indonesia Mr Rudhian Chlissma  rudhian.chlissma@eria.org   2022-05-25  2022-05-25 25 May 2022 2202 yaM 52 52-50-2202  52-50-2202   gro.aire@amssilhc.naihdur  amssilhC naihduR rM aisenodnI ,atrakaJ        NAESA dna ytiruceS cimonocE no elbatdnuoR NAESA dna ytiruceS cimonocE no elbatdnuoR";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-05-12 16:32:57";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-05-12 16:32:57";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:25:"rudhian.chlissma@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:123;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6749";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:44:"carbon-neutrality-roadmap-of-asean-countries";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:44:"Carbon Neutrality Roadmap of ASEAN Countries";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-05-31";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"5";s:7:"content";s:2229:"<p>IEEJ will present their analysis on the roadmap for ASEAN countries&rsquo; transition to carbon neutrality. Recently, with the COP26 as a trigger, the decarbonisation movement is spreading not only across developed countries but also to many other countries including the ASEAN region, and some ASEAN countries have declared carbon neutrality by the mid of this century. Such highly ambitious GHG emissions reductions require a fundamental transformation of energy systems. At the same time, the energy transition cannot be accomplished with a uniform measure. In particular, the ASEAN countries are still highly dependent on fossil fuels and experiencing high economic and energy demand growth. Given these circumstances, the study aims to quantitatively describe the pathway of energy transition necessary to realise carbon neutrality in ASEAN countries by using a cost-optimal technology selection model. The IEEJ conducted this study together with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), and fully discussed the outcomes with each of the ASEAN countries to reflect their views and realities.</p><p>The IEA is also expected to release its ASEAN Energy Outlook soon. It is our privilege that Tim Gould, Chief Energy Economist, the IEA will participate in this webinar as a commentator in the panel discussion.</p><h2>Speakers</h2><ul><li>Toshiyuki Sakamoto, Board Member, Director, IEEJ</li><li>Soichi Morimoto, Senior Researcher, Climate Change Group, IEEJ</li><li>Yuji Mizuno, Chief Researcher, CCUS Group, IEEJ</li></ul><h2>Guest Commentator</h2><p>Tim Gould, Chief Energy Economist, IEA</p><h2>Inquiries</h2><p>If you have any inquiries, please contact <a title="Send email to the IEEJ" href="mailto:ieej-mail@tky.ieej.or.jp" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ieej-mail@tky.ieej.or.jp</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="click here to register now" href="https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_e8kY-kvFTgWuzlSTIA0EBw" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to view the agenda" href="https://eneken.ieej.or.jp/en/seminar/other/ieej_webinar_for_the_world220531.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Agenda</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:4:"Zoom";s:5:"major";s:4:"IEEJ";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:4:"IEEJ";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-05-31";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3699:"Carbon Neutrality Roadmap of ASEAN Countries Carbon Neutrality Roadmap of ASEAN Countries IEEJ will present their analysis on the roadmap for ASEAN countries&rsquo; transition to carbon neutrality. Recently, with the COP26 as a trigger, the decarbonisation movement is spreading not only across developed countries but also to many other countries including the ASEAN region, and some ASEAN countries have declared carbon neutrality by the mid of this century. Such highly ambitious GHG emissions reductions require a fundamental transformation of energy systems. At the same time, the energy transition cannot be accomplished with a uniform measure. In particular, the ASEAN countries are still highly dependent on fossil fuels and experiencing high economic and energy demand growth. Given these circumstances, the study aims to quantitatively describe the pathway of energy transition necessary to realise carbon neutrality in ASEAN countries by using a cost-optimal technology selection model. The IEEJ conducted this study together with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), and fully discussed the outcomes with each of the ASEAN countries to reflect their views and realities.
The IEA is also expected to release its ASEAN Energy Outlook soon. It is our privilege that Tim Gould, Chief Energy Economist, the IEA will participate in this webinar as a commentator in the panel discussion.
Speakers

Toshiyuki Sakamoto, Board Member, Director, IEEJ
Soichi Morimoto, Senior Researcher, Climate Change Group, IEEJ
Yuji Mizuno, Chief Researcher, CCUS Group, IEEJ

Guest Commentator
Tim Gould, Chief Energy Economist, IEA
Inquiries
If you have any inquiries, please contact ieej-mail@tky.ieej.or.jp

organising a series of five Public-Private Dialogues, <em>&#039;Unpacking the RCEP Agreement&#039;</em>. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement amongst the 15 member states. RCEP will create new business opportunities and change the shape of trade in the region. Dialogue 3 will discuss the &lsquo;Trade in Services&rsquo; and how it will also facilitate the cross-border trade and speeds up delivery amongst RCEP participating countries.</p><p>With Trade in Services, RCEP will opens up services amongst member countries for professional services for instance telecommunications and financial services. There will also be mutual recognition of professional qualifications, with obligations and frameworks for increased cooperation. This sector has also become the largest recipient of the inflow for foreign direct investment (FDI) across ASEAN Member States (AMS) over the past 15 years with 38% to 69% contribution of gross domestic product (GD) of AMS. ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme is organising a series of five Public-Private Dialogues, 'Unpacking the RCEP Agreement'. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement amongst the 15 member states. RCEP will create new business opportunities and change the shape of trade in the region. Dialogue 3 will discuss the &lsquo;Trade in Services&rsquo; and how it will also facilitate the cross-border trade and speeds up delivery amongst RCEP participating countries.
With Trade in Services, RCEP will opens up services amongst member countries for professional services for instance telecommunications and financial services. There will also be mutual recognition of professional qualifications, with obligations and frameworks for increased cooperation. This sector has also become the largest recipient of the inflow for foreign direct investment (FDI) across ASEAN Member States (AMS) over the past 15 years with 38% to 69% contribution of gross domestic product (GD) of AMS. Glean insights with us to unlock its utmost potential of how RCEP could leverage the growth of trade in services in Cambodia.




9:00 &ndash; 9:10


Opening Remarks: 

Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building, ERIA
H.E. Sim Sokheng,&nbsp;Secretary of State, Ministry of Commerce, Cambodia





9:10 - 09:40


Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Trade in Services Provisions 
Moderator: Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, CBP, ERIA
Presenters:

Ms Deborah Elms,&nbsp;Executive Director, Asian Trade Center
Mr Clint O&rsquo;Connell, Partner and Head of Tax and Customs, DFDL

Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will provide a precise description of what the RCEP provisions are and whether Cambodia&rsquo;s legal and regulatory system is ready for the trade in services.




09:40 &ndash; 11:00


Session 2: Private Sector Perspectives on Opportunities for Cambodia in RCEP
Moderator: Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, CBP, ERIA

Mr Kay Lot, Entrepreneur, Business Owner&nbsp;
Ms Phurik Ratana, Private Sector and Investment Specialist&nbsp;
Mr Harrison White, CEO, CIR Media&nbsp;
Mr Ashley Irving, Principal, IDP Cambodia, Vice-President Auscham Cambodia&nbsp;

Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will enable different business interests to assess their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP trade in services could be a game changer in the services industry.




11:00 -11:15


Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on Trade in Services 

HE Sok Siphana, Senior Adviser to the Royal Government of Cambodia

Q&amp;A with the audience.&nbsp;




11:15 &ndash; 11:30


Closing remarks by MoC and ERIA

.aidobmaC ni secivres ni edart fo htworg eht egarevel dluoc PECR woh fo laitnetop tsomtu sti kcolnu ot su htiw sthgisni naelG .SMA fo )DG( tcudorp citsemod ssorg fo noitubirtnoc %96 ot %83 htiw sraey 51 tsap eht revo )SMA( setatS rebmeM NAESA ssorca )IDF( tnemtsevni tcerid ngierof rof wolfni eht fo tneipicer tsegral eht emoceb osla sah rotces sihT .noitarepooc desaercni rof skrowemarf dna snoitagilbo htiw ,snoitacifilauq lanoisseforp fo noitingocer lautum eb osla lliw erehT .secivres laicnanif dna snoitacinummocelet ecnatsni rof secivres lanoisseforp rof seirtnuoc rebmem tsgnoma secivres pu snepo lliw PECR ,secivreS ni edarT htiW
.seirtnuoc gnitapicitrap PECR tsgnoma yreviled pu sdeeps dna edart redrob-ssorc eht etatilicaf osla lliw ti woh dna ;ouqsr&secivreS ni edarT;ouqsl& eht ssucsid lliw 3 eugolaiD .noiger eht ni edart fo epahs eht egnahc dna seitinutroppo ssenisub wen etaerc lliw PECR .setats rebmem 51 eht tsgnoma tnemeerga edart eerf a fo tnemhsilbatse eht skram )PECR( pihsrentraP cimonocE evisneherpmoC lanoigeR ehT .'tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU' ,seugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP evif fo seires a gnisinagro si emmargorP gnidliuB yticapaC s;ouqsr&AIRE

3# eugolaiD - seireS eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP :tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU secivreS ni edarT - 3#  seireS eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP :tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU secivreS ni edarT - 3#  seireS eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP :tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-05-10 18:25:27";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-05-19 10:57:20";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:131;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6734";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:60:"pandemic-best-policy-strategies-balancing-health-and-economy";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:61:"Pandemic Best Policy Strategies: Balancing Health and Economy";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-05-19";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"5";s:7:"content";s:4457:"<p><strong>First regional conference on sharing pandemic best practices &ndash; virtual</strong></p><p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/2022_May_HCU.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>The COVID-19 pandemic for the past two years has transformed health systems and battled economies across the globe. Much COVID-19-focused research and development innovation, alongside the persevering efforts of political leaders to safeguard and sustain economic progress, has been undertaken. Within the diverse community of ERIA Member States alone, a variety of measures have been tackled to survive through attempts to balance each nation&rsquo;s health and economy. A first of its kind, this regional conference answers requests heard through regional meetings for such a gathering, and offers EMSs the opportunity to share with neighbors what they have learned to be most effective for them, in order to more smoothly exit this pandemic as well as better prepare for upcoming ones.</p><p>Experts have thus been invited to present their government&rsquo;s best policy strategy/ies that have had the greatest impact on balancing economy and health under the COVID-19 pandemic. This year&rsquo;s ASEAN chair, Cambodia, will open, introducing the hard-hit populous and developing archipelagos of Indonesia and the Philippines, the peninsular Thailand, the ASEAN neighbor India with its population of over one billion, and the technologically advanced Japan in East Asia. Articles, Op-Eds, policy papers, and academic publications (commentaries) are expected to arise from the presentations.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 19 May&nbsp; 2022</li><li>Time: NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:14:"Ms Nanda Putri";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-05-19";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6717:"Pandemic Best Policy Strategies: Balancing Health and Economy Pandemic Best Policy Strategies: Balancing Health and Economy First regional conference on sharing pandemic best practices &ndash; virtual

The COVID-19 pandemic for the past two years has transformed health systems and battled economies across the globe. Much COVID-19-focused research and development innovation, alongside the persevering efforts of political leaders to safeguard and sustain economic progress, has been undertaken. Within the diverse community of ERIA Member States alone, a variety of measures have been tackled to survive through attempts to balance each nation&rsquo;s health and economy. A first of its kind, this regional conference answers requests heard through regional meetings for such a gathering, and offers EMSs the opportunity to share with neighbors what they have learned to be most effective for them, in order to more smoothly exit this pandemic as well as better prepare for upcoming ones.
Experts have thus been invited to present their government&rsquo;s best policy strategy/ies that have had the greatest impact on balancing economy and health under the COVID-19 pandemic. This year&rsquo;s ASEAN chair, Cambodia, will open, introducing the hard-hit populous and developing archipelagos of Indonesia and the Philippines, the peninsular Thailand, the ASEAN neighbor India with its population of over one billion, and the technologically advanced Japan in East Asia. Articles, Op-Eds, policy papers, and academic publications (commentaries) are expected to arise from the presentations.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 19 May&nbsp; 2022
Time: 2 PM- 4 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)

Agenda




TIME (UTC+7)


AGENDA




&nbsp;14:00-14:05


&nbsp;Welcome Remarks:

Taizo Hara, Director-General of Research and Policy Design, ERIA





14:05-14:10


Opening Address:

Dr Songheang Ai, Director, Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization Regional Centre for Technical Education Development (SEAMEO TED)





&nbsp;14:10-14:50


Part 1: Managing ASEAN Member States&rsquo; Health and Economy during the Pandemic
Moderator:

Dr Antonio Villanueva, Senior Advisor on Healthcare Policy

Experts:

Prof Tjandra Yoga Aditama, former Director of Communicable Diseases at WHO SEARO, for Indonesia
Dr Maria Rosario Singh-Vergeire, Undersecretary of Health, the Philippines
Prof Prasit Watanapa, Dean, Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital, Mahidol University, Bangkok, Thailand





14:50-15:00


Break




15:00-15:40


Part 2: Managing East Asia Summit States during the Pandemic
Moderator:

Ms Asuka Nagatani, Senior Policy Officer of Healthcare Unit

Experts:

Dr Vijay Murali, COVID-19 Task Force and Ministry of Health, India
Dr Norio Ohmagari, Head of COVID-19 Task Force and Director of Disease Control and Prevention Center, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan
Dr Aladdin Rillo, Senior Economic Advisor, ERIA




15:40-15:55

Q&amp;A:

Ms Isabella Italia Gentajaya, Information and Communications, ERIA




15:55-16:00

&nbsp;Summary and Closing Remarks:

Dr Takuma Kato, Director of Healthcare Unit, ERIA

lautriv ;hsadn& secitcarp tseb cimednap gnirahs no ecnerefnoc lanoiger tsriF ymonocE dna htlaeH gnicnalaB :seigetartS yciloP tseB cimednaP ymonocE dna htlaeH gnicnalaB :seigetartS yciloP tseB cimednaP";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-05-07 16:28:15";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-05-17 15:55:59";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:20:"nanda.putri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:132;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6731";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:47:"escalating-the-role-of-gas-in-energy-transition";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:47:"Escalating the Role of Gas in Energy Transition";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-05-11";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"5";s:7:"content";s:5897:"<p><strong>Virtual Workshop as a Side Event under ETWG G20 2022.</strong></p><p><strong>Hosted by Ministry of Energy, Mineral Resources, Indonesia (MEMR) and Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</strong></p><p><strong><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_April_ETWG-G20-2022.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="800" /></strong></p><p>As developing countries aim to achieve similar economic standards of developed countries, their electricity demand has been significantly increasing. For example, between 2000 and 2017, final electricity demand in the East Asia Summit (EAS) least-developed to upper-middle income countries has increased by an average rate of 8.4 percent per year whilst that of the EAS high-income countries had increased by an average rate of merely 0.7 percent per year (Han and Kimura, 2021). Most of these countries have been depending on thermal power generation that consumes fossil fuels because of its economic feasibility and high-capacity factor.</p><p>However, to achieve the low carbon energy transition, another available options for developing countries is to shift from coal to gas power generation. Despite higher gas prices relative to coal, this shift should take place in parallel with the increasing use of renewable energies such as solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. Thus, under the low carbon energy transition period from 2020 to 2030 or 2040 facing uncertainty of volatile international energy markets both oil and gas due to the war in Ukraine caused by Russia, the role of gas must be escalated to achieve carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction while maintaining the affordability of electricity prices.</p><p>Confirming the &lsquo;Principles of Energy Collaboration&rsquo; endorsed by G20 leaders at the 2014 G20 summit in Brisbane, the energy ministers meeting in Argentina in 2018 highlighted the importance of investment in infrastructure and the role of digitalization and flexibility in the power sector, including the role of natural gas in the G20 countries.</p><p>The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency Energy Transition pillar includes the main topic of &lsquo;Global Cleaner Energy Systems and Just Transitions&rsquo; that aims at &lsquo;achieving global deal to accelerate energy transition&rsquo;.</p><p>This workshop will provide new insights into how to escalate the role of natural gas as part of the just process of low carbon energy transition in developing countries which shall foster the G20 energy transition agenda paying attention to uncertainty on gas market.</p><p>This workshop also aims to support G20 Members to understand the different pathways to escalate the use of natural gas in meeting final energy demand in developing countries in the low carbon energy transition context, while pursuing and strengthening the implementation of the previous 2021 G20 Italian action plan that includes ensuring access to clean energy for all, especially in developing countries.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Wednesday, 11 May 2022</li><li>Time: 3 PM- 5 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7))</li><li>RSVP:&nbsp;<a href="https://bit.ly/G20Webinar5">https://bit.ly/G20Webinar5</a>&nbsp;</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_April_ETWG-G20-2022-1.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="800" /></p><table border="1" width="100%" cellspacing="10" cellpadding="10"><tr><td width="12%"><p><strong>Time</strong></p></td><td width="43%"><p><strong>Topic</strong></p></td><td width="43%"><p><strong>Presenter</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="12%"><p>3 PM to 3:05 PM</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Opening Remarks</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Dr Yudo Dwinanda Priaadi,&nbsp;Chair of ETWG G20 2022</p></td></tr><tr><td width="12%"><p>3:05 PM to 3:20 PM</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Keynote Speech:</p><p>Indonesian Gas Demand and Supply Perspective</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Prof Tutuka Ariadji, Director General of Oil and Gas (MIGAS), Indonesia</p></td></tr><tr><td width="12%"><p>3:20 PM to 3:35 PM</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Keynote Speech:</p><p>Global Natural Gas Demand and Supply Perspective</p></td><td width="43%"><p>H.E. Eng. Mohamed Hamel, Secretary-General of Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)</p></td></tr><tr><td width="12%"><p>3:35 PM to 3:50 PM</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Scene setting presentation:</p><p>Global Low Carbon Energy Transition</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow of ERIA</p></td></tr><tr><td width="12%"><p>3:50 PM to 4:55 PM</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Panel Discussion moderated by Mr Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor on Energy Affairs, ERIA</p><p>This panel discussion should provide deepened insights on the different pathways to escalate the role of natural gas.&nbsp;</p><p>Q &amp; A between the moderator and the panelists on following points:&nbsp;Increase of gas production; Uncertainty on international gas markets; Carbon neutral or energy security; New gas demand in addition to power generation; fuel ammonia with CCS; Financial scheme for gas power plants to replace coal power plant; Secure upstream investment; etc.</p></td><td width="43%"><ul><li>Mr Lars Erik Aamot, Ministry of Petroleum and Energy, Norway</li><li>Mr Dmitry Sokolov, Head of the Energy Economics and Forecasting Department of the Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)</li><li>Mr Hartanto Wibowo, Director of Primary Energy, PT PLN (Indonesia State Electricity Company)</li><li>Mr Siri Jirapongphan, Former Minister of Energy, Thailand</li><li>Mr Takeshi Soda, Director of Oil and Gas Division, Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="12%"><p>4:55 PM to 5 PM</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Closing Remarks</p></td><td width="43%"><p>Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer (COO) of ERIA</p></td></tr></table><p>&nbsp;</p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://bit.ly/G20Webinar5" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:10:"Energy,G20";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"ASIA CCUS Network";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-05-11";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:9887:"Escalating the Role of Gas in Energy Transition Escalating the Role of Gas in Energy Transition Virtual Workshop as a Side Event under ETWG G20 2022.
Hosted by Ministry of Energy, Mineral Resources, Indonesia (MEMR) and Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)

As developing countries aim to achieve similar economic standards of developed countries, their electricity demand has been significantly increasing. For example, between 2000 and 2017, final electricity demand in the East Asia Summit (EAS) least-developed to upper-middle income countries has increased by an average rate of 8.4 percent per year whilst that of the EAS high-income countries had increased by an average rate of merely 0.7 percent per year (Han and Kimura, 2021). Most of these countries have been depending on thermal power generation that consumes fossil fuels because of its economic feasibility and high-capacity factor.
However, to achieve the low carbon energy transition, another available options for developing countries is to shift from coal to gas power generation. Despite higher gas prices relative to coal, this shift should take place in parallel with the increasing use of renewable energies such as solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. Thus, under the low carbon energy transition period from 2020 to 2030 or 2040 facing uncertainty of volatile international energy markets both oil and gas due to the war in Ukraine caused by Russia, the role of gas must be escalated to achieve carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction while maintaining the affordability of electricity prices.
Confirming the &lsquo;Principles of Energy Collaboration&rsquo; endorsed by G20 leaders at the 2014 G20 summit in Brisbane, the energy ministers meeting in Argentina in 2018 highlighted the importance of investment in infrastructure and the role of digitalization and flexibility in the power sector, including the role of natural gas in the G20 countries.
The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency Energy Transition pillar includes the main topic of &lsquo;Global Cleaner Energy Systems and Just Transitions&rsquo; that aims at &lsquo;achieving global deal to accelerate energy transition&rsquo;.
This workshop will provide new insights into how to escalate the role of natural gas as part of the just process of low carbon energy transition in developing countries which shall foster the G20 energy transition agenda paying attention to uncertainty on gas market.
This workshop also aims to support G20 Members to understand the different pathways to escalate the use of natural gas in meeting final energy demand in developing countries in the low carbon energy transition context, while pursuing and strengthening the implementation of the previous 2021 G20 Italian action plan that includes ensuring access to clean energy for all, especially in developing countries.
Event Details

Date: Wednesday, 11 May 2022
Time: 3 PM- 5 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7))
RSVP:&nbsp;https://bit.ly/G20Webinar5&nbsp;

Agenda





Time


Topic


Presenter




3 PM to 3:05 PM


Opening Remarks


Dr Yudo Dwinanda Priaadi,&nbsp;Chair of ETWG G20 2022




3:05 PM to 3:20 PM


Keynote Speech:
Indonesian Gas Demand and Supply Perspective


Prof Tutuka Ariadji, Director General of Oil and Gas (MIGAS), Indonesia




3:20 PM to 3:35 PM


Keynote Speech:
Global Natural Gas Demand and Supply Perspective


H.E. Eng. Mohamed Hamel, Secretary-General of Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)




3:35 PM to 3:50 PM


Scene setting presentation:
Global Low Carbon Energy Transition


Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow of ERIA




3:50 PM to 4:55 PM


Panel Discussion moderated by Mr Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor on Energy Affairs, ERIA
This panel discussion should provide deepened insights on the different pathways to escalate the role of natural gas.&nbsp;
Q &amp; A between the moderator and the panelists on following points:&nbsp;Increase of gas production; Uncertainty on international gas markets; Carbon neutral or energy security; New gas demand in addition to power generation; fuel ammonia with CCS; Financial scheme for gas power plants to replace coal power plant; Secure upstream investment; etc.



Mr Lars Erik Aamot, Ministry of Petroleum and Energy, Norway
Mr Dmitry Sokolov, Head of the Energy Economics and Forecasting Department of the Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)
Mr Hartanto Wibowo, Director of Primary Energy, PT PLN (Indonesia State Electricity Company)
Mr Siri Jirapongphan, Former Minister of Energy, Thailand
Mr Takeshi Soda, Director of Oil and Gas Division, Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan





4:55 PM to 5 PM


Closing Remarks


Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer (COO) of ERIA

sliateD tnevE edarT lanoitanretnI ni serusaeM ffiraT-noN dna ffiraT :erutceL cilbuP aisenodnI satisrevinU edarT lanoitanretnI ni serusaeM ffiraT-noN dna ffiraT :erutceL cilbuP aisenodnI satisrevinU";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-04-11 09:07:03";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-04-11 09:58:44";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:25:"catherin.safitri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:134;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6711";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:69:"making-ccs-ccus-affordable-enabling-ccus-deployment-in-g20-and-beyond";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:70:"Making CCS/CCUS Affordable: Enabling CCUS Deployment in G20 and Beyond";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-13";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:9786:"<p><strong>Virtual Workshop as a Side Event under ETWG G20 2022</strong></p><p><strong><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022-April-Making-CCS-CCUS-Affordable-Enabling-CCUS-Deployment-in-G20-and-Beyond-1.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></strong></p><p>Even when all the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) are revised and implemented, coal, oil and natural gas will still occupy over half of the total global primary energy supply. This is particularly the case in the Asian region which will comprise the bulk of incremental energy demand and CO2 emissions. Thus, the clean use of fossil fuels and Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage (CCUS) will be extremely important to decarbonise emissions. A recent study conducted by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)&rsquo;s decarbonisation scenarios showed that the marginal abatement cost for achieving net-zero emissions by 2050 will be much more expensive compared with the 2070 net-zero emissions case.</p><p>CCUS is a crucial element of the clean energy transition as it is the only technology that contributes both to directly reducing emissions in high energy intensity economic sectors and to removing CO2 to balance emissions that cannot be avoided.&nbsp; Another way to reduce emission is through carbon recycling. After CO2 is captured, it is used to create&nbsp;new materials and products. Instead of just sequestering the CO2, the CO2 will be utilized to make everything from fuel, concrete, and shoes, to cleaning products, plastics, and food. This allows us to recycle the emissions and create a circular carbon economy.</p><p>However, the deployment of CCUS will require appropriate supporting policies and investment. Thus, technical experts will need to understand the technical aspect of CCUS and its technologies to help decision-makers to decide on appropriate energy policies to support the development and deployment of CCUS.</p><p>Taking the opportunity of Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 Chairmanship, this side event workshop hosted by Asia CCUS Network and the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR) of the Republic of Indonesia are very pleased to invite all stakeholders to participate in an online workshop on &lsquo;Commercializing CCS/CCUS: Making Technologies Affordable&rsquo;. The workshop will promote knowledge-sharing on the cost structure and range of expected costs of CCUS, joint project demonstration and policy frameworks for supporting the development and deployment of CCS/CCUS. As part of this workshop, we seek potential collaborators for a joint demonstration project (coal power plant&nbsp;+ CCUS) with the participation and support of interested G20 countries.&nbsp;</p><p>The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency Energy Transition pillar includes the main topic of &lsquo;Global Cleaner Energy Systems and Just Transitions&rsquo; that aims at &lsquo;achieving global deal to accelerate energy transition&rsquo;. In this regards, multiple pathways will need to be adopted including the innovative and artificial technology such as CCUS will play important role for carbon sinks and help to decarbonise emissions in identified hard to abated economic sectors.</p><p>This workshop will provide new insights into how to make CCS/CCUS affordable to all countries, especially in the developing world. This side event workshop will help escalate the role of CCS/CCUS as part of the just process of low carbon energy transition in developing countries which shall foster the G20 energy transition agenda.</p><p>In addition, this workshop aims to support G20 Members to understand the different pathways through the application of artificial carbon sink technology such as CCS/CCUS in the low carbon energy transition context, while pursuing and strengthening the implementation of the previous 2021 G20 Italian action plan that includes ensuring access to clean energy for all, especially in developing countries.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Wednesday, 13 April 2022</li><li>Time: 4 PM- 6:05 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7))</li><li>RSVP: <a title="Click here to register" href="https://bit.ly/ETWGWebinarAttendee130422" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://bit.ly/ETWGWebinarAttendee130422</a></li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><p><img href="https://bit.ly/ETWGWebinarAttendee130422" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:15:"Energy,G20,CCUS";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Asia CCUS Network";s:16:"article_keywords";s:43:"Asia CCUS Network, G20 Indonesia 2022, CCUS";s:9:"organizer";s:102:"Asia CCUS Network and the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR) of the Republic of Indonesia";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-04-13";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-04-13";s:8:"keywords";s:12957:"Making CCS/CCUS Affordable: Enabling CCUS Deployment in G20 and Beyond Making CCS/CCUS Affordable: Enabling CCUS Deployment in G20 and Beyond Virtual Workshop as a Side Event under ETWG G20 2022

Even when all the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) are revised and implemented, coal, oil and natural gas will still occupy over half of the total global primary energy supply. This is particularly the case in the Asian region which will comprise the bulk of incremental energy demand and CO2 emissions. Thus, the clean use of fossil fuels and Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage (CCUS) will be extremely important to decarbonise emissions. A recent study conducted by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)&rsquo;s decarbonisation scenarios showed that the marginal abatement cost for achieving net-zero emissions by 2050 will be much more expensive compared with the 2070 net-zero emissions case.
CCUS is a crucial element of the clean energy transition as it is the only technology that contributes both to directly reducing emissions in high energy intensity economic sectors and to removing CO2 to balance emissions that cannot be avoided.&nbsp; Another way to reduce emission is through carbon recycling. After CO2 is captured, it is used to create&nbsp;new materials and products. Instead of just sequestering the CO2, the CO2 will be utilized to make everything from fuel, concrete, and shoes, to cleaning products, plastics, and food. This allows us to recycle the emissions and create a circular carbon economy.
However, the deployment of CCUS will require appropriate supporting policies and investment. Thus, technical experts will need to understand the technical aspect of CCUS and its technologies to help decision-makers to decide on appropriate energy policies to support the development and deployment of CCUS.
Taking the opportunity of Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 Chairmanship, this side event workshop hosted by Asia CCUS Network and the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR) of the Republic of Indonesia are very pleased to invite all stakeholders to participate in an online workshop on &lsquo;Commercializing CCS/CCUS: Making Technologies Affordable&rsquo;. The workshop will promote knowledge-sharing on the cost structure and range of expected costs of CCUS, joint project demonstration and policy frameworks for supporting the development and deployment of CCS/CCUS. As part of this workshop, we seek potential collaborators for a joint demonstration project (coal power plant&nbsp;+ CCUS) with the participation and support of interested G20 countries.&nbsp;
The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency Energy Transition pillar includes the main topic of &lsquo;Global Cleaner Energy Systems and Just Transitions&rsquo; that aims at &lsquo;achieving global deal to accelerate energy transition&rsquo;. In this regards, multiple pathways will need to be adopted including the innovative and artificial technology such as CCUS will play important role for carbon sinks and help to decarbonise emissions in identified hard to abated economic sectors.
This workshop will provide new insights into how to make CCS/CCUS affordable to all countries, especially in the developing world. This side event workshop will help escalate the role of CCS/CCUS as part of the just process of low carbon energy transition in developing countries which shall foster the G20 energy transition agenda.
In addition, this workshop aims to support G20 Members to understand the different pathways through the application of artificial carbon sink technology such as CCS/CCUS in the low carbon energy transition context, while pursuing and strengthening the implementation of the previous 2021 G20 Italian action plan that includes ensuring access to clean energy for all, especially in developing countries.
Event Details

Date: Wednesday, 13 April 2022
Time: 4 PM- 6:05 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7))
RSVP: https://bit.ly/ETWGWebinarAttendee130422

Jakarta time, UTC+7

Welcome address


Dr Yudo Dwinanda Priaadi,&nbsp;Chair of ETWG G20 2022




4:05 PM to 4:15 PM


Keynote Speech


Prof Tutuka Ariadji, Director General of Oil and Gas, Republic of Indonesia




4:15 PM to 4:25 PM


The Current State of Carbon Neutrality


Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow of ERIA, and co-chair RTWG G20 2022




4:25 PM to 4:35 PM


Introduction of MRI&rsquo;s Research Results on CCUS&rsquo;s Value Chain Costs (including some financial aspects)


Ms Kikuko Shinchi, Manager and Senior Researcher, MRI




4:35 PM to 5:20 PM


Panel Discussion moderated by Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA.
Topics will concentrate on:

How to realize CCUS and make it affordable through scaling up CCUS projects and through technology innovation.




Ms Samantha McCulloch, Head of CCUS Unit, IEA
Mr Juho Lipponen, CEM
Emily Grubert, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Carbon Management (Video record only)
Ms Guloren Turan, General Manager, Advocacy, Global CCS Institute
Mr Kim Bye Bruun, Communications &amp; Government Relations Director, Northern Lights CCS project





5:20 PM to 6 PM


Panel Discussion moderated by Dr Abdurrahman Saleh, Committee Member of BPH Migas, Ministry of Energy and Mineral resources
Topics will concentrate on:

How developing countries could implement CCUS and best practise from Indonesia.

&nbsp;



Mr Tim Dixon, IEAGHG (what the developing countries should do for promoting CCUS in their countries)
Dr Rachmat Sule, ITB (&amp; Dr Usman Pasarai, BRIN) (the role of the National CoE for CCS/CCUS for supporting the implementation of CCUS in Indonesia)
Dr Oki Muraza, Senior Vice President of Research &amp; Technology Innovation, Pertamina (Pertamina&rsquo;s role in speeding up the implementation of CCUS in Indonesia)
Dr Darshak Mehta, Senior CCUS Specialist, Asian Development Bank (financial aspect)





6 PM to 6:05 PM


Closing Remarks


Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer (COO) of ERIA

aisA";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-04-08 07:25:00";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-04-08 18:52:08";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"asuka.nagatani@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:136;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6708";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:117:"unctad-eria-e-commerce-week-how-can-women-digital-entrepreneurs-boost-inclusion-peer-learning-dialogue-across-regions";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:120:"UNCTAD-ERIA E-commerce Week:  How Can Women Digital Entrepreneurs Boost Inclusion? Peer learning dialogue across regions";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-28";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:3738:"<p><strong>The Thematic Session in Partnership with UNCTAD during E-commerce Week</strong></p><p>The digital transformation has created new opportunities for developing and emerging economies, allowing businesses to access global markets and increase their level of transactions. The COVID-19 pandemic has catalysed and accelerated the transition towards economic activity online. According to the <a href="https://unctad.org/system/files/official-document/dtlstict2020d13_en.pdf">Covid-19 and e-Commerce Global Review</a>, the share of e-commerce of global retail trade is estimated to have surged from 14 per cent in 2019 to about 17 per cent in 2020. However, in spite of the economic growth generated by the increased use of digital tools and technologies, important inequalities remain with and within countries. Some categories, such as women, are still excluded from large chunks of the digital economy. A situation that has worsened during the COVID-19 pandemic, which significantly impacted women, and slowed down years of economic and social progress. Calculations by the World Economic Forum revealed that the pandemic situation of the two last years has increased the global gender gap by 36 years, resulting today in a gender divide that is not expected to close for another 136 years.</p><p data-subtype="normal">Reducing the gender gap in the digital space will not only benefit women, but societies and economies as a whole. According to an <a href="https://pressroom.ifc.org/all/pages/PressDetail.aspx?ID=26366">International Finance Corporation report</a>&nbsp;issued in 2021, women could add over $14.5 billion to e-commerce markets in Africa alone and $280 billion in South-East Asia, between 2025 and 2030. Similarly, in Southeast Asia, <a href="/uploads/media/policy-brief/Women%E2%80%99s-Participation-in-the-Digital-Economy_1203.pdf">according to ERIA research</a>, a better inclusion of women in fast growing digital economies can have significant social and economic benefits, especially by providing access to entrepreneurship opportunity, STEM skills and careers and leadership position in the digital economy. By providing relevant support, stakeholders of the digital sector can help women tackle the challenges related to the gender digital divide and contribute to more inclusive economic growth, generating opportunities for everyone.&nbsp;This session is part of series of events highlighting the positive impact of more inclusive digital economies.</p><p data-subtype="normal">After a High-Level session dedicated to discussing how fostering more inclusive digital entrepreneurship can be a force for development, this session will pursue the discussion and gather different actors who, at their level, are taking concrete actions to address the gender digital divide and contribute to sustainable development. With the objective to facilitate cross-fertilization and peer learning across different regions, the session will enable the exchange of good practices among different stakeholders of the digital economy and encourage partnership-building at a regional and a global level, to help increase women&#039;s participation in the digital sector.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 28 April 2022</li><li>Time: 7 PM - 8 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li><li>RSVP :&nbsp;<a title="Click here to register" href="https://unctadeweek2022.pathable.co/meetings/virtual/2fkWEeGyLYo4Tar93" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">UNCTAD eCommerce Week: Virtual Meeting Details (pathable.co)</a></li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register" href="https://unctadeweek2022.pathable.co/meetings/virtual/2fkWEeGyLYo4Tar93" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:6:"UNCTAD";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-04-28";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6743:"UNCTAD-ERIA E-commerce Week:  How Can Women Digital Entrepreneurs Boost Inclusion? Peer learning dialogue across regions UNCTAD-ERIA E-commerce Week:  How Can Women Digital Entrepreneurs Boost Inclusion? Peer learning dialogue across regions The Thematic Session in Partnership with UNCTAD during E-commerce Week
The digital transformation has created new opportunities for developing and emerging economies, allowing businesses to access global markets and increase their level of transactions. The COVID-19 pandemic has catalysed and accelerated the transition towards economic activity online. According to the Covid-19 and e-Commerce Global Review, the share of e-commerce of global retail trade is estimated to have surged from 14 per cent in 2019 to about 17 per cent in 2020. However, in spite of the economic growth generated by the increased use of digital tools and technologies, important inequalities remain with and within countries. Some categories, such as women, are still excluded from large chunks of the digital economy. A situation that has worsened during the COVID-19 pandemic, which significantly impacted women, and slowed down years of economic and social progress. Calculations by the World Economic Forum revealed that the pandemic situation of the two last years has increased the global gender gap by 36 years, resulting today in a gender divide that is not expected to close for another 136 years.
Reducing the gender gap in the digital space will not only benefit women, but societies and economies as a whole. According to an International Finance Corporation report&nbsp;issued in 2021, women could add over $14.5 billion to e-commerce markets in Africa alone and $280 billion in South-East Asia, between 2025 and 2030. Similarly, in Southeast Asia, according to ERIA research, a better inclusion of women in fast growing digital economies can have significant social and economic benefits, especially by providing access to entrepreneurship opportunity, STEM skills and careers and leadership position in the digital economy. By providing relevant support, stakeholders of the digital sector can help women tackle the challenges related to the gender digital divide and contribute to more inclusive economic growth, generating opportunities for everyone.&nbsp;This session is part of series of events highlighting the positive impact of more inclusive digital economies.
After a High-Level session dedicated to discussing how fostering more inclusive digital entrepreneurship can be a force for development, this session will pursue the discussion and gather different actors who, at their level, are taking concrete actions to address the gender digital divide and contribute to sustainable development. With the objective to facilitate cross-fertilization and peer learning across different regions, the session will enable the exchange of good practices among different stakeholders of the digital economy and encourage partnership-building at a regional and a global level, to help increase women's participation in the digital sector.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 28 April 2022
Time: 7 PM - 8 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)
RSVP :&nbsp;UNCTAD eCommerce Week: Virtual Meeting Details (pathable.co)

.rotces latigid eht ni noitapicitrap s'nemow esaercni pleh ot ,level labolg a dna lanoiger a ta gnidliub-pihsrentrap egaruocne dna ymonoce latigid eht fo sredlohekats tnereffid gnoma secitcarp doog fo egnahcxe eht elbane lliw noisses eht ,snoiger tnereffid ssorca gninrael reep dna noitazilitref-ssorc etatilicaf ot evitcejbo eht htiW .tnempoleved elbaniatsus ot etubirtnoc dna edivid latigid redneg eht sserdda ot snoitca etercnoc gnikat era ,level rieht ta ,ohw srotca tnereffid rehtag dna noissucsid eht eusrup lliw noisses siht ,tnempoleved rof ecrof a eb nac pihsruenerpertne latigid evisulcni erom gniretsof woh gnissucsid ot detacided noisses leveL-hgiH a retfA

.sraey 631 rehtona rof esolc ot detcepxe ton si taht edivid redneg a ni yadot gnitluser ,sraey 63 yb pag redneg labolg eht desaercni sah sraey tsal owt eht fo noitautis cimednap eht taht delaever muroF cimonocE dlroW eht yb snoitaluclaC .ssergorp laicos dna cimonoce fo sraey nwod dewols dna ,nemow detcapmi yltnacifingis hcihw ,cimednap 91-DIVOC eht gnirud denesrow sah taht noitautis A .ymonoce latigid eht fo sknuhc egral morf dedulcxe llits era ,nemow sa hcus ,seirogetac emoS .seirtnuoc nihtiw dna htiw niamer seitilauqeni tnatropmi ,seigolonhcet dna sloot latigid fo esu desaercni eht yb detareneg htworg cimonoce eht fo etips ni ,revewoH .0202 ni tnec rep 71 tuoba ot 9102 ni tnec rep 41 morf degrus evah ot detamitse si edart liater labolg fo ecremmoc-e fo erahs eht ,weiveR labolG ecremmoC-e dna 91-divoC eht ot gnidroccA .enilno ytivitca cimonoce sdrawot noitisnart eht detarelecca dna desylatac sah cimednap 91-DIVOC ehT .snoitcasnart fo level rieht esaercni dna stekram labolg ssecca ot sessenisub gniwolla ,seimonoce gnigreme dna gnipoleved rof seitinutroppo wen detaerc sah noitamrofsnart latigid ehT
keeW ecremmoc-E gnirud DATCNU htiw pihsrentraP ni noisseS citamehT ehT snoiger ssorca eugolaid gninrael reeP ?noisulcnI tsooB sruenerpertnE latigiD nemoW naC woH  :keeW ecremmoc-E AIRE-DATCNU snoiger ssorca eugolaid gninrael reeP ?noisulcnI tsooB sruenerpertnE latigiD nemoW naC woH  :keeW ecremmoc-E AIRE-DATCNU";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-04-07 17:44:03";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-04-12 11:25:21";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:137;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6707";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:68:"asean-economic-outlook-prospects-for-growth-and-regional-cooperation";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:69:"ASEAN Economic Outlook: Prospects for Growth and Regional Cooperation";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-28";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:6509:"<div data-lineheight="1.5"><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_April_ADB-Refinitiv-ERIA-webinar-banner.png" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">After a challenging couple of years, there are signs that Southeast Asia is rising from the pandemic. In 2021, output growth in the region rebounded to 2.9% with projections to further strengthen to 4.9% in 2022 as the region continues to recover, helped by high vaccination rates and a sustained global economic recovery.</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">However, global headwinds will continue to make policymaking difficult. The long term effects of the pandemic continue to disrupt global trade and supply chains and place stress on the labor supply through prolonged unemployment and the potential of new more transmissible COVID-19 variants emerging. On top of this, recent geopolitical events have raised inflation in the region through elevated oil, commodity and food prices that could impact consumption, exchange rates, and the current account balance in the region. In addition, the recent increase in the federal funds rate is another challenge that in the short run will raise the cost of borrowing for economies that need to continue priority spending to support the poor and vulnerable.</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">As we look to the future, there is still hope for optimism in the region that may counterbalance the challenges. A focus on building partnerships to invest in green infrastructure, reduce carbon emission, and improve the sustainability and conservation of the region&rsquo;s oceans, water bodies, and marine ecosystems offer prospects for growth. Join this webinar to discover the prospects for growth in Southeast Asia, and the importance of trade and financial integration.&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>During the webinar, our speakers will discuss:</strong></div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><ul><li data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>Economic outlook for the region</strong></li><li data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>The role of trade, trade disruptions, and trade agreements</strong></li><li data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>Financial connectedness &amp; financial integration</strong></li><li data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>Challenges facing central banks in the region&nbsp;</strong></li></ul><h2 data-lineheight="2.0">Event info</h2><div data-lineheight="2.0"><strong>Date:&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>Thursday, 28 April 2022</div><div data-lineheight="2.0"><strong>Time: </strong>3 PM&nbsp;SGT (UTC+8)/ 2 PM Jakarta time (90 minutes)</div><div data-lineheight="2.0">RSVP: <a title="Click here to register" href="https://solutions.refinitiv.com/ASEANEconomicsWebinar2022?utm_campaign=618600_ADBWebinarQ2&amp;elqCampaignId=17775&amp;utm_source=ERIA&amp;utm_medium=Email&amp;utm_content=&amp;utm_term=" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register at Refinitiv&#039;s website</a></div><div data-lineheight="2.0">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="2.0"><h2 data-lineheight="1.5">Agenda</h2><div>Singapore time, UTC+8</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>3 PM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;Event Close</strong></div></div><div data-lineheight="2.0">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="2.0"><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register" href="https://solutions.refinitiv.com/ASEANEconomicsWebinar2022?utm_campaign=618600_ADBWebinarQ2&amp;elqCampaignId=17775&amp;utm_source=ERIA&amp;utm_medium=Email&amp;utm_content=&amp;utm_term=" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></div>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:27:"ERIA, ADB, SEADS, Refinitiv";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-04-28";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:8753:"ASEAN Economic Outlook: Prospects for Growth and Regional Cooperation ASEAN Economic Outlook: Prospects for Growth and Regional Cooperation &nbsp;
After a challenging couple of years, there are signs that Southeast Asia is rising from the pandemic. In 2021, output growth in the region rebounded to 2.9% with projections to further strengthen to 4.9% in 2022 as the region continues to recover, helped by high vaccination rates and a sustained global economic recovery.
&nbsp;
However, global headwinds will continue to make policymaking difficult. The long term effects of the pandemic continue to disrupt global trade and supply chains and place stress on the labor supply through prolonged unemployment and the potential of new more transmissible COVID-19 variants emerging. On top of this, recent geopolitical events have raised inflation in the region through elevated oil, commodity and food prices that could impact consumption, exchange rates, and the current account balance in the region. In addition, the recent increase in the federal funds rate is another challenge that in the short run will raise the cost of borrowing for economies that need to continue priority spending to support the poor and vulnerable.
&nbsp;
As we look to the future, there is still hope for optimism in the region that may counterbalance the challenges. A focus on building partnerships to invest in green infrastructure, reduce carbon emission, and improve the sustainability and conservation of the region&rsquo;s oceans, water bodies, and marine ecosystems offer prospects for growth. Join this webinar to discover the prospects for growth in Southeast Asia, and the importance of trade and financial integration.&nbsp;
&nbsp;
During the webinar, our speakers will discuss:
&nbsp;

Economic outlook for the region
The role of trade, trade disruptions, and trade agreements
Financial connectedness &amp; financial integration
Challenges facing central banks in the region&nbsp;

Event info

Time: 3 PM&nbsp;SGT (UTC+8)/ 2 PM Jakarta time (90 minutes)
RSVP: Register at Refinitiv's website
