;psbn& noitarepooC lanoigeR dna htworG rof stcepsorP :kooltuO cimonocE NAESA noitarepooC lanoigeR dna htworG rof stcepsorP :kooltuO cimonocE NAESA";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-04-07 17:43:23";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-04-25 09:42:41";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:138;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6706";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:58:"g20-indonesia-windows-for-recovering-together-and-stronger";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:59:"G20 Indonesia: Windows for Recovering Together and Stronger";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-27";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:5199:"<p><strong>Virtual Conference CSIS Global Dialogue 2022</strong></p><p><img src="/uploads/media/CSIS%20GD%202022.jpg" alt="" width="462" height="578" /></p><p>The overall objective of this conference is to provide a platform to discuss the key challenges confronting the thinkers and leaders in managing the global economic recovery and mitigating future risks. The 2022 Global Dialogue will focus on how COVID-19 has disrupted every aspect of our lives but at the same time offered us a unique opportunity to reset as well as reconnect. It will allow thought-leaders and stakeholders to exchange views on the adversities of COVID-19 and how to harness the opportunities to recover stronger. The Dialogue will in turn contribute to Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 2022 presidency agendas with the spirit of recovering together and stronger. font-size: 14px;">Zhang Yunling,&nbsp;International Advisory Board of T20 Indonesia, Professor, Academy Member and Director of International Studies, Chinese Academy of Social Science (CASS)</span></p></div><div data-lineheight="2.0">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="2.0"><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register" href="https://bit.ly/CGD-2022" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></div><div data-lineheight="2.0">&nbsp;</div>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:3:"G20";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:15:"David Christian";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:4:"CSIS";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-04-27";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-04-29";s:8:"keywords";s:6379:"G20 Indonesia: Windows for Recovering Together and Stronger G20 Indonesia: Windows for Recovering Together and Stronger Virtual Conference CSIS Global Dialogue 2022

The overall objective of this conference is to provide a platform to discuss the key challenges confronting the thinkers and leaders in managing the global economic recovery and mitigating future risks. The 2022 Global Dialogue will focus on how COVID-19 has disrupted every aspect of our lives but at the same time offered us a unique opportunity to reset as well as reconnect. It will allow thought-leaders and stakeholders to exchange views on the adversities of COVID-19 and how to harness the opportunities to recover stronger. The Dialogue will in turn contribute to Indonesia&rsquo;s G20 2022 presidency agendas with the spirit of recovering together and stronger. Thus, the overarching theme of the 2022 Global Dialogue is G20 Indonesia: Windows for Recovering Together and Stronger
During the conference, our speakers will discuss:
&nbsp;

COVID-19 and Global Health Cooperation
Towards Sustainable Recovery and Quality Growth
Macroeconomic Issues in Prospect of Recovery
Reviving Trade, Investment, and Connectivity
Building Human Capital for Social Cohesion and Inclusive Digital Economy
Way Forward for G20 Indonesia 2022

Event info
Date:&nbsp; Wednesday, 27 April 2022 - Friday, 29 April 2022
Time:&nbsp;&nbsp;2 PM - 5 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)
RSVP:&nbsp;&nbsp;CSIS Global Dialogue 2022
&nbsp;
For further information, please visit:&nbsp;Home - Global Dialogue 2022 (csis.or.id)
&nbsp;

Agenda
Global Dialogue Day 1: 27 April 2022

Opening Remarks:


Ahmed Saeed,&nbsp;Vice President for East Asia, Southeast Asia and the Pacific, ADB
Koji Hachiyama,&nbsp;Chief Operating Officer (COO), ERIA
Yose Rizal Damuri,&nbsp;Executive Director, CSIS

Opening Speech
Luhut B. Panjaitan,&nbsp;Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs and Investment of the Republic of Indonesia
&nbsp;
Global Dialogue Day 2: 28 April 2022
Plenary Session 3: Macroeconomic Issues in Prospect of Recovery
Leading Speaker: Stijn Claessens,&nbsp;Head of Financial Stability Policy and Deputy Head of the Monetary and Economic Department, Bank for International Settlements (TBC)
Chair: Dr&nbsp;Lili Yan Ing,&nbsp;Lead Advisor for Southeast Asia Region, ERIA
Plenary Session 4: Reviving Trade, Investment, and Connectivity
Leading Speaker: Pascal Lamy,&nbsp;President Emeritus Coordinator of the Jacques Delors think tanks network (TBC)
Chair: Prof&nbsp;Fukunari Kimura,&nbsp;Chief Economist, ERIA&nbsp;
Global Dialogue Day 3: 29 April 2022
Closing Session: Way Forward for G20 Indonesia&nbsp;2022&nbsp;
Peter Drysdale,&nbsp;Emeritus Professor of Economics and the Head of the East Asian Bureau of Economic Research and East Asia Forum at the Crawford School of Public Policy
Zhang Yunling,&nbsp;International Advisory Board of T20 Indonesia, Professor, Academy Member and Director of International Studies, Chinese Academy of Social Science (CASS)

ytivitcennoC";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-04-07 16:31:02";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-04-08 13:32:17";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"cindy.agustine@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:146;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6690";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:76:"asia-green-growth-partnership-ministerial-meeting-aggpm-public-private-forum";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:78:"Asia Green Growth Partnership Ministerial Meeting (AGGPM) Public-Private Forum";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-25";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:3147:"<div id="block-ee8d4508ec66bdd630d8" class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="preFlex flexIn">The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) will hold the first &lsquo;Asia Green Growth Partnership Ministerial Meeting (AGGPM) Public-Private Forum&rsquo;.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">This forum is an industry-government-academia collaboration to accelerate diverse and realistic energy transitions in Asia, confirmed at the 1st Asia Green Growth Partnership Ministerial Meeting (AGGPM) held on 4 October 2021.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">The Forum will focus on &#039;innovation&#039; and &#039;finance&#039; to support energy transitions and feature a variety of sessions to present concrete projects and efforts by industry, government and academia in Japan and Asia.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">The forum will open with keynote speeches by ministers from Asian countries, followed by a special ceremony session that include:</p><ol data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">An MOU signing ceremony among private companies on projects and initiatives contributing to energy transitions in Asia,</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">The presentation of an interim report on the discussion of promoting Transition Finance in Asia by the ATF Study Group led by private financial institutions,</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">The presentation of the final report on a roadmap analysis for the realization of carbon neutrality in ASEAN by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the Institute of Energy Economics, Japan (IEEJ).</p></li></ol><p class="preFlex flexIn">Additionally, the Forum will hold panel discussion sessions under the themes of 1) the mobilisation of finance and 2) the promotion of innovations that are essential for promoting energy transitions in Asia.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Prominent figures from international organisations and private companies are confirmed to join the sessions to have lively discussions on the future pathways of energy transitions in line with actual situations in Asia.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn" style="padding-left: 30px;">Date and time: <strong>25 April 2022, 3:00 pm - 6:30 pm (JST)</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn" style="padding-left: 30px;">Event: online</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">For further information, please visit: <a href="https://www.aggpm2022.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://www.aggpm2022.org/</a></p></div></div><div id="block-yui_3_17_2_1_1649297189332_25995" class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2"><div class="sqs-block-content"><h4 class="preFlex flexIn"><a class="bluebtn" href="https://asiaccusnetwork-eria.squarespace.com/s/AGGPM-Public-Private-Forum-Event-Infomation-4ymy.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Download the brochure of the programme</a></h4><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register" href="https://jcs.eventsair.com/the-1st-aggpm-public-private-forum/attendee-registration/Site/Register" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></p></div></div>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:10:"METI Japan";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-04-25";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4327:"Asia Green Growth Partnership Ministerial Meeting (AGGPM) Public-Private Forum Asia Green Growth Partnership Ministerial Meeting (AGGPM) Public-Private Forum The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) will hold the first &lsquo;Asia Green Growth Partnership Ministerial Meeting (AGGPM) Public-Private Forum&rsquo;.
This forum is an industry-government-academia collaboration to accelerate diverse and realistic energy transitions in Asia, confirmed at the 1st Asia Green Growth Partnership Ministerial Meeting (AGGPM) held on 4 October 2021.
The Forum will focus on 'innovation' and 'finance' to support energy transitions and feature a variety of sessions to present concrete projects and efforts by industry, government and academia in Japan and Asia.
The forum will open with keynote speeches by ministers from Asian countries, followed by a special ceremony session that include:


An MOU signing ceremony among private companies on projects and initiatives contributing to energy transitions in Asia,


The presentation of an interim report on the discussion of promoting Transition Finance in Asia by the ATF Study Group led by private financial institutions,


The presentation of the final report on a roadmap analysis for the realization of carbon neutrality in ASEAN by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the Institute of Energy Economics, Japan (IEEJ).


Additionally, the Forum will hold panel discussion sessions under the themes of 1) the mobilisation of finance and 2) the promotion of innovations that are essential for promoting energy transitions in Asia.
Prominent figures from international organisations and private companies are confirmed to join the sessions to have lively discussions on the future pathways of energy transitions in line with actual situations in Asia.
Date and time: 25 April 2022, 3:00 pm - 6:30 pm (JST)
Event: online
For further information, please visit: https://www.aggpm2022.org/




Download the brochure of the programme

.;ouqsr&muroF etavirP-cilbuP )MPGGA( gniteeM lairetsiniM pihsrentraP htworG neerG aisA;ouqsl& tsrif eht dloh lliw )ITEM( yrtsudnI dna edarT ,ymonocE fo yrtsiniM ehT muroF etavirP-cilbuP )MPGGA( gniteeM lairetsiniM pihsrentraP htworG neerG aisA muroF etavirP-cilbuP )MPGGA( gniteeM lairetsiniM pihsrentraP htworG neerG aisA";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-04-07 11:08:36";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-04-07 11:18:38";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:15:"energy@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:147;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6659";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:57:"epr-for-plastics-in-viet-nam-challenges-and-opportunities";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:58:"EPR for Plastics in Viet Nam: Challenges and Opportunities";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-01";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:15726:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/RKCMPD/PSP-Viet-Nam/2022_March_PSP_31.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p><strong>ASEAN+3 Private Sector Initiatives to Reduce Marine Plastics - online event series</strong></p><p>The private sector in ASEAN+3 countries have been contributing significantly to the reduction of plastic waste and by consequence marine plastic debris in the region. Their efforts can range from both production and consumption (so-called &ldquo;upstream&rdquo;) level to recycling and waste management (so-called &ldquo;downstream&rdquo;) level. In Viet Nam, the new extended producers&rsquo; responsibility (EPR) approach has come into effect in January 2022, which will impact business operations on plastic packaging including PET bottle, EPS, PSP, PVC, plastic container tray, and film. According to the EPR principles, producers will be in charge not only to produce such commodities but will be held responsible until the waste stage of their life cycle. How to effectively implement this policy and create positive impacts on the environment will be the upcoming challenges for the country.</p><p>Tr&ecirc;n thá»±c táº¿, khu vá»±c tÆ° nh&acirc;n táº¡i c&aacute;c nÆ°á»›c ASEAN + 3 Ä‘&atilde; v&agrave; Ä‘ang Ä‘&oacute;ng g&oacute;p Ä‘&aacute;ng ká»ƒ v&agrave;o viá»‡c giáº£m thiá»ƒu r&aacute;c tháº£i nhá»±a v&agrave; giáº£m r&aacute;c nhá»±a biá»ƒn trong khu vá»±c. Nhá»¯ng ná»— lá»±c cá»§a há» c&oacute; thá»ƒ bao gá»“m cáº£ cáº¥p Ä‘á»™ sáº£n xuáº¥t v&agrave; ti&ecirc;u d&ugrave;ng (Ä‘Æ°á»£c gá»i l&agrave; &ldquo;thÆ°á»£ng nguá»“n&rdquo;) Ä‘áº¿n t&aacute;i cháº¿ v&agrave; quáº£n l&yacute; cháº¥t tháº£i (Ä‘Æ°á»£c gá»i l&agrave; &ldquo;háº¡ nguá»“n&rdquo;). Táº¡i Viá»‡t Nam, phÆ°Æ¡ng ph&aacute;p tiáº¿p cáº­n tr&aacute;ch nhiá»‡m má»Ÿ rá»™ng cá»§a nh&agrave; sáº£n xuáº¥t (EPR) má»›i c&oacute; hiá»‡u lá»±c v&agrave;o th&aacute;ng 01 nÄƒm 2022, sáº½ t&aacute;c Ä‘á»™ng Ä‘áº¿n hoáº¡t Ä‘á»™ng kinh doanh bao b&igrave; nhá»±a bao gá»“m chai PET, EPS, PSP, PVC, khay nhá»±a v&agrave; m&agrave;ng nhá»±a. Theo c&aacute;c nguy&ecirc;n táº¯c EPR, c&aacute;c nh&agrave; sáº£n xuáº¥t sáº½ kh&ocirc;ng chá»‰ chá»‹u tr&aacute;ch nhiá»‡m sáº£n xuáº¥t nhá»¯ng máº·t h&agrave;ng Ä‘&oacute; m&agrave; c&ograve;n chá»‹u tr&aacute;ch nhiá»‡m cho Ä‘áº¿n giai Ä‘oáº¡n tháº£i bá» trong v&ograve;ng Ä‘á»i cá»§a ch&uacute;ng. L&agrave;m tháº¿ n&agrave;o Ä‘á»ƒ thá»±c hiá»‡n hiá»‡u quáº£ ch&iacute;nh s&aacute;ch n&agrave;y v&agrave; táº¡o ra nhá»¯ng t&aacute;c Ä‘á»™ng t&iacute;ch cá»±c Ä‘áº¿n m&ocirc;i trÆ°á»ng sáº½ l&agrave; nhá»¯ng th&aacute;ch thá»©c sáº¯p tá»›i Ä‘á»‘i vá»›i quá»‘c gia.</p><p>ERIA&rsquo;s Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), in collaboration with the Vietnam Administration of Seas and Islands (VASI) of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE), will shed light on the opportunities and constraints to implement EPR on plastics in Viet Nam by engaging in a discussion with the private sector, who will be the key stakeholder in the process.</p><p>RKC-MPD cá»§a ERIA phá»‘i há»£p vá»›i Tá»•ng cá»¥c Biá»ƒn v&agrave; Háº£i Ä‘áº£o Viá»‡t Nam (VASI) cá»§a Bá»™ T&agrave;i nguy&ecirc;n v&agrave; M&ocirc;i trÆ°á»ng (MONRE) sáº½ l&agrave;m s&aacute;ng tá» nhá»¯ng cÆ¡ há»™i v&agrave; háº¡n cháº¿ Ä‘á»ƒ thá»±c hiá»‡n EPR Ä‘á»‘i vá»›i nhá»±a táº¡i Viá»‡t Nam báº±ng c&aacute;ch tham gia v&agrave;o má»™t cuá»™c tháº£o luáº­n vá»›i khu vá»±c tÆ° nh&acirc;n, sáº½ l&agrave; b&ecirc;n li&ecirc;n quan ch&iacute;nh trong qu&aacute; tr&igrave;nh n&agrave;y.</p><p data-key="146"><span data-key="147">The forum will be an occasion for Vietnam Administration of Seas and Islands (VASI), Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) of Viet Nam, a Vietnamese business alliance, Vietnamese private companies, and international businesses operating in Viet Nam to stocktake the progress made and discuss the many ways private companies can contribute to combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris, especially taking into consideration the new EPR scheme. RKC-MPD will reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP) to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness of the platform and attract a larger number of private companies to join the fight against marine plastics. </span></p><p data-key="148" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="149"> Diá»…n Ä‘&agrave;n sáº½ l&agrave; dá»‹p Ä‘á»ƒ Tá»•ng cá»¥c Biá»ƒn v&agrave; Háº£i Ä‘áº£o Viá»‡t Nam, Bá»™ T&agrave;i nguy&ecirc;n v&agrave; M&ocirc;i trÆ°á»ng Viá»‡t Nam, li&ecirc;n minh doanh nghiá»‡p Viá»‡t Nam, c&aacute;c c&ocirc;ng ty tÆ° nh&acirc;n Viá»‡t Nam v&agrave; c&aacute;c doanh nghiá»‡p quá»‘c táº¿ hoáº¡t Ä‘á»™ng táº¡i Viá»‡t Nam giá»›i thiá»‡u nhá»¯ng tiáº¿n bá»™ Ä‘&atilde; Ä‘áº¡t Ä‘Æ°á»£c v&agrave; tháº£o luáº­n vá» c&aacute;ch m&agrave; c&aacute;c c&ocirc;ng ty tÆ° nh&acirc;n c&oacute; thá»ƒ Ä‘&oacute;ng g&oacute;p trong viá»‡c chá»‘ng láº¡i r&aacute;c tháº£i nhá»±a v&agrave; r&aacute;c nhá»±a biá»ƒn, Ä‘áº·c biá»‡t l&agrave; xem x&eacute;t chÆ°Æ¡ng tr&igrave;nh EPR má»›i. RKC-MPD sáº½ giá»›i thiá»‡u láº¡i Ná»n táº£ng khu vá»±c tÆ° nh&acirc;n (PSP) cho c&ocirc;ng ch&uacute;ng, Ä‘áº·c biá»‡t l&agrave; c&aacute;c c&ocirc;ng ty tÆ° nh&acirc;n, Ä‘á»ƒ n&acirc;ng cao nháº­n thá»©c hÆ¡n vá» ná»n táº£ng n&agrave;y v&agrave; thu h&uacute;t má»™t sá»‘ lÆ°á»£ng lá»›n hÆ¡n c&aacute;c c&ocirc;ng ty tÆ° nh&acirc;n tham gia cuá»™c chiáº¿n chá»‘ng láº¡i r&aacute;c nhá»±a biá»ƒn.</span></p><p>Event Details</p><p>Date: Friday, 1 April 2022<br /> Time: 9 AM - 11 AM (Jakarta time, UTC+7))<br /> RSVP:&nbsp; <a href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/epr-for-plastics-in-viet-nam-challenges-and-opportunities-tickets-294413969107">https://www.eventbrite.com/e/epr-for-plastics-in-viet-nam-challenges-and-opportunities-tickets-294413969107</a></p><p><strong>NG&Agrave;Y V&Agrave; GIá»œ</strong></p><p>April 1st 2022, 09:00-11:00, Hanoi time (GMT+7)<br />Ng&agrave;y 01 th&aacute;ng 4 nÄƒm 2022, 09: 00-11: 00, giá» H&agrave; Ná»™i (GMT + 7)<br />RSVP: <a href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/epr-for-plastics-in-viet-nam-challenges-and-opportunities-tickets-294413969107">https://www.eventbrite.com/e/epr-for-plastics-in-viet-nam-challenges-and-opportunities-tickets-294413969107</a>&nbsp;</p><h2>Webinar Agenda</h2><p>Hosted by the RKC-MPD of ERIA and VASI, the Webinar will last 2 hours via Zoom platform with a moderated panel discussion.</p><table width="654"><tr><td width="203"><p>TIME</p></td><td width="451"><p>AGENDA&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td width="203"><p>9 AM &ndash; 9:15 AM</p></td><td width="451"><p>Start of Webinar by MC Ms Ellen Putri Edita (ERIA)</p><p>Welcome Remarks:</p><ul><li>Mr Michikazu Kojima, Senior Advisor to ERIA</li><li>Mr Pham Thu Hang, Deputy Director-General, Vietnam Administration of Seas and Islands (VASI)</li></ul><p>NgÆ°á»i dáº«n chÆ°Æ¡ng tr&igrave;nh: C&ocirc; Ellen Putri Edita (ERIA)<br />Ch&agrave;o má»«ng c&aacute;c Ä‘áº¡i biá»ƒu v&agrave; báº¯t Ä‘áº§u Há»™i tháº£o<br />Ph&aacute;t biá»ƒu khai máº¡c:<br />&bull; &Ocirc;ng Michikazu Kojima, TÆ° váº¥n cáº¥p cao, RKC-MPD, ERIA<br />&bull; L&atilde;nh Ä‘áº¡o Tá»•ng cá»¥c Biá»ƒn v&agrave; Háº£i Ä‘áº£o Viá»‡t Nam</p></td></tr><tr><td width="203"><p>9:15 AM - 10:15 AM</p></td><td width="451"><p>Panel Discussion</p><p>Speakers:</p><ul><li>Mr Nguyen Thi, Principal Official of the Department of Legal Affairs (MONRE)</li><li>Presentation: Mr Fausto Tazzi, Vice President of the Vietnam Packaging Recycling Alliance (PRO Vietnam)</li><li>Presentation: Mr Long Nguyen, Deputy CEO of An Phat Holdings</li><li>Presentation: Mr Ekkasit Lakkananithiphan, the President of Dow Vietnam</li><li>Presentation: Mr Hideki Wada, Director of Vietnam Waste Planning Company</li></ul><p>Moderated by&nbsp;Dr Nguyen My Hang, Deputy Director of the Department of Science, Technology and International Cooperation (VASI), and Ellen Putri Edita</p><p>Äiá»u phá»‘i:<br />&bull; TS Nguyá»…n Má»¹ Háº±ng, Ph&oacute; Vá»¥ trÆ°á»Ÿng Vá»¥ Khoa há»c, C&ocirc;ng nghá»‡ v&agrave; Há»£p t&aacute;c Quá»‘c táº¿, Tá»•ng cá»¥c Biá»ƒn v&agrave; Háº£i Ä‘áº£o Viá»‡t Nam<br />Nhá»¯ng ngÆ°á»i tham gia há»™i tháº£o:<br />&bull; Bá»™ T&agrave;i nguy&ecirc;n v&agrave; M&ocirc;i trÆ°á»ng (C&aacute;c quy Ä‘á»‹nh vá» EPR v&agrave; kh&oacute; khÄƒn táº¡i Viá»‡t Nam)<br />&bull; Li&ecirc;n minh T&aacute;i cháº¿ Bao b&igrave; Viá»‡t Nam (PRO Viá»‡t Nam)<br />&bull; C&ocirc;ng ty tÆ° nh&acirc;n Viá»‡t Nam<br />&bull; &Ocirc;ng Ekkasit Lakkananithiphan, Chá»§ tá»‹ch Dow Viá»‡t Nam<br />&bull; &Ocirc;ng Hideki Wada, Gi&aacute;m Ä‘á»‘c, C&ocirc;ng ty Quy hoáº¡ch Cháº¥t tháº£i Viá»‡t Nam</p><p>Má»—i th&agrave;nh vi&ecirc;n há»™i tháº£o sáº½ tr&igrave;nh b&agrave;y 8 ph&uacute;t vá» chá»§ Ä‘á» Ä‘&atilde; chá»n</p></td></tr><tr><td width="203"><p>10:15 AM -10:50 AM</p></td><td width="451"><p>Q&amp;A&nbsp;</p><p>Tháº£o luáº­n Há»i &amp; Ä&aacute;p má»Ÿ</p></td></tr><tr><td width="203"><p>10:50 AM -10:55 AM</p></td><td width="451"><p>Introduction of RKC-MPD&rsquo;s Private Sector Platform</p><p>ERIA má»i c&aacute;c Ä‘áº¡i biá»ƒu tham gia v&agrave;o ná»n táº£ng trá»±c tuyáº¿n</p></td></tr><tr><td width="203"><p>10:55 AM - 11:00 AM</p></td><td width="451"><p>Closing of the Webinar</p><p>&Ocirc;ng Michikazu Kojima, Cá»‘ váº¥n cao cáº¥p, RKC-MPD, ERIA</p></td></tr></table><p>The webinar will be in Vietnamese and English with simultaneous translation.</p><p>Há»™i tháº£o trá»±c tuyáº¿n Ä‘Æ°á»£c phi&ecirc;n dá»‹ch Ä‘á»“ng thá»i tiáº¿ng Viá»‡t v&agrave; tiáº¿ng Anh.</p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/RKCMPD/PSP-Viet-Nam/2022_March_Concept-Note-of-PSP-Viet-Nam-Event_Bilingual.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer"><img src="/uploads/media/Events/RKCMPD/2022_March_PSPVietNam.pdf" alt="" />CONCEPT NOTE</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/epr-for-plastics-in-viet-nam-challenges-and-opportunities-tickets-294413969107" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:13:"Ms Hera Diani";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-04-01";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:19781:"EPR for Plastics in Viet Nam: Challenges and Opportunities EPR for Plastics in Viet Nam: Challenges and Opportunities ASEAN+3 Private Sector Initiatives to Reduce Marine Plastics - online event series
The private sector in ASEAN+3 countries have been contributing significantly to the reduction of plastic waste and by consequence marine plastic debris in the region. Their efforts can range from both production and consumption (so-called &ldquo;upstream&rdquo;) level to recycling and waste management (so-called &ldquo;downstream&rdquo;) level. In Viet Nam, the new extended producers&rsquo; responsibility (EPR) approach has come into effect in January 2022, which will impact business operations on plastic packaging including PET bottle, EPS, PSP, PVC, plastic container tray, and film. According to the EPR principles, producers will be in charge not only to produce such commodities but will be held responsible until the waste stage of their life cycle. How to effectively implement this policy and create positive impacts on the environment will be the upcoming challenges for the country.
Tr&ecirc;n thá»±c táº¿, khu vá»±c tÆ° nh&acirc;n táº¡i c&aacute;c nÆ°á»›c ASEAN + 3 Ä‘&atilde; v&agrave; Ä‘ang Ä‘&oacute;ng g&oacute;p Ä‘&aacute;ng ká»ƒ v&agrave;o viá»‡c giáº£m thiá»ƒu r&aacute;c tháº£i nhá»±a v&agrave; giáº£m r&aacute;c nhá»±a biá»ƒn trong khu vá»±c. Nhá»¯ng ná»— lá»±c cá»§a há» c&oacute; thá»ƒ bao gá»“m cáº£ cáº¥p Ä‘á»™ sáº£n xuáº¥t v&agrave; ti&ecirc;u d&ugrave;ng (Ä‘Æ°á»£c gá»i l&agrave; &ldquo;thÆ°á»£ng nguá»“n&rdquo;) Ä‘áº¿n t&aacute;i cháº¿ v&agrave; quáº£n l&yacute; cháº¥t tháº£i (Ä‘Æ°á»£c gá»i l&agrave; &ldquo;háº¡ nguá»“n&rdquo;). Táº¡i Viá»‡t Nam, phÆ°Æ¡ng ph&aacute;p tiáº¿p cáº­n tr&aacute;ch nhiá»‡m má»Ÿ rá»™ng cá»§a nh&agrave; sáº£n xuáº¥t (EPR) má»›i c&oacute; hiá»‡u lá»±c v&agrave;o th&aacute;ng 01 nÄƒm 2022, sáº½ t&aacute;c Ä‘á»™ng Ä‘áº¿n hoáº¡t Ä‘á»™ng kinh doanh bao b&igrave; nhá»±a bao gá»“m chai PET, EPS, PSP, PVC, khay nhá»±a v&agrave; m&agrave;ng nhá»±a. Theo c&aacute;c nguy&ecirc;n táº¯c EPR, c&aacute;c nh&agrave; sáº£n xuáº¥t sáº½ kh&ocirc;ng chá»‰ chá»‹u tr&aacute;ch nhiá»‡m sáº£n xuáº¥t nhá»¯ng máº·t h&agrave;ng Ä‘&oacute; m&agrave; c&ograve;n chá»‹u tr&aacute;ch nhiá»‡m cho Ä‘áº¿n giai Ä‘oáº¡n tháº£i bá» trong v&ograve;ng Ä‘á»i cá»§a ch&uacute;ng. L&agrave;m tháº¿ n&agrave;o Ä‘á»ƒ thá»±c hiá»‡n hiá»‡u quáº£ ch&iacute;nh s&aacute;ch n&agrave;y v&agrave; táº¡o ra nhá»¯ng t&aacute;c Ä‘á»™ng t&iacute;ch cá»±c Ä‘áº¿n m&ocirc;i trÆ°á»ng sáº½ l&agrave; nhá»¯ng th&aacute;ch thá»©c sáº¯p tá»›i Ä‘á»‘i vá»›i quá»‘c gia.
ERIA&rsquo;s Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), in collaboration with the Vietnam Administration of Seas and Islands (VASI) of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE), will shed light on the opportunities and constraints to implement EPR on plastics in Viet Nam by engaging in a discussion with the private sector, who will be the key stakeholder in the process.
RKC-MPD cá»§a ERIA phá»‘i há»£p vá»›i Tá»•ng cá»¥c Biá»ƒn v&agrave; Háº£i Ä‘áº£o Viá»‡t Nam (VASI) cá»§a Bá»™ T&agrave;i nguy&ecirc;n v&agrave; M&ocirc;i trÆ°á»ng (MONRE) sáº½ l&agrave;m s&aacute;ng tá» nhá»¯ng cÆ¡ há»™i v&agrave; háº¡n cháº¿ Ä‘á»ƒ thá»±c hiá»‡n EPR Ä‘á»‘i vá»›i nhá»±a táº¡i Viá»‡t Nam báº±ng c&aacute;ch tham gia v&agrave;o má»™t cuá»™c tháº£o luáº­n vá»›i khu vá»±c tÆ° nh&acirc;n, sáº½ l&agrave; b&ecirc;n li&ecirc;n quan ch&iacute;nh trong qu&aacute; tr&igrave;nh n&agrave;y.
The forum will be an occasion for Vietnam Administration of Seas and Islands (VASI), Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) of Viet Nam, a Vietnamese business alliance, Vietnamese private companies, and international businesses operating in Viet Nam to stocktake the progress made and discuss the many ways private companies can contribute to combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris, especially taking into consideration the new EPR scheme. RKC-MPD will reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP) to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness of the platform and attract a larger number of private companies to join the fight against marine plastics. 
 Diá»…n Ä‘&agrave;n sáº½ l&agrave; dá»‹p Ä‘á»ƒ Tá»•ng cá»¥c Biá»ƒn v&agrave; Háº£i Ä‘áº£o Viá»‡t Nam, Bá»™ T&agrave;i nguy&ecirc;n v&agrave; M&ocirc;i trÆ°á»ng Viá»‡t Nam, li&ecirc;n minh doanh nghiá»‡p Viá»‡t Nam, c&aacute;c c&ocirc;ng ty tÆ° nh&acirc;n Viá»‡t Nam v&agrave; c&aacute;c doanh nghiá»‡p quá»‘c táº¿ hoáº¡t Ä‘á»™ng táº¡i Viá»‡t Nam giá»›i thiá»‡u nhá»¯ng tiáº¿n bá»™ Ä‘&atilde; Ä‘áº¡t Ä‘Æ°á»£c v&agrave; tháº£o luáº­n vá» c&aacute;ch m&agrave; c&aacute;c c&ocirc;ng ty tÆ° nh&acirc;n c&oacute; thá»ƒ Ä‘&oacute;ng g&oacute;p trong viá»‡c chá»‘ng láº¡i r&aacute;c tháº£i nhá»±a v&agrave; r&aacute;c nhá»±a biá»ƒn, Ä‘áº·c biá»‡t l&agrave; xem x&eacute;t chÆ°Æ¡ng tr&igrave;nh EPR má»›i. RKC-MPD sáº½ giá»›i thiá»‡u láº¡i Ná»n táº£ng khu vá»±c tÆ° nh&acirc;n (PSP) cho c&ocirc;ng ch&uacute;ng, Ä‘áº·c biá»‡t l&agrave; c&aacute;c c&ocirc;ng ty tÆ° nh&acirc;n, Ä‘á»ƒ n&acirc;ng cao nháº­n thá»©c hÆ¡n vá» ná»n táº£ng n&agrave;y v&agrave; thu h&uacute;t má»™t sá»‘ lÆ°á»£ng lá»›n hÆ¡n c&aacute;c c&ocirc;ng ty tÆ° nh&acirc;n tham gia cuá»™c chiáº¿n chá»‘ng láº¡i r&aacute;c nhá»±a biá»ƒn.

.yrtnuoc eht rof segnellahc gnimocpu eht eb lliw tnemnorivne eht no stcapmi evitisop etaerc dna ycilop siht tnemelpmi ylevitceffe ot woH .elcyc efil rieht fo egats etsaw eht litnu elbisnopser dleh eb lliw tub seitidommoc hcus ecudorp ot ylno ton egrahc ni eb lliw srecudorp ,selpicnirp RPE eht ot gnidroccA .mlif dna ,yart reniatnoc citsalp ,CVP ,PSP ,SPE ,elttob TEP gnidulcni gnigakcap citsalp no snoitarepo ssenisub tcapmi lliw hcihw ,2202 yraunaJ ni tceffe otni emoc sah hcaorppa )RPE( ytilibisnopser ;ouqsr&srecudorp dednetxe wen eht ,maN teiV nI .level );ouqdr&maertsnwod;ouqdl& dellac-os( tnemeganam etsaw dna gnilcycer ot level );ouqdr&maertspu;ouqdl& dellac-os( noitpmusnoc dna noitcudorp htob morf egnar nac stroffe riehT .noiger eht ni sirbed citsalp eniram ecneuqesnoc yb dna etsaw citsalp fo noitcuder eht ot yltnacifingis gnitubirtnoc neeb evah seirtnuoc 3+NAESA ni rotces etavirp ehT
seires tneve enilno - scitsalP eniraM ecudeR ot sevitaitinI rotceS etavirP 3+NAESA seitinutroppO dna segnellahC :maN teiV ni scitsalP rof RPE seitinutroppO dna segnellahC :maN teiV ni scitsalP rof RPE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-03-10 14:25:50";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-03-31 13:17:21";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:19:"hera.diani@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:148;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6655";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:108:"regional-comprehensive-economic-partnership-implications-challenges-and-future-growth-of-east-asia-and-asean";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:111:"Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership:  Implications, Challenges and Future Growth of East Asia and ASEAN";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-03-14";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"3";s:7:"content";s:8459:"<p>The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is the largest free trade agreement in 2020, completed on 15 November 2020, comprising 10 members of ASEAN (Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam) and five other regional countries that ASEAN has existing free trade agreements: Australia, China, India, Japan, South Korea, and New Zealand.<a href="#_ftn1" name="_ftnref1"><sup>[1]</sup></a><a href="#_ftn2" name="_ftnref2"><sup>[2]</sup></a> Currently, it is the largest trading block in the world consisting of a combined population of 2.2 billion people (30% of the world population), total regional gross domestic product (GDP) of around $38,813 billion (30% of global GDP in 2019), and nearly 28% of global trade.</p><p>It sets an important agenda for trade and investment in global trade in terms of opening large domestic market (demand), releasing huge resources for trade and investment, and creating dynamic regional and global value-chain activities.</p><p>The RCEP as a &#039;living&#039; agreement will be able to create a wider regional integration agenda to address key contemporary issues such as the environment and climate change, skills development, green transformation, and developing digital and smart urban centres. ASEAN centrality, as highlighted by the RCEP framework, is critical for the post-pandemic recovery and structural transformation of the region.&nbsp;</p><p>As part of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) research project, this workshop aims to address the structure of the RCEP in terms of the complexity of the RCEP commitments modalities and mechanism, it explores the various elements of the agreement and discusses the key potential implications to the integration process in the region. For example, it will carefully examine the commitments and compare them with those of other agreements, including the CPTPP. The project underlines some key features of the agreement and analyses how these could strengthen regional integration. The impact of businesses, behind-the-border issues, and the domestic capacity of the respective RCEP member countries will also be discussed, in addition to a formal assessment of the potential benefits of the RCEP. Finally, this study also attempts to address emerging issues especially with respect to the COVID-19 pandemic recovery.</p><p>The workshop, organised by ERIA in collaboration with the Ministry of Commerce, Kingdom of Cambodia as a side-event for Cambodia ASEAN Chairmanship, will also include a book launch titled &#039;Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership: Implications, Challenges and Future Growth of East Asia and ASEAN&#039;.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Monday, 14 March 2022</li><li>Time: 8:30 AM- 3:30 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" title="President of ERIA and Cambodia&#039;s Minister of Commerce Launch Monograph on RCEP" href="/news-and-views/president-of-eria-and-cambodias-minister-of-commerce-launch-monograph-on-rcep/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Read the Press Release</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="RCEP: Implications, Challenges and Future Growth of East Asia and ASEAN" href="/uploads/media/RCEP-Monograph-Launch-14-March-2022-FINAL.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Download the Monograph</a></p><h2><strong>Relive the Webinar</strong></h2><table style="width: 622px;"><tr><td style="width: 354.872px;"><h2>Opening Session</h2><ul><li>Professor Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of ERIA</li><li>HE Mr Pan Sorasak, Minister of Commerce, Ministry of Commerce, Kingdom of Cambodia&nbsp;</li></ul><p><strong>Launching of the ERIA RCEP&nbsp;</strong></p><p>Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership: Implications, Challenges, and Future Growth of East Asia and ASEAN&nbsp;</p><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/ACIlkDdSrDg" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: Regional Integration: Potential Growth </strong></p><ul><li>Prof Fukunari Kimura, ERIA and Keio University</li></ul><p><strong>History, Negotiations, and Structure of RCEP</strong></p><ul><li>Dr Thangavelu, Sunway University and University of Adelaide</li><li>Dr Dionisius A. Ramli, ERIA</li></ul><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/5IUE9lCovMQ" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 354.872px;">&nbsp;</td></tr><tr><td style="width: 354.872px;"><h2>Panel Discussion on Cambodian Economy</h2><p>Moderator: Prof Shandre Mugan Thangavelu, Sunway University and University of Adelaide</p><ul><li>HE Sim Sokheng, Secretary of State, Ministry of Commerce, Kingdom of Cambodia</li><li>HE Chan Sopheap, Under-Secretary of State, Ministry of Economy and Finance</li><li><p>H.E. Meng Nimol, Deputy Director-General, Cambodian Chamber of Commerce, Kingdom of Cambodia</p></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 354.872px;"><h2>Closing Remarks</h2><ul><li>Prof Fukunari Kimura, Chief Economist, ERIA</li></ul><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/u8GLhUNp-gM" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 354.872px;">&nbsp;</td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Download the concept note and programme" href="/uploads/media/Events/2022_March_RCEP-Monograph-Launch-Concept-Note-and-Programme_1.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CONCEPT NOTE AND PROGRAMME</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/293031273427" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p><p><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1">[1]</a> India has opted out of the agreement, but with some provisions to join RCEP in future.</p><p><a href="#_ftnref2" name="_ftn2">[2]</a> The ASEAN Framework for RCEP was adopted by the ASEAN Leaders during the 19th ASEAN Summit in November 2011 in Bali, Indonesia. The Joint Declaration of Ministers for launch of RCEP negotiations was done on 20 November 2012 in Phnom Penh, Cambodia during the 21st ASEAN Summit.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Hybrid event";s:5:"major";s:9:"Hardianti";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:45:"ERIA and the Ministry of Commerce of Cambodia";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-03-14";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-03-14";s:8:"keywords";s:12463:"Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership:  Implications, Challenges and Future Growth of East Asia and ASEAN Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership:  Implications, Challenges and Future Growth of East Asia and ASEAN The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is the largest free trade agreement in 2020, completed on 15 November 2020, comprising 10 members of ASEAN (Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam) and five other regional countries that ASEAN has existing free trade agreements: Australia, China, India, Japan, South Korea, and New Zealand.[1][2] Currently, it is the largest trading block in the world consisting of a combined population of 2.2 billion people (30% of the world population), total regional gross domestic product (GDP) of around $38,813 billion (30% of global GDP in 2019), and nearly 28% of global trade.
It sets an important agenda for trade and investment in global trade in terms of opening large domestic market (demand), releasing huge resources for trade and investment, and creating dynamic regional and global value-chain activities.
The RCEP as a 'living' agreement will be able to create a wider regional integration agenda to address key contemporary issues such as the environment and climate change, skills development, green transformation, and developing digital and smart urban centres. ASEAN centrality, as highlighted by the RCEP framework, is critical for the post-pandemic recovery and structural transformation of the region.&nbsp;
As part of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) research project, this workshop aims to address the structure of the RCEP in terms of the complexity of the RCEP commitments modalities and mechanism, it explores the various elements of the agreement and discusses the key potential implications to the integration process in the region. For example, it will carefully examine the commitments and compare them with those of other agreements, including the CPTPP. The project underlines some key features of the agreement and analyses how these could strengthen regional integration. The impact of businesses, behind-the-border issues, and the domestic capacity of the respective RCEP member countries will also be discussed, in addition to a formal assessment of the potential benefits of the RCEP. Finally, this study also attempts to address emerging issues especially with respect to the COVID-19 pandemic recovery.
The workshop, organised by ERIA in collaboration with the Ministry of Commerce, Kingdom of Cambodia as a side-event for Cambodia ASEAN Chairmanship, will also include a book launch titled 'Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership: Implications, Challenges and Future Growth of East Asia and ASEAN'.
Event Details

Date: Monday, 14 March 2022
Time: 8:30 AM- 3:30 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)

Read the Press Release
Download the Monograph
Relive the Webinar

Professor Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of ERIA

Launching of the ERIA RCEP&nbsp;
Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership: Implications, Challenges, and Future Growth of East Asia and ASEAN&nbsp;

The Implications of RCEP for Asian Regional Integration

Dr Shiro Armstrong, Australian National University

Moderator: HE Penn Sovicheat, Under-Secretary of State, Ministry of Commerce, Kingdom of Cambodia

Potential Impact of RCEP and Structural Transformation of Cambodia

Comparison of RCEP and Other Free Trade Agreements

CONCEPT NOTE AND PROGRAMME
REGISTER NOW
[1] India has opted out of the agreement, but with some provisions to join RCEP in future.
[2] The ASEAN Framework for RCEP was adopted by the ASEAN Leaders during the 19th ASEAN Summit in November 2011 in Bali, Indonesia. The Joint Declaration of Ministers for launch of RCEP negotiations was done on 20 November 2012 in Phnom Penh, Cambodia during the 21st ASEAN Summit. 17:38:58";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";s:0:"";s:10:"majorEmail";s:18:"hardianti@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:149;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6641";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:42:"the-future-of-education-and-skills-in-asia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:42:"The Future of Education and Skills in Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-03-10";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"3";s:7:"content";s:5565:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/The-Future-of-Education-%26-Skills-in-Asia_cover_800x408.png" alt="" width="800" height="408" /></p><p>The robust technological innovation has transformed a new pathway in the education ecosystem. New skills are required to compete in the current 4IR industry and development. Building the future of education systems requires the curricula as a solid foundation to foster the creation of new skills and abilities in the 4IR industry. In ensuring inclusion and equity in education, it is important to engage with the underprivileged, gender equality, and disability.&nbsp;</p><p>ERIA in partnership with The Asian Network will host a virtual conference on&nbsp;<em>&lsquo;The Future of Education and Skills in Asia&rsquo;</em>&nbsp;on March 10th, 2022. This virtual conference will gather 12 Leaders from Asia (Cambodia, Japan, India, Indonesia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam) sharing their expertise in Education, Entrepreneurship, Skills, and Technology for Good.</p><p>H.E Hang Chuon Naron, Minister of Education, Youths and Sports of Cambodia; Mrs Sofia Shakil, Director Economic programs of The Asia Foundation; Mrs Mariagrazia Squicciarini, Chief of Executive Office Social and Human Sciences Sector of UNESCO; Mrs Yuri Obara Belfali, Head of Early Childhood and Schools of OECD will also deliver special remarks in this virtual conference.&nbsp;</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 10&nbsp;March 2022</li><li>Time: 2 PM- 6 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7))</li><li>RSVP:&nbsp;<a NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:26:"ERIA and the Asian Network";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-03-10";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-03-10";s:8:"keywords";s:6753:"The Future of Education and Skills in Asia The Future of Education and Skills in Asia The robust technological innovation has transformed a new pathway in the education ecosystem. New skills are required to compete in the current 4IR industry and development. Building the future of education systems requires the curricula as a solid foundation to foster the creation of new skills and abilities in the 4IR industry. In ensuring inclusion and equity in education, it is important to engage with the underprivileged, gender equality, and disability.&nbsp;
ERIA in partnership with The Asian Network will host a virtual conference on&nbsp;&lsquo;The Future of Education and Skills in Asia&rsquo;&nbsp;on March 10th, 2022. This virtual conference will gather 12 Leaders from Asia (Cambodia, Japan, India, Indonesia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam) sharing their expertise in Education, Entrepreneurship, Skills, and Technology for Good.
H.E Hang Chuon Naron, Minister of Education, Youths and Sports of Cambodia; Mrs Sofia Shakil, Director Economic programs of The Asia Foundation; Mrs Mariagrazia Squicciarini, Chief of Executive Office Social and Human Sciences Sector of UNESCO; Mrs Yuri Obara Belfali, Head of Early Childhood and Schools of OECD will also deliver special remarks in this virtual conference.&nbsp;
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 10&nbsp;March 2022
Time: 2 PM- 6 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7))
RSVP:&nbsp;https://www.runtheworld.today/app/c/education_skills_asia

Many of the region&#039;s hard-won gains in reducing poverty, creating jobs, and enhancing health and well-being have been reversed, with the poor and vulnerable particularly hard-hit.&nbsp;</p><p>While countries continue to grapple with the severe economic, health, and social impacts of the pandemic, vaccine rollouts, the promise of new treatments, substantial economic relief, and targeted social support are helping to make inroads. Green shoots of recovery are starting to appear, and Southeast Asian nations are now laying the groundwork for reopening, and a more enduring recovery.</p><p>The Southeast Asia Development Symposium (SEADS) 2022, &#039;<strong>Sustainable Solutions for Southeast Asia&#039;s Recovery,&#039;</strong>&nbsp;happening on 16-17 March, will explore measures that can help the region &#039;build back better&#039; and rebound from the pandemic.</p><p>SEADS 2022 will focus on actionable solutions supporting three key lynchpins of the region&#039;s recovery and revitalization:&nbsp;</p><ul><li>Addressing debilitating supply chain bottlenecks;</li><li>Rejuvenating the region&#039;s once-flourishing tourism industry; and</li><li>Advancing digital transformation.</li></ul><p>SEADS 2022 will also explore new opportunities that can take the region beyond business as usual by helping countries:</p><ul><li>Enhance domestic resource mobilization;</li><li>Find green and environmentally sustainable pathways;</li><li>Improve inclusivity for the poor and other vulnerable groups; and</li><li>Promote equality and greater opportunities for women.</li></ul><p>It is hoped that SEADS 2022 can contribute to dialogue at the 2022 ASEAN Finance Ministers&#039; Meeting, ADB Annual Meeting, and G20 Summit (being hosted by Indonesia).</p><p>On 16 March at 1:30&nbsp;PM (UTC+8), the SEADS 2022 session on Women Driving Sustainable Transformation in ASEAN, organised by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in collaboration with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), will discuss how women are driving the sustainable transition in Southeast Asia.</p><table width="100%"><tr><td><table href="https://seads.adb.org/symposium/2022/registration" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:14:"Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:12:"ADB and ERIA";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-03-16";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-03-16";s:8:"keywords";s:6307:"ADB SEADS 2022: Women Driving Sustainable Transformation in ASEAN ADB SEADS 2022: Women Driving Sustainable Transformation in ASEAN The pandemic has had a deep and profound impact throughout Southeast Asia. Many of the region's hard-won gains in reducing poverty, creating jobs, and enhancing health and well-being have been reversed, with the poor and vulnerable particularly hard-hit.&nbsp;
While countries continue to grapple with the severe economic, health, and social impacts of the pandemic, vaccine rollouts, the promise of new treatments, substantial economic relief, and targeted social support are helping to make inroads. Green shoots of recovery are starting to appear, and Southeast Asian nations are now laying the groundwork for reopening, and a more enduring recovery.
The Southeast Asia Development Symposium (SEADS) 2022, 'Sustainable Solutions for Southeast Asia's Recovery,'&nbsp;happening on 16-17 March, will explore measures that can help the region 'build back better' and rebound from the pandemic.
SEADS 2022 will focus on actionable solutions supporting three key lynchpins of the region's recovery and revitalization:&nbsp;

Addressing debilitating supply chain bottlenecks;
Rejuvenating the region's once-flourishing tourism industry; and
Advancing digital transformation.

SEADS 2022 will also explore new opportunities that can take the region beyond business as usual by helping countries:

Enhance domestic resource mobilization;
Find green and environmentally sustainable pathways;
Improve inclusivity for the poor and other vulnerable groups; and
Promote equality and greater opportunities for women.

It is hoped that SEADS 2022 can contribute to dialogue at the 2022 ASEAN Finance Ministers' Meeting, ADB Annual Meeting, and G20 Summit (being hosted by Indonesia).
On 16 March at 1:30&nbsp;PM (UTC+8), the SEADS 2022 session on Women Driving Sustainable Transformation in ASEAN, organised by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in collaboration with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), will discuss how women are driving the sustainable transition in Southeast Asia.












Agenda:
(UTC+8)




1:30-1:33 PM


Opening remarks by Ramesh SubramaniamDirector-General, Southeast Asia Regional Department, ADB&nbsp;




1:33-1:40 PM


Remarks by Dr Ing Kantha PhaviMinister of Women's Affairs, Cambodia




1:40-2:40 PM


Panel discussion

Moderator: Sonomi Tanaka, Country Director, Lao PDR, ADB&nbsp;
Denica Riadini-Flesch,&nbsp;Founder and CEO, SukkhaCitta&nbsp;
Von Leong,&nbsp;Co-Founder and General Partner, Purpose Venture Capital&nbsp;
Priyanka Chetry, CEO of Grocerdel
Dr Vanny Narita,&nbsp;Senior Officer, Science and Technology Division, ASEAN Economic Community Department, ASEAN Secretariat&nbsp;





2:40-2:55 PM


Q&amp;A session




2:55-3:00 PM


Closing remarks by Dr Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Strategy and Partnership Director, ERIA

;psbn&.tih-drah ylralucitrap elbarenluv dna roop eht htiw ,desrever neeb evah gnieb-llew dna htlaeh gnicnahne dna ,sboj gnitaerc ,ytrevop gnicuder ni sniag now-drah s'noiger eht fo ynaM .aisA tsaehtuoS tuohguorht tcapmi dnuoforp dna peed a dah sah cimednap ehT NAESA ni noitamrofsnarT elbaniatsuS gnivirD nemoW :2202 SDAES BDA NAESA ni noitamrofsnarT elbaniatsuS gnivirD nemoW :2202 SDAES BDA";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-02-24 14:02:26";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-03-14 15:15:01";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";s:0:"";s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:151;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6627";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:29:"australias-experience-on-ccus";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:30:"Australia's Experience on CCUS";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-02-28";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"2";s:7:"content";s:4447:"<p><strong><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022-Feb-5thACN.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></strong></p><p><strong>The 5<sup>th</sup> Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference</strong></p><p>The Asia CCUS Network was successfully launched on 22-23rd June 2021. Currently 14 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, India and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions are joining the Network. Members share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region, and the Asia CCUS Network aims to contribute through the collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS through organizing knowledge sharing conference regarding CCUS.</p><p>The Australian Government is focused on accelerating large-scale deployment of CCUS under its Long-Term Emissions Reduction Plan through a range of measures and initiatives such as the National CCUS Technology Emissions Abatement Strategy (NCAS), the CCUS Development Fund and CCUS Hubs and Technologies programs. Underpinning these efforts is the technical and research work undertaken by key scientific and research organisations such as the CSIRO and Geoscience Australia. Australia is interested in working with like-minded countries on ways to deploy CCUS and values forums such as the Asia CCUS Network to share experiences and expertise.</p><p>This conference aims to share the experience from Australia on CCUS policy development as well as experiences from CCUS Development Fund grantees. There will be three guest speakers from Australia. Corporate Carbon who has received funding to support the development of direct air capture technology couple with solar PV that can produce a clean fuel with carbon neutrality.</p><p>The second speaker will be from Mineral Carbonation International who will talk about their world-first mineral carbonation mobile demonstration plant. And the final speaker is from Carbon Transport and Storage, a Glencore company, who&#039;s project aims to demonstrate the technical viability, integration and safe operation of CCS in the Surat Basin in Queensland, Australia.</p><p><strong>Agendaï¿½</strong></p><table style="height: 553px; width: 865.5px;"><tr><td style="width: 225px;">3 PM - 3:10 PM</td><td style="width: 623.5px;"><p><strong>Opening</strong></p><ul><li>Taizo Hara, Director General of Research and Policy Design Administration of ERIA (3-5 minutes)</li><li>Dan Quinn, General Manager, Resource Strategy, Onshore Resources Division, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources, Australia (3-5 minutes)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 225px;">3: 10 PM - 3:45 PM</td><td style="width: 623.5px;"><p><strong>Introduction of Australian CCUS Projects: Direct Air Capture, Carbon Recycling and CO2 Storage </strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong><strong>Dr Han Phoumin, ERIA</strong></p><ul><li>Julian Turecek, Executive Director/ Project Director, Direct Air Capture (DAC) <strong>Corporate Carbon</strong>: &#039;Solar powered direct air capture&#039;</li><li>Sophia Hamblin Wang, Chief Operating Officer, <strong>Mineral Carbonation International </strong>(MCI) : &#039;A scalable carbon platform technology that safely captures and converts industrial CO2 emissions into solid bulk materials used in new low-carbon products for construction, industrial and consumer markets and enabling the circular economy&#039;.</li><li>Darren Greer, General Manager:&nbsp;<strong>Carbon Transport and Storage</strong>, a Glencore Company (CTSCo): &#039;Technical viability, integration and safe operation of CCS in the Surat Basin in Queensland, Australia&#039;</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 225px;">3:45 PM - 4 PM</td><td style="width: 623.5px;"><p><strong>Comments</strong></p><ul><li>Souksakhone Philavanh, Director of Energy Law Division, Department of Law, Ministry of Energy and Mines, Government of the Lao PDR</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 225px;">4 PM - 4:25 PM</td><td style="width: 623.5px;"><strong>Open discussion Session</strong></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 225px;">4:25 PM - 4:30 PM</td><td style="width: 623.5px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks </strong></p><ul><li>Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/270760049597"><strong>REGISTER NOW</strong></a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:12:"Ms Tri Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-02-28";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-02-28";s:8:"keywords";s:7337:"Australia's Experience on CCUS Australia's Experience on CCUS The 5th Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference
The Asia CCUS Network was successfully launched on 22-23rd June 2021. Currently 14 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, India and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions are joining the Network. Members share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region, and the Asia CCUS Network aims to contribute through the collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS through organizing knowledge sharing conference regarding CCUS.
The Australian Government is focused on accelerating large-scale deployment of CCUS under its Long-Term Emissions Reduction Plan through a range of measures and initiatives such as the National CCUS Technology Emissions Abatement Strategy (NCAS), the CCUS Development Fund and CCUS Hubs and Technologies programs. Underpinning these efforts is the technical and research work undertaken by key scientific and research organisations such as the CSIRO and Geoscience Australia. Australia is interested in working with like-minded countries on ways to deploy CCUS and values forums such as the Asia CCUS Network to share experiences and expertise.
This conference aims to share the experience from Australia on CCUS policy development as well as experiences from CCUS Development Fund grantees. There will be three guest speakers from Australia. Corporate Carbon who has received funding to support the development of direct air capture technology couple with solar PV that can produce a clean fuel with carbon neutrality.
The second speaker will be from Mineral Carbonation International who will talk about their world-first mineral carbonation mobile demonstration plant. And the final speaker is from Carbon Transport and Storage, a Glencore company, who's project aims to demonstrate the technical viability, integration and safe operation of CCS in the Surat Basin in Queensland, Australia.
Agendaï¿½



3 PM - 3:10 PM

Opening

Taizo Hara, Director General of Research and Policy Design Administration of ERIA (3-5 minutes)
Dan Quinn, General Manager, Resource Strategy, Onshore Resources Division, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources, Australia (3-5 minutes)




3: 10 PM - 3:45 PM

Introduction of Australian CCUS Projects: Direct Air Capture, Carbon Recycling and CO2 Storage 
Moderator:&nbsp;Dr Han Phoumin, ERIA

Julian Turecek, Executive Director/ Project Director, Direct Air Capture (DAC) Corporate Carbon: 'Solar powered direct air capture'
Sophia Hamblin Wang, Chief Operating Officer, Mineral Carbonation International (MCI) : 'A scalable carbon platform technology that safely captures and converts industrial CO2 emissions into solid bulk materials used in new low-carbon products for construction, industrial and consumer markets and enabling the circular economy'.
Darren Greer, General Manager:&nbsp;Carbon Transport and Storage, a Glencore Company (CTSCo): 'Technical viability, integration and safe operation of CCS in the Surat Basin in Queensland, Australia'




3:45 PM - 4 PM

Comments

Souksakhone Philavanh, Director of Energy Law Division, Department of Law, Ministry of Energy and Mines, Government of the Lao PDR




4 PM - 4:25 PM
Open discussion Session


4:25 PM - 4:30 PM

Closing Remarks 

Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA

ecnerefnoC gnirahS egdelwonK )NCA( krowteN SUCC aisA ht5 ehT SUCC no ecneirepxE s'ailartsuA SUCC no ecneirepxE s'ailartsuA";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-02-16 11:07:34";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-02-21 10:23:49";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";s:0:"";s:10:"majorEmail";s:18:"tri.manik@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:152;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6618";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:79:"toward-plastic-waste-free-thailand-single-use-plastic-reduction-and-replacement";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:80:"Toward Plastic Waste Free Thailand: Single Use Plastic Reduction and Replacement";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-02-18";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"2";s:7:"content";s:9991:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022-Feb-RKCMPD-PSP-WEBINAR-THAI_1.png" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p><strong>ASEAN+3 Private Sector Initiatives to Reduce Marine Plastics - online event series</strong></p><p>à¸—à¹ˆà¸²à¸™à¸ªà¸²à¸¡à¸²à¸£à¸–à¸­à¹ˆà¸²à¸™à¸„à¸³à¹à¸›à¸¥à¸ à¸²à¸©à¸²à¹„à¸—à¸¢à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸šà¸£à¸´à¹€à¸§à¸“à¸”à¹‰à¸²à¸™à¸¥à¹ˆà¸²à¸‡à¸‚à¹‰à¸­à¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸ à¸²à¸©à¸²à¸­à¸±à¸‡à¸à¸¤à¸©</p><p>ERIA&rsquo;s Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), in collaboration with Thailand Environment Institute (TEI), will discuss the role played by the private sectors in Thailand in the reduction of marine plastic debris, by shedding light on innovative approaches proposed to reduce and replace single-use plastics to address this pressing issue. Innovation, in this context will encompass a wide array of practices that distance themselves from the traditional linear (take-make-use-dispose) way of thinking and proposes more responsible and sustainable business models.</p><p>à¹ƒà¸™à¸›à¸±à¸ˆà¸ˆà¸¸à¸šà¸±à¸™ à¸ à¸²à¸„à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™à¹ƒà¸™à¸›à¸£à¸°à¹€à¸—à¸¨à¸ªà¸¡à¸²à¸Šà¸´à¸à¸­à¸²à¹€à¸‹à¸µà¸¢à¸™+3 à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸¡à¸µà¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¸ªà¸³à¸„à¸±à¸à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸¥à¸”à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸œà¸¥à¸à¸£à¸°à¸—à¸šà¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¸—à¸°à¹€à¸¥à¹ƒà¸™à¸ à¸¹à¸¡à¸´à¸ à¸²à¸„ à¸•à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¹à¸•à¹ˆà¸‚à¸±à¹‰à¸™à¸•à¸­à¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸œà¸¥à¸´à¸•à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸à¸²à¸£à¸šà¸£à¸´à¹‚à¸ à¸„ (à¹€à¸£à¸µà¸¢à¸à¸§à¹ˆà¸² "à¸•à¹‰à¸™à¸™à¹‰à¸³") à¹„à¸›à¸ˆà¸™à¸–à¸¶à¸‡à¸‚à¸±à¹‰à¸™à¸•à¸­à¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸£à¸µà¹„à¸‹à¹€à¸„à¸´à¸¥à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸à¸²à¸£à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¸à¸²à¸£à¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¹€à¸ªà¸µà¸¢ (à¹€à¸£à¸µà¸¢à¸à¸§à¹ˆà¸² "à¸›à¸¥à¸²à¸¢à¸™à¹‰à¸³") à¹ƒà¸™à¹‚à¸­à¸à¸²à¸ªà¸™à¸µà¹‰ RKC-MPD à¸ à¸²à¸¢à¹ƒà¸•à¹‰à¸à¸²à¸£à¸”à¸³à¹€à¸™à¸´à¸™à¸‡à¸²à¸™à¸‚à¸­à¸‡ ERIA à¸£à¹ˆà¸§à¸¡à¸à¸±à¸šà¸ªà¸–à¸²à¸šà¸±à¸™à¸ªà¸´à¹ˆà¸‡à¹à¸§à¸”à¸¥à¹‰à¸­à¸¡à¹„à¸—à¸¢ (TEI) à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¸‡à¸²à¸™à¸ªà¸±à¸¡à¸¡à¸™à¸²à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸ˆà¸°à¹à¸ªà¸”à¸‡à¸šà¸—à¸šà¸²à¸—à¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¸ à¸²à¸„à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™à¹ƒà¸™à¸›à¸£à¸°à¹€à¸—à¸¨à¹„à¸—à¸¢à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸à¸²à¸£à¸¥à¸”à¹à¸¥à¸°à¹ƒà¸Šà¹‰à¸§à¸±à¸ªà¸”à¸¸à¸—à¸”à¹à¸—à¸™à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¹à¸šà¸šà¹ƒà¸Šà¹‰à¸„à¸£à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¹€à¸”à¸µà¸¢à¸§à¸—à¸´à¹‰à¸‡ à¹€à¸žà¸·à¹ˆà¸­à¸Šà¹ˆà¸§à¸¢à¹à¸à¹‰à¹„à¸‚à¸›à¸±à¸à¸«à¸²à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¸—à¸°à¹€à¸¥</p><p>The forum will be an occasion for the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) of Thailand, a Thai business alliance, and Thai private companies, and other stakeholders to stocktake the progress made, and discuss the many ways private companies can contribute in combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris. RKC-MPD will reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP) to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness of the platform and attract a larger number of private companies to join the fight against marine plastics.</p><p>à¸à¸²à¸£à¸ªà¸±à¸¡à¸¡à¸™à¸²à¸„à¸£à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¸™à¸µà¹‰à¸–à¸·à¸­à¹€à¸›à¹‡à¸™à¹‚à¸­à¸à¸²à¸ªà¸ªà¸³à¸«à¸£à¸±à¸šà¸«à¸™à¹ˆà¸§à¸¢à¸‡à¸²à¸™à¸ à¸²à¸„à¸£à¸±à¸ à¸à¸¥à¸¸à¹ˆà¸¡à¸ à¸²à¸„à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™ à¸šà¸£à¸´à¸©à¸±à¸—à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™ à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸œà¸¹à¹‰à¸¡à¸µà¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¹€à¸ªà¸µà¸¢à¸­à¸·à¹ˆà¸™ à¹† à¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¸›à¸£à¸°à¹€à¸—à¸¨à¹„à¸—à¸¢ à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸£à¸§à¸šà¸£à¸§à¸¡à¸‚à¹‰à¸­à¸¡à¸¹à¸¥à¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸à¹‰à¸²à¸§à¸«à¸™à¹‰à¸²à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸”à¸³à¹€à¸™à¸´à¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸«à¸²à¸£à¸·à¸­à¹€à¸à¸µà¹ˆà¸¢à¸§à¸à¸±à¸šà¸§à¸´à¸˜à¸µà¸à¸²à¸£à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸šà¸£à¸´à¸©à¸±à¸—à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™à¸ªà¸²à¸¡à¸²à¸£à¸–à¸¡à¸µà¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¸£à¹ˆà¸§à¸¡à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¸à¸²à¸£à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¸—à¸°à¹€à¸¥ à¸£à¸§à¸¡à¸—à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¸™à¸³à¹€à¸ªà¸™à¸­ Private Sector Platform (PSP) à¸‚à¸­à¸‡ RKC-MPD à¹‚à¸”à¸¢à¹€à¸‰à¸žà¸²à¸°à¸à¸±à¸šà¸šà¸£à¸´à¸©à¸±à¸—à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™ à¹€à¸žà¸·à¹ˆà¸­à¸ªà¸£à¹‰à¸²à¸‡à¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸•à¸£à¸°à¸«à¸™à¸±à¸à¸£à¸¹à¹‰à¹€à¸à¸µà¹ˆà¸¢à¸§à¸à¸±à¸šà¹à¸žà¸¥à¸•à¸Ÿà¸­à¸£à¹Œà¸¡à¹à¸¥à¸°à¹€à¸Šà¸´à¸à¸Šà¸§à¸™à¸šà¸£à¸´à¸©à¸±à¸—à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™à¹€à¸‚à¹‰à¸²à¸¡à¸²à¸¡à¸µà¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¸£à¹ˆà¸§à¸¡à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¸à¸²à¸£à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¸—à¸°à¹€à¸¥</p><p><strong>Date and Time:&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p><p>18 February 2022, 10:00-12:00, Bangkok time (GMT+7)</p><p><strong>Agenda:&nbsp;</strong></p><table width="654"><tr><td width="198"><p><strong>TIME</strong></p></td><td width="439"><p><strong>AGENDA&nbsp;</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="198"><p>10:00 &ndash; font-family: &#039;Calibri&#039;,sans-serif; color: #201f1e;">The webinar can be watched both in English and in Thai (bilingual event)</span></p><p style="background: white;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: &#039;Leelawadee UI&#039;,sans-serif; color: #201f1e;">à¸‡à¸²à¸™à¸ªà¸±à¸¡à¸¡à¸™à¸²à¸™à¸µà¹‰à¹€à¸›à¹‡à¸™à¸‡à¸²à¸™à¸£à¸¹à¸›à¹à¸šà¸šà¸ªà¸­à¸‡à¸ à¸²à¸©à¸²</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: &#039;Calibri&#039;,sans-serif; color: #201f1e;">&nbsp;</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: &#039;Leelawadee UI&#039;,sans-serif; color: #201f1e;">à¸—à¹ˆà¸²à¸™à¸ªà¸²à¸¡à¸²à¸£à¸–à¸£à¸±à¸šà¸Šà¸¡à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸—à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¸ à¸²à¸©à¸²à¸­à¸±à¸‡à¸à¸¤à¸©à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸ à¸²à¸©à¸²à¹„à¸—à¸¢</span></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/uploads/media/Events/Concept%20Note%20_Thailand%20PSP%20event_11Feb2022.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CONCEPT NOTE</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/toward-plastic-waste-free-thailand--tickets-261620382607" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:13:"Ms Hera Diani";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-02-18";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:17191:"Toward Plastic Waste Free Thailand: Single Use Plastic Reduction and Replacement Toward Plastic Waste Free Thailand: Single Use Plastic Reduction and Replacement ASEAN+3 Private Sector Initiatives to Reduce Marine Plastics - online event series
à¸—à¹ˆà¸²à¸™à¸ªà¸²à¸¡à¸²à¸£à¸–à¸­à¹ˆà¸²à¸™à¸„à¸³à¹à¸›à¸¥à¸ à¸²à¸©à¸²à¹„à¸—à¸¢à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸šà¸£à¸´à¹€à¸§à¸“à¸”à¹‰à¸²à¸™à¸¥à¹ˆà¸²à¸‡à¸‚à¹‰à¸­à¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸ à¸²à¸©à¸²à¸­à¸±à¸‡à¸à¸¤à¸©
ERIA&rsquo;s Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), in collaboration with Thailand Environment Institute (TEI), will discuss the role played by the private sectors in Thailand in the reduction of marine plastic debris, by shedding light on innovative approaches proposed to reduce and replace single-use plastics to address this pressing issue. Innovation, in this context will encompass a wide array of practices that distance themselves from the traditional linear (take-make-use-dispose) way of thinking and proposes more responsible and sustainable business models.
à¹ƒà¸™à¸›à¸±à¸ˆà¸ˆà¸¸à¸šà¸±à¸™ à¸ à¸²à¸„à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™à¹ƒà¸™à¸›à¸£à¸°à¹€à¸—à¸¨à¸ªà¸¡à¸²à¸Šà¸´à¸à¸­à¸²à¹€à¸‹à¸µà¸¢à¸™+3 à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸¡à¸µà¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¸ªà¸³à¸„à¸±à¸à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸¥à¸”à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸œà¸¥à¸à¸£à¸°à¸—à¸šà¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¸—à¸°à¹€à¸¥à¹ƒà¸™à¸ à¸¹à¸¡à¸´à¸ à¸²à¸„ à¸•à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¹à¸•à¹ˆà¸‚à¸±à¹‰à¸™à¸•à¸­à¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸œà¸¥à¸´à¸•à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸à¸²à¸£à¸šà¸£à¸´à¹‚à¸ à¸„ (à¹€à¸£à¸µà¸¢à¸à¸§à¹ˆà¸² "à¸•à¹‰à¸™à¸™à¹‰à¸³") à¹„à¸›à¸ˆà¸™à¸–à¸¶à¸‡à¸‚à¸±à¹‰à¸™à¸•à¸­à¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸£à¸µà¹„à¸‹à¹€à¸„à¸´à¸¥à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸à¸²à¸£à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¸à¸²à¸£à¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¹€à¸ªà¸µà¸¢ (à¹€à¸£à¸µà¸¢à¸à¸§à¹ˆà¸² "à¸›à¸¥à¸²à¸¢à¸™à¹‰à¸³") à¹ƒà¸™à¹‚à¸­à¸à¸²à¸ªà¸™à¸µà¹‰ RKC-MPD à¸ à¸²à¸¢à¹ƒà¸•à¹‰à¸à¸²à¸£à¸”à¸³à¹€à¸™à¸´à¸™à¸‡à¸²à¸™à¸‚à¸­à¸‡ ERIA à¸£à¹ˆà¸§à¸¡à¸à¸±à¸šà¸ªà¸–à¸²à¸šà¸±à¸™à¸ªà¸´à¹ˆà¸‡à¹à¸§à¸”à¸¥à¹‰à¸­à¸¡à¹„à¸—à¸¢ (TEI) à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¸‡à¸²à¸™à¸ªà¸±à¸¡à¸¡à¸™à¸²à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸ˆà¸°à¹à¸ªà¸”à¸‡à¸šà¸—à¸šà¸²à¸—à¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¸ à¸²à¸„à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™à¹ƒà¸™à¸›à¸£à¸°à¹€à¸—à¸¨à¹„à¸—à¸¢à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸à¸²à¸£à¸¥à¸”à¹à¸¥à¸°à¹ƒà¸Šà¹‰à¸§à¸±à¸ªà¸”à¸¸à¸—à¸”à¹à¸—à¸™à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¹à¸šà¸šà¹ƒà¸Šà¹‰à¸„à¸£à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¹€à¸”à¸µà¸¢à¸§à¸—à¸´à¹‰à¸‡ à¹€à¸žà¸·à¹ˆà¸­à¸Šà¹ˆà¸§à¸¢à¹à¸à¹‰à¹„à¸‚à¸›à¸±à¸à¸«à¸²à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¸—à¸°à¹€à¸¥
The forum will be an occasion for the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) of Thailand, a Thai business alliance, and Thai private companies, and other stakeholders to stocktake the progress made, and discuss the many ways private companies can contribute in combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris. RKC-MPD will reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP) to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness of the platform and attract a larger number of private companies to join the fight against marine plastics.
à¸à¸²à¸£à¸ªà¸±à¸¡à¸¡à¸™à¸²à¸„à¸£à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¸™à¸µà¹‰à¸–à¸·à¸­à¹€à¸›à¹‡à¸™à¹‚à¸­à¸à¸²à¸ªà¸ªà¸³à¸«à¸£à¸±à¸šà¸«à¸™à¹ˆà¸§à¸¢à¸‡à¸²à¸™à¸ à¸²à¸„à¸£à¸±à¸ à¸à¸¥à¸¸à¹ˆà¸¡à¸ à¸²à¸„à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™ à¸šà¸£à¸´à¸©à¸±à¸—à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™ à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸œà¸¹à¹‰à¸¡à¸µà¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¹€à¸ªà¸µà¸¢à¸­à¸·à¹ˆà¸™ à¹† à¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¸›à¸£à¸°à¹€à¸—à¸¨à¹„à¸—à¸¢ à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸£à¸§à¸šà¸£à¸§à¸¡à¸‚à¹‰à¸­à¸¡à¸¹à¸¥à¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸à¹‰à¸²à¸§à¸«à¸™à¹‰à¸²à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸”à¸³à¹€à¸™à¸´à¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸«à¸²à¸£à¸·à¸­à¹€à¸à¸µà¹ˆà¸¢à¸§à¸à¸±à¸šà¸§à¸´à¸˜à¸µà¸à¸²à¸£à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸šà¸£à¸´à¸©à¸±à¸—à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™à¸ªà¸²à¸¡à¸²à¸£à¸–à¸¡à¸µà¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¸£à¹ˆà¸§à¸¡à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¸à¸²à¸£à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¹à¸¥à¸°à¸‚à¸¢à¸°à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¸—à¸°à¹€à¸¥ à¸£à¸§à¸¡à¸—à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¸™à¸³à¹€à¸ªà¸™à¸­ Private Sector Platform (PSP) à¸‚à¸­à¸‡ RKC-MPD à¹‚à¸”à¸¢à¹€à¸‰à¸žà¸²à¸°à¸à¸±à¸šà¸šà¸£à¸´à¸©à¸±à¸—à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™ à¹€à¸žà¸·à¹ˆà¸­à¸ªà¸£à¹‰à¸²à¸‡à¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸•à¸£à¸°à¸«à¸™à¸±à¸à¸£à¸¹à¹‰à¹€à¸à¸µà¹ˆà¸¢à¸§à¸à¸±à¸šà¹à¸žà¸¥à¸•à¸Ÿà¸­à¸£à¹Œà¸¡à¹à¸¥à¸°à¹€à¸Šà¸´à¸à¸Šà¸§à¸™à¸šà¸£à¸´à¸©à¸±à¸—à¹€à¸­à¸à¸Šà¸™à¹€à¸‚à¹‰à¸²à¸¡à¸²à¸¡à¸µà¸ªà¹ˆà¸§à¸™à¸£à¹ˆà¸§à¸¡à¹ƒà¸™à¸à¸²à¸£à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¸à¸²à¸£à¸žà¸¥à¸²à¸ªà¸•à¸´à¸à¸—à¸°à¹€à¸¥

seires tneve enilno - scitsalP eniraM ecudeR ot sevitaitinI rotceS etavirP 3+NAESA tnemecalpeR dna noitcudeR citsalP esU elgniS :dnaliahT eerF etsaW citsalP drawoT tnemecalpeR dna noitcudeR citsalP esU elgniS :dnaliahT eerF etsaW citsalP drawoT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-02-04 14:52:52";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-02-16 11:09:52";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:19:"hera.diani@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:153;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6606";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:111:"unpacking-the-rcep-agreement-public-private-dialogue-2-the-rcep-rules-of-origin-and-what-they-mean-for-cambodia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:113:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement, Public-Private Dialogue 2: The RCEP Rules of Origin and What They Mean for Cambodia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-02-10";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"2";s:7:"content";s:3695:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022-January-10-RCEP-Rules-of-Origin-PPD-Photo-flyer.png" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p>The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement amongst 15 states. RCEP will create new business opportunities and change the shape of trade in the region.</p><p>ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme is organising a series of five Public-Private Dialogues, &#039;Unpacking the RCEP Agreement&#039;. Dialogue 2 will discuss the Rules of Origin that determines which goods originate from RCEP member countries, so can benefit from preferential tariff treatment. As RCEP consolidates ROO by making it easier for exporters to cumulate and rely on a single proof of origin, it will also facilitates the cross-border trade and speeds up delivery amongst RCEP countries. Glean insights together with our distinguished panel of speakers.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Thursday, 10 February 2022, 9 AM&nbsp;&ndash; 11 AM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><h2>Agenda (as of 8 February 2022)</h2><table style="width: 616px;"><tr><td style="width: 106.556px;"><p>9:00 &ndash; 9:10</p></td><td style="width: 494.444px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks: </strong></p><p>H.E. RCEP will create new business opportunities and change the shape of trade in the region.
ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme is organising a series of five Public-Private Dialogues, 'Unpacking the RCEP Agreement'. Dialogue 2 will discuss the Rules of Origin that determines which goods originate from RCEP member countries, so can benefit from preferential tariff treatment. As RCEP consolidates ROO by making it easier for exporters to cumulate and rely on a single proof of origin, it will also facilitates the cross-border trade and speeds up delivery amongst RCEP countries. Glean insights together with our distinguished panel of speakers.&nbsp;
Date and Time:
Thursday, 10 February 2022, 9 AM&nbsp;&ndash; 11 AM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Agenda (as of 8 February 2022)




9:00 &ndash; 9:10


Opening Remarks: 
H.E. SIM Sokheng, Secretary of State, Ministry of Commerce
Mr. Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building, ERIA




9:10 - 09:40


Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Rules of Origin Provisions
Moderator: Mr. Sven Callebaut, International Trade and E-Trade Adviser
Presenters:

Ms. Deborah Elms,&nbsp;Executive Director, Asian Trade Centre
Mr UN Chantha, Director of Export Import Department, Ministry of Commerce

&nbsp;Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will provide a precise description of what the RCEP provisions are and whether Cambodia&rsquo;s legal and regulatory system is fit-for-purpose.




09:40 &ndash; 10:30


Session 2: Private sector perspectives on opportunities for Cambodia in RCEP
Moderator:&nbsp;Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building, ERIA.&nbsp;
Panelists:

Mr Clint O&rsquo;Connell, Partner and Head of Tax and Customs, DFDL
Mr Robin Flint, First Secretary, Australian Embassy in Cambodia (currently seconded to MoC Cambodia)

Q&amp;A with the audience. This session will enable different business interests to assess their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP agreement could be a game changer in their industry.&nbsp;




10.30-10:45


Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on The RCEP Rules of Origin and What They Mean for Cambodia 
By: HE SOK Siphana, Senior Advisor to the Royal Government of Cambodia
Q&amp;A with the audience.




10:45 &ndash; 11:00


Closing remarks by ERIA
