.noiger eht ni edart fo epahs eht egnahc dna seitinutroppo ssenisub wen etaerc lliw PECR .setats 51 tsgnoma tnemeerga edart eerf a fo tnemhsilbatse eht skram )PECR( pihsrentraP cimonocE evisneherpmoC lanoigeR ehT aidobmaC rof naeM yehT tahW dna nigirO fo seluR PECR ehT :2 eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP ,tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU aidobmaC rof naeM yehT tahW dna nigirO fo seluR PECR ehT :2 eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP ,tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-01-27 11:08:10";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-02-09 19:12:21";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"16";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:154;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6602";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:146:"oecd-eria-high-level-event-on-gearing-up-for-a-post-pandemic-world-designing-policies-for-an-innovative-and-sustainable-recovery-in-southeast-asia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:147:"OECD-ERIA High-Level Event on Gearing up for a Post-Pandemic World: Designing Policies for an Innovative and Sustainable Recovery in Southeast Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-02-08";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"2";s:7:"content";s:2432:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_Feb_Flyer_OECD_ERIA_1.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Amid a global context of recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, countries, industries and firms are faced with the intensification of two core transformational trends to society: on the one hand, the increased adoption of digital technologies can be key to spurring a leap in aggregate productivity and promoting the catch-up of actors that were previously lagging behind. On the other, it has become clear that innovation and systemic change will be crucial in confronting the challenge of climate change and achieving carbon neutrality for sustainable long-term economic growth. Governments can play a decisive role in designing industry, innovation and entrepreneurship policy mixes that allow firms to better navigate and thrive during these transitions.</p><p>The objective of this high-level panel is to approach these pressing questions with and among regional stakeholders in Southeast Asia. The discussion of recent analysis from OECD, ERIA, and partner organisations will also serve as a channel to gather feedback and ideas from actors in the region on the mechanisms that may help boost productivity, digital technology diffusion and integration of global value chains (GVCs) across Southeast Asia.</p><p><strong>Speakers</strong>:</p><ul><li><strong>Jaehan Cho </strong>(Director, Innovative Growth Policy Division, Korea Institute for Industrial Economics and Trade)</li><li><strong>Venkatachalam Anbumozhi</strong> (Director of Research Strategy and Innovation)</li><li><strong>Julia Tijaja</strong> (Former Director of ASEAN Integration Monitoring at the ASEAN Secretariat)</li><li><strong>Siah Hwee Ang</strong> (Professor of International Business and Strategy and Director of Southeast Asia Centre of Asia-Pacific Excellence, Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand)</li></ul><p>Moderator: <strong>Chiara Criscuolo </strong>(Head, Productivity, Innovation and Entrepreneurship Division, OECD)</p><p><strong>Date, time :</strong></p><p>Tuesday, 8 February 2022, 2 PM - 3:30 PM (Jakarta time, UTC +7)</p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/uploads/media/Events/2022_Feb_Agenda-OECD-ERIA.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">AGENDA</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://meetoecd1.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_si1IoUnDSguNiBW5nhG9pQ" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:9:"OECD-ERIA";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-02-08";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4571:"OECD-ERIA High-Level Event on Gearing up for a Post-Pandemic World: Designing Policies for an Innovative and Sustainable Recovery in Southeast Asia OECD-ERIA High-Level Event on Gearing up for a Post-Pandemic World: Designing Policies for an Innovative and Sustainable Recovery in Southeast Asia Amid a global context of recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, countries, industries and firms are faced with the intensification of two core transformational trends to society: on the one hand, the increased adoption of digital technologies can be key to spurring a leap in aggregate productivity and promoting the catch-up of actors that were previously lagging behind. On the other, it has become clear that innovation and systemic change will be crucial in confronting the challenge of climate change and achieving carbon neutrality for sustainable long-term economic growth. Governments can play a decisive role in designing industry, innovation and entrepreneurship policy mixes that allow firms to better navigate and thrive during these transitions.
The objective of this high-level panel is to approach these pressing questions with and among regional stakeholders in Southeast Asia. The discussion of recent analysis from OECD, ERIA, and partner organisations will also serve as a channel to gather feedback and ideas from actors in the region on the mechanisms that may help boost productivity, digital technology diffusion and integration of global value chains (GVCs) across Southeast Asia.
Speakers:

Jaehan Cho (Director, Innovative Growth Policy Division, Korea Institute for Industrial Economics and Trade)
Venkatachalam Anbumozhi (Director of Research Strategy and Innovation)
Julia Tijaja (Former Director of ASEAN Integration Monitoring at the ASEAN Secretariat)
Siah Hwee Ang (Professor of International Business and Strategy and Director of Southeast Asia Centre of Asia-Pacific Excellence, Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand)

Moderator: Chiara Criscuolo (Head, Productivity, Innovation and Entrepreneurship Division, OECD)
Date, time :
Tuesday, 8 February 2022, 2 PM - 3:30 PM (Jakarta time, UTC +7)
AGENDA

Rainy Days: High Season for Marine Plastic Litter? The Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) of ERIA, in collaboration with UNDP Indonesia, invite you to discuss the on-going rainy season and how plastic litter might have bigger impact to people&rsquo;s livelihood.
SDG Talks on marine plastic debris is stressing the dire situation of marine plastic debris and the role of youth around the world to ensure a better future through activism, diplomacy, interests, and how to lead by examples. The talkshow will present expert on marine plastic and oceanography to share insights about marine plastic situation in Indonesia, particularty how the rainy season can afffect the plastic waste to be carried into the ocean, as well as young activists to share their personal insights and how-to.
The event will be held as follows:
Date: 26 January 2022
Time: 10 AM - 11:30 AM, Jakarta time (UTC+7)
Opening Remarks:

Suryo Utomo Tomi &ndash; Head of Communication UNDP Indonesia
Michikazu Kojima - Research Fellow, RKC-MPD, ERIA

Panelists:

Dr. M. Reza Cordova - Researcher in the Research Center for Oceanography, National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN)
Tiza Mafira &ndash; Associate Director at Climate Policy Initiative and Co-Founder/Executive Director of Plastic Bag Diet Movement
Laura Seca Widyatmodjo &ndash; Founder of Young Golfers for A Cause
Livita Sumali &ndash; UNDP&rsquo;s Archipelagic and Island States Forum Rep.

For many rural women in India and ASEAN, entrepreneurship is part of a broader livelihood strategy, however, they&rsquo;re faced with pivotal barriers from access to resources, limited social and legal protection, to difficulties in entering new and lucrative markets to expand their businesses.</p><p>With the 4th episode of ERIA-CIIE.CO online discussion, we aim to introduce the Indian and ASEAN women entrepreneurship ecosystems to various stakeholders in the region, from the emerging social enterprise, startup &amp; incubator as well as policy. A</strong>&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td style="border-color: #000000; width: 197.542px;"><p>3:55 &ndash; 4:00 PM, IST or</p><p>5.25 &ndash; 5.30 PM, WIB</p></td><td style="border-color: #000000; width: 439.458px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks and End of Webinar</strong></p></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/women-entrepreneurs-focusing-at-the-grassroots-tickets-249093103177" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-01-27";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4525:"Women Entrepreneurs: Focusing at the Grassroots Women Entrepreneurs: Focusing at the Grassroots ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series &ndash; Building Prolific Entrepreneurship Ecosystem in ASEAN with Insight from India -&nbsp;Episode #4
Rural women increasingly run their own enterprises, yet their socio-economic contributions and entrepreneurial potential remain largely unrecognized and untapped. For many rural women in India and ASEAN, entrepreneurship is part of a broader livelihood strategy, however, they&rsquo;re faced with pivotal barriers from access to resources, limited social and legal protection, to difficulties in entering new and lucrative markets to expand their businesses.
With the 4th episode of ERIA-CIIE.CO online discussion, we aim to introduce the Indian and ASEAN women entrepreneurship ecosystems to various stakeholders in the region, from the emerging social enterprise, startup &amp; incubator as well as policy. We will be focusing on key initiatives and challenges in the ecosystem for rural women entrepreneurs and sharing inspired ideas that leverage the livelihood/women economy and entrepreneurship in rural areas.
Join us as we discuss women entrepreneurs; focusing on rural women empowerment!
CONCEPT NOTE




TIME


AGENDA&nbsp;




&nbsp;2:30 &ndash;2:40 PM, IST or
4:00 &ndash; 4:10 PM, WIB


Start of Webinar | Welcome Remarks
Giulia Ajmone Marsan
Director, Strategy and Partnership, ERIA&nbsp;




&nbsp;2:40 &ndash; 3:40 PM, IST or
4.10 &ndash; 5:10 PM, WIB


Panel Discussion 
Speakers:

Ajaita Shah,&nbsp;Founder and CEO of Frontier Markets, India
Chetna Sinha,&nbsp;Founder-Chairperson of the Mann Deshi Bank and Mann Deshi Foundation, India
Denica Riadini-Flesch,&nbsp;Founder and CEO of SukkhaCitta, Indonesia
Lida Loem,&nbsp;Co-founder and Technical Advisor at SHE Investments, Cambodia

Moderated by Trisha Ghoshal
Specialist &ndash; Insight, CIIE.CO

5:10 &ndash; 5:25 PM, WIB

4# edosipE;psbn&- aidnI morf thgisnI htiw NAESA ni metsysocE pihsruenerpertnE cifilorP gnidliuB ;hsadn& seireS ranibeW OC.EIIC-AIRE stoorssarG eht ta gnisucoF :sruenerpertnE nemoW stoorssarG eht ta gnisucoF :sruenerpertnE nemoW";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-01-17 14:15:53";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-01-25 14:57:14";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:157;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6588";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:76:"prospect-of-natural-gas-demand-and-supply-in-the-east-asia-summit-eas-region";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:78:"Prospect of Natural Gas Demand and Supply in the East Asia Summit (EAS) Region";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-01-26";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"1";s:7:"content";s:2271:"<h2>Date and Time</h2><p>Wednesday, 26 January 2022, 10 - 12 AM Doha Time (UTC + 3), 2 - 4 PM Jakarta Time (UTC + 7)</p><h2>Background</h2><p>According to the &lsquo;EAS Energy Outlook&rsquo; which is updated by ERIA every two years, primary natural gas consumption in the 17 East Asia Summit (EAS) countries will increase by 100% from 1,865 Mtoe in 2017 to 3,734 Mtoe by 2050. Natural gas is used mainly for power generation in the region. Other uses include heat for the industrial, commercial, and residential sectors as well as transport fuel for vehicles; the demand in these sectors has been increasing remarkably due to the lower environmental load of natural gas compared to oil and coal. Looking at natural gas supply in the EAS region, both countries within and outside EAS have been increasing their natural gas production, especially the production of shale gas in the United States. As demand is projected to continue increasing, long term contracts can supply stability to natural gas production countries, but on the other hand, spot market provides LNG at market prices to natural gas consuming countries to meet short-term fluctuating LNG demand.</p><p>Against this background, ERIA and GECF (Gas Exporting Countries Forum) will hold a joint workshop to discuss the future of natural gas supply and demand up to 2050 with participation of VIPs from both EAS and GECF to deliver opening remarks and keynote speeches, expert presentations, and panel discussions on natural gas demand in the Asia region and global natural gas supply.</p><h2>Theme</h2><p>Natural gas is currently considered as a clean fuel to replace coal power generation to achieve carbon neutrality or the low carbon energy transition after COP26. The joint workshop will discuss:</p><ul><li>Natural gas demand in Asia (EAS) region up to 2050 paying attention to carbon neutrality</li><li>Natural gas supply in the world up to 2050 paying attention to potential of new gas fields</li><li>Panel discussion on LNG hub in Asia region, balance of long-term contract and spot markets, new natural gas demand development, CCUS, etc</li></ul><h2><a class="bluebtn" title="Register Now via Eventbrite" href="https://bit.ly/PNGDSER" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></h2>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:46:"Energy,ASEAN,Asia,Natural gas,East Asia Summit";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:13:"ERIA and GECF";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-01-26";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-01-26";s:8:"keywords";s:4777:"Prospect of Natural Gas Demand and Supply in the East Asia Summit (EAS) Region Prospect of Natural Gas Demand and Supply in the East Asia Summit (EAS) Region Date and Time
Wednesday, 26 January 2022, 10 - 12 AM Doha Time (UTC + 3), 2 - 4 PM Jakarta Time (UTC + 7)
Background
According to the &lsquo;EAS Energy Outlook&rsquo; which is updated by ERIA every two years, primary natural gas consumption in the 17 East Asia Summit (EAS) countries will increase by 100% from 1,865 Mtoe in 2017 to 3,734 Mtoe by 2050. Natural gas is used mainly for power generation in the region. Other uses include heat for the industrial, commercial, and residential sectors as well as transport fuel for vehicles; the demand in these sectors has been increasing remarkably due to the lower environmental load of natural gas compared to oil and coal. Looking at natural gas supply in the EAS region, both countries within and outside EAS have been increasing their natural gas production, especially the production of shale gas in the United States. As demand is projected to continue increasing, long term contracts can supply stability to natural gas production countries, but on the other hand, spot market provides LNG at market prices to natural gas consuming countries to meet short-term fluctuating LNG demand.
Against this background, ERIA and GECF (Gas Exporting Countries Forum) will hold a joint workshop to discuss the future of natural gas supply and demand up to 2050 with participation of VIPs from both EAS and GECF to deliver opening remarks and keynote speeches, expert presentations, and panel discussions on natural gas demand in the Asia region and global natural gas supply.
Theme
Natural gas is currently considered as a clean fuel to replace coal power generation to achieve carbon neutrality or the low carbon energy transition after COP26. The joint workshop will discuss:

Natural gas demand in Asia (EAS) region up to 2050 paying attention to carbon neutrality
Natural gas supply in the world up to 2050 paying attention to potential of new gas fields
Panel discussion on LNG hub in Asia region, balance of long-term contract and spot markets, new natural gas demand development, CCUS, etc

Jakarta time) / 4 PM - 5.30 (UTC+9; Japan time)&nbsp;</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Register via Eventbrite" href="https://bit.ly/nextAJCO" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p><p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_Jan_The%20NextChapterofASEANandJapanEconomicCooperationinthePost-PandemicEraPOSTER2.png" alt="" width="800" height="1132" /></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:18:"Ms Isabella Italia";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-01-10";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4149:"The Next Chapter of ASEAN and Japan Economic Cooperation in the Post-Pandemic Era The Next Chapter of ASEAN and Japan Economic Cooperation in the Post-Pandemic Era Foreign Policy Community of Indonesia, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), the Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry of Japan (METI), and the ASEAN-METI Economic Cooperation Committee will convene a virtual public forum as a part of the Dialogue for Innovative and Sustainable Growth between Japan and ASEAN (DISG) titled 'The Next Chapter of ASEAN and Japan Economic Cooperation in the Post-Pandemic Era' on 10th of January 2022.  The public forum will discuss the next step of ASEAN-Japan economic cooperation. What would be the state of Indonesia-Japan economic cooperation during the pandemic? What are the opportunities that can be seized together? What are the challenges? How does Japanese investment in the region help the economic recovery efforts? And how do we bring cooperation to the next chapter?&nbsp;

&nbsp;Dr Dino Patti Djalal&nbsp;&ndash; Founder and Chairman of Foreign Policy Community of Indonesia (FPCI)

fo retpahC txeN ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-01-04 15:19:46";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-01-10 16:24:33";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:24:"isabella.italia@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:159;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6567";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:51:"asia-ccus-network-workshop-on-ccus-model-case-study";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:51:"Asia CCUS Network Workshop on CCUS Model Case Study";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-01-18";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"1";s:7:"content";s:4591:"<h2><img src="/uploads/media/2022-Jan-Asia-CCUS-Network-Workshop-on-CCUS-Model-Case-Study.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></h2><h2><em><strong>Cost Structure of CCUS and the Legal Framework</strong></em></h2><h2>Background and Objectives</h2><p>At the 1st Asia CCUS Network Forum held in June 2021, it was concluded that CCUS and Carbon Recycling are crucial technologies for the East Asia Summit (EAS) region to achieve carbon neutrality in the future amidst the expected increase of fossil fuel consumption in the region. It was also discussed by the stakeholders that participated in the Forum, that to bring more CCUS projects to the commercialisation stage, issues, such as the lack of an adequate legal framework to address liability and a project pipeline through pilot projects need to be resolved. Moreover, it is expected that to accelerate the deployment of CCUS in the EAS region, there is a need to bridge the gap and to implement knowledge and experience sharing amongst the ASEAN and Asia region.</p><p>Building upon the outcome of previous discussions as described above, this workshop hosted by ERIA and METI aims to serve as an opportunity to share knowledge about the cost structure of CCUS projects through model case study and discuss policies and measures that may contribute to developing enabling environment of the business case of CCUS.</p><p>The goals of the workshop are as follows:</p><ul><li>Promote the knowledge share on the cost structure and range of expected costs of CCUS.</li><li>Exchange ideas of policies and measures that may be beneficial to bring down costs.</li><li>Discuss possibilities of regional response for policy formulation.</li></ul><h2>Programme (DRAFT)</h2><p>Date: 18 January 2022</p><p>Time: 9 AM to 11 AM Jakarta time (UTC+7)</p><p>[Draft as of 27 December 2021]</p><table style="width: 699px;"><tr><td style="width: 99.4028px;"><p><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p></td><td style="width: 285.597px;"><p><strong>Topic</strong></p></td><td style="width: 291px;"><strong>Topic</strong></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 99.4028px;"><strong>9:00-9:05</strong></td><td style="width: 285.597px;">Welcome address</td><td style="width: 291px;">Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor on Energy Affairs, ERIA</td></tr><tr><td style="width: 99.4028px;"><p><strong>9:05-10:00</strong></p></td><td /></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Japan";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-01-18";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-01-18";s:8:"keywords";s:6899:"Asia CCUS Network Workshop on CCUS Model Case Study Asia CCUS Network Workshop on CCUS Model Case Study Cost Structure of CCUS and the Legal Framework
Background and Objectives
At the 1st Asia CCUS Network Forum held in June 2021, it was concluded that CCUS and Carbon Recycling are crucial technologies for the East Asia Summit (EAS) region to achieve carbon neutrality in the future amidst the expected increase of fossil fuel consumption in the region. It was also discussed by the stakeholders that participated in the Forum, that to bring more CCUS projects to the commercialisation stage, issues, such as the lack of an adequate legal framework to address liability and a project pipeline through pilot projects need to be resolved. Moreover, it is expected that to accelerate the deployment of CCUS in the EAS region, there is a need to bridge the gap and to implement knowledge and experience sharing amongst the ASEAN and Asia region.
Building upon the outcome of previous discussions as described above, this workshop hosted by ERIA and METI aims to serve as an opportunity to share knowledge about the cost structure of CCUS projects through model case study and discuss policies and measures that may contribute to developing enabling environment of the business case of CCUS.
The goals of the workshop are as follows:

Promote the knowledge share on the cost structure and range of expected costs of CCUS.
Exchange ideas of policies and measures that may be beneficial to bring down costs.
Discuss possibilities of regional response for policy formulation.

Programme (DRAFT)
Date: 18 January 2022
Time: 9 AM to 11 AM Jakarta time (UTC+7)
[Draft as of 27 December 2021]

Also, there will be panel discussion among key figures from ASEAN and Japan to discuss how ASEAN and Japan can collaborate more in the field of HRD, and what ASEAN can expect from Japan and how Japan should respond to it, and vice versa.

.aisA tsaehtuoS ni noitulover lairtsudni htruof eht ni yllaicepse ,tnempoleved ecruoser namuh fo seitivitca tsetal eht erahs lliw napaJ dna NAESA morf serugif yek ,ranibew siht nI tnempoleveD ecruoseR namuH rof noitaroballoC napaJ-NAESA gnitomorP tnempoleveD ecruoseR namuH rof noitaroballoC napaJ-NAESA gnitomorP";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-12-14 16:18:31";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-12-14 16:20:16";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:24:"isabella.italia@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:161;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6527";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:102:"social-enterprises-and-disability-fostering-innovation-awareness-and-social-impact-in-the-asean-region";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:105:"Social Enterprises and Disability: Fostering Innovation, Awareness, and Social Impact in the ASEAN Region";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-12-08";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"12";s:7:"content";s:4158:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/Photo-Flyer---Eventbrite-copy.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Social enterprises (SEs) have emerged as key actors for developing new, innovative and scalable forms of support for persons with disabilities. Social entrepreneurship is a growing phenomenon both worldwide and across the region, and SEs are uniquely positioned to provide solutions to some of the challenges facing persons with disabilities today &ndash; including effective responses to the significant issue of unequal employment.</p><p>The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) has recently released a <a href="/publications/social-enterprises-and-disability-fostering-innovation-awareness-and-social-impact-in-the-asean-region/">research project reports</a>, authored by Impact 46, a social impact accelerator . This study aims to analyse the role of social enterprises as key actors to foster innovation, awareness, and inclusion for people with disability in the ASEAN region. It brings together the perspectives of various social enterprises across the ASEAN region. To discuss the findings of this study ERIA is organizing a dissemination event on 8 December 2021.</p><table width="678"><tr style="height: 39px;"><td style="height: 39px;" width="121"><p><strong>Time</strong></p></td><td style="height: 39px;" width="217"><p><strong>Agenda</strong></p></td><td style="height: 39px;" colspan="2" width="340"><p><strong>Speaker</strong></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 31px;"><td style="height: 31px;" width="121"><p>&nbsp;2:00 &ndash; 2:10 PM</p></td><td style="height: 31px;" width="217"><p>&nbsp;Opening Remarks &nbsp;</p></td><td style="height: 31px;" colspan="2" width="340"><ul><li><strong>HE. Will Nankervis,&nbsp;</strong>Australian Ambassador to ASEAN</li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 124px;"><td style="height: 124px;" width="121"><p>&nbsp;2:10- 2:20 PM</p></td><td style="height: 124px;" width="217"><p>&nbsp;Presentation</p></td><td style="height: 124px;" colspan="2" width="340"><ul><li><strong>Nicola Crosta,&nbsp;</strong>Founder and CEO of Impact46</li><li><strong>Allison Sanders, </strong>Director of Impact and Development<strong>&nbsp;</strong>of Impact46</li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 275px;"><td style="height: 275px;" width="121"><p>&nbsp;2:20- 3:00PM</p></td><td style="height: 275px;" width="217"><p>&nbsp;Panel Discussion</p></td><td style="height: 275px;" colspan="2" width="340"><p><strong>&nbsp;</strong><strong>Speakers: </strong></p><ul><li><strong>Max Simpson,&nbsp;</strong>Founder and CEO, Steps with Theera (Thailand)</li><li><strong>Sokny Onn,&nbsp;</strong>Country Directors, Epic Arts (Cambodia)</li><li><strong>Koh Seng Choon,&nbsp;</strong>Executive Director, Project Dignity (Singapore)</li><li><strong>Victoria Morris,&nbsp;</strong>Chief Executive Officer, Alina Vision (Vietnam)</li></ul><p>Moderated by OOI Tiat Jin (TJ), Founder &amp; Principal Consultant, Curated Connectors, Singapore</p></td></tr><tr style="height: 33px;"><td style="height: 33px;" width="121"><p>3:00- 3:10 PM</p></td><td style="height: 33px;" colspan="3" width="558"><p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Q &amp; A Session</p></td></tr><tr style="height: 60.4445px;"><td style="height: 60.4445px;" width="121"><p>&nbsp;3:10- 3:15PM</p></td><td style="height: 60.4445px;" colspan="2" width="222"><p>&nbsp;Closing remarks</p></td><td style="height: 60.4445px;" width="336"><ul><li><strong>Giulia Ajmone Marsan,&nbsp;</strong>Director of Strategy and Partnerships, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 23px;"><td style="height: 23px;" width="121">&nbsp;</td><td style="height: 23px;" width="217">&nbsp;</td><td style="height: 23px;" width="4">&nbsp;</td><td style="height: 23px;" width="336">&nbsp;</td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/217745772467" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-12-08";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:5117:"Social Enterprises and Disability: Fostering Innovation, Awareness, and Social Impact in the ASEAN Region Social Enterprises and Disability: Fostering Innovation, Awareness, and Social Impact in the ASEAN Region Social enterprises (SEs) have emerged as key actors for developing new, innovative and scalable forms of support for persons with disabilities. Social entrepreneurship is a growing phenomenon both worldwide and across the region, and SEs are uniquely positioned to provide solutions to some of the challenges facing persons with disabilities today &ndash; including effective responses to the significant issue of unequal employment.
The Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) has recently released a research project reports, authored by Impact 46, a social impact accelerator . This study aims to analyse the role of social enterprises as key actors to foster innovation, awareness, and inclusion for people with disability in the ASEAN region. It brings together the perspectives of various social enterprises across the ASEAN region. To discuss the findings of this study ERIA is organizing a dissemination event on 8 December 2021.




Time


Agenda


Speaker




&nbsp;2:00 &ndash; 2:10 PM


&nbsp;Opening Remarks &nbsp;



HE. Will Nankervis,&nbsp;Australian Ambassador to ASEAN





&nbsp;2:10- 2:20 PM


&nbsp;Presentation



Nicola Crosta,&nbsp;Founder and CEO of Impact46
Allison Sanders, Director of Impact and Development&nbsp;of Impact46





&nbsp;2:20- 3:00PM

Sokny Onn,&nbsp;Country Directors, Epic Arts (Cambodia)

Victoria Morris,&nbsp;Chief Executive Officer, Alina Vision (Vietnam)

Moderated by OOI Tiat Jin (TJ), Founder &amp; Principal Consultant, Curated Connectors, Singapore

Giulia Ajmone Marsan,&nbsp;Director of Strategy and Partnerships, ERIA

Innovators &ndash; 2021 In Retrospect: Looking Back and Empowered Forward</strong></p><p>Throughout this series on Entrepreneurship, Startups and Innovation (E-S-I), it has been evident that the vibrancy of these ecosystems are crucial for economic recovery and growth beyond the pandemic. Of great importance is the continued partnership between the public sector, educational institutions and the private sector. &nbsp;</p><p>The ongoing development of entrepreneurial skills and mindsets, the curation of safety nets to encourage creativity and innovation, these are just some of the required ingredients to the fostering of next generation entrepreneurs and innovators.Join us in conversation to get inspired and glean insight from our 5 speakers in this series finale.&nbsp;</p><table><tr><td width="141"><p><strong>TIME</strong></p></td><td width="459"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p><p><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="141"><p>2:00 &ndash; 2:05 PM</p></td><td width="459"><p><strong>Start of Webinar | Welcome Remarks</strong></p><p><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p><p><strong>Giulia Ajmone Marsan</strong></p><p>Director, Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</p></td></tr><tr><td width="141"><p>2:05 &ndash; 3:00 PM</p></td><td width="459"><p><strong>Panel Discussion </strong></p><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Pranpreya Sriwannawit Lundberg,&nbsp;</strong>Policy Specialist. Throughout this series on Entrepreneurship, Startups and Innovation (E-S-I), it has been evident that the vibrancy of these ecosystems are crucial for economic recovery and growth beyond the pandemic. Of great importance is the continued partnership between the public sector, educational institutions and the private sector. &nbsp;
The ongoing development of entrepreneurial skills and mindsets, the curation of safety nets to encourage creativity and innovation, these are just some of the required ingredients to the fostering of next generation entrepreneurs and innovators.Join us in conversation to get inspired and glean insight from our 5 speakers in this series finale.&nbsp;

Approach)";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-11-22";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"11";s:7:"content";s:0:"";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Cooperation Programme: Workshop on Trade in Services Agreement (Negative-List Approach) CCS-JAPAN Cooperation Programme: Workshop on Trade in Services Agreement (Negative-List Approach)        Virtual Room  Ms Sheila Fathiya sheila.fathiya@eria.org   2021-11-22 2021-11-23 2021-11-22 22 November 2021 1202 rebmevoN 22 22-11-1202 32-11-1202 22-11-1202   gro.aire@ayihtaf.aliehs ayihtaF aliehS sM  mooR lautriV        )hcaorppA tsiL-evitageN( tnemeergA secivreS ni edarT no pohskroW :emmargorP noitarepooC NAPAJ-SCC )hcaorppA tsiL-evitageN( tnemeergA secivreS ni edarT no pohskroW :emmargorP noitarepooC NAPAJ-SCC";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-11-04 11:43:33";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-11-04 11:45:02";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"14";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"sheila.fathiya@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:167;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6506";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:58:"publication-and-book-launch-indonesia-manufacturing-review";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:60:"Publication and Book Launch 'Indonesia Manufacturing Review'";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-11-17";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"11";s:7:"content";s:7114:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/Webinar%20Launching%20buku%20kajian%20manufaktur%204.5%20English.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="800" /></p><p>Indonesian Ministry of National Development Planning (PPN/Bappenas) has collaborated with Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) to complete a study titled &lsquo;Kajian Sektor Manufaktur (Manufacturing Sector Review)&rsquo;. This study has started in 2018 and been a part of a background study for Indonesian Mid-term National Planning (RPJMN) 2020-2024 for manufacturing industries. This study has also been updated to cover issues on manufacturing sectors during COVID-19 pandemic. Analysis used in this study involved secondary data analytics and focus group discussions with related ministries/government institutions, major manufacturing industry players and academicians, and other stakeholders.</p><p>Industry sector is one of the main drivers of Indonesian economy. Manufacturing sector has constantly made up for around 20% of Indonesian GDP and non-oil and gas manufacturing contribution to export has increased rapidly to around 50% since around 1990s. Industrialization has been one of strategies to transform Indonesian economy to be more inclusive and sustainable. On the other hand, during COVID-19 pandemic, manufacturing sectors had suffered multiple drawbacks, from the decline in production to value chain disruptions, sales decline, labor cut-off, and bankruptcy. In 2020, manufacturing sector&rsquo;s rate of GDP growth contracted by 2.5% (y-o-y), but in Q2-2021, the figure has improved to 6.6% (y-o-y).</p><p>One of strategies to improve Indonesian manufacturing sector performance is constructing a solid and comprehensive planning of manufacturing sector development. The policy directions shall cover analysis on relevant issues, opportunities, and challenges faced by each sub-sectors in manufacturing industries. This study focused on five sub-sectors, which are (i) food and beverage industry; (ii) textile, garment, and footwear industry; (iii) automotive industry; (iv) chemical industry; and (v) metal industry. Moreover, this study also provided an up-to-date analysis on current challenges, especially on (i) technological advancement; (ii) human resources and labor; (iii) global value chain; (iv) a review on sub-sectors in manufacturing sector and their auxiliary services; (v) export and utilization of Free Trade Agreement (FTA); (vi) energy availability; and (vii) financial support system. This study also provided policy suggestions to support the growth and development of manufacturing industries.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Wednesday,&nbsp; 17 November 2021, 13<span class="event-time-localized">:00 PM- - 15:20 PM (UTC +7)</span></p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><strong>Agenda:&nbsp;</strong></p><table style="width: 784px;"><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;"><p><strong>Time&nbsp;</strong></p></td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;"><p><strong>Event&nbsp;</strong></p></td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;"><strong>Speaker/Moderator/PIC</strong></td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;"><p><strong>13.00 &ndash; 13.05</strong></p></td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;">Opening</td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;">&nbsp;</td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;">13.05 &ndash; 13.10</td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;">Brief Report by Bappenas</td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;"><p><strong>Economy Deputy at Indonesian Ministry of&nbsp; National Development Planning / Bappenas</strong></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;">13.10 &ndash; 13.20</td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;">Opening Remarks</td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;"><p><strong>Dr. (H.C.)&nbsp;H. Suharso Monoarfa</strong></p><p><em>Minister of PPN/Chief of Bappenas</em></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;">&nbsp;13.20 &ndash; 13.30</td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;">&nbsp;Opening Remarks&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;"><p><strong>Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura</strong></p><p><em>President of Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</em></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;">13.30 &ndash; 14.00</td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;"><p>Indonesian Manufacturing Review &ndash; Study Results</p></td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;"><p><strong>Dionisius A. Narjoko,&nbsp;</strong><em>Senior Economist, ERIA</em></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;">&nbsp;14.00 &ndash; 14.15&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;"><p>International Production Network post the Covid-19 Pandemic&nbsp;</p></td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;"><strong>Fukunari Kimura,&nbsp;</strong><em>Chief Economist, ERIA</em></td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;">14.15 &ndash; 14.50</td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;">Discussion session by discussants</td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;"><p><strong>Discussants:</strong></p><ul><li><strong> Dr. Ir. Dradjad Irianto, M.Eng, </strong><em>Professor at Insititut Teknologi Bandung</em></li><li><strong> Maman Setiawan, </strong><em>Center of Economics and Development Studies at Universitas Padjajaran</em></li><li><strong> Vivi Alatas</strong>, <em>Chief Executive Officer of Asakreativita</em></li></ul><p><strong>Moderator,</strong> Director for Industry, Tourism, and Creative Economy, <em>Indonesian Ministry of National Development Planning / Bappenas</em></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;">14.50 &ndash; 15.10</td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;">Q&amp;A Session</td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;"><p><strong>Moderator,</strong>&nbsp;Director for Industry, Tourism, and Creative Economy, <em>Indonesian Ministry of National Development Planning / Bappenas</em></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;">15.10 &ndash; 15.15</td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;">Conclusion</td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;"><strong>Economy Deputy, </strong><em>Indonesian Ministry of National Development Planning / Bappenas </em></td></tr><tr style="height: 42px;"><td style="width: 200px; height: 42px;">15.15 &ndash; 15.20</td><td style="width: 398.812px; height: 42px;">Closing</td><td style="width: 497.188px; height: 42px;">&nbsp;</td></tr></table><p><strong>Note</strong><strong>:</strong></p><p>This event will be held in a bilingual manner (English and Bahasa Indonesia).</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="REGISTER&nbsp;" href="https://bit.ly/3neuaBo" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:18:"Ms Hardianti Sukma";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:4:"ERIA";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-11-17";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-11-17";s:8:"keywords";s:9153:"Publication and Book Launch 'Indonesia Manufacturing Review' Publication and Book Launch 'Indonesia Manufacturing Review' Indonesian Ministry of National Development Planning (PPN/Bappenas) has collaborated with Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) to complete a study titled &lsquo;Kajian Sektor Manufaktur (Manufacturing Sector Review)&rsquo;. This study has started in 2018 and been a part of a background study for Indonesian Mid-term National Planning (RPJMN) 2020-2024 for manufacturing industries. This study has also been updated to cover issues on manufacturing sectors during COVID-19 pandemic. Analysis used in this study involved secondary data analytics and focus group discussions with related ministries/government institutions, major manufacturing industry players and academicians, and other stakeholders.
Industry sector is one of the main drivers of Indonesian economy. Manufacturing sector has constantly made up for around 20% of Indonesian GDP and non-oil and gas manufacturing contribution to export has increased rapidly to around 50% since around 1990s. Industrialization has been one of strategies to transform Indonesian economy to be more inclusive and sustainable. On the other hand, during COVID-19 pandemic, manufacturing sectors had suffered multiple drawbacks, from the decline in production to value chain disruptions, sales decline, labor cut-off, and bankruptcy. In 2020, manufacturing sector&rsquo;s rate of GDP growth contracted by 2.5% (y-o-y), but in Q2-2021, the figure has improved to 6.6% (y-o-y).
One of strategies to improve Indonesian manufacturing sector performance is constructing a solid and comprehensive planning of manufacturing sector development. The policy directions shall cover analysis on relevant issues, opportunities, and challenges faced by each sub-sectors in manufacturing industries. This study focused on five sub-sectors, which are (i) food and beverage industry; (ii) textile, garment, and footwear industry; (iii) automotive industry; (iv) chemical industry; and (v) metal industry. Moreover, this study also provided an up-to-date analysis on current challenges, especially on (i) technological advancement; (ii) human resources and labor; (iii) global value chain; (iv) a review on sub-sectors in manufacturing sector and their auxiliary services; (v) export and utilization of Free Trade Agreement (FTA); (vi) energy availability; and (vii) financial support system. This study also provided policy suggestions to support the growth and development of manufacturing industries.

The ASEM (Asia-Europe Meeting)13 Plenary Study Book is the outcome of Cambodia's initiative in close collaboration with and strong support from ERIA to contribute to the reinvigorating of multilateralism for a better, stronger, inclusive, and resilient future of Asia-Europe partnership and cooperation, and ultimately transforming ASEAM into a dynamic, resilient, and sustainable community for the peoples of Asia and Europe in the next 25 years and beyond.


Agenda (as of 5 Nov 2021)
(Phnom Penh time, UTC+7)



9:00-9:05 AM
Welcoming Remarks by H.E. Tean Samnang, President of the National Institute of Diplomacy of International Relations


9:05-9:20 AM
Brief presentation on findings of ASEM13 Plenary Book by Ms Anita Prakash, Senior Policy Advisor, Office of President of ERIA


9:20-9:35 AM
Remarks of Professor Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)


9:35-9:50 AM
Keynote Remarks of H.E. Mr PRAK Sokhonn, Deputy Prime Minister, Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation of the Kingdom of Cambodia Book Launching and Photo Session


9:50-10:00 AM
Keynote Remarks of H.E. Mr PRAK Sokhonn, Deputy Prime Minister, Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation of the Kingdom of Cambodia Book Launching and Photo Session


10:00-10:30 AM
Q and A Session moderated by H.E Dr SOK Siphana, Senior Adviser to the Royal Government of Cambodia and ASEM SOM Leader



&nbsp;

tneve siht tuobA hcnuaL kooB yranelP 31MESA hcnuaL kooB yranelP 31MESA";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-11-04 11:29:49";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-11-09 09:55:59";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"14";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:21:"kemala.putri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:170;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6502";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:54:"the-4th-asia-ccus-network-knowledge-sharing-conference";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:54:"The 4th Asia CCUS Network Knowledge Sharing Conference";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-11-17";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"11";s:7:"content";s:4399:"<p class="preFlex flexIn">&nbsp;<img src="/uploads/media/Events/2021-4th-CCUS.png" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">The Asia CCUS Network was successfully launched on 22-23rd June 2021. Initially, 13 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions decided to join the Network. Members share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region, and the Asia CCUS Network aims to contribute through the collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">The mission of this network is to facilitate deployment of CCUS through: (i) promoting knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings; (ii) conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and (iii) holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS. The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through collaboration of research and innovation.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">The Clean Energy Ministerial (CEM) CCUS Initiative plays a critical role to support the adoption and deployment of CCUS around the world. The Asia CCUS Network is partnering with the CEM CCUS Initiative and the European Commission in co-hosting this knowledge-sharing conference on the topic of &#039;Learning from failures &ndash; building on success: EU experience on CCUS&#039;.&nbsp;</p><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Wednesday,&nbsp; 17 November 2021,&nbsp;<span class="event-time-localized">3:00 PM&nbsp;&nbsp;4:30 PM (UTC +7)</span></p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><table style="width: 614px;"><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p><strong>TIME</strong></p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>15:00 PM &ndash; 15:10 PM</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Taizo Hara, </strong>Director General of Research and Policy Design Administration of ERIA</li><li><strong>Juho Lipponen</strong>, Coordinator CEM CCUS Initiative</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>15:10 PM &ndash; 15:50 PM</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Moderator:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Han Phoumin</strong>, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Chris Bolesta</strong>, CCUS Policy Lead at EU Commission: &lsquo;Learning from failures &ndash; building on success: EU experience on CCUS&rsquo;</li><li><strong>Per-Olof Granstr&ouml;m</strong>, EU Director, Zero-Emissions Platform (ZEP): &lsquo;ZEP&rsquo;s view on EU experience&rsquo;</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>15:50 PM &ndash; 16:25 PM</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Open discussion Session</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>16:25 PM &ndash; 16:30 PM</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks:</strong></p><ul><li><div id="block-888dab804c721b30ec43" class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>Shigeru Kimura</strong>, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA</p></div></div><div id="block-ed3b88ee55b04a6ec005" class="sqs-block button-block sqs-block-button" data-block-type="53">&nbsp;</div></li></ul></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" title="REGISTER&nbsp;" href="https://bit.ly/3EC3qRl" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:16:"Ms Dian Lutfiana";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-11-17";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-11-17";s:8:"keywords";s:6099:"The 4th Asia CCUS Network Knowledge Sharing Conference The 4th Asia CCUS Network Knowledge Sharing Conference &nbsp;
The Asia CCUS Network was successfully launched on 22-23rd June 2021. Initially, 13 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions decided to join the Network. Members share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region, and the Asia CCUS Network aims to contribute through the collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS.
The mission of this network is to facilitate deployment of CCUS through: (i) promoting knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings; (ii) conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and (iii) holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS. The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through collaboration of research and innovation.
The Clean Energy Ministerial (CEM) CCUS Initiative plays a critical role to support the adoption and deployment of CCUS around the world. The Asia CCUS Network is partnering with the CEM CCUS Initiative and the European Commission in co-hosting this knowledge-sharing conference on the topic of 'Learning from failures &ndash; building on success: EU experience on CCUS'.&nbsp;
Date and Time:
Wednesday,&nbsp; 17 November 2021,&nbsp;3:00 PM&nbsp;&nbsp;4:30 PM (UTC +7)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)




TIME


AGENDA




15:00 PM &ndash; 15:10 PM


Opening Remarks:

Taizo Hara, Director General of Research and Policy Design Administration of ERIA
Juho Lipponen, Coordinator CEM CCUS Initiative





15:10 PM &ndash; 15:50 PM


Moderator:

Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA

Speakers:

Chris Bolesta, CCUS Policy Lead at EU Commission: &lsquo;Learning from failures &ndash; building on success: EU experience on CCUS&rsquo;
Per-Olof Granstr&ouml;m, EU Director, Zero-Emissions Platform (ZEP): &lsquo;ZEP&rsquo;s view on EU experience&rsquo;





15:50 PM &ndash; 16:00 PM


Commentary session:

Saleh Abdurrahman, Member of Committee for Downstream Oil and Gas Regulatory Body Former, Senior Advisor for Environment and Spatial Planning Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR), Indonesia





16:00 PM &ndash; 16:25 PM


Open discussion Session




16:25 PM &ndash; 16:30 PM


Closing Remarks:




Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA

;psbn&.'SUCC no ecneirepxe UE :sseccus no gnidliub ;hsadn& seruliaf morf gninraeL' fo cipot eht no ecnerefnoc gnirahs-egdelwonk siht gnitsoh-oc ni noissimmoC naeporuE eht dna evitaitinI SUCC MEC eht htiw gnirentrap si krowteN SUCC aisA ehT .dlrow eht dnuora SUCC fo tnemyolped dna noitpoda eht troppus ot elor lacitirc a syalp evitaitinI SUCC )MEC( lairetsiniM ygrenE naelC ehT
.noitavonni dna hcraeser fo noitaroballoc hguorht tnemyolped sti dna ygolonhcet SUCC fo tsoc eht rewol ot ytilibapac ;ouqsr&seirtnuoc dliub ot pleh yllautneve lliw taht pihsrentrap ygolonhcet noissime wol eht no etaroballoc dna krow ot noiger eht ni seirtnuoc rof seitinutroppo sedivorp krowteN SUCC aisA ehT .SUCC no pag egdelwonk eht egdirb ot spohskrow gniniart gnidliub yticapac gnidloh )iii( dna ;noiger SAE eht ni SUCC fo sdradnats lagel dna ,lacimonoce ,lacinhcet no seiduts hcraeser gnitcudnoc )ii( ;sgniteem dna ,spohskrow ,secnerefnoc ,murof launna na gnidloh hguorht gnirahs egdelwonk gnitomorp )i( :hguorht SUCC fo tnemyolped etatilicaf ot si krowten siht fo noissim ehT
.SUCC fo tnemyolped dna tnempoleved no noitarepooc dna noitaroballoc eht hguorht etubirtnoc ot smia krowteN SUCC aisA eht dna ,noiger naisA eht tuohguorht tnempoleved SUCC fo noisiv eht erahs srebmeM .krowteN eht nioj ot dediced snoitutitsni hcraeser dna laicnanif ,seinapmoc ,snoitasinagro lanoitanretni 001 naht erom dna )napaJ dna ,ailartsuA ,setatS detinU eht ,seirtnuoc rebmem NAESA lla( seirtnuoc 31 ,yllaitinI .1202 enuJ dr32-22 no dehcnual yllufsseccus saw krowteN SUCC aisA ehT
;psbn& ecnerefnoC gnirahS egdelwonK krowteN SUCC aisA ht4 ehT ecnerefnoC gnirahS egdelwonK krowteN SUCC aisA ht4 ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-11-03 14:28:28";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-11-03 15:37:17";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"14";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:22:"dian.lutfiana@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:171;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6501";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:73:"malaysias-private-sector-innovation-as-a-driver-to-tackle-marine-plastics";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:82:"Malaysiaâ€™s Private Sector: Innovation as a Driver to Tackle Marine Plastics";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-11-23";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"11";s:7:"content";s:6566:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/Eventbrite%20Banner%20(PSP%20Series%202).png" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Plastic is a material that is versatile, resistant, lightweight, and inexpensive to produce, which makes it ubiquitous in our everyday lives. However, the amount of plastic waste released in our environment and its negative effects on our marine ecosystem have attracted increasing scientific concern in recent years. East and Southeast Asian regions are recognised as the biggest contributors to marine plastic pollution due to rapid economic growth and the lack of solid waste management infrastructure. Indeed, ASEAN+3 region is estimated to account for 62.6% of the world leakage of plastics to the ocean, including Malaysia which ranks third in the world, according to a study by Dutch scientist Lourens Meijer et. al. (2021).</p><p>Alarmed by this regional situation, the ASEAN Member States in 2019 welcomed the ASEAN Framework of Action on Marine Debris and adopted the Bangkok Declaration on Combating Marine Debris in ASEAN Region. In May 2021, ASEAN as a group officially launched the ASEAN Regional Action Plan for Combating Marine Debris in the ASEAN Member States (2021-2025), which recognises the urgent need to combat marine litter, including by promoting platforms for knowledge sharing, innovative solutions, and best practices to address this issue.</p><p>Although much is still left to be studied, particularly the long-term impacts of plastics on our marine ecosystem, and its potential harm to human health through the food chain, there is a wide international consensus to take urgent preventative actions before further damage is done. Echoing these concerns, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) has established the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) in 2019 to provide the ASEAN+3 Member States with support in addressing emerging challenges associated with marine plastic debris.</p><p>In fact, the private sector in ASEAN+3 countries have been contributing significantly to the reduction of plastic waste and by consequence marine plastic debris in the region. Their efforts can range from both production and consumption (so-called &ldquo;upstream&rdquo;) level to recycling and waste management (so-called &ldquo;downstream&rdquo;) level. <strong>At the occasion of this forum, ERIA&rsquo;s RKC-MPD will focus on the role played by the private sectors in Malaysia by shedding light on innovative technologies and approaches developed to address this pressing issue. </strong>Innovation, in this context will encompass a wide array of practices that distance themselves from the traditional linear (take-make-use-dispose) way of thinking and proposes more responsible and sustainable business models.</p><p>One of the important missions of RKC-MPD is to promote private companies whose business activities help combat marine plastic litter, in the hope to promote this positive shift. RKC-MPD has established an online platform titled &lsquo;Private sector initiatives to reduce plastic waste and marine plastic debris&rsquo; (<a href="https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story">https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story</a>). This online interface called the Private Sector Platform (PSP) hosts information submitted by private companies operating in all ASEAN+3 countries to showcase their products, services, or technologies contributing to the reduction of plastic waste and marine plastic debris. The platform collects and disseminates private companies&rsquo; business activities that are conducive to marine plastics mitigation. It also aims to encourage Business-to-Business, Business-to-Government and/or Business-to-Consumer opportunities in the ASEAN+3 region.</p><p>The forum will be an occasion for the Ministry of Environment and Water of Malaysia, a Malaysian business alliance, and Malaysian private companies to stocktake the progress made, and discuss the many ways private companies can contribute in combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris. RKC-MPD will reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP) to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness of the platform and attract a larger number of private companies to join the fight against marine plastics.</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Tuesday, 23 November 2021,&nbsp;9 AM -&nbsp;10:30&nbsp;PM (UTC+7; Jakarta time) / 10 AM - 11.30 (UTC+8; Malaysia time)&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><table style="width: 614px;"><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p><strong>TIME</strong></p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>10:00-10:10 AM</p><p>10:10-10:12 AM</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Michikazu Kojima,&nbsp;</strong>Research Fellow, Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), ERIA</li><li><strong>Dato&#039; Jana Santhiran a/l Muniayan,</strong> Deputy Secretary General, Ministry of Environment and Water of Malaysia</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>10:12-10:45AM</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Moderator:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Fusanori Iwasaki,</strong> Senior Research Associate and Executive Assistant to the President of ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Panellists:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Pauline Goh,</strong> General Manager, Malaysian Recycling Alliance Berhad (MAREA)</li><li><strong>Ayamany A/L P Sinakalai,</strong> CEO, FALLALEAF</li><li><strong>Wee Ching Yun,</strong> Chairman of Sustainability Sub-Committee, Malaysia Plastic Manufacturers Association (MPMA)</li><li><strong>Thomas Chhoa,</strong> Senior Advisor in the Office of the CEO, Alliance to End Plastic Waste (AEPW)</li><li><strong>Ellen Putri Edita,</strong> Research Associate, the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), ERIA</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>10:45-11:28 AM</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Open Discussion with Q &amp; A</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>11.28-11.30 AM</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Michikazu Kojima, </strong>Research Fellow, RKC-MPD, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" title="REGISTER" href="https://bit.ly/3wawgVS" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:22:"Ms Devina Anglingdarma";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:4:"ERIA";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-11-23";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-11-23";s:8:"keywords";s:11347:"Malaysiaâ€™s Private Sector: Innovation as a Driver to Tackle Marine Plastics Malaysiaâ€™s Private Sector: Innovation as a Driver to Tackle Marine Plastics Plastic is a material that is versatile, resistant, lightweight, and inexpensive to produce, which makes it ubiquitous in our everyday lives. However, the amount of plastic waste released in our environment and its negative effects on our marine ecosystem have attracted increasing scientific concern in recent years. East and Southeast Asian regions are recognised as the biggest contributors to marine plastic pollution due to rapid economic growth and the lack of solid waste management infrastructure. Indeed, ASEAN+3 region is estimated to account for 62.6% of the world leakage of plastics to the ocean, including Malaysia which ranks third in the world, according to a study by Dutch scientist Lourens Meijer et. al. (2021).
Alarmed by this regional situation, the ASEAN Member States in 2019 welcomed the ASEAN Framework of Action on Marine Debris and adopted the Bangkok Declaration on Combating Marine Debris in ASEAN Region. In May 2021, ASEAN as a group officially launched the ASEAN Regional Action Plan for Combating Marine Debris in the ASEAN Member States (2021-2025), which recognises the urgent need to combat marine litter, including by promoting platforms for knowledge sharing, innovative solutions, and best practices to address this issue.
Although much is still left to be studied, particularly the long-term impacts of plastics on our marine ecosystem, and its potential harm to human health through the food chain, there is a wide international consensus to take urgent preventative actions before further damage is done. Echoing these concerns, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) has established the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) in 2019 to provide the ASEAN+3 Member States with support in addressing emerging challenges associated with marine plastic debris.
In fact, the private sector in ASEAN+3 countries have been contributing significantly to the reduction of plastic waste and by consequence marine plastic debris in the region. Their efforts can range from both production and consumption (so-called &ldquo;upstream&rdquo;) level to recycling and waste management (so-called &ldquo;downstream&rdquo;) level. At the occasion of this forum, ERIA&rsquo;s RKC-MPD will focus on the role played by the private sectors in Malaysia by shedding light on innovative technologies and approaches developed to address this pressing issue. Innovation, in this context will encompass a wide array of practices that distance themselves from the traditional linear (take-make-use-dispose) way of thinking and proposes more responsible and sustainable business models.
One of the important missions of RKC-MPD is to promote private companies whose business activities help combat marine plastic litter, in the hope to promote this positive shift. RKC-MPD has established an online platform titled &lsquo;Private sector initiatives to reduce plastic waste and marine plastic debris&rsquo; (https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story). This online interface called the Private Sector Platform (PSP) hosts information submitted by private companies operating in all ASEAN+3 countries to showcase their products, services, or technologies contributing to the reduction of plastic waste and marine plastic debris. The platform collects and disseminates private companies&rsquo; business activities that are conducive to marine plastics mitigation. It also aims to encourage Business-to-Business, Business-to-Government and/or Business-to-Consumer opportunities in the ASEAN+3 region.
The forum will be an occasion for the Ministry of Environment and Water of Malaysia, a Malaysian business alliance, and Malaysian private companies to stocktake the progress made, and discuss the many ways private companies can contribute in combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris. RKC-MPD will reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP) to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness of the platform and attract a larger number of private companies to join the fight against marine plastics.
Date and Time:
Tuesday, 23 November 2021,&nbsp;9 AM -&nbsp;10:30&nbsp;PM (UTC+7; Jakarta time) / 10 AM - 11.30 (UTC+8; Malaysia time)&nbsp;
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)

Michikazu Kojima, Research Fellow, RKC-MPD, ERIA

.)1202( .la .te rejieM sneruoL tsitneics hctuD yb yduts a ot gnidrocca ,dlrow eht ni driht sknar hcihw aisyalaM gnidulcni ,naeco eht ot scitsalp fo egakael dlrow eht fo %6.26 rof tnuocca ot detamitse si noiger 3+NAESA ,deednI .erutcurtsarfni tnemeganam etsaw dilos fo kcal eht dna htworg cimonoce dipar ot eud noitullop citsalp eniram ot srotubirtnoc tseggib eht sa desingocer era snoiger naisA tsaehtuoS dna tsaE .sraey tnecer ni nrecnoc cifitneics gnisaercni detcartta evah metsysoce eniram ruo no stceffe evitagen sti dna tnemnorivne ruo ni desaeler etsaw citsalp fo tnuoma eht ,revewoH .sevil yadyreve ruo ni suotiuqibu ti sekam hcihw ,ecudorp ot evisnepxeni dna ,thgiewthgil ,tnatsiser ,elitasrev si taht lairetam a si citsalP scitsalP eniraM elkcaT ot revirD a sa noitavonnI :rotceS etavirP s™€âaisyalaM scitsalP eniraM elkcaT ot revirD a sa noitavonnI :rotceS etavirP s™€âaisyalaM";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-11-03 14:04:58";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-11-16 16:56:08";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:28:"devina.anglingdarma@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:172;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6497";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:69:"eria-ciieco-webinar-series-on-innovation-and-digitalisation-in-agtech";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:70:"ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series on Innovation and Digitalisation in Agtech";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-11-11";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"11";s:7:"content";s:3532:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2021-Nob-CIIE.CO-3-v1.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p><strong>ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series - Building Prolific Entrepreneurship Ecosystem in ASEAN with Insight from India Episode #3: Innovation and Digitalisaion in Agtech</strong></p><p>Agriculture is a key contributor to economic development and serves as the main source of a livelihood for a large segment across ASEAN and India. Over the years, the creation and adoption of cutting-edge technologies has allowed the development of Agriculture Technology or &ldquo;Agtech&rdquo; &ndash; enabling entrepreneurs, public, and private sectors to offer innovative solutions to areas such as digital market and financial access for smallholder farmers, production and supply chains services, smart farming solutions, and agri-food technology and innovation.</p><p>With the 3<sup>rd</sup> episode of ERIA-CIIE.CO online discussion, we aim to share knowledge and experience from experts and leading startups on Agtech innovation and digitalisation in the region, as well as learning the major challenges and opportunities on Agtech industries in the post-Covid-19 world. &nbsp;</p><p>Join us as we harvest new insights on Agtech innovations and learn how technology is used in agriculture today!</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Thursday, 11 November 2021, 2:30 - 4:00 PM, IST / 4:00 - 5:30 PM, WIB</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><table style="width: 614px;"><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p><strong>TIME</strong></p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>2:30 &ndash; 2:40 PM, IST</p><p>or</p><p>4:00 - 4:10 PM, WIB</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Start of Webinar | Welcome Remarks</strong></p><p><strong>Giulia Ajmone Marsan</strong></p><p>Director, Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 182.347px;"><p>2:40 &ndash; 3:40 PM, IST</p><p>or</p><p>4:10 - 5:10 PM</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Panel Discussion</strong></p><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li>Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi, Director of Research Strategy and Innovation, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li><li>Ritchie Goenawan, Chief Marketing Officer and Director of People &amp; 4:00 PM, IST</p><p>or</p><p>5:25 - 5:30 PM, WIB</p></td><td style="width: 416.653px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks and End of Webinar</strong></p></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/innovation-and-digitalisation-in-agtech-tickets-203522399977" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/%5BConcept%20Note%5D%20ERIA-CIIE.CO%20Roundtable%20on%20Innovation%20and%20Digitalisation%20in%20Agtech.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CONCEPT NOTE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-11-11";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-11-11";s:8:"keywords";s:5047:"ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series on Innovation and Digitalisation in Agtech ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series on Innovation and Digitalisation in Agtech ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series - Building Prolific Entrepreneurship Ecosystem in ASEAN with Insight from India Episode #3: Innovation and Digitalisaion in Agtech
Agriculture is a key contributor to economic development and serves as the main source of a livelihood for a large segment across ASEAN and India. Over the years, the creation and adoption of cutting-edge technologies has allowed the development of Agriculture Technology or &ldquo;Agtech&rdquo; &ndash; enabling entrepreneurs, public, and private sectors to offer innovative solutions to areas such as digital market and financial access for smallholder farmers, production and supply chains services, smart farming solutions, and agri-food technology and innovation.
With the 3rd episode of ERIA-CIIE.CO online discussion, we aim to share knowledge and experience from experts and leading startups on Agtech innovation and digitalisation in the region, as well as learning the major challenges and opportunities on Agtech industries in the post-Covid-19 world. &nbsp;
Join us as we harvest new insights on Agtech innovations and learn how technology is used in agriculture today!
Date and Time:
Thursday, 11 November 2021, 2:30 - 4:00 PM, IST / 4:00 - 5:30 PM, WIB
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
