href="https://bit.ly/3pdu7Hp" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:0:"";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-11-02";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-11-02";s:8:"keywords";s:8197:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement, Public-Private Dialogue 1: The RCEP E-Commerce Provisions and What They Mean for Cambodia Unpacking the RCEP Agreement, Public-Private Dialogue 1: The RCEP E-Commerce Provisions and What They Mean for Cambodia Unpacking the RCEP Agreement, Public-Private Dialogue 1: The RCEP E-Commerce Provisions and What They Mean for Cambodia
The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement amongst 15 states. RCEP will create new business opportunities and change the shape of trade in the region.
ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme is organising a series of five Public-Private Dialogues, 'Unpacking the RCEP Agreement'. Dialogue 1 will discuss the e-commerce provisions and the digitalization of trade, and the potential impact it may have on your business. The Dialogue will bring together business, government, and international trade experts to share their perspectives.
If you are in Cambodia, glean insights together with our distinguished panel of speakers on how to maximise the benefits from e-commerce.
Date and Time:
Tuesday, 2 November 2021, 8.30 AM&nbsp;&ndash; 12.30 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Agenda (as of 27 October 2021)
(Phnom Penh and Jakarta time, UTC+7)



Time
Agenda Item
Notes


8:30 &ndash; 9:00 AM

Opening Remarks
Host: Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building, ERIA

HE SIM Sokheng, Secretary of State, Ministry of Commerce
Mr Andreas ZURBRUGG, Deputy Ambassador, Australian Embassy, Cambodia


&nbsp;


9:00 - 10:00 AM

Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP e-commerce agreement and Cambodia&rsquo;s Work Plan for its implementation
Moderator: Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade and E-Trade Adviser
Presenters:

HE SOK Siphana, Senior Advisor to the Royal Government of Cambodia
Deborah ELMS, CEO, Asia Trade Centre
SRENG Nearirath, Deputy Head of Banking and Finance Practice Group, DFDL Mekong (Cambodia)

Q&amp;A with the audience.


This session will provide a precise description of what the RCEP e-commerce provisions are and whether Cambodia&rsquo;s legal and regulatory system for e-commerce is ready to accelerate cross-border e-commerce.



10:00 -10:10 AM
&nbsp;Break
&nbsp;


10:10 &ndash; 11:30 AM

Session 2: Private sector perspectives on opportunities for Cambodia in RCEP
Moderator: Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, CBP, ERIA
Panellists: 

Mr CHEA Langda, Founder and CEO, BookMeBus
Mr Maxime Rosburger, Partner &amp; COO, Kiwipay Pte Ltd.
LCT CHEA Ratha, Vice President, Cambodia Women Entrepreneur Association
Mr Kenneth TANG, Auscham Cambodia and Managing Director, Dynamic Technologies
Mr PRAYAG Chitrakar, Country Manager, DHL Express (Cambodia) Ltd.

Q&amp;A with the audience.


This session will enable different business interests to assess their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP agreement could be a game-changer in their industry.



11.30 AM - 12.15 PM

Session 3: Panel Discussion on Bridging National Interests and Global Trends
Moderator: Mr Danny Burrows, Founder and Principal, TradeWorthy Ltd.
Panellists: 

DG RATH Saravuth, General Directorate of International Trade, Ministry of Commerce
Mr MOM Varin, Vice-President, Cambodia E-business Association and CEO, AngkorStores.com
Representative, Australian Embassy in Cambodia.

Q&amp;A with the audience.


The session will seek to enhance public-private dialogue on e-commerce and, more broadly, of RCEP implementation, with a view to discuss possible follow-up actions to increase the capacity of public officials and MSMEs alike to respond to regional opportunities created by RCEP.




12:15 PM &ndash; 12:30 PM


Closing remarks
HE SIM Sokheng, Secretary of State / HE Rath Saravuth, Director General, Ministry of Commerce (TBC)

&nbsp;

MA 01:01- 00:01

Join us in conversation as our 4 speakers share their thoughts on this topic of growing interest.</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Thursday, 21 October 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><table><tr><td width="141"><p><strong>TIME</strong></p></td><td width="459"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="141"><p>2.00 &ndash; The COVID-19 pandemic has brought about heightened scrutiny on climate change agendas and sustainability practices. Entrepreneurs whose focus revolves around sustainability have also come to the forefront in recent years. What future opportunities await Sustainability Entrepreneurship and how will it drive post-pandemic recovery? Join us in conversation as our 4 speakers share their thoughts on this topic of growing interest.
Date and Time:
Thursday, 21 October 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)




TIME


AGENDA




2.00 &ndash; 2.05 PM


Start of Webinar | Welcome Remarks
Giulia Ajmone Marsan
Director, Strategy and Partnership, ERIA




2.05 &ndash; 3.00 PM


Panel Discussion 
Speakers:

Chan Mun Wei,&nbsp;Founder and Principal Consultant, SustainableSG, Singapore
Jeong Hyop Lee,&nbsp;Senior Advisor, Deep Science and Tech Programme Management Unit for Competitiveness Thailand
Ayako Mizuno,&nbsp;Programme Manager, Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), ERIA
Nicola Crosta,&nbsp;Founder and CEO, Impact46, Thailand

Moderated by OOI Tiat Jin (TJ)
Founder &amp; Principal Consultant, Curated Connectors, Singapore




3.00 &ndash; 3.10PM


Q &amp; A
Moderated by Lina Maulidina Sabrina
Programme Officer, ERIA




3.10 &ndash; 3.15 PM


Closing Remarks and End of Webinar

This event will be streamed online via Zoom webinar.

Date: Wednesday, 27 October 2021
Time: 3:30 PM to 5 PM (Hanoi time, UTC+7) or 5:30 PM to 7 PM (Tokyo time, UTC+9)
Format: Zoom webinar, RSVP is required
Language: English



Opening Remarks
The representative of Medical Excellence&nbsp;JAPAN
Keynote Address

For the Future, the Role of Viet Nam and Japan in the Western Pacific Region: Dr Takeshi Kasai (WHO Regional Director for the Western Pacific)
Health Development in Viet Nam:&nbsp;Vice Minister H.E. Mr Nguyen Truong Son, Ministry of Health of Viet Nam

Panel Discussion
Moderator: Dr Mitsuhiro Ushio, former Health Policy Advisor to Ministry of Health, Viet Nam
Panellist

Dr Pham Nguyen Quy, M.D., Ph.D., Department of Medical Oncology, Kyoto Miniren Central Hospital, Kyoto University, Y hoc cong
Ms Pham Thi Minh Chau, Deputy Director, International Cooperation Department, Ministry of Health, Viet Nam
Mr Yukinori Tominaga, Chairperson of Japanese Pharmaceutical Alliance in Viet Nam
Dr Koji Wada, Professor, Department of Public Health, Faculty of Medicine, International University of Health and Welfare

Special Advice
Dr Tran Thi Giang Huong (Director, Program for Disease Control, WHO WPRO)
Concluding Remarks
Dr Hiroki Nakatani (Special Advisor to the President of ERIA)


Organised by

Medical Excellence JAPAN (MEJ)
Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)

Supported by&nbsp;

Viet Nam: Ministry of Health
Japan: Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry

of ERIA Member States and Dialogue Partners Ambassadors Meeting of ERIA Member States and Dialogue Partners        Virtual Room  Ms Sarah Tavia  sarah.tavia@eria.org   2021-10-06 2021-10-06 2021-10-06 6 October 2021 1202 rebotcO 6 60-01-1202 60-01-1202 60-01-1202   gro.aire@aivat.haras  aivaT haraS sM  mooR lautriV        srentraP eugolaiD dna setatS rebmeM AIRE fo gniteeM srodassabmA srentraP eugolaiD dna setatS rebmeM AIRE fo gniteeM srodassabmA";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-10-06 10:38:28";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-10-06 10:38:28";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"14";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:20:"sarah.tavia@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:179;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6445";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:23:"ccus-technical-workshop";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:23:"CCUS Technical Workshop";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-10-05";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:8080:"<p class="preFlex flexIn">The Asia CCUS Network has been successfully launched on 22-23rd June 2021 with initially 13 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions that share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region. The Network members have expressed their intention to participate to share the vision of the Asia CCUS Network that aims to contribute to the decarbonisation of emissions in Asia through collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS. The mission of this network is to facilitate deployment of CCUS through: (i) promoting knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings; (ii) conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and (iii) holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS. The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through collaboration of research and innovation.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">At the 1st Asia CCUS Network Forum held on 22-23 June 2021, it was concluded that CCUS and Carbon Recycling are crucial technologies for the ASEAN region to achieve carbon neutrality amidst climate and energy security concerns in the future. It was also discussed by the stakeholders that participated in the Forum, that in order to bring more CCUS projects to commercialization stage, issues, such as the lack of an adequate legal framework to address liability and a technical framework through pilot projects need to be resolved. Moreover, it is expected that in order to accelerate the deployment of CCUS in ASEAN region, there is a need to bridge the gap and to implement knowledge and experience sharing amongst the ASEAN and Asian region.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Building upon the outcome of the 1st Asia CCUS Network Forum as described above, the Asia CCUS Network (ACN) will organize a virtual technical workshop about CCUS in the October 2021. This workshop hosted by ACN aims to serve as an opportunity to instill knowledge about latest technologies and the current trend of CCUS through real case studies by top notch lecturers.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">The goals of the CCUS technical workshops are as follows.</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">Promote the knowledge sharing on the latest CCUS technology through lecture session.</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">Accelerate further consideration of application of mainstream CCUS technologies to ASEAN region.</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">Exchange ideas and issues about CCUS technology.</p></li></ul><p class="preFlex flexIn">There will be a total of three workshops to be organized. The 1st day of the workshop is about the technical aspect of carbon capture technology. The 2nd day is the technical aspect of transport &amp; storage technology. The 3rd day will be about the utilization of CO2.</p><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>DAY 1 -&nbsp;CCUS Technical Workshop: Technical Aspect of Carbon Capture Technology</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Tuesday, 5 October 2021&nbsp;</p><h4 class="preFlex flexIn">Agenda</h4><p class="preFlex flexIn"><em>(as of 22 September 2021)</em></p><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>Technical Workshop 1: Technical Aspect of Carbon Capture Technology</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">(Jakarta Time, UTC+7)</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">9:00-9:15 <strong>Opening Remarks (Overview of Asia CCUS Network) </strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist of ERIA</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">9:15-9:30 <strong>Introduction to capacity building and overview of CCUS business development in Asia</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">9:30-10:10 <strong>Overview of carbon capture technologies. Their advantages and disadvantages.</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Dr David Kearns, Principal Consultant-CCS technology, GCCSI</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">10:10-10:50 <strong>Case Study on chemical absorption technologies</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">(TBC) Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Engineering</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">10:50-11:00 <strong>Closing Speech</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI</p><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a class="bluebtn" title="https://bit.ly/CCUSTW1" href="https://bit.ly/CCUSTW1" target="_blank" Technology&nbsp;</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Wednesday, 6 October 2021&nbsp;</p><h4 class="preFlex flexIn">Agenda</h4><p class="preFlex flexIn">(as of 16 September 2021)</p><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>Technical Workshop 2: Technical aspect of carbon transportation &amp; storage technology </strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">(Jakarta Time)</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">9:00-9:15 <strong>Opening Remarks (Overview of Asia CCUS Network)</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist of ERIA</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">9:15-9:30 Innovative Technologies for the Earth (RITE)</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">10:50-11:00 <strong>Closing Speech</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI</p><p flexIn">(Jakarta Time)</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">9:00-9:15<strong> Opening Remarks (Overview of Asia CCUS Network)</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist of Pertamina RTC, Indonesia</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">10:10-10:50 <strong>CO2 Utilization Research Activities and Potential Industrial Application</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Mr Ning Yan, Dean&rsquo;s Chair Associate Professor, Head of Green Catalysis Lab, National University of Singapore</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">10:50-11:00 <strong>Closing Speech</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI</p><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a class="bluebtn" title="REGISTER&nbsp;" href="https://bit.ly/CCUSTW3" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:15:"Ms Tri Mulianik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-10-05";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-10-07";s:8:"keywords";s:11537:"CCUS Technical Workshop CCUS Technical Workshop The Asia CCUS Network has been successfully launched on 22-23rd June 2021 with initially 13 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions that share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region. The Network members have expressed their intention to participate to share the vision of the Asia CCUS Network that aims to contribute to the decarbonisation of emissions in Asia through collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS. The mission of this network is to facilitate deployment of CCUS through: (i) promoting knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings; (ii) conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and (iii) holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS. The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through collaboration of research and innovation.
At the 1st Asia CCUS Network Forum held on 22-23 June 2021, it was concluded that CCUS and Carbon Recycling are crucial technologies for the ASEAN region to achieve carbon neutrality amidst climate and energy security concerns in the future. It was also discussed by the stakeholders that participated in the Forum, that in order to bring more CCUS projects to commercialization stage, issues, such as the lack of an adequate legal framework to address liability and a technical framework through pilot projects need to be resolved. Moreover, it is expected that in order to accelerate the deployment of CCUS in ASEAN region, there is a need to bridge the gap and to implement knowledge and experience sharing amongst the ASEAN and Asian region.
Building upon the outcome of the 1st Asia CCUS Network Forum as described above, the Asia CCUS Network (ACN) will organize a virtual technical workshop about CCUS in the October 2021. This workshop hosted by ACN aims to serve as an opportunity to instill knowledge about latest technologies and the current trend of CCUS through real case studies by top notch lecturers.
The goals of the CCUS technical workshops are as follows.


Promote the knowledge sharing on the latest CCUS technology through lecture session.


Accelerate further consideration of application of mainstream CCUS technologies to ASEAN region.


Exchange ideas and issues about CCUS technology.


There will be a total of three workshops to be organized. The 1st day of the workshop is about the technical aspect of carbon capture technology. The 2nd day is the technical aspect of transport &amp; storage technology. The 3rd day will be about the utilization of CO2.
DAY 1 -&nbsp;CCUS Technical Workshop: Technical Aspect of Carbon Capture Technology
Tuesday, 5 October 2021&nbsp;
Agenda
(as of 22 September 2021)
Technical Workshop 1: Technical Aspect of Carbon Capture Technology
(Jakarta Time, UTC+7)
9:00-9:15 Opening Remarks (Overview of Asia CCUS Network) 
Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist of ERIA
9:15-9:30 Introduction to capacity building and overview of CCUS business development in Asia
Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI
9:30-10:10 Overview of carbon capture technologies. Their advantages and disadvantages.
Dr David Kearns, Principal Consultant-CCS technology, GCCSI
10:10-10:50 Case Study on chemical absorption technologies
(TBC) Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Engineering
10:50-11:00 Closing Speech
Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI
REGISTER&nbsp;
&nbsp;DAY 2 &nbsp;-&nbsp;CCUS Technical Workshop: Technical Aspect of Carbon Transportation &amp; Storage Technology&nbsp;
Wednesday, 6 October 2021&nbsp;
Agenda
(as of 16 September 2021)
Technical Workshop 2: Technical aspect of carbon transportation &amp; storage technology 
(Jakarta Time)
9:00-9:15 Opening Remarks (Overview of Asia CCUS Network)
Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist of ERIA
9:15-9:30 Introduction to capacity building and overview of CCUS business development in Asia
Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI
9:30-10:10 Overview of marine / pipeline transportation technologies (TBC)
Mr Ulysses Coulmas, Researcher, MRI
10:10-10:50 Overview of storage technologies 
Dr Ziqiu&nbsp;Xue, Chief researcher, CO2 Storage Technology Group,  Research Institute for Innovative Technologies for the Earth (RITE)
10:50-11:00 Closing Speech
Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI
REGISTER&nbsp;
&nbsp;DAY 3&nbsp; -&nbsp;CCUS Technical Workshop:&nbsp;Utilisation of CO2
Thursday, 7 October 2021&nbsp;
Agenda
(as of 22 September 2021)
Technical Workshop3: Utilization of CO2
(Jakarta Time)
9:00-9:15 Opening Remarks (Overview of Asia CCUS Network)
Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist of ERIA
9:15-9:30 Introduction to capacity building and overview of CCUS business development in Asia
Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI
9:30-10:10 Research activities of CCU technologies in Indonesia
Ms Dewi Mersitarini, Advisor CCUS, Pertamina RTC, Indonesia
10:10-10:50 CO2 Utilization Research Activities and Potential Industrial Application
Mr Ning Yan, Dean&rsquo;s Chair Associate Professor, Head of Green Catalysis Lab, National University of Singapore
10:50-11:00 Closing Speech
Mrs Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher of MRI

The digital revolution, whilst catalysing such initiatives, is not without its constraints. There are both hardware and heartware challenges, yet for those who have overcome them, the rewards extend beyond material wealth. Their success fuels the aspirations of the next generation.</p><p>Join us as we talk to four inspirational women who have bravely entered the realm of entrepreneurship and ecommerce. Be inspired!</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Thursday, 23 September 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li>Lishia Erza, CEO, ASYX, Indonesia</li><li>Pennie Lim, CEO Homa Sdn Bhd, Malaysia</li><li>Mel Nava, Co-Founder and CEO 1Export, Philippines</li><li>Syanaz Winanto, Founder of Rorokenes, Member of eTrade for Women Community from Indonesia</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" title="PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;" href="/uploads/media/Events/2021-Sept-E-S-I-8_fin.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/women-in-e-commerce-tickets-171670841107" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-09-23";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:2949:"ERIA Entrepreneurship-Startup-Innovation (E-S-I) webinar episode 8: Women In E-commerce ERIA Entrepreneurship-Startup-Innovation (E-S-I) webinar episode 8: Women In E-commerce ERIA Webinar Series #8 - 'Entrepreneurship, Start-Ups and Innovation (E-S-I) in ASEAN and East Asia for The Post-Pandemic Recovery'
There are many initiatives globally to encourage and empower women to become entrepreneurs. The digital revolution, whilst catalysing such initiatives, is not without its constraints. There are both hardware and heartware challenges, yet for those who have overcome them, the rewards extend beyond material wealth. Their success fuels the aspirations of the next generation.
Join us as we talk to four inspirational women who have bravely entered the realm of entrepreneurship and ecommerce. Be inspired!
Date and Time:
Thursday, 23 September 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Welcome Remark:

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA

Speakers:

Lishia Erza, CEO, ASYX, Indonesia
Pennie Lim, CEO Homa Sdn Bhd, Malaysia
Mel Nava, Co-Founder and CEO 1Export, Philippines
Syanaz Winanto, Founder of Rorokenes, Member of eTrade for Women Community from Indonesia

PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;

!deripsni eB .ecremmoce dna pihsruenerpertne fo mlaer eht deretne ylevarb evah ohw nemow lanoitaripsni ruof ot klat ew sa su nioJ
.noitareneg txen eht fo snoitaripsa eht sleuf sseccus riehT .htlaew lairetam dnoyeb dnetxe sdrawer eht ,meht emocrevo evah ohw esoht rof tey ,segnellahc erawtraeh dna erawdrah htob era erehT .stniartsnoc sti tuohtiw ton si ,sevitaitini hcus gnisylatac tslihw ,noitulover latigid ehT .sruenerpertne emoceb ot nemow rewopme dna egaruocne ot yllabolg sevitaitini ynam era erehT
'yrevoceR cimednaP-tsoP ehT rof aisA tsaE dna NAESA ni )I-S-E( noitavonnI dna spU-tratS ,pihsruenerpertnE' - 8# seireS ranibeW AIRE ecremmoc-E nI nemoW :8 edosipe ranibew )I-S-E( noitavonnI-putratS-pihsruenerpertnE AIRE ecremmoc-E nI nemoW :8 edosipe ranibew )I-S-E( noitavonnI-putratS-pihsruenerpertnE AIRE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-09-14 14:21:00";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-09-20 14:55:46";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"14";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:182;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6437";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:54:"the-3rd-asia-ccus-network-knowledge-sharing-conference";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:54:"The 3rd Asia CCUS Network Knowledge Sharing Conference";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-10-14";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:5056:"<p>The Asia CCUS Network has been successfully launched on 22-23rd June 2021 with initially 13 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions that share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region. The Network members have expressed their intention to participate to share the vision of the Asia CCUS Network that aims to contribute to the decarbonisation of emissions in Asia through collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS. The mission of this network is to facilitate deployment of CCUS through: (i) promoting knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings; (ii) conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and (iii) holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS. The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through collaboration of research and innovation.</p><p>The Oil and Gas Climate Initiative (OGCI) is an international industry-led organization which includes 12 member companies from the oil and gas industry: BP, Chevron, CNPC, Eni, Equinor, ExxonMobil, Occidental, Petrobras, Repsol, Saudi Aramco, Shell and Total represent over &#039;30% of global operated oil and gas production." It was established in 2014 and has a mandate to work together to &#039;accelerate the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions&#039; in full support of the Paris Agreement and its aims. OGCI&#039;s focus now is to reduce methane gas emissions (leaks), reduce carbon dioxide emissions, and promote carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). Funds set up by OGCI also invest in companies in these three areas.</p><p>The ACN will be an active forum to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS technologies, policy development to support the development and deployment of CCUS in Asia. Thus, this conference hosted in collaboration with OGCI will help to bring in their collective latest studies and up to date knowledge on CCUS in Asia, specifically on CO2 storage, can facilitate an increased understanding of project finance risk related to sequestration.</p><h2>Agenda</h2><p><em>(as of 13 September 2021)</em></p><p>MC: Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA</p><table style="width: 434px;"><tr><td style="width: 241.588px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">15:00 &ndash; 15:10</span></td><td style="width: 431.412px;"><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Opening </strong>&nbsp;</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Taizo Hara, Director General of Research and Policy Design Administration of ERIA (3-5 minutes)</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Julien Perez, Vice President Strategy and Policy, OGCI (3-5 Minutes)</span></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 241.588px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">15:10 &ndash; 16:00</span></td><td style="width: 431.412px;"><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Presentation by OGCI</strong></span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Iain Macdonald, CCUS Workstream Lead: Introduction of OGCI (5-10 minutes)</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Owain Tucker / Lesley Seldon, Storage Working Group: Lecture on CO2 Storage (30-40 minutes)</span></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 241.588px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">16:00 &ndash; 16:10</span></td><td style="width: 431.412px;"><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Comments</strong> </span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Petronas (TBC)</span></p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Dr Hiroshi Okabe</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"> Director, Reservoir Evaluation Team, CCS Group</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"> Director, EOR Division, Technology Department</span><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation (JOGMEC)JOGMEC</span></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 241.588px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">16:10 &ndash; 16:30 &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></td><td style="width: 431.412px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Open discussion Session to the Presentations</strong></span></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 241.588px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">16:30</span></td><td style="width: 431.412px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Closing Remarks </strong>by Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA</span></td></tr></table>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:11:"energy,CCUS";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:4:"ERIA";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-10-14";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-10-14";s:8:"keywords";s:7205:"The 3rd Asia CCUS Network Knowledge Sharing Conference The 3rd Asia CCUS Network Knowledge Sharing Conference The Asia CCUS Network has been successfully launched on 22-23rd June 2021 with initially 13 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions that share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region. The Network members have expressed their intention to participate to share the vision of the Asia CCUS Network that aims to contribute to the decarbonisation of emissions in Asia through collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS. The mission of this network is to facilitate deployment of CCUS through: (i) promoting knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings; (ii) conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and (iii) holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS. The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through collaboration of research and innovation.
The Oil and Gas Climate Initiative (OGCI) is an international industry-led organization which includes 12 member companies from the oil and gas industry: BP, Chevron, CNPC, Eni, Equinor, ExxonMobil, Occidental, Petrobras, Repsol, Saudi Aramco, Shell and Total represent over '30% of global operated oil and gas production." It was established in 2014 and has a mandate to work together to 'accelerate the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions' in full support of the Paris Agreement and its aims. OGCI's focus now is to reduce methane gas emissions (leaks), reduce carbon dioxide emissions, and promote carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). Funds set up by OGCI also invest in companies in these three areas.
The ACN will be an active forum to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS technologies, policy development to support the development and deployment of CCUS in Asia. Thus, this conference hosted in collaboration with OGCI will help to bring in their collective latest studies and up to date knowledge on CCUS in Asia, specifically on CO2 storage, can facilitate an increased understanding of project finance risk related to sequestration.
Agenda
(as of 13 September 2021)
MC: Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA



15:00 &ndash; 15:10

Opening &nbsp;
Taizo Hara, Director General of Research and Policy Design Administration of ERIA (3-5 minutes)
Julien Perez, Vice President Strategy and Policy, OGCI (3-5 Minutes)



15:10 &ndash; 16:00

Presentation by OGCI
Iain Macdonald, CCUS Workstream Lead: Introduction of OGCI (5-10 minutes)
Owain Tucker / Lesley Seldon, Storage Working Group: Lecture on CO2 Storage (30-40 minutes)



16:00 &ndash; 16:10

Comments 
Petronas (TBC)
Dr Hiroshi Okabe Director, Reservoir Evaluation Team, CCS Group Director, EOR Division, Technology Department
Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation (JOGMEC)JOGMEC

aisA dr3 ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-09-13 18:46:31";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-09-20 09:17:32";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:18:"tri.manik@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:183;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6429";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:82:"the-10th-eria-editors-roundtable-overcoming-covid-19-from-adversity-to-opportunity";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:107:"The 10th ERIA Editorsâ€™ Roundtable: â€˜Overcoming COVID-19: From Adversity to Opportunityâ€™";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-10-08";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:4435:"<p>Well into the second year of the pandemic and it is difficult to say when this will end.&nbsp; While all ASEAN members struggle to address the myriad challenges that COVID-19 has brought, they have all recognized the need for more regional cooperation to promote a more resilient, prosperous, and sustainable future. Many pre-existing trends have been accelerated like the adoption of the digital economy and the green economy.&nbsp; Policymakers also see the opportunity to promote new strategies of cooperation and planning.&nbsp; &nbsp;Given the current circumstances, the 10<sup>th</sup> ERIA Editors&rsquo; Roundtable will be held online for the second time. This event is expected to draw a large audience from the region and beyond. Online participants will learn first-hand from ASEAN scholars and experts about how they are trying to bring back robust economies. Through this interaction, editors and media influencers will be able to strengthen their capacities to cover the pandemic and the region&rsquo;s recovery plan. ERIA is delighted to be supported by our Media Co-host: The Scoop, Brunei Darussalam.</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Friday, 8 October 2021, 9:00 AM to 11.30 AM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><strong>Agenda:</strong></p><table style="width: 800px;"><tr><td style="width: Roundtable</a></h2>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Editorsâ€™ Roundtable: â€˜Overcoming COVID-19: From Adversity to Opportunityâ€™ The 10th ERIA Editorsâ€™ Roundtable: â€˜Overcoming COVID-19: From Adversity to Opportunityâ€™ Well into the second year of the pandemic and it is difficult to say when this will end.&nbsp; While all ASEAN members struggle to address the myriad challenges that COVID-19 has brought, they have all recognized the need for more regional cooperation to promote a more resilient, prosperous, and sustainable future. Many pre-existing trends have been accelerated like the adoption of the digital economy and the green economy.&nbsp; Policymakers also see the opportunity to promote new strategies of cooperation and planning.&nbsp; &nbsp;Given the current circumstances, the 10th ERIA Editors&rsquo; Roundtable will be held online for the second time. This event is expected to draw a large audience from the region and beyond. Online participants will learn first-hand from ASEAN scholars and experts about how they are trying to bring back robust economies. Through this interaction, editors and media influencers will be able to strengthen their capacities to cover the pandemic and the region&rsquo;s recovery plan. ERIA is delighted to be supported by our Media Co-host: The Scoop, Brunei Darussalam.
Date and Time:
Friday, 8 October 2021, 9:00 AM to 11.30 AM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)

noiger eht morf ecneidua egral a ward ot detcepxe si tneve sihT .emit dnoces eht rof enilno dleh eb lliw elbatdnuoR ;ouqsr&srotidE AIRE ht01 eht ,secnatsmucric tnerruc eht neviG;psbn& ;psbn&.gninnalp .erutuf elbaniatsus dna ,suorepsorp ,tneiliser erom a etomorp ot noitarepooc lanoiger erom rof deen eht dezingocer lla evah yeht ,thguorb sah 91-DIVOC taht segnellahc dairym eht sserdda ot elggurts srebmem NAESA lla elihW ;psbn&.dne lliw siht nehw yas ot tluciffid si ti dna cimednap eht fo raey dnoces eht otni lleW ™€âytinutroppO ot ytisrevdA morF :91-DIVOC gnimocrevO˜€â :elbatdnuoR ™€âsrotidE AIRE ht01 ehT ™€âytinutroppO ot ytisrevdA morF :91-DIVOC gnimocrevO˜€â :elbatdnuoR ™€âsrotidE AIRE ht01 ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-09-10 14:31:11";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-10-25 18:52:20";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:24:"isabella.italia@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:184;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6428";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:63:"how-private-companies-in-indonesia-combat-marine-plastic-debris";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:63:"How Private Companies in Indonesia Combat Marine Plastic Debris";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-09-21";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:6395:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Photo%20Flyer%20Revised.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="225" /></p><p>Plastic is a material that is versatile, resistant, lightweight, and inexpensive to produce, which makes it ubiquitous in our everyday lives. However, the amount of plastic waste released in our environment and its negative effects on our marine ecosystem have attracted increasing scientific concern in recent years. East and Southeast Asian regions are recognised as the biggest contributors of marine plastic pollution due to rapid economic growth and the lack of solid waste management infrastructure. Indonesia, in particular, ranks fifth in the world among countries that have mismanaged their plastic wastes, according to a study by Dutch scientist Lourens Meijer et. al. (2021).</p><p>Alarmed by this situation, the ASEAN Member States in 2019 welcomed the ASEAN Framework of Action on Marine Debris and adopted the Bangkok Declaration on Combating Marine Debris in ASEAN Region. In May 2021, ASEAN as a group officially launched the ASEAN Regional Action Plan for Combating Marine Debris in the ASEAN Member States (2021-2025), which recognises the urgent need to combat marine litter, including by promoting platforms for knowledge sharing, innovative solutions, and best practices to address this issue.</p><p>Although much is still left to be studied, particularly the long-term impacts of plastics on our marine ecosystem, and its potential harm to human health through the food chain, there is a wide international consensus to take urgent preventative actions before further damage is done. Echoing these concerns, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) has established the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) in 2019 to provide ASEAN+3 Member States with support in addressing emerging challenges associated with marine plastic debris.</p><p>At the occasion of this forum, ERIA&rsquo;s RKC-MPD will focus on the important role played by the private sector, especially in tackling plastic waste both from upstream and downstream levels. The private sector in ASEAN+3 countries has been contributing to the reduction of plastic waste and by consequence marine plastic debris in the region. Their efforts can range from improved resource efficiency, to enhanced waste management, proper recycling, to innovative technologies leading to a more sustainable production and consumption patterns.</p><p>However, many such initiatives are not sufficiently recognised and acknowledged. One of the important missions of RKC-MPD is to promote private companies whose business activities help combat marine plastic litter, in the hope of further promoting this positive shift. RKC-MPD has established online platform titled &lsquo;Private sector initiatives to reduce plastic waste and marine plastic debris&rsquo; (<a href="https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story">https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story</a>). It hosts information submitted by private companies from all ASEAN+3 countries to showcase their products, services, or technologies contributing to the reduction of plastic waste and marine plastic debris. The platform collects and disseminates private companies&rsquo; business activities that are conducive to marine plastics mitigation. It also aims to facilitate Business-to-Business, Business-to-Government and/or Business-to-Consumer opportunities in the ASEAN+3 region.</p><p>The forum will be an occasion for the Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs and Investment of the Republic Indonesia and Indonesian private companies to share the initiatives of private sector in combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris. RKC-MPD will also reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP)&nbsp; to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness on the platform and its objectives. It aims to attract a larger number of private companies to take part in this initiative and join forces in the fight against marine plastics.</p><h2><strong>DATE AND TIME</strong></h2><p>21 September 2021, 10:00-11:30 AM Jakarta time (GMT+7)</p><h2><strong>AGENDA</strong></h2><table style="width: 639.885px;"><tr><td style="width: 144px;"><p><strong>TIME</strong></p></td><td style="width: 480.885px;"><p><strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; AGENDA </strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 144px;"><p>10:00-10:10AM</p></td><td style="width: 480.885px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks:</strong></p><p>Michikazu Kojima, Research Fellow, Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), ERIA</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 144px;"><p>10:15-10:45AM</p></td><td style="width: 480.885px;"><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp; </strong><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p><p>Hera Diani, Communication Expert, RKC-MPD, ERIA</p><p><strong>Panelists:</strong></p><ul><li>Rofi Alhanif, Deputy Assistant for Waste and Waste Management, the Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs and Investment&nbsp;</li><li>Osachi Takagi, Acting Chairperson of the Japan Clean Ocean Material Alliance (CLOMA) Indonesia Working Group and Operating Officer for the Performance Materials Business Unit at MITSUI &amp; CO., LTD.</li><li>Karyanto Wibowo, Sustainability Director of Danone Indonesia and Chairman of Packaging and Recycling Association for Indonesia Sustainable Environment (PRAISE)</li><li>Novita Tan, CEO of Rebricks</li><li>Ernest Layman, CEO and Co-Founder of Rekosistem</li><li>Ayako Mizuno, Programme Manager, the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), ERIA</li></ul><p>Each panelist will deliver a 5-minute presentation on the selected topic</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 144px;"><p>10:45-11:30AM</p></td><td style="width: 480.885px;"><p><strong>Open Discussion with Q &amp; A </strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 144px;">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 480.885px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks </strong></p><p>Michikazu Kojima, Research Fellow, RKC-MPD, ERIA</p></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/how-private-companies-in-indonesia-combat-marine-plastic-debris-tickets-168394022053" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:22:"Ms Devina Anglingdarma";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-09-21";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:11259:"How Private Companies in Indonesia Combat Marine Plastic Debris How Private Companies in Indonesia Combat Marine Plastic Debris Plastic is a material that is versatile, resistant, lightweight, and inexpensive to produce, which makes it ubiquitous in our everyday lives. However, the amount of plastic waste released in our environment and its negative effects on our marine ecosystem have attracted increasing scientific concern in recent years. East and Southeast Asian regions are recognised as the biggest contributors of marine plastic pollution due to rapid economic growth and the lack of solid waste management infrastructure. Indonesia, in particular, ranks fifth in the world among countries that have mismanaged their plastic wastes, according to a study by Dutch scientist Lourens Meijer et. al. (2021).
Alarmed by this situation, the ASEAN Member States in 2019 welcomed the ASEAN Framework of Action on Marine Debris and adopted the Bangkok Declaration on Combating Marine Debris in ASEAN Region. In May 2021, ASEAN as a group officially launched the ASEAN Regional Action Plan for Combating Marine Debris in the ASEAN Member States (2021-2025), which recognises the urgent need to combat marine litter, including by promoting platforms for knowledge sharing, innovative solutions, and best practices to address this issue.
Although much is still left to be studied, particularly the long-term impacts of plastics on our marine ecosystem, and its potential harm to human health through the food chain, there is a wide international consensus to take urgent preventative actions before further damage is done. Echoing these concerns, the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) has established the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) in 2019 to provide ASEAN+3 Member States with support in addressing emerging challenges associated with marine plastic debris.
At the occasion of this forum, ERIA&rsquo;s RKC-MPD will focus on the important role played by the private sector, especially in tackling plastic waste both from upstream and downstream levels. The private sector in ASEAN+3 countries has been contributing to the reduction of plastic waste and by consequence marine plastic debris in the region. Their efforts can range from improved resource efficiency, to enhanced waste management, proper recycling, to innovative technologies leading to a more sustainable production and consumption patterns.
However, many such initiatives are not sufficiently recognised and acknowledged. One of the important missions of RKC-MPD is to promote private companies whose business activities help combat marine plastic litter, in the hope of further promoting this positive shift. RKC-MPD has established online platform titled &lsquo;Private sector initiatives to reduce plastic waste and marine plastic debris&rsquo; (https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story). It hosts information submitted by private companies from all ASEAN+3 countries to showcase their products, services, or technologies contributing to the reduction of plastic waste and marine plastic debris. The platform collects and disseminates private companies&rsquo; business activities that are conducive to marine plastics mitigation. It also aims to facilitate Business-to-Business, Business-to-Government and/or Business-to-Consumer opportunities in the ASEAN+3 region.
The forum will be an occasion for the Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs and Investment of the Republic Indonesia and Indonesian private companies to share the initiatives of private sector in combatting plastic waste and marine plastic debris. RKC-MPD will also reintroduce the Private Sector Platform (PSP)&nbsp; to the public, particularly to the private companies, to raise more awareness on the platform and its objectives. It aims to attract a larger number of private companies to take part in this initiative and join forces in the fight against marine plastics.
DATE AND TIME
21 September 2021, 10:00-11:30 AM Jakarta time (GMT+7)
AGENDA




TIME

10:00-10:10AM


Opening Remarks:
Michikazu Kojima, Research Fellow, Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), ERIA

Hera Diani, Communication Expert, RKC-MPD, ERIA

Karyanto Wibowo, Sustainability Director of Danone Indonesia and Chairman of Packaging and Recycling Association for Indonesia Sustainable Environment (PRAISE)
Novita Tan, CEO of Rebricks
Ernest Layman, CEO and Co-Founder of Rekosistem
Ayako Mizuno, Programme Manager, the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD), ERIA

10:45-11:30AM


Open Discussion with Q &amp; A

Closing Remarks 
Michikazu Kojima, Research Fellow, RKC-MPD, ERIA

draft";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-09-08";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:21701:"<p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textlight_italic;"><img src="/uploads/media/Flyer%20copy%201.2.jpg" alt="" /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series -&nbsp;</strong><strong>Building Prolific Entrepreneurship Ecosystems in ASEAN</strong><strong>&nbsp;with&nbsp;</strong><strong>Insights from India&nbsp;</strong><strong>Episode #2:&nbsp;Technology and Distribution Innovations in Healthtech</strong></span></span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">The pandemic has put healthcare at the forefront of human existence as never seen before. Within the healthcare universe, healthcare technologies or &ldquo;Healthtech&rdquo; has emerged with rapid adoption of technology such as telemedicine and e-pharmacy that has catapulted the Indian and SEA healthtech sector to a path of high growth.</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">With this second episode of online roundtable by CIIE.CO and ERIA, we aim to bring spotlight to distribution innovation and development of healthtech. The discussion will capture relevant knowledge and experiences from the perspective of start-up business, impact investment as well as policy lenses to leverage technology for a better healthcare ecosystem, against the backdrop of Covid-19 in the region.</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Date and Time:</strong></span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Wednesday, 8 September 2021,&nbsp;2:30 - 4:00 pm, IST / 4:00 - 5:30 pm, WIB</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Location:</strong></span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></span></p><ul><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Speakers:</strong></span></p><ul><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Dr. Satya Prakash Dash; Core Volunteer at iSPIRT National Health Stack, India</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Von Leong, Co-founder &amp; General Partner, Purpose Venture Capital, Singapore</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Alfonsius Timboel, Chief Product Officer, HaloDoc, Indonesia</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Moderator:&nbsp;</span></p><ul><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Chintan Antani,&nbsp;AVP-Seed Investment &amp; Portfolio, CIIE.CO, India</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">AGENDA</span></p><table style="width: 993px;" border="1"><tr><td style="width: 229.831px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">TIME</span></td><td style="width: 748.268px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">AGENDA</span></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 229.831px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">2:30 &ndash;2:40 PM, IST</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">or</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">4:00 &ndash; 4:10 PM, WIB</span></td><td style="width: 748.268px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Start of Webinar | Welcome Remarks</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Giulia Ajmone Marsan</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Director, Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</span></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 229.831px;"><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">2:40 &ndash; 3:40 PM, IST</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">or</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">4.10 &ndash; 5:10 PM, WIB</span></p></td><td style="width: 748.268px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Panel Discussion</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Speakers:</span><br /><ul><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Dr. Satya Prakash Dash; Member-Board of Directors &amp; Member Investment Committee Board Member, Venture Center, Pune;&nbsp;Former Director, Global Innovations PATH;&nbsp;Former COO, ABLE</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Nita Tyagi, Platform Adoption Architect, Program Director - National Urban Stack Uttrakhand, India; Core Volunteer at iSPIRT National Health Stack, India</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Von Leong, Co-founder &amp; General Partner, Purpose Venture Capital, Singapore</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Alfonsius Timboel, Chief Product Officer, HaloDoc, Indonesia</span></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 229.831px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">3:40 &ndash; 3:55 PM, IST</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">or</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">5:10 &ndash; 5:25 PM, WIB</span></td><td style="width: 748.268px;"><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Q &amp; A</span></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 229.831px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">3:55 &ndash; 4:00 PM, IST</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">or</span><br /><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">5.25 &ndash; 5.30 PM, WIB</span></td><td style="width: 748.268px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Closing Remarks and End of Webinar</span></td></tr></table><p><strong>Background of the Study</strong></p><p>This study is conducted by CIIE.CO and ERIA. The purpose of the study is to open collaboration and peer learning between India and ASEAN and share knowledge and tools relevant to entrepreneurship ecosystems in the South Asian region. As part of this study four open virtual roundtables will be conducted with thought leaders and relevant industry experts from India and ASEAN. Each of the roundtables will be based on a theme which is relevant and important for the Indian and ASEAN entrepreneurship ecosystems, with the first roundtable focusing on incubators.</p><p><strong>Objectives of the Roundtable</strong></p><p>With this second in the series of roundtables, we aim to introduce the Indian and ASEAN healthtech innovation ecosystems to various stakeholders from the region, from the lens of startups as well as policy. We will be focusing on the telemedicine and e-pharmacy innovation ecosystem and would be looking forward to achieving the following objectives in our moderated discussion.</p><ul><li>Highlight and analyse the developments in the telemedicine and e-pharmacy innovation ecosystem</li><li>Trace the future trajectory of these innovations</li><li>Analyse the impact of Covid-19 on the adoption of disruptive technologies</li><li>Explore the need of healthcare data interoperability - privacy and security</li><li>Analyse the gaps in terms of policy and regulatory framework and come up with actionable policy recommendations/interventions</li></ul><p><strong>Outcome of the Roundtable</strong></p><p>Based on the roundtable discussions and secondary research, a policy brief will be published which can be used by policymakers, investors, incubators and other ecosystem stakeholders, to design and implement actionable policy interventions.</p><p><strong>1. Healthtech Ecosystem in India</strong></p><p>India&rsquo;s healthcare ecosystem is on the verge of a paradigm shift. After remaining resistant to digital reforms for the longest time, the sector is now open to innovation and digital technology-driven healthcare delivery that became a necessity owing to the pandemic. Within the healthcare universe, healthcare technologies, popularly known as &ldquo;Healthtech&rdquo; has been in the spotlight with rapid adoption of technology. Healthtech sectors include telemedicine (online doctor consultation, remote diagnosis &amp; more), e-pharmacy (online sale of medicines and pharmaceutical products), online fitness and wellness, healthcare IT &amp; analytics, home healthcare &amp; personal home management. Healthtech accounts for less than 1% of the overall healthcare industry in India, and was estimated at USD 1.9 billion (2020), implying a huge market opportunity. India has more than 5,000 healthtech startups and the healthtech market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 39% to touch USD 5.0 billion by 2023.<a href="#_ftn1" name="_ftnref1"><strong><sup>[1]</sup></strong></a></p><p>&nbsp;The pandemic underlined the weak healthcare infrastructure in the country, however, its disruptive nature also inspired promising innovations. There has been an increased adoption of teleconsultation, online diagnostics, e-pharmacy, remote diagnosis and monitoring etc., which has catapulted the healthtech sector to a path of high growth. For example, the government&rsquo;s eSanjeevani initiative (national telemedicine service), launched in November 2019, had facilitated 3 million consultations by March 2021<a href="#_ftn2" name="_ftnref2"><strong><sup>[2]</sup></strong></a>. The consumer adoption that healthtech has been able to achieve would have taken at least another 4-5 years in a non-Covid scenario. It is expected that, in the future, healthtech might operate on a hybrid model, with almost 15-20 percent of the Indian healthcare services expected to shift from physical to virtual service.<a href="#_ftn3" name="_ftnref3"><strong><sup>[3]</sup></strong></a>&nbsp; Given the sensitive nature of healthcare, there is a need for a robust policy and regulatory framework to back healthcare innovations. Thus, it is important to discuss how such a framework can encourage innovations within the ecosystem, without compromising patient safety &amp; security.</p><p><strong>1.1 Policy and Regulatory framework - Focus on Telemedicine and e-Pharmacy</strong></p><p>The&nbsp;<u>Drugs and Cosmetics Act (1940)</u>&nbsp;regulates the manufacture and sale of drugs in India, however it does not mention e-pharmacies. As this leads to uncertainty, the&nbsp;<u>draft e-pharmacy rules (2018)&nbsp;</u>was proposed by the government, however they have not been notified yet. On March 25, 2020 in response to the nation-wide lockdown, the&nbsp;<u>Telemedicine Guidelines (2020)</u>&nbsp;were notified. These guidelines laid down the norms regarding consultation by doctors via phone, video and chat applications. However, given that, the regulatory clarity around the e-healthcare industry does not extend to the e-pharmacy industry, and that online delivery of medicines cannot be separated from online consultations, a standardised regulatory regime needs to be set up to provide clarity to the stakeholders. The lack of proper rules has also prevented large investments into the e-pharmacy space. In the absence of clear regulations, e-pharmacy startups have started offering online doctor consultations and online diagnostic services besides operating as marketplaces and catering to patients as a platform for ordering medicines from the sellers that adhere to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act and Rules of India. Other regulations, like the Information Technology Act and the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, also apply. For instance, 1mg is a digital healthcare platform that acts as a one-stop shop for consumers providing both e-pharmacy and online consultations, along with online diagnostics and lab testing services.</p><p><strong>1.2 Management of Healthcare Data in Telemedicine &amp; E-Pharmacy</strong></p><p>Since e-pharmacy and telemedicine involves an online medium of exchange and storage of healthcare data, it is crucial to understand the policies and regulations that apply to such mediums. The&nbsp;<u>Information Technology (Reasonable Security Practices and Procedures and Sensitive Personal Data or Information) Rules 2011</u>&nbsp;regulates the exchange of sensitive personal data between patients and healthcare professionals. The&nbsp;<u>Digital Information Security in Healthcare Act (DISHA 2018 - Proposed)</u>&nbsp;provides stringent provisions for data safety and privacy. The&nbsp;<u>Personal Data Protection Bill (PDP 2019 - Proposed)</u>&nbsp;aims to protect the privacy of individuals and governs the relationship between individuals and entities processing their personal data. While DISHA takes a more rigorous view of individual&rsquo;s control, PDP has a more lenient approach, leading to different positions being enunciated by DISHA and the PDP Bill.</p><p><strong>1.3 Proposed Health Data Management Framework</strong></p><p>Apart from data protection, the need of the hour is interoperability of healthcare data. Healthcare data in India is fairly fragmented, given the interaction of citizens ranges across multiple healthcare providers viz. diagnostic centres, hospitals, medical practitioners and pharmacies. If this data can be made interoperable to be shared across providers, it will make things seamless and also save time and money. For example, a physician does not have to ask a patient to re-do a scan that was already done in the recent past.</p><p>The&nbsp;<u>Electronic Health Records Standards (2013/2016)</u>&nbsp;recommends the adoption of interoperable electronic health informatic standards in electronic health and medical records. The&nbsp;&nbsp;<u>Health Data Management (HDM) Policy (2020)</u>&nbsp;aims to digitize the entire healthcare ecosystem of India. HDM sets out the minimum standards for data privacy protection that should be followed across the board. The HDM stems from the National Health Policy of 2017 and the resultant National Digital Health Blueprint (NDHB), which was intended to create an enabling and interoperable digital framework to support universal health coverage while ensuring the security of sensitive personal medical data. However, experts have pointed out drawbacks, ranging from allowing Aadhaar (identity card) to be used for creation of health IDs to excessive collection of personal data and leaving scope for data re-identification. In a nutshell, data security and privacy remains an overriding concern in the field of telehealth.</p><ol start="2"><li><strong>Healthtech Ecosystem in ASEAN</strong></li></ol><p>For Southeast Asia (SEA) consumers in this mobile-first region, healthtech solutions are increasingly becoming a lifestyle staple. Digital tools are bringing healthcare solutions to consumers&rsquo; fingertips, giving them access to customised, patient-first healthcare experiences. Southeast Asia&rsquo;s high mobile penetration rates and number of mobile users has allowed the digitalization of healthcare through the proliferation of health-related mobile apps. Currently in eight ASEAN nations, over 55% of their population are active internet users and enjoy over 90% mobile network coverage of their populations.<a href="#_ftn4" name="_ftnref4"><strong><sup>[4]</sup></strong></a>&nbsp;This growing number of mobile users have fueled openness for healthtech innovation and opportunities in SEA. The region is enjoying strong growth in telehealth, digital therapeutics, diagnostics, remote patient monitoring and analytics.</p><p>However, demand for healthcare in the region has never been greater, especially with the current Covid-19 pandemic. As ASEAN demographic level will continue to rise faster (e.g.:&nbsp; Malaysia, Philippines and Indonesia population are expected to go up by 40 percent by 2050), the region is still facing the longstanding problems such as shortage of physicians/doctors, understaffed hospitals and unequal access and standards of healthcare across SEA.</p><p>The critical needs for a better healthcare response during the pandemic combined with the changing demographics of SEA means that an intervention is due for healthcare systems in ASEAN member states. The healthcare sector in the region needs to look for innovative solutions to figure out how to be more effective and efficient without spending excessively, and thus, need to leverage its technology for a better healthcare solution.</p><p><strong>2.1 Robust Actors Defining the Healthtech Ecosystem in ASEAN</strong></p><p>Various actors and players are beginning to take different approaches to define the Healthtech ecosystem in the region. Across SEA, nontraditional entrants such as industrial and retail conglomerates, banks, consumer-tech companies and telco-companies are now as important as the traditional healthcare incumbents such as insurers, providers and government agencies.<a href="#_ftn5" name="_ftnref5"><strong><sup>[5]</sup></strong></a>&nbsp;Furthermore, as collaboration and strategic partnerships are critical to scale up the business, many corporates and healthtech ventures are also increasingly entering into partnerships to scale digital health services. For instance, the region&rsquo;s leading app such as Halodoc, offers an integrated healthcare content, consultation, and medicine purchase to a collaboration for medicine delivery between regional ride-hailing tech companies such as Go-Jek. In 2019, the healthtech sector in SEA saw a record-breaking funding level (266 million USD) compared to 2018 (118 million USD) as deal volume rose at a CAGR of 63% &ndash; with Singapore and Indonesia continuing to account for the majority of the region&rsquo;s funding.<a href="#_ftn6" name="_ftnref6"><strong><sup>[6]</sup></strong></a></p><p>The growing number of actors, capital and consumers in SEA healthtech ecosystem has called for a need for a practical policy framework and healthcare governance to regulate the business models, manage the distribution innovation and assist the implementation of healtech services in the region.</p><p><strong>2.2 Policy Framework and Challenges Ahead</strong></p><p>Southeast Asian governments have recognized the need for healthcare reforms and have put forward policy plans to move in that direction. E-health and healthtech present huge opportunities for ASEAN governments to translate the various healthcare policies in the past decade into wider practice. The Masterplan on ASEAN Connectivity 2025 estimates that the potential of digital disruption in healthcare in the region can result in economic benefits of USD 20-53 billion by 2030.<a href="#_ftn7" name="_ftnref7"><strong><sup>[7]</sup></strong></a></p><p>Some ASEAN countries like Singapore, Philippines and Thailand have developed policies/framework that facilitate the use of technology in healthcare. In Singapore,&nbsp;<u>national telemedicine guidelines</u>&nbsp;have set clear principles around areas such as AI and data governance, medical devices, and telemedicine.&nbsp;<u>The Personal Data Protection Act</u>&nbsp;introduced in 2012 and advisory guidelines for healthcare were also issued by the Singaporean government to ensure data protection. With its&nbsp;<u>2014-2020 eHealth Strategic Framework Plan</u>, the Philippines envisioned that eHealth would enable widespread access to health care services and health information . Similarly, as part of Thailand 4.0, the Ministry of Public Health has developed a 2<u>017-2026 eHealth Strategy</u>&nbsp;to develop Thailand as a medical hub in ASEAN by 2025.</p><p>However, as it stands, all countries in ASEAN have multiple major IT investments, across sectors that are plagued by issues of fragmentation in investments, uncoordinated planning, and low uptake of technologies. Moreover, many of the governments are still facing problems in the regulatory implementation. For instance, in Indonesia, there is still no general law on data protection. In the Philippines, the major issues to implement eHealth Strategic Framework is the fragmented health system which lacks health information exchange allowing for the sharing of health data that would allow more efficient provision of private and public healthcare.</p><ol start="3"><li><strong>Conclusion</strong></li></ol><p>The Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the trajectory of the healthcare ecosystems across both India and the ASEAN region. Furthermore, in both ecosystems inventive technologies in the form of healthtech (with a special emphasis on e-pharmacy and telemedicine) have been paving the way forward, which has also led to collaborations between various stakeholders in the sector to fuel innovative disruptions. Recognizing the importance and need for healthtech, governments across both the ecosystems have created, or are in the process of creating policies and frameworks to regulate this space. However, each region has its own drawbacks in terms of regulation, implementation, and privacy. Therefore, it becomes critical to not only discuss the development &amp; future trajectory of this space, but also to analyse the gaps that currently exist and to consider the implications and solutions to such issues.</p><p><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1"></a></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><a class="bluebtn" title="Technology and Distribution Innovations in Healthtech" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/technology-and-distribution-innovations-in-healthtech-tickets-169039546835" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></span></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-09-08";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:34765:"ERIA- CIIE.CO Webinar Series on Technology and Distribution Innovations in Healthtech draft ERIA- CIIE.CO Webinar Series on Technology and Distribution Innovations in Healthtech draft ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series -&nbsp;Building Prolific Entrepreneurship Ecosystems in ASEAN&nbsp;with&nbsp;Insights from India&nbsp;Episode #2:&nbsp;Technology and Distribution Innovations in Healthtech
The pandemic has put healthcare at the forefront of human existence as never seen before. Within the healthcare universe, healthcare technologies or &ldquo;Healthtech&rdquo; has emerged with rapid adoption of technology such as telemedicine and e-pharmacy that has catapulted the Indian and SEA healthtech sector to a path of high growth.
With this second episode of online roundtable by CIIE.CO and ERIA, we aim to bring spotlight to distribution innovation and development of healthtech. The discussion will capture relevant knowledge and experiences from the perspective of start-up business, impact investment as well as policy lenses to leverage technology for a better healthcare ecosystem, against the backdrop of Covid-19 in the region.
Date and Time:
Wednesday, 8 September 2021,&nbsp;2:30 - 4:00 pm, IST / 4:00 - 5:30 pm, WIB
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
