Q &amp; A



3:55 &ndash; 4:00 PM, ISTor5.25 &ndash; 5.30 PM, WIB
Closing Remarks and End of Webinar



Background of the Study
This study is conducted by CIIE.CO and ERIA. The purpose of the study is to open collaboration and peer learning between India and ASEAN and share knowledge and tools relevant to entrepreneurship ecosystems in the South Asian region. As part of this study four open virtual roundtables will be conducted with thought leaders and relevant industry experts from India and ASEAN. Each of the roundtables will be based on a theme which is relevant and important for the Indian and ASEAN entrepreneurship ecosystems, with the first roundtable focusing on incubators.
Objectives of the Roundtable
With this second in the series of roundtables, we aim to introduce the Indian and ASEAN healthtech innovation ecosystems to various stakeholders from the region, from the lens of startups as well as policy. We will be focusing on the telemedicine and e-pharmacy innovation ecosystem and would be looking forward to achieving the following objectives in our moderated discussion.

Highlight and analyse the developments in the telemedicine and e-pharmacy innovation ecosystem
Trace the future trajectory of these innovations
Analyse the impact of Covid-19 on the adoption of disruptive technologies
Explore the need of healthcare data interoperability - privacy and security
Analyse the gaps in terms of policy and regulatory framework and come up with actionable policy recommendations/interventions

Outcome of the Roundtable
Based on the roundtable discussions and secondary research, a policy brief will be published which can be used by policymakers, investors, incubators and other ecosystem stakeholders, to design and implement actionable policy interventions.
1. Healthtech Ecosystem in India
India&rsquo;s healthcare ecosystem is on the verge of a paradigm shift. After remaining resistant to digital reforms for the longest time, the sector is now open to innovation and digital technology-driven healthcare delivery that became a necessity owing to the pandemic. Within the healthcare universe, healthcare technologies, popularly known as &ldquo;Healthtech&rdquo; has been in the spotlight with rapid adoption of technology. Healthtech sectors include telemedicine (online doctor consultation, remote diagnosis &amp; more), e-pharmacy (online sale of medicines and pharmaceutical products), online fitness and wellness, healthcare IT &amp; analytics, home healthcare &amp; personal home management. Healthtech accounts for less than 1% of the overall healthcare industry in India, and was estimated at USD 1.9 billion (2020), implying a huge market opportunity. India has more than 5,000 healthtech startups and the healthtech market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 39% to touch USD 5.0 billion by 2023.[1]
&nbsp;The pandemic underlined the weak healthcare infrastructure in the country, however, its disruptive nature also inspired promising innovations. There has been an increased adoption of teleconsultation, online diagnostics, e-pharmacy, remote diagnosis and monitoring etc., which has catapulted the healthtech sector to a path of high growth. For example, the government&rsquo;s eSanjeevani initiative (national telemedicine service), launched in November 2019, had facilitated 3 million consultations by March 2021[2]. The consumer adoption that healthtech has been able to achieve would have taken at least another 4-5 years in a non-Covid scenario. It is expected that, in the future, healthtech might operate on a hybrid model, with almost 15-20 percent of the Indian healthcare services expected to shift from physical to virtual service.[3]&nbsp; Given the sensitive nature of healthcare, there is a need for a robust policy and regulatory framework to back healthcare innovations. Thus, it is important to discuss how such a framework can encourage innovations within the ecosystem, without compromising patient safety &amp; security.
1.1 Policy and Regulatory framework - Focus on Telemedicine and e-Pharmacy
The&nbsp;Drugs and Cosmetics Act (1940)&nbsp;regulates the manufacture and sale of drugs in India, however it does not mention e-pharmacies. As this leads to uncertainty, the&nbsp;draft e-pharmacy rules (2018)&nbsp;was proposed by the government, however they have not been notified yet. On March 25, 2020 in response to the nation-wide lockdown, the&nbsp;Telemedicine Guidelines (2020)&nbsp;were notified. These guidelines laid down the norms regarding consultation by doctors via phone, video and chat applications. However, given that, the regulatory clarity around the e-healthcare industry does not extend to the e-pharmacy industry, and that online delivery of medicines cannot be separated from online consultations, a standardised regulatory regime needs to be set up to provide clarity to the stakeholders. The lack of proper rules has also prevented large investments into the e-pharmacy space. In the absence of clear regulations, e-pharmacy startups have started offering online doctor consultations and online diagnostic services besides operating as marketplaces and catering to patients as a platform for ordering medicines from the sellers that adhere to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act and Rules of India. Other regulations, like the Information Technology Act and the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, also apply. For instance, 1mg is a digital healthcare platform that acts as a one-stop shop for consumers providing both e-pharmacy and online consultations, along with online diagnostics and lab testing services.
1.2 Management of Healthcare Data in Telemedicine &amp; E-Pharmacy
Since e-pharmacy and telemedicine involves an online medium of exchange and storage of healthcare data, it is crucial to understand the policies and regulations that apply to such mediums. The&nbsp;Information Technology (Reasonable Security Practices and Procedures and Sensitive Personal Data or Information) Rules 2011&nbsp;regulates the exchange of sensitive personal data between patients and healthcare professionals. The&nbsp;Digital Information Security in Healthcare Act (DISHA 2018 - Proposed)&nbsp;provides stringent provisions for data safety and privacy. The&nbsp;Personal Data Protection Bill (PDP 2019 - Proposed)&nbsp;aims to protect the privacy of individuals and governs the relationship between individuals and entities processing their personal data. While DISHA takes a more rigorous view of individual&rsquo;s control, PDP has a more lenient approach, leading to different positions being enunciated by DISHA and the PDP Bill.
1.3 Proposed Health Data Management Framework
Apart from data protection, the need of the hour is interoperability of healthcare data. Healthcare data in India is fairly fragmented, given the interaction of citizens ranges across multiple healthcare providers viz. diagnostic centres, hospitals, medical practitioners and pharmacies. If this data can be made interoperable to be shared across providers, it will make things seamless and also save time and money. For example, a physician does not have to ask a patient to re-do a scan that was already done in the recent past.
The&nbsp;Electronic Health Records Standards (2013/2016)&nbsp;recommends the adoption of interoperable electronic health informatic standards in electronic health and medical records. The&nbsp;&nbsp;Health Data Management (HDM) Policy (2020)&nbsp;aims to digitize the entire healthcare ecosystem of India. HDM sets out the minimum standards for data privacy protection that should be followed across the board. The HDM stems from the National Health Policy of 2017 and the resultant National Digital Health Blueprint (NDHB), which was intended to create an enabling and interoperable digital framework to support universal health coverage while ensuring the security of sensitive personal medical data. However, experts have pointed out drawbacks, ranging from allowing Aadhaar (identity card) to be used for creation of health IDs to excessive collection of personal data and leaving scope for data re-identification. In a nutshell, data security and privacy remains an overriding concern in the field of telehealth.

Healthtech Ecosystem in ASEAN

For Southeast Asia (SEA) consumers in this mobile-first region, healthtech solutions are increasingly becoming a lifestyle staple. Digital tools are bringing healthcare solutions to consumers&rsquo; fingertips, giving them access to customised, patient-first healthcare experiences. Southeast Asia&rsquo;s high mobile penetration rates and number of mobile users has allowed the digitalization of healthcare through the proliferation of health-related mobile apps. Currently in eight ASEAN nations, over 55% of their population are active internet users and enjoy over 90% mobile network coverage of their populations.[4]&nbsp;This growing number of mobile users have fueled openness for healthtech innovation and opportunities in SEA. The region is enjoying strong growth in telehealth, digital therapeutics, diagnostics, remote patient monitoring and analytics.
However, demand for healthcare in the region has never been greater, especially with the current Covid-19 pandemic. As ASEAN demographic level will continue to rise faster (e.g.:&nbsp; Malaysia, Philippines and Indonesia population are expected to go up by 40 percent by 2050), the region is still facing the longstanding problems such as shortage of physicians/doctors, understaffed hospitals and unequal access and standards of healthcare across SEA.
The critical needs for a better healthcare response during the pandemic combined with the changing demographics of SEA means that an intervention is due for healthcare systems in ASEAN member states. The healthcare sector in the region needs to look for innovative solutions to figure out how to be more effective and efficient without spending excessively, and thus, need to leverage its technology for a better healthcare solution.
2.1 Robust Actors Defining the Healthtech Ecosystem in ASEAN
Various actors and players are beginning to take different approaches to define the Healthtech ecosystem in the region. Across SEA, nontraditional entrants such as industrial and retail conglomerates, banks, consumer-tech companies and telco-companies are now as important as the traditional healthcare incumbents such as insurers, providers and government agencies.[5]&nbsp;Furthermore, as collaboration and strategic partnerships are critical to scale up the business, many corporates and healthtech ventures are also increasingly entering into partnerships to scale digital health services. For instance, the region&rsquo;s leading app such as Halodoc, offers an integrated healthcare content, consultation, and medicine purchase to a collaboration for medicine delivery between regional ride-hailing tech companies such as Go-Jek. In 2019, the healthtech sector in SEA saw a record-breaking funding level (266 million USD) compared to 2018 (118 million USD) as deal volume rose at a CAGR of 63% &ndash; with Singapore and Indonesia continuing to account for the majority of the region&rsquo;s funding.[6]
The growing number of actors, capital and consumers in SEA healthtech ecosystem has called for a need for a practical policy framework and healthcare governance to regulate the business models, manage the distribution innovation and assist the implementation of healtech services in the region.
2.2 Policy Framework and Challenges Ahead
Southeast Asian governments have recognized the need for healthcare reforms and have put forward policy plans to move in that direction. E-health and healthtech present huge opportunities for ASEAN governments to translate the various healthcare policies in the past decade into wider practice. The Masterplan on ASEAN Connectivity 2025 estimates that the potential of digital disruption in healthcare in the region can result in economic benefits of USD 20-53 billion by 2030.[7]
Some ASEAN countries like Singapore, Philippines and Thailand have developed policies/framework that facilitate the use of technology in healthcare. In Singapore,&nbsp;national telemedicine guidelines&nbsp;have set clear principles around areas such as AI and data governance, medical devices, and telemedicine.&nbsp;The Personal Data Protection Act&nbsp;introduced in 2012 and advisory guidelines for healthcare were also issued by the Singaporean government to ensure data protection. With its&nbsp;2014-2020 eHealth Strategic Framework Plan, the Philippines envisioned that eHealth would enable widespread access to health care services and health information . Similarly, as part of Thailand 4.0, the Ministry of Public Health has developed a 2017-2026 eHealth Strategy&nbsp;to develop Thailand as a medical hub in ASEAN by 2025.
However, as it stands, all countries in ASEAN have multiple major IT investments, across sectors that are plagued by issues of fragmentation in investments, uncoordinated planning, and low uptake of technologies. Moreover, many of the governments are still facing problems in the regulatory implementation. For instance, in Indonesia, there is still no general law on data protection. In the Philippines, the major issues to implement eHealth Strategic Framework is the fragmented health system which lacks health information exchange allowing for the sharing of health data that would allow more efficient provision of private and public healthcare.

Conclusion

The Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the trajectory of the healthcare ecosystems across both India and the ASEAN region. Furthermore, in both ecosystems inventive technologies in the form of healthtech (with a special emphasis on e-pharmacy and telemedicine) have been paving the way forward, which has also led to collaborations between various stakeholders in the sector to fuel innovative disruptions. Recognizing the importance and need for healthtech, governments across both the ecosystems have created, or are in the process of creating policies and frameworks to regulate this space. However, each region has its own drawbacks in terms of regulation, implementation, and privacy. Therefore, it becomes critical to not only discuss the development &amp; future trajectory of this space, but also to analyse the gaps that currently exist and to consider the implications and solutions to such issues.

15:49:36";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:189;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6412";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:84:"eria--ciieco-webinar-series-on-technology-and-distribution-innovations-in-healthtech";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:85:"ERIA- ASEAN</strong><strong>&nbsp;with&nbsp;</strong><strong>Insights from India&nbsp;</strong><strong>Episode #2:&nbsp;Technology and Distribution Innovations in Healthtech</strong></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">The pandemic has put healthcare at the forefront of human existence as never seen before. The discussion will capture relevant knowledge and experiences from the perspective of start-up business, impact investment as well as policy lenses to leverage technology for a better healthcare ecosystem, against the backdrop of Covid-19 in the region.</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Date and Time:</strong></span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Wednesday, 8 September 2021,&nbsp;2:30 - 4:00 pm, IST / 4:00 - 5:30 pm, WIB</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Location:</strong></span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></span></p><ul><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Speakers:</strong></span></p><ul><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Dr. Satya Prakash Dash;&nbsp;&nbsp;Founding &amp; Former Head Strategy, BIRAC India, Board Member Venture Center, India</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Nita Tyagi, Platform Adoption Architect, Program Director - National Urban Stack Uttarakhand, India; Portfolio, CIIE.CO, India</span></li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/uploads/media/Agenda_ERIA%20and%20CIIE%232_HealthTechh.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">AGENDA</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="CONCEPT NOTE" href="/uploads/media/Events/2021_Technology-and-Distribution-Innovations-in-Healthtech.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CONCEPT NOTE</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/technology-and-distribution-innovations-in-healthtech-tickets-169039546835" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-09-08";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4121:"ERIA- CIIE.CO Webinar Series on Technology and Distribution Innovations in Healthtech ERIA- CIIE.CO Webinar Series on Technology and Distribution Innovations in Healthtech ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series -&nbsp;Building Prolific Entrepreneurship Ecosystems in ASEAN&nbsp;with&nbsp;Insights from India&nbsp;Episode #2:&nbsp;Technology and Distribution Innovations in Healthtech
The pandemic has put healthcare at the forefront of human existence as never seen before. Within the healthcare universe, healthcare technologies or &ldquo;Healthtech&rdquo; has emerged with rapid adoption of technology such as telemedicine and e-pharmacy that has catapulted the Indian and SEA healthtech sector to a path of high growth.
With this second episode of online roundtable by CIIE.CO and ERIA, we aim to bring spotlight to distribution innovation and development of healthtech. The discussion will capture relevant knowledge and experiences from the perspective of start-up business, impact investment as well as policy lenses to leverage technology for a better healthcare ecosystem, against the backdrop of Covid-19 in the region.
Date and Time:
Wednesday, 8 September 2021,&nbsp;2:30 - 4:00 pm, IST / 4:00 - 5:30 pm, WIB
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Welcome Remark:

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA

Speakers:

Dr. Satya Prakash Dash;&nbsp;&nbsp;Founding &amp; Former Head Strategy, BIRAC India, Board Member Venture Center, India
Nita Tyagi, Platform Adoption Architect, Program Director - National Urban Stack Uttarakhand, India; Core Volunteer at iSPIRT National Health Stack, India
Von Leong, Co-founder &amp; General Partner, Purpose Venture Capital, Singapore
Alfonsius Timboel, Chief Product Officer, HaloDoc, Indonesia

Moderator:&nbsp;

Chintan Antani,&nbsp;AVP-Seed Investments &amp; Portfolio, CIIE.CO, India

AGENDA
CONCEPT NOTE

:emiT dna etaD
.noiger eht ni 91-divoC fo pordkcab eht tsniaga ,metsysoce erachtlaeh retteb a rof ygolonhcet egarevel ot sesnel ycilop sa llew sa tnemtsevni tcapmi ,ssenisub pu-trats fo evitcepsrep eht morf secneirepxe dna egdelwonk tnaveler erutpac lliw noissucsid ehT .hcethtlaeh fo tnempoleved dna noitavonni noitubirtsid ot thgiltops gnirb ot mia ew ,AIRE dna OC.EIIC yb elbatdnuor enilno fo edosipe dnoces siht htiW
.htworg hgih fo htap a ot rotces hcethtlaeh AES dna naidnI eht detlupatac sah taht ycamrahp-e dna enicidemelet sa hcus ygolonhcet fo noitpoda dipar htiw degreme sah ;ouqdr&hcethtlaeH;ouqdl& ro seigolonhcet erachtlaeh ,esrevinu erachtlaeh eht nihtiW .erofeb nees reven sa ecnetsixe namuh fo tnorferof eht ta erachtlaeh tup sah cimednap ehT
hcethtlaeH ni snoitavonnI noitubirtsiD dna ygolonhceT;psbn&:2# edosipE;psbn&aidnI morf sthgisnI;psbn&htiw;psbn&NAESA ni smetsysocE pihsruenerpertnE cifilorP gnidliuB;psbn&- seireS ranibeW OC.EIIC-AIRE hcethtlaeH ni snoitavonnI noitubirtsiD dna ygolonhceT no seireS ranibeW OC.EIIC -AIRE hcethtlaeH ni snoitavonnI noitubirtsiD dna ygolonhceT no seireS ranibeW OC.EIIC -AIRE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-08-31 11:37:50";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-09-06 14:20:16";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"14";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:190;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6398";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:81:"the-4th-east-asia-energy-forum-a-low-carbon-energy-transition-in-the-asean-region";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:82:"The 4th East Asia Energy Forum: A Low-Carbon Energy Transition in the ASEAN Region";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-09-13";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:14343:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/POSTER.jpg" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Availability, accessibility, and affordability of energy supply is the most fundamental requirement for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member countries in their energy policy planning and implementation. The East Asia Summit (EAS) Energy Outlook, updated by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) in 2019-20, suggested that ASEAN would still depend on fossil fuels by 2050 and the share of fossil fuels per total primary energy supply (TPES) in 2050 would be 87% in the Business-as-Usual (BAU) scenario and 82% under the Alternative Policy Scenario (APS) including aggressive energy efficiency and conservation (EEC) and variable renewable energy (vRE) targets. CO2 emissions by ASEAN countries from 2017 to 2050 are expected to increase by 3.2 times in the BAU scenario and by 2.3 times under the APS.</p><p>On the other hand, the Paris Agreement sets the long-term temperature goal to hold the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2&deg;C above pre-industrial levels and pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5&deg;C above pre-industrial levels. In order to achieve the long-term temperature goal, Parties to the Paris Agreement aim to reach global peaking of greenhouse gas emissions as soon as possible and to undertake rapid reductions thereafter so as to achieve a balance between anthropogenic emissions by sources and removals by sinks of GHGs (carbon neutrality) in the second half of this century. With this in mind, a growing number of countries have announced carbon neutral goals by 2050 for contributing to the above objective of the Paris Agreement. The IEA released &lsquo;<a title="Net Zero by 2050: A Roadmap for the Global Energy Sector" href="https://www.iea.org/reports/net-zero-by-2050" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Net Zero by 2050: A Roadmap for the Global Energy Sector</a>&rsquo;depicting a pathway towards global net-zero emission in the world by 2050 including the ASEAN region. However, carbon neutrality cannot be achieved by simply announcing it. One size does not fit all. As the Parties to the Paris Agreement, ASEAN countries need to pursue low carbon energy transition pathways aiming at carbon neutrality as their ultimate objective taking into account each country&rsquo;s specific national circumstances and ensuring other policy objectives, namely, availability, accessibility and affordability. With the participation of policymakers, energy analysts and private sectors in the EAS region, the Fourth East Asia Energy Forum will discuss feasible and ASEAN specific pathways towards of carbon neutrality as their ultimate objective. &nbsp;</p><p>The Fourth East Asia Energy Forum will consist of the following three parts: 1. Gas and vRE as low carbon transition energy towards carbon neutrality, 2. Hydrogen and Ammonia as energy technologies for ultimate carbon neutrality, and 3. Carbon Neutral Pathway for ASEAN. Carbon Capture Utilization and Storage (CCUS) is also one of the indispensable zero-carbon technologies. Since it was already taken up at the Third East Asia Energy Forum held in November 2020 and the First Asia CCUS Network Forum in June 2021, it will be discussed in part 2 together with hydrogen and ammonia.</p><p>In panel session 1, the role of natural gas and VRE such as solar PV will be discussed in the transitional phase towards carbon neutrality until when hydrogen, ammonia and CCUS technologies will commercially be available after 2040. In panel session 2, the role of hydrogen and ammonia and their supply-demand potential in terms of production storage transport and consumption will be discussed expecting their commercial availability after 2040. In panel session 3, experts and policymakers will discuss how to achieve net zero-emission in ASEAN beyond 2050 utilizing hydrogen, ammonia and CCUS via transitional phase utilizing natural gas and vRE.</p><p>The Fourth East Asia Energy Forum, &lsquo;A Low-Carbon Energy Transition in the ASEAN Region&rsquo;, co-hosted by ERIA and Ministry of Energy, Brunei Darussalam, will be a virtual forum due to the COVID-19. It will discuss the current status and holistic low carbon energy transition towards ultimate objective of carbon neutrality in the EAS region with particular focus on the ASEAN region</p><p>The Forum will be privileged to have an opening address by H.E. Dato Seri Setia Dr Awang Haji Mat Suny bin Haji Md Hussein, Minister of Energy, Brunei Darussalam, and H.E. Dato Lim Jock Hoi, Secretary-General of ASEAN. ERIA also aims to have keynote speeches by ministers from ASEAN 8 countries, Japan and United States.</p><h1>Relive the Webinar</h1><p>MC: Ms Lydia Ruddy, Director of Communications, ERIA</p><h2>Opening Remarks and Keynote Speeches</h2><p><strong><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/sIiUKfkSa-g" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>Welcome and Opening Address</strong></p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">H.E. Dato Seri Setia Dr Awang Haji Mat Suny bin Haji Md Hussein, Minister of Energy, Brunei Darussalam (Video)</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">H.E. Dato Lim Jock Hoi, Secretary-General of ASEAN (Videoï¼‰&nbsp;</p></li></ul><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>Keynote Speeches</strong></p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">H.E. Mr Suy Sem, Minister of Mines and Energy, Cambodia (Video)</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">H.E. Mr Arifin Tasrif, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resource, Indonesia (Video)</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">H.E. Kiyoshi Ejima, State Minister of Economic, Trade and Industry, Japan (Video)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">H.E. Posadas, Undersecretary of Department of Energy, Philippines (Video)</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">Dr Jennifer Wilcox, Acting Assistant Secretary of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, Department of Energy, United States (Video)</p></li></ul><h2>Scene Setting Presentation</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/BX8-ib6LMuk" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia</p><p class="preFlex flexIn pdf"><a title="Click here to download presentation" href="/uploads/media/presentations/2021_September_ERIA_4th-East-Asia-Energy-Forum_Jun-Arima_Contribution-of-a-Low-Carbon-Energy-Transition-to-Carbon-Neutrality-in-the-ASEAN-Region.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">&lsquo;Contribution of a Low Carbon Energy Transition to Carbon Neutrality in the&nbsp; ASEAN Region&rsquo;&nbsp;</a></p><h2 class="preFlex flexIn">Panel Session 1</h2><p class="preFlex flexIn"><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/owUtO86nknU" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>Panel Session 1: Natural Gas and vRE as Transition Energy </strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Moderator: Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Victor Jona, Undersecretary of State, Ministry of Mines and Energy, Cambodiaã€€</p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">Dr Norasikin Ahmad Ludin, Assistant Professor, Solar Energy Research Institute (SERI), Malaysia National University</p><p class="preFlex flexIn pdf"><a title="Click here to download" Technologies</strong></p><p class="preFlex flexIn">-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Moderator: Mr Shigeru Kimura, Special Adviser on Energy Affairs, ERIA</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">-&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Panel Discussion</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="preFlex flexIn">Ms Ayaka Jones, International Technical Advisor, Strategic Engagement, Office of Carbon Management, Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, U.S. Department of Energy</p><p class="pdf"><a title="Click here to download presentation" href="/uploads/media/presentations/2021_September_ERIA_4th-East-Asia-Energy-Forum_Ayaka-Jones_USDOE_%20Carbon-Capture-Utilization-and-Storage-CCUS-US-Perspectives.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener Neutrality Policy for Thailand</a></p></li></ul><h2 class="preFlex flexIn">Closing Remarks</h2><p class="preFlex flexIn"><strong><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Miq_9pHL3KQ" width="560" ERIA</p><p class="preFlex flexIn">&nbsp;</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:22:"East Asia Energy Forum";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:22:"East Asia Energy Forum";s:9:"organizer";s:4:"ERIA";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-09-13";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-09-13";s:8:"keywords";s:17509:"The 4th East Asia Energy Forum: A Low-Carbon Energy Transition in the ASEAN Region The 4th East Asia Energy Forum: A Low-Carbon Energy Transition in the ASEAN Region Availability, accessibility, and affordability of energy supply is the most fundamental requirement for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member countries in their energy policy planning and implementation. The East Asia Summit (EAS) Energy Outlook, updated by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) in 2019-20, suggested that ASEAN would still depend on fossil fuels by 2050 and the share of fossil fuels per total primary energy supply (TPES) in 2050 would be 87% in the Business-as-Usual (BAU) scenario and 82% under the Alternative Policy Scenario (APS) including aggressive energy efficiency and conservation (EEC) and variable renewable energy (vRE) targets. CO2 emissions by ASEAN countries from 2017 to 2050 are expected to increase by 3.2 times in the BAU scenario and by 2.3 times under the APS.
On the other hand, the Paris Agreement sets the long-term temperature goal to hold the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2&deg;C above pre-industrial levels and pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5&deg;C above pre-industrial levels. In order to achieve the long-term temperature goal, Parties to the Paris Agreement aim to reach global peaking of greenhouse gas emissions as soon as possible and to undertake rapid reductions thereafter so as to achieve a balance between anthropogenic emissions by sources and removals by sinks of GHGs (carbon neutrality) in the second half of this century. With this in mind, a growing number of countries have announced carbon neutral goals by 2050 for contributing to the above objective of the Paris Agreement. The IEA released &lsquo;Net Zero by 2050: A Roadmap for the Global Energy Sector&rsquo;depicting a pathway towards global net-zero emission in the world by 2050 including the ASEAN region. However, carbon neutrality cannot be achieved by simply announcing it. One size does not fit all. As the Parties to the Paris Agreement, ASEAN countries need to pursue low carbon energy transition pathways aiming at carbon neutrality as their ultimate objective taking into account each country&rsquo;s specific national circumstances and ensuring other policy objectives, namely, availability, accessibility and affordability. With the participation of policymakers, energy analysts and private sectors in the EAS region, the Fourth East Asia Energy Forum will discuss feasible and ASEAN specific pathways towards of carbon neutrality as their ultimate objective. &nbsp;
The Fourth East Asia Energy Forum will consist of the following three parts: 1. Gas and vRE as low carbon transition energy towards carbon neutrality, 2. Hydrogen and Ammonia as energy technologies for ultimate carbon neutrality, and 3. Carbon Neutral Pathway for ASEAN. Carbon Capture Utilization and Storage (CCUS) is also one of the indispensable zero-carbon technologies. Since it was already taken up at the Third East Asia Energy Forum held in November 2020 and the First Asia CCUS Network Forum in June 2021, it will be discussed in part 2 together with hydrogen and ammonia.
In panel session 1, the role of natural gas and VRE such as solar PV will be discussed in the transitional phase towards carbon neutrality until when hydrogen, ammonia and CCUS technologies will commercially be available after 2040. In panel session 2, the role of hydrogen and ammonia and their supply-demand potential in terms of production storage transport and consumption will be discussed expecting their commercial availability after 2040. In panel session 3, experts and policymakers will discuss how to achieve net zero-emission in ASEAN beyond 2050 utilizing hydrogen, ammonia and CCUS via transitional phase utilizing natural gas and vRE.
The Fourth East Asia Energy Forum, &lsquo;A Low-Carbon Energy Transition in the ASEAN Region&rsquo;, co-hosted by ERIA and Ministry of Energy, Brunei Darussalam, will be a virtual forum due to the COVID-19. It will discuss the current status and holistic low carbon energy transition towards ultimate objective of carbon neutrality in the EAS region with particular focus on the ASEAN region
The Forum will be privileged to have an opening address by H.E. Dato Seri Setia Dr Awang Haji Mat Suny bin Haji Md Hussein, Minister of Energy, Brunei Darussalam, and H.E. Dato Lim Jock Hoi, Secretary-General of ASEAN. ERIA also aims to have keynote speeches by ministers from ASEAN 8 countries, Japan and United States.
Relive the Webinar
MC: Ms Lydia Ruddy, Director of Communications, ERIA

&#039;Entrepreneurship, Start-Ups and Innovation (E-S-I) in ASEAN and East Asia for The Post-Pandemic Recovery&#039;</p><p data-key="41"><span data-key="42">Entrepreneurship has increasingly been unbounded by distance, geography and time zones. Let their perspectives challenge your paradigm and status quo!</span></p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Tuesday, 31 August 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li>Laurent Tam Nguyen,&nbsp;Co-Founder and General Manager Digital Mekong, Vietnam</li><li>Haewon Rah,&nbsp;Engagement Manager Techstars, Korea</li><li>Jirut Wattoom,&nbsp;Technology Strategy Manager, Chemicals Business, SCG Partner SPRINT Accelerator, Thailand</li><li>Wisnu Nugrahadi,&nbsp;CEO and Co-Founder Sampingan, Indonesia</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/uploads/media/ESI-7%20Agenda%20final.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/borderless-entrepreneurship-is-that-the-future-tickets-167694888927" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-08-31";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-08-31";s:8:"keywords";s:3091:"E-S-I Episode 7 Borderless Entrepreneurship â€“ Is that the Future? E-S-I Episode 7 Borderless Entrepreneurship â€“ Is that the Future? ERIA Webinar Series #7 - 'Entrepreneurship, Start-Ups and Innovation (E-S-I) in ASEAN and East Asia for The Post-Pandemic Recovery'
Entrepreneurship has increasingly been unbounded by distance, geography and time zones. Digital transformation and global connectivity have enabled entrepreneurs to be as borderless as their ideas can take them. Yet, the current pandemic has thrown to light both the pros and cons of such ecosystems. Borderless entrepreneurship &ndash; is that truly the future and way forward? 
Join us as we converse with speakers from 4 countries of diverse backgrounds. Let their perspectives challenge your paradigm and status quo!
Date and Time:
Tuesday, 31 August 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Welcome Remark:

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA

Speakers:

Laurent Tam Nguyen,&nbsp;Co-Founder and General Manager Digital Mekong, Vietnam
Haewon Rah,&nbsp;Engagement Manager Techstars, Korea
Jirut Wattoom,&nbsp;Technology Strategy Manager, Chemicals Business, SCG Partner SPRINT Accelerator, Thailand
Wisnu Nugrahadi,&nbsp;CEO and Co-Founder Sampingan, Indonesia

PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;

PDR";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-08-13";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:0:"";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual (NEGATIVE-LIST APPROACH), Vientiane, Lao PDR        Virtual Room Ms Lina Maulidina  lina.maulidina@eria.org   2021-08-13 2021-08-13 2021-08-13 13 August 2021 1202 tsuguA 31 31-80-1202 31-80-1202 31-80-1202   gro.aire@anidiluam.anil  anidiluaM aniL sM mooR lautriV        RDP oaL ,enaitneiV ,)HCAORPPA TSIL-EVITAGEN( TNEMEERGA SECIVRES NI EDART NO POHSKROW S'RDP OAL :EMMARGORP NOITAREPOOC NAPAJ-SCC RDP oaL ,enaitneiV ,)HCAORPPA TSIL-EVITAGEN( TNEMEERGA SECIVRES NI EDART NO POHSKROW S'RDP OAL :EMMARGORP NOITAREPOOC NAPAJ-SCC";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-08-09 13:38:52";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-08-09 13:39:11";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"14";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:195;O:8:"stdClass":46:{s:9:"short_des";N;s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6360";s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:58:"the-2nd-asia-ccus-network-acn-knowledge-sharing-conference";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:60:"The 2nd Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-07-28";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:7247:"<p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">The Asia CCUS Network has been successfully launched on 22-23 June 2021 with initially 13 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions that share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region.</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">The Network members have expressed their intention to participate to share the vision of the Asia CCUS Network that aims to contribute to the decarbonisation of emissions in Asia through collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS.</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">The mission of this network is to facilitate deployment of CCUS through:</span></p><ol style="list-style-type: lower-roman;"><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">promoting knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings;</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS.</span></li></ol><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through the collaboration of research and innovation.</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">At the 1st Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference held on 26&nbsp;July, the International Energy Agency (IEA) introduced the recent IEA&rsquo;s published report on &#039;CCUS: The Opportunity in Southeast Asia&#039;, which gave a whole emphasis and focus on ASEAN region. Stakeholders in Asia have to gain more awareness and understanding of the future opportunity for clean technologies such as CCUS for carbon abatement as part of the pathway to carbon neutrality.</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">At the 2nd Asia CCUS Network (CAN) Knowledge Sharing Conference, the Asia CCUS Network is very pleased to invite experts from the Department of Energy, United States of America (USDOE) to share their insights and experiences about CCUS development and policy to support the deployment of CCUS technology. &nbsp;</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">The ACN will be an active forum to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS technologies, policy development to support the development and deployment of CCUS in Asia. Thus, this conference hosted in collaboration with IEA will help to bring in update knowledge, opportunity for investment in CCUS in Asia.</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong><em>&nbsp;</em></strong></span></p><h2><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Agenda</span></h2><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong><em>Wednesday, 28 July 2021 :&nbsp; Experience from the United States Department of Energy&nbsp; in CCUS Development and Deployment</em></strong></span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong><em>(Jakarta Standard Time, UTC+7)</em></strong></span></p><table style="width: 473px;"><tr><td style="width: 249.763px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">8:00 &ndash; 8:05 AM</span></td><td style="width: 229.237px;"><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Opening </strong>Remarks</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Taizo Hara, Director General of Research and Policy Design Administration of ERIA (5 minutes)</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Jarad Daniels, Director, Strategic Planning, Analysis and Engagement, Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management USDOE</span></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 249.763px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">8:05 &ndash; 8:50<strong>&nbsp;</strong>AM</span></td><td style="width: 229.237px;"><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Presentation by USDOE (MC and moderator: Han Phoumin)</span></p><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Jarad Daniels, Director, Strategic Planning, Analysis and Engagement, Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management USDOE:</span></p><ul><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">S. policies that support CCUS development</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Key federal environmental regulations that affect CCUS projects</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Federal (DOE&rsquo;s) CCUS R&amp;D programs</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">CCUS projects in the United States</span></li><li><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">International engagement</span></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 249.763px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">8:50 &ndash; 9:05 AM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></td><td style="width: 229.237px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Comments</strong> by Jesus Tamang, Director Energy Policy and Planning Bureau, DOE, Philippines.</span></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 249.763px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">9:05 &ndash; 9:25 AM</span></td><td style="width: 229.237px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Open discussion Session to the Presentations</strong></span></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 249.763px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">9:25 &ndash; 9:30 AM</span></td><td style="width: 229.237px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Closing Remarks </strong>by Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA</span></td></tr></table><h2>Relive the Webinar</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/N5gj_TZYHP8" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><h2>Mr Jarad Daniels&#039; Presentation</h2><p><iframe style="border: 1px solid #CCC; border-width: 1px; margin-bottom: 5px; max-width: 100%;" src="//www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/key/KOUQ9V5eB8JosK" width="595" height="485" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" data-mce-fragment="1"> </iframe></p><div style="margin-bottom: 5px;"><strong> <a title="Development of Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) in the United States" href="//www.slideshare.net/ERIAOrg/development-of-carbon-capture-utilization-and-storage-ccus-in-the-united-states" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Development of Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) in the United States</a> </strong> from <strong><a href="https://www.slideshare.net/ERIAOrg" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia</a></strong></div>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:17:"Asia CCUS Network";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-07-28";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-07-28";s:8:"keywords";s:8027:"The 2nd Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference The 2nd Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference The Asia CCUS Network has been successfully launched on 22-23 June 2021 with initially 13 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions that share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region.
The Network members have expressed their intention to participate to share the vision of the Asia CCUS Network that aims to contribute to the decarbonisation of emissions in Asia through collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS.
The mission of this network is to facilitate deployment of CCUS through:

promoting knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings;
conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and
holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS.

The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through the collaboration of research and innovation.
At the 1st Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference held on 26&nbsp;July, the International Energy Agency (IEA) introduced the recent IEA&rsquo;s published report on 'CCUS: The Opportunity in Southeast Asia', which gave a whole emphasis and focus on ASEAN region. Stakeholders in Asia have to gain more awareness and understanding of the future opportunity for clean technologies such as CCUS for carbon abatement as part of the pathway to carbon neutrality.
At the 2nd Asia CCUS Network (CAN) Knowledge Sharing Conference, the Asia CCUS Network is very pleased to invite experts from the Department of Energy, United States of America (USDOE) to share their insights and experiences about CCUS development and policy to support the deployment of CCUS technology. &nbsp;
The ACN will be an active forum to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS technologies, policy development to support the development and deployment of CCUS in Asia. Thus, this conference hosted in collaboration with IEA will help to bring in update knowledge, opportunity for investment in CCUS in Asia.
&nbsp;
Agenda
Wednesday, 28 July 2021 :&nbsp; Experience from the United States Department of Energy&nbsp; in CCUS Development and Deployment
(Jakarta Standard Time, UTC+7)



8:00 &ndash; 8:05 AM

Opening Remarks
Taizo Hara, Director General of Research and Policy Design Administration of ERIA (5 minutes)
Jarad Daniels, Director, Strategic Planning, Analysis and Engagement, Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management USDOE



8:05 &ndash; 8:50&nbsp;AM

Presentation by USDOE (MC and moderator: Han Phoumin)
Jarad Daniels, Director, Strategic Planning, Analysis and Engagement, Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management USDOE:

S. policies that support CCUS development
Key federal environmental regulations that affect CCUS projects
Federal (DOE&rsquo;s) CCUS R&amp;D programs
CCUS projects in the United States
International engagement




8:50 &ndash; 9:05 AM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;
Comments by Jesus Tamang, Director Energy Policy and Planning Bureau, DOE, Philippines.


9:05 &ndash; 9:25 AM
Open discussion Session to the Presentations


9:25 &ndash; 9:30 AM
Closing Remarks by Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA

the vision of the Asia CCUS Network that aims to contribute to the decarbonisation of emissions in Asia through collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS.</p><p>The mission and meetings;</li><li>conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and</li><li>holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS.</li></ol><p>The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through the collaboration of research and innovation.</p><p>The International Energy Agency (IEA) plays an important role in supporting the adoption and deployment of CCUS around the world. Recently, IEA published a report on &#039;CCUS: The Opportunity in Southeast Asia&#039;, which gave a whole emphasis and focus on the ASEAN region. Therefore, the Asia CCUS Network is very pleased to invite experts from International Energy Agency (IEA) to share their insights and findings of the report to audiences in the ASEAN region.</p><p>The report is available here for pre-reading: [<a href="https://www.iea.org/reports/carbon-capture-utilisation-and-storage-the-opportunity-in-southeast-asia" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://www.iea.org/reports/carbon-capture-utilisation-and-storage-the-opportunity-in-southeast-asia</a>].</p><p>The ACN will be an active forum to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS technologies, policy development to support the development and deployment of CCUS in Asia. Thus, this conference is hosted in collaboration with IEA will help to bring in update knowledge, opportunity for investment in CCUS in Asia.</p><p><strong><em>&nbsp;</em></strong></p><h2>Agenda<strong>&nbsp;</strong><strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>(Jakarta Standard Time, UTC+7)</h2><table style="width: 471.675px;"><tr><td style="width: 153px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">3:00 &ndash; 4:00 PM&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></td><td style="width: 322.675px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Comments</strong> by Dr Twarath Sutabutr, Chief Inspector General, Ministry of Energy Thailand</span></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 153px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">4:00 &ndash; 4:25 PM</span></td><td style="width: 322.675px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">Open discussion session to the Presentations</span></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 153px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;">4:25 &ndash; 4:30 PM&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></td><td style="width: 322.675px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><strong>Closing Remarks </strong>by Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA.</span></td></tr></table><h2>&nbsp;</h2><h2>Relive the Webinar</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/ezJzz-ccZUU" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><h2>Dr Raimund Malischek&#039;s Presentation</h2><p style="margin: 12px auto 6px auto; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,Sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; -x-system-font: none; display: block;"><a style="text-decoration: underline;" title="View Opportunities for CCUS in Southeast Asia - Dr Raimund Malischek on Scribd" href="https://www.scribd.com/document/517483900/Opportunities-for-CCUS-in-Southeast-Asia-Dr-Raimund-Malischek#from_embed">Opportunities for CCUS in Southeast Asia - Dr Raimund Malischek</a> by <a style="text-decoration: underline;" title="View Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia&#039;s profile on Scribd" href="https://www.scribd.com/user/538869539/Economic-Research-Institute-for-ASEAN-and-East-Asia#from_embed">Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia</a> on Scribd</p><p><iframe id="doc_14041" class="scribd_iframe_embed" title="Opportunities for CCUS in Southeast Asia - Dr Raimund Malischek" src="https://www.scribd.com/embeds/517483900/content?start_page=1&amp;view_mode=slideshow&amp;access_key=key-UYmcFFZfT7dmHDlibBaM" width="600" height="800" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" data-auto-height="false" data-aspect-ratio="1.414442700156986" data-mce-fragment="1"></iframe></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-07-26";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-07-26";s:8:"keywords";s:6795:"The 1st Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference The 1st Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference The Asia CCUS Network has been successfully launched on 22-23 June 2021 with initially 13 countries (all ASEAN member countries, the United States, Australia, and Japan) and more than 100 international organisations, companies, financial and research institutions that share the vision of CCUS development throughout the Asian region.
The Network members have expressed their intention to participate to share the vision of the Asia CCUS Network that aims to contribute to the decarbonisation of emissions in Asia through collaboration and cooperation on development and deployment of CCUS.
The mission of this network is to facilitate deployment of CCUS through:

&nbsp;promoting knowledge sharing through holding an annual forum, conferences, workshops, and meetings;
conducting research studies on technical, economical, and legal standards of CCUS in the EAS region; and
holding capacity building training workshops to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS.

The Asia CCUS Network provides opportunities for countries in the region to work and collaborate on the low emission technology partnership that will eventually help to build countries&rsquo; capability to lower the cost of CCUS technology and its deployment through the collaboration of research and innovation.
The International Energy Agency (IEA) plays an important role in supporting the adoption and deployment of CCUS around the world. Recently, IEA published a report on 'CCUS: The Opportunity in Southeast Asia', which gave a whole emphasis and focus on the ASEAN region. Therefore, the Asia CCUS Network is very pleased to invite experts from International Energy Agency (IEA) to share their insights and findings of the report to audiences in the ASEAN region.
The report is available here for pre-reading: [https://www.iea.org/reports/carbon-capture-utilisation-and-storage-the-opportunity-in-southeast-asia].
The ACN will be an active forum to bridge the knowledge gap on CCUS technologies, policy development to support the development and deployment of CCUS in Asia. Thus, this conference is hosted in collaboration with IEA will help to bring in update knowledge, opportunity for investment in CCUS in Asia.
&nbsp;

3:00 &ndash; 3:10 PM

3:10 &ndash; 3:50 PM&nbsp;

Dr Raimund Malischek (30 minutes): Results and finding of the report.



3:50 &ndash; 4:00 PM&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;

4:00 &ndash; 4:25 PM

4:25 &ndash; 4:30 PM&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;
Closing Remarks by Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA.

.aisA ni SUCC ni tnemtsevni rof ytinutroppo ,egdelwonk etadpu ni gnirb ot pleh lliw AEI htiw noitaroballoc ni detsoh si ecnerefnoc siht ,suhT .aisA ni SUCC fo tnemyolped dna tnempoleved eht troppus ot tnempoleved ycilop ,seigolonhcet SUCC no pag egdelwonk eht egdirb ot murof evitca na eb lliw NCA ehT
.]aisa-tsaehtuos-ni-ytinutroppo-eht-egarots-dna-noitasilitu-erutpac-nobrac/stroper/gro.aei.www//:sptth[ :gnidaer-erp rof ereh elbaliava si troper ehT
.noiger NAESA eht ni secneidua ot troper eht fo sgnidnif dna sthgisni rieht erahs ot )AEI( ycnegA ygrenE lanoitanretnI morf strepxe etivni ot desaelp yrev si krowteN SUCC aisA eht ,eroferehT .noiger NAESA eht no sucof dna sisahpme elohw a evag hcihw ,'aisA tsaehtuoS ni ytinutroppO ehT :SUCC' no troper a dehsilbup AEI ,yltneceR .dlrow eht dnuora SUCC fo tnemyolped dna noitpoda eht gnitroppus ni elor tnatropmi na syalp )AEI( ycnegA ygrenE lanoitanretnI ehT
.noitavonni dna hcraeser fo noitaroballoc eht hguorht tnemyolped sti dna ygolonhcet SUCC fo tsoc eht rewol ot ytilibapac ;ouqsr&seirtnuoc dliub ot pleh yllautneve lliw taht pihsrentrap ygolonhcet noissime wol eht no etaroballoc dna krow ot noiger eht ni seirtnuoc rof seitinutroppo sedivorp krowteN SUCC aisA ehT

.SUCC no pag egdelwonk eht egdirb ot spohskrow gniniart gnidliub yticapac gnidloh
dna ;noiger SAE eht ni SUCC fo sdradnats lagel dna ,lacimonoce ,lacinhcet no seiduts hcraeser gnitcudnoc
;sgniteem dna ,spohskrow ,secnerefnoc ,murof launna na gnidloh hguorht gnirahs egdelwonk gnitomorp;psbn&

:hguorht SUCC fo tnemyolped etatilicaf ot si krowten siht fo noissim ehT
.SUCC fo tnemyolped dna tnempoleved no noitarepooc dna noitaroballoc hguorht aisA ni snoissime fo noitasinobraced eht ot etubirtnoc ot smia taht krowteN SUCC aisA eht fo noisiv eht erahs ot etapicitrap ot noitnetni rieht desserpxe evah srebmem krowteN ehT
.noiger naisA eht tuohguorht tnempoleved SUCC fo noisiv eht erahs taht snoitutitsni hcraeser dna laicnanif ,seinapmoc ,snoitasinagro lanoitanretni 001 naht erom dna )napaJ dna ,ailartsuA ,setatS
